headline: PC Makers And Microsoft Squabble Over Desktop Icons
abstract: Personal computer makers are unhappy with conditions set by Microsoft Corp for placement of software and services of rival software companies on desktops screen of new Microsoft Windows XP operating system; conditions, which require three Microsoft icons on desktop for each non-Microsoft icon, limit PC makers' ability to sell valuable icon space to other software companies; similarly, Microsoft's abrupt announcement in July that it will not ship Windows XP with software necessary to run programs written in Java means that PC makers must quickly decide whether to install Java software themselves or drop it even though many consumers find it useful (M)

headline: Siemens, Posting 3rd-Quarter Loss, Fires a Unit Chief
abstract: Siemens posts worse-than-expected loss of $428 million in its third quarter; traditional operations posted solid gains, but mobile phone and phone networks units lost combined 1.1 billion euros, or about $964.6 million, in quarter; Roland Koch will step down as head of networks unit and be succeeded by Thomas Ganswindt; photo (M)

headline: Former Workers at Lucent See Nest Eggs Vanish, Too
abstract: Longtime employees of Lucent Technologies and onetime parent AT&T have not only lost jobs to layoffs but have also seen savings stashed in company stock largely evaporate with 90 percent plunge in stock price since end of 1999; Stephen J Gilligan, 48, and others explain particular pain of being hurt by 'family' company they believed was rock solid; photos; workers who took advantage of employee stock purchase plan and also invested in Lucent through 401(k) programs lost in both portions of their retirement savings; company has also trimmed its traditional retirement plan (M)

headline: How to Move The Home Page To a New Home
abstract: Advice on how to move Internet home page to new Internet service provider; drawing (M)

headline: Wahid, Still Angry, Returns to Indonesia From U.S. Medical Visit
abstract: Former Pres Abdurrahman Wahid of Indonesia returns home after medical checkup in United States, still angry over his ouster and promising to set up clearinghouse for complaints about government; his successor, Megawati Sukarnoputri, has been paralyzed by infighting over her first presidential duty, selecting cabinet; although Wahid has been removed, his cabinet members remain in place while Megawati struggles to balance demands of her supporters; she has asked departing ministers not to make policy while they remain in place, but some have ignored her request (M)

headline: Earnings Rise 75% At Federated Stores, Aided by a Catalog
abstract: Federated Department Stores Inc says fiscal second-quarter earnings rose 75 percent, to $110 million; sales fell 8.2 percent, to $3.73 million (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Sun To Show New Computer
abstract: Sun Microsystems Inc plans to show off its most powerful computer, Starcat, which it hopes will safeguard its position at high end of server-system market; computer harnesses 106 of Suns UltraSparc III computer chips, each running at 900 megahertz (S)

headline: Corporate Paper Trails Lie Buried in Soot
abstract: Businesses have to address loss of records from World Trade Center; while many financial firms have automatic backups of their records, law firms are expecially dependent on hard copies of documents that might be used in litigation or as legally binding originals; federal regulators are also concerned about status of files and other documents in their offices at Center; Securities and Exchange Commission and Federal Employment Opportunity Commission had regional offices in 7 World Trade Center, which is one of buildings that collapsed after attack; New York State Department of Taxation and Finance had 222 employees in Center, of which 40 are unaccounted for (M)

headline: Pakistan's Leader Tries to Assure Country
abstract: Pakistan's military ruler took to nationwide television to defend his decision to cooperate with the United States in its search for Osama bin Laden.

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Kashmir: Militants Blamed For Killings Of 9
abstract: Nine people are killed and 30 wounded when gunmen open fire at railway station in Jammu; police blame militants opposed to India's rule over state of Jammu and Kashmir (S)

headline: Consumer Spending Declines As Japanese Try to Save More
abstract: Japan reports spending by households headed by salaried workers dropped 3.3 percent in real terms in June from June 2000 as consumers saved more in anticipation of tougher economic times; spending rate of 68.9 percent of disposable income is lowest since government began to compile data; unemployment rate remained at record 4.9 percent, June (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Comdisco Posts A Loss
abstract: Comdisco Inc reports net loss of $164 million in fiscal third quarter, compared to net income of $17 million year earlier; revenue dropped 28 percent, to $585 million (S)

headline: Preparing Boomers For Long-Time Care
abstract: Studies indicate that baby boomers are unprepared for long-term health care needs, many of them being in denial (S)

headline: Winning Strategies Buys Specialty Shop
abstract: Winning Strategies buys Warren Kremer Paino advertising agency in cash deal (S)

headline: Diageo Says Nonliquor Units Continued to Underperform
abstract: Diageo, which is trying to focus on its strength as world's biggest liquor company, says its other businesses continue to stumble, including Burger King fast-food chain; Diageo wants to concentrate on liquor and spin off or sell 11,000-outlet Burger King chain; sales at Burger King fell again in second half of year (M)

headline: An annual survey forecasts slow growth in communications spending for the next five years.
abstract: Advertising column explores prediction by Veronis Suhler, investment banking firm that specializes in media, that advertising spending in United States would increase 6.9 percent next year, following 11.1 percent increase in 2000 (M)

headline: Profit Falls 23% at Credit Suisse Group
abstract: Credit Suisse Group says profit fell 23 percent in second quarter from year earlier; income fell 24 percent, to $1.6 billion, in first half of year; photo (M)

headline: Stocks Fall on Warnings by Key Technology Companies
abstract: Stocks fall sharply; Dow Jones industrial average drops 227.18 points, or 2.2 percent, to 10,252.68; Nasdaq composite index drops 75.95 points, or 3.7 percent, to 2,004.16; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index falls 28.65 points, or 2.4 percent, to 1,190.59; Treasury securities prices rise; 10-year note rises 13/32, to 97 10/32, to yield 5.36 percent; 30-year bond rises 11/32, to 94 31/32, to yield 5.73 percent; stock price graph and tables; key rates table (M)

headline: Three Arabs Slain; Jewish Settlers Claim Responsibility
abstract: Three Palestinians, including baby, are killed in village of Idna near West Bank city of Hebron in drive-by shooting that police attribute to Jewish gunmen; Committee for Security on the Roads, group of militant Jewish settlers in Hebron area linked to banned anti-Arab Kach movement, claims responsibility; Prime Min Ariel Sharon's office condemns shooting and pledges to apprehend killers; attack is also denounced by umbrella council of Jewish settlers in West Bank as well as by United States; Palestinian officials accuse Sharon's government of abetting violence, and call for international force to be created to protect Palestinians; photo; map (M)

headline: Market Place; During a Bear Market, There's Really No Place Like Home
abstract: Market Place column says rising value of Americans' homes is acting as bulwark against persistent economic slide, offsetting some of decline in stock portfolios as homeowners refinance their mortgages, either to lower their monthly payments or to borrow money against rising value of those homes; says Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, seems to be depending on housing as buffer against recession until companies, which have severely cut back their capital spending, start to invest again and to rebuild inventories; graph (M)

headline: From a Crisp Web Image To a Blur, Via the Printer
abstract: Q. Why do some pictures I see online look fine on my screen but get blurry when I try to print them?    A. Most photographs and other images that you see on your computer monitor -- those from Web pages, for example -- are created in a lower resolution than what most printers need to produce smooth, clear images. The resolution is the number of dots per inch used to create the image. Generally, the smaller the number of dots per inch, the lower the quality of the printed image.

headline: Forecasting Index Registers Third Consecutive Increase
abstract: Conference Board reports index of leading economic indicators rose 0.3 percent in June after 0.4 percent increase in May; Commerce Department says trade deficit narrowed 11.4 percent in May, to 16-month low of $28.3 billion; Labor Department says first-time claims for unemployment insurance fell 35,000 last week, to 414,000; graph (M)

headline: TBWA Acquires Two Agencies
abstract: TBWA Worldwide acquires Weiss Stagliano Partners and O'Malley & Hogan and will merge them to form Brand Architecture International (S)

headline: U.S. Tariff Put On Lumber From Canada
abstract: Commerce Department imposes 19.3 percent tariff on Canadian softwood lumber, siding with US wood producers who complained that Canadian lumber producers benefited unfairly from government subsidies; higher domestic lumber prices will likely follow (M)

headline: I.B.M. Earnings Meet Expectations
abstract: IBM reports revenue in second quarter was $21.57 billion, 0.4 percent less than quarter year ago and nearly $1 billion short of what analysts expected; net income was $2.05 billion, 5.4 percent increase from year earlier (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: New Cellular Service
abstract: NTT DoCoMo, Japan's leading mobile phone service company, will introduce its third-generation of cellular service on Oct 1, as planned (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Chechnya Leaders Escape Bomb
abstract: Bomb explodes bene

headline: New Economy, Same Harassment Problems
abstract: Sexual harassment lawsuit brought by Lori Park, software engineer, against her employer, Juno Online Services, illustrates how easily hostile work environment can arise for women in new economy of Internet, where conventions and rule books of old economy were disdained and office romances and other corporate taboos flourished; complaint was settled in arbitration; women faced with sexual harassment in heyday of Internet boom were more likely to move on to other jobs than to sue, but they are likely to sue now that there not so many jobs to be had; one lawyer estimates that two out of five managers at such companies will be targets of lawsuits in coming years, twice rate of managers at bricks-and-mortar businesses; photos (L)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Intel Deal Lifts Rambus
abstract: Shares of memory chip designer Rambus rise $1.11, or 16.7 percent, to $7.76, after company announces expanded patent-licensing agreement with Intel worth $200 million over five years; Intel uses Rambus design, called RDRAM, to increase performance of its fastest Pentium 4 processors; Intel will pay Rambus $10 million a quarter for five years; graph (S)

headline: Peru, Pressing Japan, Issues an Order for Fujimori's Arrest
abstract: Peru issues international arrest order for Alberto K Fujimori, exiled former president, on charges that he shared responsibility for 25 death-squad slayings in the early years of his decade-long rule; warrant is intended to press Japan to extradite Fujimori so he can stand trial on wide assortment of charges; Japan insists that Fujimori is Japanese citizen and will not be forced to return to Peru (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: Dispute On Afghan Refugees
abstract: United Nations suspends its role in screening of Afghan refugees in Pakistan for asylum, saying Pakistan forcibly deported over 130 (S)

headline: Better Networks: Look to Nature
abstract: Ideas for advances in data routing are beginning to emerge from study of swarm intelligence of ants, whose actions are primitive individually but collectively result in efficient solutions to complex problems; ants find shortest route between nest and food source by laying down pheromone trails, and researchers are creating what might be viewed as artificial ants: small pieces of software that travel through network depositing artificial pheromone as they seek out optimal routes; swarm intelligence is subject of Steven Johnson's book Emergence: The Connected Lives of Ants, Brains, Cities and Software (M)

headline: Workers' Productivity Made Gains, Report Says
abstract: The productivity of workers grew at a strong rate in the second quarter as the effect of job cuts reduced the number of hours worked, the government reported today

headline: Technology Briefing
abstract: PEOPLEAT&T EXECUTIVE JOINS PALM Palm Inc. has appointed David C. Nagel president and chief executive officer of a new software subsidiary. Mr. Nagel, 56, has served as AT&T's chief technology officer since 1996 and is already a member of the board of Palm, the hand-held computer maker. Before coming to AT&T, he headed research and development at Apple Computer. The move comes soon after Palm bought the software created by Be Incorporated, an innovative operating system company formed by another Apple alumnus, Jean-Louis Gassée. Like many high-tech companies, Palm has suffered a drop in sales this year. In a statement, Mr. Nagel said that he wa

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Secret Police Files
abstract: Custodian of East Germany's Stasi secret police files, Marianne Birthler, asks Germany's Supreme Court to re-examine earlier ruling that said agency could not release records on former Chancellor Helmut Kohl without his permission (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: China: Leaders Gather By The Sea
abstract: China's top leaders begin annual retreat in seaside resort of Beidaihe (S)

headline: Japanese Premier Changes Plans and Visits War Shrine
abstract: In a sudden change of plans, Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi visited a shrine honoring Japan's war dead today

headline: World Briefing | Asia: India: Many Left Homeless By Monsoon Rains
abstract: Monsoon rains force 500,000 people to flee their homes in state of Orissa, India (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Oil Found
abstract: Brazil's state-controlled oil company Petróleo Brasileiro S.A., or Petrobras, has discovered up to 130 million barrels of additional reserves in four fields along the northeastern coast. The discoveries came as the fields were entering periods of stable or falling production. In one of the largest finds in the last 30 years, the company detected as much as 80 million barrels in one of the fields, which are 10 miles off the coast of the state of Sergipe. With the discovery, Petrobras has extended exploration of the field for two years.   Jennifer L. Rich (NYT)

headline: TESORO CUTS PROFIT OUTLOOK, SAYING MARGINS ARE LOWER
abstract: Tesoro Petroleum, which refines oil in Washington State, Alaska and Hawaii, says that third-quarter earnings will fall short of analysts' projections; says that second-quarter profit more than doubled, with net income rising to $29.5 million, from $14.6 million (S)

headline: A Team Is in Place to Overhaul Gazprom
abstract: Industry analysts say sweeping changes in top management of Russia's Gazprom clear way for new chief executive, Aleksei Miller, to begin long-awaited revamping of company (M)

headline: Mexico President and Bush Wrestle With Immigration Issues
abstract: President Vicente Fox seemed to differ with President Bush today on a timetable for resolving key immigration issues.

headline: Online Course Lets the Isolated Bring Their Medical Skills Up to Date
abstract: Online training is being used to enhance skills of medical professionals who work with and make prostheses for amputees; workers in far-flung regions are no longer isolated from each other or from updates in technology that helps them become more effective; photo (M)

headline: HERCULES TO LAY OFF 300 WORKERS IN COST-CUTTING MOVE
abstract: Hercules Inc, top producer of paper-making chemicals, will lay off at least 300 workers, or 3 percent of its work force, as part of plant to save $100 million a year (S)

headline: How Long an Impact on Consumer Spending?
abstract: DIARY How Long an Impact On Consumer Spending?  Many people were already worried about corporate layoffs and a volatile stock market, but last week's terrorist attacks are expected to further dent consumer spending.

headline: Jobs Data and Earnings Warnings Send Stocks Reeling
abstract: Stocks fell sharply today as profit warnings from technology companies, accompanied by a weak employment report, undermined investors' confidence that the underlying economy, if not profits, would be recovering by the end of the year.

headline: Flight Student Says Hijacker Never Left A Companion
abstract: Article on Anne Greaves, Briton with lifelong dream of learning to fly, attended flight training school with Mohammed Atta; investigators believe he had pivotal role in attacks on New York and Washington, DC; Greaves's observations of Atta and his behavior while at school together noted; photo (M)

headline: Russians Resist Rumsfeld Effort to Set Aside ABM Treaty
abstract: The defense secretary met President Vladimir V. Putin and his defense minister for talks that highlighted disagreements on missile defense.

headline: World Briefing | Asia: North Korea: Chinese Leader Arrives
abstract: Chinese Pres Jiang Zemin begins three-day visit to North Korea, first by Chinese leader since 1992; is greeted by Kim Jong Il; photo (S)

headline: IN AMAZON'S STOCK SALE TO AOL, A CLAUSE ABOUT TAKEOVER
abstract: Amazon.com agreement to sell $100 million of stock to America Online includes provision that lets AOL propose takeover of company, world's largest Internet retailer (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Retailers' Sales Rise 2.4% As Shoppers Grow Cautious  In malls and Main Streets across the country, shoppers appear to be closely watching how and where they spend their money, with retail sales rising just 2.4 percent over all in July.    Discount retailers posted the strongest gains, with Wal-Mart and Kmart doing better than expected, but other merchants had disappointing sales. Gap, for example, said that sales in stores open at least a year fell 12 percent, steeper than expected. [Page C3.]

headline: MUTUAL INSURER CUTS 1,370 JOBS, MOST IN TEXAS
abstract: United Services Automobile Association, mutual insurance and financial services company, to cut 1,370 jobs, almost 6 percent of work force (S)

headline: Fed Cuts Rates By Half-Point In an Attempt To Aid Stocks
abstract: Federal Reserve cuts its federal funds rate on overnight loans among banks to 3 percent from 3.5 percent before stock market reopens, and promises that it will go to great lengths to keep financial markets operating smoothly in aftermath of terrorist attacks; cuts discount rate on loans to banks from Federal Reserve system to 2.5 percent from 3 percent; action is not enough to overcome heavy downdraft in share prices once trading resumes on Wall Street; there were growing signs that economy, which was weakening before terrorist attacks, could be in for rough ride in coming months, suggesting that Fed may continue its rate-cutting campaign for rest of year; European Central Bank matches Fed's rate cut, saying it is acting in coordination with Fed to limit worldwide economic damage stemming from attacks; central banks in Canada, Switzerland and Sweden also cut rates; Pres Bush says 'underpinnings for growth are there' despite tough conditions in many industries; Treasury Sec Paul H O'Neill says recovery is just around corner; US Airways announces that it will lay off as many as 11,000 employees; graph (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Qualcomm Investing In Nextwave
abstract: Qualcomm, which licenses patents for mobile telephones used by 90 million people, will invest $300 million in NextWave Telecom, bankrupt wireless carrier that holds claims to disputed airwave space in US; Qualcomm spokeswoman says investment depends on NextWave's completing bankruptcy reorganization and getting frequencies 'free and clear' (S)

headline: Brussels Sues Swissair In Move to Aid Sabena
abstract: brussels sues swissair in move

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: CODE-ALARM INC., Madison Heights, Mich., a maker of automobile security systems, said it would supply its PowerCode key-fob remote starting and security system to cars and trucks made by Ford Motor Co., Dearborn Mich., and grant Ford the option to buy a minority stake in Code-Alarm over five years. Terms were not disclosed.    HOUSEHOLD INTERNATIONAL INC., Prospect Heights, Ill., the largest independent consumer finance company in the U.S., said it would provide customers of Microsoft Corp., Redmond, Wash., the software maker, with revolving credit to buy software, hardware and other computer products for building Microsoft systems. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: World Briefing | Asia/Pacific: Japan: Mad Cow Disease Suspected
abstract: Japanese government says it has found suspected case of mad cow disease in a single Holstein dairy cow in Chiba prefecture near Tokyo, in what would be first case in Asia (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: AT&T CORP., New York, the long-distance telephone company, said it would close a customer-service office in San Antonio to cut costs after demand for calling services declined. The company has not decided whether or not to offer the office's 590 employees other jobs at AT&T.

headline: Far Conflict Challenges TV Networks Shy of Cash
abstract: American broadcast news organizations, which have undergone two decades-worth of cuts in their foreign news budgets, scramble to set up operations in Pakistani capital of Islamabad as world's media prepares for anticipated US retaliation against terrorist attacks (M)

headline: Private Sector; He Puts the Labor In Labor Day, Officially
abstract: John J Sweeney, president of AFL-CIO, has busy Labor Day schedule in Los Angeles and Oakland, Calif; photo (S)

headline: Amid the Toasts, a Subtle Soda War
abstract: Amid the Toasts, A Subtle Soda War  Once, Vicente Fox was president of Coca-Cola of Mexico. Now he is president of the country. So it was no surprise that Douglas N. Daft, chief executive of Coca-Cola, was among the 136 people receiving a coveted invitation to George W. Bush's first state dinner, honoring Mr. Fox, on Wednesday.

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Mugabe Reaffirms Land Transfer
abstract: Pres Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe says government will continue to redistribute white-owned farms to blacks, even though continued occupation by black squatters has been ruled illegal by courts (S)

headline: AIR CANADA AND I.B.M. FORM $908 MILLION PARTNERSHIP
abstract: Air Canada and IBM agree to $908 million partnership to develop information-technology services and products; IBM will manage airline's computer and information technology operations (S)

headline: Health Care Gap Has British Looking Abroad
abstract: Britons, frustrated with long waits for surgery under state-run health service, are going to state-run health systems in continental Europe for care at cost far lower than that of private health care in Britain; Min Alan Milburn has introduced policy that will let local British health authorities negotiate with other European Union health services for hundreds of operations to clear patient backlog; photos (M)

headline: United Arab Emirates Breaks Diplomatic Ties With Taliban
abstract: United Arab Emirates, one of only three countries to recognize Taliban, breaks off relations with Afghanistan because of its refusal to hand over terrorist mastermind Osama bin Laden (S)

headline: The Iron Lady's Sequel Haunts Britain's Tories
abstract: Margaret Thatcher, still steely and crusty at age 75, continues to insert herself into British politics, campaigning for Conservative candidates in last two elections, undeterred by defeats; photo; former prime minister's latest foray is endorsement of Iain Duncan Smith for party leader and denunciation of rival Kenneth Clarke (M)

headline: Keeping the Lifelines Open
abstract: Telecommunications system in United States, particularly in New York, has survived probably biggest test ever of its ability to withstand physical attack and national emergency in wake of terrorist attacks; several companies trucked in temporary cellular towers to lower Manhattan, 911 system was never disrupted, New Yorkers were able to make long distance calls despite heavy phone volume and, for most users, Internet was slowed but intact; experience provides lessons about how networks adapt to extreme conditions and what more can be done to preserve them in emergencies; photos; diagram (M)

headline: Mourn The Dead, But Not New York
abstract: Tom Redburn column says that while the dead of Sept 11 must be mourned, elegies for New York City as major financial center are inappropriate and premature (M)

headline: Nasdaq Selects Marketing Agency
abstract: Nasdaq stock market selects McKinney & Silver, subsidiary of Havas Advertising, to handle its creative and media accounts (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: Envoys Can't See Jailed Citizens
abstract: Afghan officials grant visas to diplomats from United States, Australia and Germany but say they will not be permitted to visit eight imprisoned aid workers from three nations who were arrested on charges of preaching Christianity (S)

headline: Tough U.S. Visa Policy Riles Shut-Out Scholars in China
abstract: American Embassy visa section in Beijing rejects record number of visa applications from Chinese scholars this year, prompting applicants to charage that its decisions are arbitrary and unfair; Chinese complain that on basis of interviews lasting less than five minutes thousands of Chinese have found longstanding plans to study, travel and work jettisoned; those denied visas include students with full scholarships to Ivy League schools and grandparents wanting to see first grandchild; while cases are not unique to China, numbers have become huge and aftermath especially far-reaching as there are currently more students at American universities from China than from any other country; denials disproportionately affect young, highly educated students and professionals, seeding anti-American resentment in group that has played important role in improving ties between both countries; American Embassy officials are inclined to be suspicious since, historically, majority of Chinese students have remained in US after graduation, although most do so legally; officials acknowledge that large numbers of Chinese have faced rejections in current year and that rate is high compared with 2000, but they say more people are being rejected because more high school students are applying and because total number of applications is growing so fast; photo (M)

headline: Unit of Kirshenbaum Named Media Kitchen
abstract: Kirshenbaum Bond Creative Network forms media planning and buying agency, Media Kitchen, that will focus on creative media communications; Paul Woolmington, unit chairman and chief executive, comments on plans (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Thailand: Cement Stake
abstract: Mexico's Cemex is close to purchasing 72.5 percent stake in Thailand's cement company TPI Polene for $300 million (S)

headline: JDS Uniphase Will Write Down $44.8 Billion in Assets
abstract: JDS Uniphase, a leading manufacturer of components for telecommunications networks, said yesterday that it was writing down by $44.8 billion the value of companies it had acquired in two years of rapid growth. It was believed to be the largest loss in business history.    In addition to the extraordinary accounting adjustment, a step that JDS had warned investors to expect several months ago, the company reported that business had slowed even more than previously projected. It said that it would eliminate a further 7,000 workers in addition to 9,000 already laid off this year and that its advice to Wall Street on June 14 that it would record $450 million in revenue in the current quarter had been too optimistic.

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Kenya: No Law, No Loan
abstract: International Monetary Fund will keep in place freeze on lending to Kenya after Parliament's rejection of anticorruption measure (S)

headline: NOW, MANY WORDS FROM OUR SPONSOR
abstract: Fay Weldon breaks new commercial ground with The Bulgari Connection, fittingly-titled novel that contains commercial pitches for which London jewelry store paid author undisclosed sum; her photo; Bulgari connection is most visible episode yet in ongoing courtship pairing authors and publishers desperate for marketing support; book's publisher and marketing executives like Michael Nyman are enthusiastic, but others in book world bristle; Letty Cottin Pogrebin deplores 'billboarding' that erodes reader confidence in authenticity of narrative and adds to cynicism (M)

headline: A Vote to Lift a Cuba Ban
abstract: House votes, 240 to 186, for measure that would effectively lift ban on most travel to Cuba; vote reflects growing sentiment in Congress that many sanctions on Pres Fidel Castro's government have outlived their usefulness; members of House Republican leadership who oppose lifting sanctions are expected to intervene and make certain measure dies this year, as they did with similar measure last year (S)

headline: Competition Forces 3 Casual Brands to Rethink Strategy : Life in the Global Fast Lane
abstract: MILAN—  When selling a casual, youthful lifestyle to the world, it must be difficult to admit to suffering from bouts of stress or concern about the speed of modern life.

headline: Executive Changes at Media Firms
abstract: Allison Barnes and Natalie Conway were named vice presidents at Starcom North America, Chicago

headline: War Crimes Court Takes It Easy On a Cooperative Bosnian Serb
abstract: United Nations war crimes tribunal sentences Stevan Todorovic, former Bosnia Serb police chief of Bosanski Samac, to 10 years in prison for persecution of non-Serbs; links light sentence to guilty plea and pledge to cooperate with court (M)

headline: U.N. ADMITS ERROR IN HANDLING VIDEO OF ARAB FIGHTERS
abstract: UN admits misjudgments and deliberate evasions in handling of videotape related to kidnapping of three Israeli soldiers by Arab guerrillas in Lebanon last October; investigators insist tape, made day after abduction, did not contain information on kidnapping; Sec Gen Kofi Annan regrets staff errors; Israeli Amb Yehuda Lancry accepts UN offer to view edited version with guerrillas' faces obscured; Israel believes tape made by UN observer force contains valuable information; photo of aftermath of protest in Jerusalem over incident (M)

headline: Appeals Court Overturns Fine in Bid Disclosure
abstract: Federal appeals court overturns sanctions imposed against Howard B Sirota, New York lawyer accused of breaching confidentiality order in class-action cases against Cendant Corp following disclosures of accounting problems at company in 1998 (S)

headline: After a Delay, U.S. Envoy Starts in Post At the U.N.
abstract: John D Negroponte, new United States ambassador to United Nations, formally presents his credentials to Sec Gen Kofi Annan, ending hiatus of eight months without American representative; his arrival coincides with presentation of $31 million check from Ted Turner's United Nations Foundation, which Turner pledged to help seal deal under which Washington agrees to start paying back debt to UN; Congress is expected to make $582 million payment this year toward debt that it calculates at $1.3 billion (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Australia/New Zealand: New Zealand: Reports Of Phone Sale
abstract: British Telecommunications sells its New Zealand unit, Clear Communications, to consortium of investors and Berkshire Partners of Boston (S)

headline: A campaign for an online brokerage firm promises to eliminate the 'middleman.'
abstract: Article on online brokerage firm Brokerage America's advertising campaign that promises to eliminate 'middleman'; $7 million campaign was developed by Dirty Water Integrated; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Autonomy Slips
abstract: Shares in Autonomy Corp falls 7 percent on concerns that orders for its information management software will be delayed as large corporations fall back on spending (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: US dollar falls against euro and rises against Japanese yen; in New York, euro settles at 91.70 cents, up from 91.14 cents; dollar trades at 120.45 yen, up from 119.75 yen; graph; chart (S)

headline: Chinese Creating a New Vigor in Russian Far East
abstract: Parts of Russia's far east that border China are attracting Chinese traders and investors, causing Pres Vladimir V Putin to worry that Chinse economic expansion will crowd out Russian commerce and political power unless Moscow repopulates and rebuilds revaged region; few Russians want to move to far east, and the Chinese do; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Stock Prices Resume Slide, Reaching Levels of 1998  After seeming to stabilize earlier in the week, stocks plunged as investors grew fearful that the economy is falling into a recession and anxious about what might unfold as the United States struggles to combat terrorism.    The main market gauges are now only a few points above the lows they reached in the fall of 1998. So far this week, the Dow Jones industrials have dropped 1,220 points, or 12.8 percent. The Nasdaq is down 13.3 percent, and the S.& P. 500 has fallen 9.9 percent. [Page C7.]

headline: Lord Longford, Champion of Eccentric Causes, Dies at 95
abstract: Lord Longford, Labor peer famed for championing social outcasts and unpopular causes, dies at age 95; photo (M)

headline: A Forecaster's Art Takes a Sharp Turn
abstract: Louis Crandall, president and chief economist at Wrightson Associates, which was located on 25th floor of 1 World Trade Center, says difficult times lie ahead for both investors and forecasters like himself; says attack on world's financial capital has pushed economy into unpredictable territory; photo (M)

headline: Koizumi Sees Election Victory as Mandate
abstract: Prime Min Junichiro Koizumi, Japan's most popular leader since World War II, is taking his party's election victory as mandate to pursue reforms to restore Japan's economic and social vitality; faces resistance from Finance Ministry and conservatives in his party to his bid to shift money away from public works projects that favor ruling party's core supporters to programs to deal with social adjustments (M)

headline: Will the Economy Ever Party Like It's 1999? Don't Count on It.
abstract: The release of revised data from the past few years has some economists arguing that the new economy was not as "new" as some had thought

headline: INVESTING WITH/Edward J. Goldstein And David L. Thompson; First Funds Growth & Income Portfolio
abstract: Investing With column on $1 billion First Funds Growth & Income Portfolio, co-managed by David J Goldstein and David L Thompson; graph; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Economic Stimulus
abstract: Singapore's government announces 2.2 billion Singapore dollars ($1.2 billion) of stimulus measures to offset export slowdown that has thrown economy into recession (S)

headline: 'Die Hard' DVD Puts Viewer In the Film Editor's Chair
abstract: Fox Home Entertainment introduces DVD of 1988 film Die Hard with software that allows viewer to edit specific scenes using remote control; photo (S)

headline: Cheaper and Hand-Held, With a Retooled Engine
abstract: Casio's Cassiopeia BE-300 hand-held Pocket Manager offers simplified features and low price; photo (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Bank's Profit Is Up
abstract: Standard Chartered PLC reports first-half new income rose 11 percent, to $404 million, up from $363 million in 2000 period; graph (S)2

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Trizechahn's Profit Falls
abstract: TrizecHahn, Canadian real estate company, reports second-quarter earnings drop of 7.3 percent, reflecting loss of revenue from properties sold; photo of company head Peter Munk (S)

headline: Analysts' Group Halts Forums on Companies
abstract: New York Society of Security Analysts, one of nation's largest organizations devoted to advancing quality of security analysis, has halted its public forums examining management's responsibility to shareholders at public companies; society is reacting to concerns within its top ranks that forums have taken too aggressive approach; suspensions comes as investors, securities regulators and members of Congress are questioning whether Wall Street analysts are up to job of providing investors with unbiased, rigorous analysis of public companies' propsects; there is fear that brokerage firm research has been corrupted by analysts' eagerness to write glowing reports to help win lucrative investment banking business for their firms (M)

headline: White House In No Hurry With Options To Kyoto Pact
abstract: Pres Bush and his administration are said to be in no hurry to propose alternative to Kyoto climate control treaty they have rejected; administration officials say they consider climate change and need to curb greenhouses gases to be serious issue, but business executives and experts who have briefed cabinet say there appears to be little if any pressure from top to come up with new proposals (M)

headline: Frederick Moss; Stock Exchange Chairman, 72
abstract: Frederick Moss, Cincinnati Stock Exchange chairman, dies at age 72 (S)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Eritrea: Officials Defend Crackdown
abstract: Eritrean government says its crackdown on opposition leaders and journalists was prompted by disloyal and insulting acts against ruling party when country was in fierce battle with neighboring Ethiopia in 2000; photo (S)

headline: Hand-Held Satellite Phones Resurface in Tragedy's Wake
abstract: Iridium Satellite and Globalstar Telecommunications, embattled sellers of hand-held satellite phones, are getting renewed respect since many cellphone systems failed in New York and Washington in wake of terrorist attacks; Iridium units are being used by disaster workers in both cities (M)

headline: BUSH PLEDGES ATTACK ON AFGHANISTAN UNLESS IT SURRENDERS BIN LADEN NOW; HE CREATES CABINET POST FOR SECURITY
abstract: Pres Bush, in address to joint meeting of Congress, demands that Afghanistan's leaders immediately deliver Osama bin Laden and his network and close down every terrorist camp in country or face military attack by United States; says demands are not open to negotiation or discussion; outlines broad framework for campaign against terrorism, reaching far beyond Afghanistan and bin Laden's organization, Al Qaeda; says terrorist network involves thousands of people in more than 60 countries; makes clear American ground troops would be involved, perhaps soon; tells military to 'be ready'; says any nation that continues to harbor or support terrorism will be regarded by US as hostile regime; warns nation to expect long campaign that will be fought with visible weapons of war and secret operations; creates new cabinet-level post and appoints Gov Tom Ridge of Pennsylvania to lead Office of Homeland Security; speech is interrupted many times by applause and cheering; photos (L)

headline: Democrats Try to Work Up A Shield Plan of Their Own
abstract: With the Bush administration moving briskly toward a missile shield, a group of national security experts in the Democratic Party is pushing Congressional Democrats to unite around an alternative that they contend would be less costly and less threatening to arms control agreements.     Those experts say the agreement on Sunday between Mr. Bush and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia to begin talks on offensive and defensive weapons has given Mr. Bush, at least temporarily, new momentum on missile defense. They say it has put new pressure on the Democrats to do something more than simply issue critiques of Mr. Bush's plan.

headline: Move to Curb Biotech Crops Ignores Poor, U.N. Finds
abstract: New United Nations survey finds opposition in richer countries to genetically modified crops may set back ability of poorest nations to feed growing populations; movement against crops genetically changed to produce higher yield, more nutritional value and pest or disease control is strongest among Western Europeans and to some extent Americans; report draws comparison to successful Western-led efforts to ban use of industrial pesticide DDT worldwide, which has allowed resurgent population of mosquitoes to devastate tropical countries with several virulent strains of malaria; still, UN is also concerned about consequences of genetic advancements; World Health Orgn and Food and Agriculture Orgn have jointly recommended that governments test all genetically modified organisms before they enter market (M)

headline: Cunard Selects TBWA/Chiat/Day
abstract: The Cunard Line, a division of the Carnival Corporation, which operates cruise ships like the QE2, said yesterday that it had named the New York office of TBWA/Chiat/Day, part of the TBWA Worldwide unit of the Omnicom Group, to handle its account. Billings were estimated at $6 million to $10 million.

headline: F.C.C. Approves Fox Takeover of 10 Chris-Craft TV Stations
abstract: The Federal Communications Commission voted to approve Fox Television Stations Inc.'s application to acquire Chris-Craft Industries, which owns 10 television stations.

headline: Tech Future Is Said to Brighten
abstract: A new survey of chief information officers suggests that the drastic recent cuts in corporate technology budgets may be starting to end. Still, the free-spending days of last year are not likely to return soon.    Over the next 12 months, the executives plan to increase information-technology spending by 6.3 percent on average, according to the June poll, which will be released today by CIO Magazine. That is up from the 3.8 percent average when the executives were asked the question in May, but down from 18 percent in September, when the survey began.

headline: Fireworks No Treat for Washington
abstract: Thunderous fireworks display following Pres Bush's state dinner for Pres Vicente Fox angers and confuses hundreds of Washington residents, who complain about unexpected barrage in calls to police; spokeswoman for Laura Bush says fireworks were not meant to be disruptive (S)

headline: 2 More Agencies Decide To End Operations
abstract: Add two more agencies to the growing list of ones closing.    Biederman Kelly Krimstein & Partners in New York is closing, effective Tuesday, for what the agency's news release described as ''changing business plans.'' The statement was sent by e-mail from John Kelly, president and chief executive.

headline: Pop-Up Web Ads Pose a Measurement Puzzle
abstract: X10 Wireless Technologies uses advertising technology that opens X10 Web page on surfer's computer screen, whether surfer wants it there or not; this type of ad, called pop-under, is distinct from pop-up windows long seen by users of America Online service that appear on top of other pages; X10 ads open up in separate, full browser window, underneath whatever site user is viewing; only after user closes chosen window does lurking pop-under window become visible; technique raises debate among publishers and advertisers about whether this format is simply too obnoxious to be efffective way to sell things; chart (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: B.A.T. Profit Is Up
abstract: British American Tobacco reports second-quarter profit rose 7.9 percent, to 287 million pounds ($409 million), up from 266 million pounds ($379 million) in 2000 period (S)

headline: Central Banks in U.S. and Europe Cut Interest Rates by Half Point
abstract: In a bold moves to try to keep stock markets from tumbling, The Federal Reserve and the European Central Bank both cut interest rates by half a percentage point today.

headline: World Briefing | United Nations: Investigation Of Videotape
abstract: UN completes investigation of handling of contentious videotape that may relate to kidnapping almost year ago of three Israeli soldiers by Hezbollah; officials say there initially unaware of videotape, made by UN forces in southern Lebanon, that reportedly shows vehicles used in abduction (S)

headline: WELLS FARGO PLANS TO BUY BACK $1.3 BILLION IN STOCK
abstract: Wells Fargo & Co plans to buy back as much as $1.3 billion of its shares over time for uses that include acquisitions and employee benefit plans (S)

headline: Airline Pact Reached
abstract: American Airlines and union leaders for its flight attendants reach tentative agreement; flight attendants will receive immediate 9.2 percent pay increase and cumulative raises of 25.7 percent over six-year term of contract (S)

headline: Text of European Commission Statement on G.E.-Honeywell Vote
abstract: Following is the full text of the statement today by the European Commission on its veto of the proposed General Electric-Honeywell merger:

headline: Bennigan's Settles in Harassment Suit
abstract: Bennigan's Grill and Tavern agrees to pay $160,000 and apologize to nine women who worked at restaurant in Phoenix to settle sexual harassment lawsuit brought by Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (S)

headline: Colombia Arrests 3 as I.R.A. Bomb Experts
abstract: Three men suspected of being members of Irish Republican Army are arrested in Colombia on charges of having provided training in explosives to Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia; development raises doubts in Northern Ireland about IRA's commitment to peace efforts and renews concerns that Colombian guerrillas are planning urban terrorist attacks; two suspects are identified as James Monaghan and Martin McCaulley and third used alias David Bracken; photo (M)

headline: Those Were the Days
abstract: Marci McKim letter, responding to July 5 article about mid-sized personal computing device, recalls her first laptop computer

headline: Germany Urges the Czechs To Close a Nuclear Plant
abstract: Germany government has called on Czech Republic to close Temelin nuclear power plant; shares in CEZ, company that owns Temelin, fall more than 20 percent to two-year low before trading is suspended by Prague Stock Exchange; plant's two units began operating last October, but have yet to go fully on line; they are now sidelined by faulty turbine; photos (M)

headline: CHINESE UNSWAYED AS POWELL PUSHES U.S. MISSILE PLAN
abstract: Secretary of State Colin L Powell, in Beijing, meets separately with Pres Jiang Zemin and Prime Min Zhu Rongji, to lay groundwork for visit by Pres Bush in October; says two sides will talk more about human rights and weapons sales; says he brought up human rights at every meeting, but he did not raise specific cases of people in detention; says scope of differences on human rights will be discussed in formal dialogue that will be resumed in coming months; Human Rights Watch says dialogue in such talks in past has been 'pro forma'; both sides say they look forward to building 'constructive' relations, but Bush administration's plan for missile shield remains big obstacle; Powell makes little headway in overcoming China's opposition to missile shield; Beijing fears it could undercut its small nuclear arsenal; photo (M)

headline: Drug Control Office Reopening Bidding
abstract: White House Office of National Drug Control Policy will reopen bidding for media planning and buying duties for its antidrug campaign; those duties have been handled since December 1998 by Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide, part of WPP Group, which faces criminal and civil investigation into reports that it overbilled drug control agency (M)

headline: Shares Fall After Worrisome Report From Federal Reserve
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average drops 165.24 points, to 10,293.50; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index falls 20.87 points, to 1,183.53; Nasdaq composite index falls 61.43 points, 3 percent to 1,966.36; tables; graph (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Brocade Meets Expectations
abstract: Brocade Communications Systems says fiscal third-quarter earnings were down 40 percent from year earlier, to $12.1 million; sales rose to $116.3 million from $92.1 million; graph (S)

headline: Personal Business; How to Regain a Mouthful of Luster, for a Price
abstract: Teeth-whitening business is growing across America; costs and procedures vary; among most popular is Brite-Smile system, which was developed by John Warner and is administered by about 3,000 independent dentists nationwide and in 14 company-owned centers in 12 cities; photos (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Thailand: Rates Steady
abstract: Thailand's central bank leaves its benchmark 14-day repurchase rate unchanged at 2.5 percent, even as it says economic growth might slow to smaller-than-expected 1.5 percent this year (S)

headline: World Briefing | Middle East: Iraq: U.S. Attacks Again
abstract: American warplanes strike at Iraq for fourth time in less than two weeks (S)

headline: Microsoft Earnings Rise, Excluding Charge
abstract: The Microsoft Corporation reported strong quarterly revenue growth today, but the software company sharply reduced its profit forecast for the coming months

headline: Lisa J. Raines, 42, a Lobbyist for Biotechnology
abstract: Lisa J Raines, senior vice president at Genzyme Corp and one of earliest lobbyists for biotechnology industry, dies in crash of hijacked plane that hit Pentagon; she was 42 (M)

headline: Using Software to Sniff Out Electronic Evidence
abstract: Growing number of consulting firms help lawyers prepare for trial by providing computers and software that can assemble and sort through electronic documents, including e-mail messages and internal memorandums; such documents are growing in importance as evidence in court because people and companies increasingly use electronic media to discuss important ideas and strategies; new service promises to make lives of litigators little easier, letting them focus on analyzing evidence even when confronted with large numbers of documents; it may also mean that lawyers will spend less time sifting through documents and more time thinking about them (M)

headline: New Currency Feeding Jitters For Europeans
abstract: European Union is anxiously readying for historic conversion from national currencies to euro currency on Jan 1; if all goes well, conversion to new notes and coins could give new power and legitimacy to common currency being adopted by 12 of the 15 EU countries, and some see it as major step in unification and economic well-being of Europe; but even as European Central Bank gets set to unveil final design of new notes and coins next month, exactly what will happen on 'E-Day' remains subject of intense debate; European Union and Central Bank officials, after years of planning for Continent's biggest peacetime undertaking, say they are counting on orderly transition, but still admit to worries about myriad things that could go wrong; doomsayers abound across EU, and anxiety is growing, much as it did with Year 2000 computer scare; about 50 billion in new coins and 14.5 billion notes are to be pumped into circulation; chart of conversion rates; photos of coins showing side that will be same throughout EU; opposite sides will have different motifs chosen by each country (M)

headline: 18 CNN Journalists Protest Departure of Chief Counsel
abstract: CNN's journalists, who in the last few months have endured layoffs and management changes without visible complaint, protested this week over the sudden departure of the network's chief counsel, Eve Burton.    In a letter Tuesday to top executives of Turner Broadcasting System, CNN's parent within AOL Time Warner, and to Walter Isaacson, the network's new chairman, 18 high-ranking journalists who are women called on the network to bring Ms. Burton back. The group included the anchor Judy Woodruff, the chief international correspondent Christiane Amanpour and the legal analyst Greta Van Susteren.

headline: Beyond The Gloom, Some Value In Utilities
abstract: Kenneth N Gilpin interviews Jonathan C Raleigh, utilities industry analyst at Goldman Sachs, on effect of World Trade Center tragedy on stocks in that sector; photo (M)

headline: Certicom Plans Job Cuts
abstract: Union leaders at Mexican unit of Volkswagen say they will strike, halting production of New Beetle and other models in pay dispute; union represents 12,500 workers at plant in Puebla, Mex (S)

headline: Data on Genetically Modified Corn
abstract: Six scientific studies conclude that genetically modified BT corn poses 'negligible' risk to monarch butterflies; crops in question contain bacterial gene that causes plants to produce toxin that kills pests; papers say there is little risk to monarchs from two main types of BT corn grown because pollen is not toxic in concentrations that monarch larvae would encounter in fields (M)

headline: Derek Freeman, Who Challenged Margaret Mead on Samoa, Dies at 84
abstract: Derek Freeman, professor of anthropology at Australian National University, dies at age 84; photo (M)

headline: Italy's Prime Minister Steps Out of the Summit Meeting and Into a Firestorm
abstract: Prime Min Silvio Berlusconi of Italy comes under severe criticisms for fatal violence that marred Group of 8 economic summit in Genoa; Italians are enraged over police raid on headquarters of protestor's coordinator, Genoa Social Forum; Berlusconi had hoped to come off as master of ceremonies who coaxed colleagues into producing concrete assistance to developing world; dead protestor, identified as 23-year-old Carlo Giuliani, was shot while hurling fire extinguisher at police officer (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: China: U.S. To Pay Expenses
abstract: United States Government decides to pay China about $34,500 in compensation for expenses incurred during stand-off over Navy surveillance plane that made emergency landing on Hainan island; US rejects figure of $1 million that Chinese demanded for feeding and care of 24 crew members detained for 11 days (S)

headline: Going a Mile High and Back Over an Unwanted Nickname
abstract: A Denver sports columnist is complicating the sale of naming rights for the city's new football stadium

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: New Version Of Rogue Program Strikes
abstract: Third

headline: Brazil Steps on U.S. Toes With a Plan for Fighter Jets
abstract: Brazil has set aside $700 million to buy up to 24 supersonic fighter jets; is demanding any supplier provide advanced avionics and let domestic aerospace industry build planes in Brazil; bold requirement puts Brazil in direct conflict with United States, which does not sell its most sophisticated weaponry in Latin America or transfer technology; France may be willing to meet demands, enabling Brazil to make cheaper fighter plane for sale in third world and undermine US use of arms sales to sway allies and tilt regional balances of power (M)

headline: More on Microsoft Windows XP
abstract: There’s still more to say about Windows XP. Here are a few more points worth considering as you ponder making the leap.

headline: Fast Investments, Missing Returns; U.S. Charges Internet Operation Was a Huge Scam
abstract: By last September, life was getting rough for Donald A. English.    An unemployed single father, Mr. English was almost out of cash. His family was threatened with eviction. Collection agencies were at the door. His credit cards were mostly tapped out.

headline: Istanbul Journal; Great Divide Widens As Economy Worsens
abstract: Gap between wealthy elite and struggling poor is growing wider and more visible as Turkey suffers worst economic crisis in its modern history; political leaders are concerned about potential for social explosion as poor watch rich glide along, seemingly unscathed and ostentatiously displaying their wealth, particularly in Instanbul; photos (Istanbul Journal) (M)h

headline: Personal Business; A Revised Set of Rules for the Road
abstract: Experts suggest practical ways for air travelers to prepare themselves for emergencies in post-Sept 11 world; photo; drawings (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: BT Offered $25.7 Billion For Its Fixed-Line Network  A consortium led by a major German bank has offered to buy the fixed-line network of British Telecommunications for £18 billion, or $25.7 billion, people close to the discussions said.    The offer, by Westdeutsche Landesbank Girozentrale, is more comprehensive than an earlier $11.4 billion bid for British Telecom's local loop -- the copper wires that connect 28 million customers to its network. BT rebuffed that offer, from an American group made up of Babcock & Brown, an asset finance company, and Chancery Lane Capital, an investment bank, late last month. [Page C2.]

headline: BP Predicts It Will Meet Output Target For the Year
abstract: BP says it plans to meet output increase of 5 to 7 percent targeted earlier in year; reports first half net income rose to $3.8 billion, up from $3.6 billion in 2000 period (M)

headline: More Signs of Trouble for Ireland's Technology Boom
abstract: Ireland's Baltimore Technologies says it will halve its work force, delist from Nasdaq stock market and sell nonessential businesses; reports second-quarter loss of $691 million on revenue of $23.2 million, about same as last year; Tellabs, American telecommunications equipment manufacturer, will close its plant in Drogheda, Ireland, with loss of 200 jobs, as part of plan to cut 1,000 jobs worldwide, or 12 percent of its work force; General Semiconductor plans to do same after 20 years in Cork, leaving 670 people unemployed (M)

headline: Marquee Firm In California Cuts Lawyers
abstract: Cooley Godward, one of San Francisco area's highest-flying law firms during Internet boom, will lay off more than 10 percent of firm's 645 lawyers; popular perception of employment stability provided by large firms becomes suspect (M)

headline: Malone Leaves AT&T Board a Month Early
abstract: John C Malone, who is one of AT&T Corp's largest individual shareholders, resigns from company's board earlier than planned after he is excluded from talks related to Comcast's offer to buyh AT&T's cable systems; planned to step down on Aug 10 when Liberty Media, his programming company, is expected to be formally separated from AT&T; is weighing his own bid for AT&T's cable properties together with large private investors (M)

headline: PROMOTIONAL PRODUCTS COMPANY FILES FOR CHAPTER 11
abstract: HA-LO Industries, distributor of promotional products, files for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection (S)

headline: The Lingering Impact of a Fraud Case
abstract: DIARY The Lingering Impact Of a Fraud Case An arbitration panel in Boston delivered two messages to Wall Street firms last week. The first: Don't think that just because you clear another firm's trades, you can escape liability if that firm defrauds a customer. And second: If you stall in arbitration, be prepared to pay for your actions

headline: Fox, on State Visit, Calls for Migration Pact This Year
abstract: Startling his American hosts, President Vicente Fox of Mexico today said he hoped to reach agreement with the United States on a migration policy in the next few months

headline: Phone Firms Seek More Time on 911 Locator
abstract: Several major mobile phone companies say they may not meet Oct 1 Federal Communications Commission deadline for being able to pinpoint location of subscribers making emergency 911 calls on specially equipped phones; say new phones and systems for receiving and interpreting site data are unlikely to be in broad use until sometime in 2002; Verizon Wireless and other carriers are seeking extensions (M)

headline: U.S. Walkout: Was It Repudiated or Justified by the Conference's Accord?
abstract: News analysis on whether US was justified in walking out of UN's Durban conference on racism to protest hijacking by Israel haters; critics say US gave up chance to display impressive social achievements that would have been presented by Sec Colin Powell, himself descended from slaves; those supporting walkout include longtime Mideast negotiator Dennis Ross, who says US absence forced Europeans to step up and work for responsible outcome (M)

headline: A Caddy That Gives Tips Instead of Accepting Them
abstract: SkyGolf GPS Personal Caddy, from SkyHawke Technologies, weds hand-held computer to global positioning system to assist golfers at any one of 500 US golf courses; photo (M)

headline: College Saving, by the Numbers
abstract: James Schembari column calculating how much he will need to pay his children's college tuition (M)

headline: Timorese Vote in Prelude to Nationhood
abstract: East Timorese election draws huge turnout in party-like atmosphere as residents take crucial step in establishing self rule after 25 years of Indonesian occupation and two years of United Nations administration; election will create 88-member Assembly that is to draw up new constitution and prepare for full independent nationhood next year; photo ()

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Nokia To Buy Amber Networks
abstract: Nokia agrees to purchase Amber Networks Inc for $421 million in stock, to acquire networking gear used to direct Internet traffic (S)

headline: Market Place; Nurse Shortage Puts a Premium on Staff Agencies
abstract: Hospitals across country are struggling with acute shortaes of nurses, but hospitals' problem is big opportunity for some nurse staffing companies; Staffing Industry Report says hospitals paid $7.2 billion last year for temporary employees, mainly nurses; says spending on medical staffing is likely to increase more than 20 percent this year, to $8.7 billion in 2001 and $10.6 billion in 2002; Cross Country and AMN Healthcare, companies that dominate traveling nursing business, are planning initial public offerings (Market Place column) (M)

headline: Australia Open to Foreign Airline Stake
abstract: Australia would "look favorably" on a new foreign buyer for Air New Zealand Ltd.'s stake in the country's ailing second-largest carrier, Australia's treasurer said.

headline: In Europe, Some Critics Say the Attacks Stemmed From American Failings
abstract: Europeans, while expressing solidarity and sympathy, are divided in response to terrorist attacks on America; inconsistencies of American foreign policies and sheer weight of dominance in world have caused resentment; some Europeans feel that Americans have blind confidence in country's goodness and fail to see that some American actions are regarded by many as domineering pursuit of national self-interest (M)

headline: OPEC Plans A Reduction In Daily Output Of About 4%
abstract: OPEC decides to reduce its daily production by about 4 percent, or one million barrels, to buoy crude oil prices amid fears that worldwide oil demand is weakening; industry analysts do not expect move to produce spike in oil prices to last year's levels of $30 a barrel or more; say OPEC risks driving price of crude oil higher in fall and winter, just as demand for heating oil surges; price of oil for September delivery rises to $26.84, or 53 cents more than previous day; graphs (M)

headline: Another Lender to Stop Sales Of Single-Premium Coverage
abstract: Household International says it will yield to pressure from consumer groups and stop selling single-premium credit life insurance policies to people who take out home loans, which have been criticized as predatory (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Industrial Output Rises
abstract: France's industrial production rose in May for first time in three months (S)

headline: Privacy Group Is Taking Issue With Microsoft
abstract: Electronic Privacy Information Center intends to file formal complaint with Federal Trade Commission about Microsoft Corp's plans to bundle its Passport identification into its new Windows XP operating system; Senate Judiciary Committee plans to hold hearings in September on Microsoft's plans for integrating Web sevices into new operating system, which is scheduled to be introduced Oct 25; Sen Charles E Schumer, member of Judiciary committee, urges Justice Department and several state attorneys general to enjoin Microsoft from shipping Windows XP unless it scales back its plans (M)

headline: South Korea Lowers Forecast On Growth to 2%-3% Range
abstract: South Korean finance ministry cuts economic growth forecast to 2 to 3 percent range from 4 to 5 percent range in wake of terrorist attacks on United States (M)

headline: 20 Koreans Cut Off Fingers in an Anti-Japanese Protest
abstract: Twenty young Korean protesters chopped off the tips of their little fingers today while shouting "Apologize, apologize!" for offenses that they said the Japanese had committed against the Korean people

headline: P.& G. Reports Net Loss After Cost of Revamping
abstract: Procter & Gamble reports net loss of $320 million for fiscal fourth quarter ended June 30, mostly because of $1.16 billion restructuring charge, compared with year-earlier net income of $516 million; profit, excluding revamping charges, rose 7.7 percent, to $837 million, compared with $777 million a year ago (M)

headline: Campaigns for several products are shifting their focus from 'women only' to include 'real men.'
abstract: Article on growing number of companies that are shifting their advertising campaigns that focus on 'women only' to include 'real men'; specific campaigns noted (M)

headline: AFTER LOSS, ANC RENTAL CONSIDERS SALE OF COMPANY
abstract: ANC Rental Corp, parent of Alamo and National car rental companies, considers selling itself after reporting quarterly loss of $23.6 million, in contrast to income of $15.5 million year ago; revenue falls 6.4 percent; shares drop 24 cents, to $3.36 (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: COMPUCOM SYSTEMS INC., Dallas, a provider of network products and integration services and a unit of Safeguard Scientifics has agreed to buy certain assets of Excell Data Corp., Bellevue, Wash., a developer of online business software and Web sites for the information-technology industry, for an undisclosed amount of cash.    AMERICAN BILTRITE INC., Wellesley Hills, Mass., a maker of protective papers and films, flooring and industrial rubber products through its K&M Associates LP unit, has agreed to buy certain assets of Swank Inc's., Attleboro, Mass., women's costume jewelry division. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: JetBlue Airways Leaves Arnold Worldwide
abstract: JetBlue Airways ends its yearlong relationship with Arnold Worldwide; billings estimated at $14 million (S)

headline: World Briefing
Beijing Stages War Games, Mostly for Taiwan
abstract: China's latest and largest war games are described in unusual detail by official Chinese magazine, apparently to warn Taiwan not to be complacent about peace; games off southeastern coast simulated assault on one of Taiwan's outlying islands, which would likely be China's first step in any hostilities (S)

headline: Deployment of Troops to Macedonia Approved by NATO
abstract: NATO formally gave the go-ahead today for its full 3,500-soldier mission to disarm rebels in Macedonia.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: CARGILL INC., Wayzata, Minn., the largest agricultural producer, said it would build a plant to produce corn syrup in Shanghai in an equal joint venture with Global Bio-Chem Technology Group, Hong Kong, a corn processor. The 100,000-metric-ton-a-year factory is expected to cost $10.3 million.

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Even with oil prices down, OPEC is expected to maintain production levels.
abstract: Market Place column says OPEC is expected to maintain production levels despite decline in prices; cartel is under international pressure to keep prices low to avoid aggravating global economic slump; graph; chart (M)

headline: Profit Rises 9.1% At Pixar Animation
abstract: Pixar Animation Studios reports profit for 2001 second quarter rose 9.1 percent, to $8.75 million, compared with $8.02 million in year-earlier period (S)

headline: How Is Libel Different in Cyberspace?
abstract: What happens when arguably libelous material is "re-posted" in an Internet news group or bulletin board?

headline: Duong Van Minh, 85, Saigon Plotter, Dies
abstract: Duong Van Minh, Vietnamese general who led coup in 1963 that overthrew Ngo Dinh Diem as president of South Vietnam and later became republic's last president for few days before surrendering Saigon to North Vietnam, dies at age 85; photo (M)

headline: Business; For Better or Worse, Winemakers Go High Tech
abstract: New treatments and additives are spreading through US wine industry, enabling winemakers to adjust taste and texture of their products in response to consumer demand; changes have helped minimize risks of bad vintages and contributed to 25 percent increase in annual domestic wine production over last decade, but they have also inflamed emotional debate winemakers are erasing mystique of regional differences in wine; graph; photos (M)

headline: Morgan Stanley and Analyst Sued Over Advice
abstract: Two lawsuits filed by investors accuse Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Co and Mary Meeker, one of its analysts, of fraud in recommendations concerning stocks of eBay Inc and Amazon.com (M)

headline: London Journal; 5 Characters in Search of an Office
abstract: Five members of Britain's Conservative Party are locked in wide-open race for party's succeed William Hague as leader; they are Michael Ancram, Kenneth Clarke, David Davis, Iain Duncan Smith and Michael Portillo; photo (M)

headline: MILITARY SCUTTLES STRATEGY REQUIRING '2-WAR' CAPABILITY
abstract: United States abandons requirement that its military be prepared to fight two major wars simultaneously; adopts new strategy in which armed forces are ordered to 'win decisively' in single major conflict, defend American territory against new threats while conducting holding actions elsewhere around globe; for first time, defense of American homeland is incorporated into guidelines for American military strategy that are used to request money for military; so-called 'two-war' strategy has been in effect since 1993; senior administration officials hoped shifting from two-war capability would provide significant savings through personnel cuts, but they now find sizable increase in forces might be required, because of number of missions other than major regional war for which military must prepare; changes are laid out in 29-page classified document that has been approved by Defense Sec Donald Rumsfeld, armed service chiefs and regional war-fighting commanders (M)

headline: Feeling Restless At Macy's Parade
abstract: Michelle Slatalla Online Shopper column on shopping on newly redesigned Bloomingdale's and Macy's Web sites; holds sites are made for leisurely browsing, while she usually hunts online for specific items; photo (M)

headline: Market Place; Shareholders May Be Ready For Rebellion
abstract: Independent analysts say Computer Associates will probably defeat Sam Wyly's attempt to replace four members of its board, but Wyly's bid has already encouraged change at Computer Associates; since Ranger Governance, Wyly's investment company, began its bid in June, Computer Associates has added two new outside directors; chief executive, Sanjay Kumar, says company will add more board members next few months; Wyly has attacked board of Computer Associates as rubber stamp for chairman, Charles Wang, and Kumar (Market Place column) (M)

headline: People
abstract: Tom Burr, executive vice president and managing director at Hakuhodo Advertising America, is named to new post of chief operating officer (S)

headline: Leaders Draft 'Last Ditch' Package to Rescue Ulster Accord
abstract: National Security Archive, private research group, releases official State Department history that discloses new details of US policy during 1965 campaign by Indonesian Army to wipe out Communist opposition, which brought General Suharto to power as country's dictator, replacing Pres Sukarno; Central Intelligence Agency spokesman says CIA and State Department had tried to delay publication to avoid roiling relations at time of political turmoil in Indonesia; photo of Abdurrahman Wahid, ousted as Indonesia's president this week, who arrives in US for medical treatment (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Long-Distance Test A Success
abstract: Group of technology companies successfully tests network that enables storage and transfer of data over long distances; effort, known as Promontory Project, demonstrates that large amounts of data can be moved as fast as 10 billion bits a second (S)

headline: A Cool Gunman Wounds 10 Outside Israeli Defense Office
abstract: Palestinian gunman, in one of more brazen strikes in heart of Israel, sprays automatic rifle fire outside Israeli Defense Ministry on major thoroughfare in Tel Aviv that is part of military compound; wounds 10 people, mostly soldiers on lunch break, before he is shot and killed by traffic policeman while trying to escape; incident occurs on another day of relentless attacks and counterattacks that have made mockery of declared cease-fire, with no clear sense of where conflict is headed; Palestinians kill Israeli woman and wound four other people in West Bank near Jewish settlement of Alfe Menashe; Israeli Army fires missile at car in West Bank City of Tulkarm, killing Islamic militant accused of anti-Israel terrorism; soldiers in Tulkarm also fatally shoot Palestinian during alleged attempt to plant roadside bomb with accomplice, who escapes; Israeli missile strike, third in less than week, is part of Israel's pattern of singling out certain Palestinians for death; Prime Min Ariel Sharon says he will not abandon tactic; Israeli officials underscore point by announcing on television names of seven men on wanted list for supposed involvement in terrorism, past and present; photo (M)

headline: A.I.G. Group Nears Deal on Hyundai Units
abstract: American International Group resolves dispute with Hyundai Securities, apparently removing last major barrier to its takeover of Hyundai Group's financial units; will buy 33.1 percent controling stake in Hyundai Securities for $310 million and invest $540 million in two affiliated firms, Hyundai Investment Trust and Securities and Hyundai Investment Trust Management; deal calls for South Korea to invest $750 million in two affiliates; gives AIG consortium control of all three firms (M)

headline: Xerox Moves Up an Insider to Be Its Chief
abstract: The Xerox Corporation said yesterday that it had named Anne M. Mulcahy, its president and a 25-year employee, to be chief executive, effective Aug. 1. Ms. Mulcahy, 48, will succeed Paul A. Allaire, who will remain chairman until the end of the year.    The promotion comes just one day after Xerox announced a fourth consecutive quarterly loss but assured analysts that it would be making money again before the year was out. Investors seemed pleased with the promotion, sending Xerox's stock up 41 cents, to $8.

headline: Muslims in U.S. Seek Financing; Pursing the American Dream While Following the Koran
abstract: American financial services companies are beginning to fashion products for Muslims, who are barred from paying or receiving interest; HSBC Bank USA is already positioning itself to mine Muslim home financing market in New York City area; Muslim market is not typical immigrant or ethnic market that can be reached by educating people about American-style credit or translating mortgage documents; graphs; photos (M)

headline: BOSTON SCIENTIFIC ARTERY PRODUCT PASSES TEST
abstract: Study by Germany's Siegburg Heart Center finds Boston Scientific Corp's experimental drug-coated stent, metal-mesh tube used to prop open cleared arteries, prevents blood vessels from reclogging (S)

headline: Hitachi Unit Is Said to Be Buying Consulting Firm
abstract: Hitachi Ltd's Experio Solutions Internet consulting unit to acquire WaveBend Solutions consulting firm for $17.5 million (M)

headline: EARL SCHEIB SAYS IT WILL CLOSE 41 OF ITS AUTO BODY SHOPS
abstract: Earl Scheib Inc, owner of chain of auto body shops, plans to close 26 percent of its stores in next three years; move could eliminate as many as 328 jobs, or 33 percent of its staff (S)

headline: One Investor. Two Brokers. An Account Runs Dry.
abstract: John Teeples, whose $700,000 investment portfolio was reduced to $403.95 and $40,000 in taxes owed in only 16 months, says two brokers at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, Arun Sardana and Michael Moriarty, capitalized on his naivete; 13 customers who lost total of $20 million accuse two brokers of widespread pattern of sales-practice violations, including recommendation of highly speculative stock trades and excessive use of margin borrowing; their complaints are now in process of arbitration; Teeples's story is just one of many tales beginning to emerge as investors realize that their decimate portfolios may never come back; photos; chart; graph (L)

headline: OPEC Leaders Indicate They Are Set to Cut Output Again
abstract: OPEC leaders indicate that they plan to reduce daily production for third time this year to shore up flagging crude oil prices; analysts say decision could come as early as next week and would probably lead to decrease of 750,000 to one million barrels per day, or 3 percent to 4 percent of OPEC's current daily output of 24.2 million barrels; OPEC's move would come in response to growing perceptions within international oil markets of abundance of oil and other energy sources as economies around world slow; OPEC favors crude oil prices of $25 to $28 per barrel; has said it will reduce daily production if average oil price falls below $22; OPEC News Agency reports average declined 56 cents per barrel on July 18 to $22.64; crude oil for September delivery closes at $25.94 on New York Mercantile Exchange, increase of $1.16 from previous day; graph; chart (M)

headline: Two Nations Cut Interest Rates
abstract: Bank of Korea reduces its overnight call interest rate by half percentage point to 4 percent, lowest in bank's history; Reserve Bank of New Zealand reduces its benchmark overnight cash rate target half point, to 5.25 percent (M)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: EUROPE

headline: New Trouble for Swissair Means a New Revamping
abstract: Swissair Group says it will take steps to reorganize by reducing it work force and its long-haul flight schedule; is also seeking government support to stay in operation; photo (M)

headline: Japan Says Its Armed Forces Will Actively Back the U.S.
abstract: In a sharp break with the past, Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi announced today that his country's armed forces would actively support American reprisals for last week's terrorist attacks.

headline: Suit Says Aetna Violated Hiring Agreement
