abstract: Aetna Inc is accused by WellPoint Health Networks Inc of violating agreement by hiring a WellPoint executive, Ronald A Williams, as chief of health operations; lawsuit says two companies agreed in August 2000 not to solicit or hire certain employees of other for one-year period (S)

headline: Temirtau Journal; Steel Company Buys a Mill, Gets a Kazakh Town
abstract: Ispat International, which acquired aging steel mill in Temirtau, Kazakhstan, in 1995, has rescued city from chaos left by collapse of Soviet Union; has taken over many basic services; revitalized steel plant offers glimmer of hope in bleak city; is symbol of nation's effort to rebuild economy through foreign investment and privatization; map; photo (M)

headline: Connections to a Tragedy: Creating a Record of Awful Days
abstract: New York Times business reporter Riva D Atlas remembers business associates and friends lost in terrorist attacks on World Trade Center and how she and her colleagues are trying to create record of awful days (M)

headline: Consumer Spending Returning to Normal
abstract: Largest retail chains, including Wal-Mart Stores, Kmart and Sears, Roebuck & Co, report spending patterns returned to near normal levels during weekend following terrorist attacks, but business remains down from last year; graphs (M)

headline: Shares of Marconi Tumble and Technology Follows
abstract: Shares of Marconi, Britain's largest telephone equipment maker, fall by more than half in vivid display of spiraling decline in Europe's telecommunications industry; Marconi has warned that sales will be sharply reduced and that operating profit will be half this year's, with 4,000 more jobs being eliminated; graph (M)

headline: Moving to Jersey City Until Further Notice
abstract: Merrill Lynch & Co is relocated to Jersey City after being locked out of its headquarters in World Financial Center, across West Street from fallen World Trade Center; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Pirelli Seeks New Terms
abstract: Pirelli says it wants to renegotiate its deal with holding company Bell SA over acquisition of Olivett, whose stock price has fallen 50 percent since July (S)

headline: Defiant Chirac Denies Corruption Charges, Avoiding Specifics
abstract: French Pres Jacques Chirac, under mounting pressure to respond to charges he paid cash for $300,000 worth of airplane tickets for himself and entourage, denies any wrongdoing and scores investigators for sloppy work, Bastille Day television interview; avoids giving details (M)

headline: Article 2001070393384805479 -- No Title
abstract: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Gucci Expands Again
abstract: Gucci Group to buy 91 percent of rival luxury goods maker Balenciaga; Balenciaga plans to open stores in several cities to spur sales; graph (S)

headline: People Power; Talk if You Must, but at Least Put Some Muscle Into Idle Chat
abstract: Aladdinpower, hand-held generator that looks like tension grip, allows user to convert squeezes into energy that can be transferred to almost any cell phone or other device with rechargeable batteries; Motorola will introduce similar product later this year; photo (M)

headline: USA Networks to Buy Stake in Expedia
abstract: The Microsoft Corporation agreed to sell its controlling interest in Expedia Inc., an online travel reservation company, to USA Networks

headline: Très Facile
abstract: To the Editor:    In your Q & A of Aug. 9 you discussed ways of putting Spanish-language characters in e-mail messages. I would like to suggest another, easier (for me) method to send messages in European languages.

headline: 2 Groups Try to Involve Public In Internet Address Policy
abstract: In an effort to increase public participation in policy decisions regarding the Internet's address system, two groups issued reports this week with recommendations on how best to involve individuals in policy matters

headline: JUDGE DENIES CLASS ACTION IN BIAS SUITS AGAINST LOCKHEED
abstract: Judge J Owen Forrester refuses, in Atlanta US District Court, to grant class-action status to two race-discrimination lawsuits against Lockheed Martin by ten black workers at its aeronautics division (S)

headline: Layoffs Push Jobless Claims to 9-Year High
abstract: Labor Department reports first-time jobless claims rose by 58,000, to 450,000 in week ended Sept 22, highest level in nine years as people dismissed after Sept 11 terrorist attacks began to file claims for state aid; Commerce Department reports orders for durable goods in August fell 0.3 percent, compared with revised 1.1 percent decrease in July; says new-home sales increased 0.6 percent, to annual rate of 898,000 houses, from July pace of 893,000 that was weaker than first reported; graph on prices of new homes (M)

headline: Webdenda: Executive Changes at Media Firms
abstract: Chris Byrnes, senior editor and graphics director at Charlex, New York, was named president. He succeeds Alex Weil, who continues as chief executive and executive creative director. Also at Charlex, nine executives were named vice presidents: Steve Chiarello, senior producer; Tom Ferguson, business manager; Marc Goldfine, senior flame artist; Donna Herman, financial controller; Amy Kindred, executive producer; David Langley, corporate affairs; Grey Oyen, senior flame artist and technical director; Harry Skopas, director for engineering; and John Zawisha, senior editor.

headline: World Briefing | Asia: North Korea: Leader On The Road
abstract: North Korea's leader Kim Jong Il begins journey to Moscow aboard Trans-Siberian Railroad, but train makes only 20-minute stop in Khabarovsk, city where historians say he was born (S)

headline: CNN Returns to Its Element but Faces High Expectations
abstract: Terrorist attacks in New York and Washington have thrust CNN back into clear leadership position in cable news, though network is under pressure and facing expectations that no other news organization is likely to face: namely that whenever American retaliation takes place, CNN will be in position to cover it; photo (M)

headline: Profit Soars at German Software Giant
abstract: Germany's SAP, Europe's biggest software maker, reports 78 percent rise in second-quarter profit, to 206 million euros ($179 million); sales were up 24 percent, to 1.85 billion euros; photo (M)

headline: Uncertainty in U.S. Disrupts Investment Plans in Russia
abstract: Deals between Russian and American companies are being reconsidered or postponed as companies watch for signs of how much investor interest remains after terrorist attacks in US; Russian companies have been struggling for three years to rehabilitate their reputations among international investors after country's financial crisis; Russia remains risk emerging market, and fear of risk is common side effect of disasters and market disruptions (M)

headline: He Puts the Labor in Labor Day, Officially
abstract: He Puts the Labor In Labor Day, Officially  Tomorrow, when most American workers will be resting in honor of their toils the rest of the year, John J. Sweeney, the president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., will be working overtime

headline: Gillette Hires BBDO for Oral Care Work
abstract: Gillette Hires BBDO For Oral Care Work The Gillette Company has expanded its relationship with the New York office of BBDO Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group, by naming BBDO New York to handle creative duties for its worldwide oral-care businesses, including the Oral B line of toothbrushes and dental floss along with the Braun line of oral-care appliances. Annual spending was estimated at $100 million

headline: DRUG DATA COMPANY IS TOLD TO SHARE ITS GERMAN SYSTEM
abstract: European Commission orders IMS Health, world's largest collector of pharmaceutical sales and prescription data, to license way it organizes data on German market; finds IMS abuses its dominant position in market; IMS to appeal (S)

headline: AT&T and British Telecom Study Possible Closing of Joint Venture
abstract: AT&T and British Telecommunications are exploring the possibility of ending a joint venture that focuses on providing large corporations with telecommunications services, people close to the companies said yesterday.    The chairmen of the two companies, Sir Christopher Bland of British Telecommunications and C. Michael Armstrong of AT&T, discussed the move on Friday. Closing the venture, Concert, is one of several possible options, people close to the companies said. B.T. has also discussed selling its stake to AT&T, but concern over such a transaction heightened recently after European regulators sought to block General Electric's acquisition of Honeywell.

headline: U.N. Certifies First Election In the Newly Born East Timor
abstract: UN certifies results of East Timor's first democratic election, and newly chosen constituent assembly prepares to start drafting Constitution that will set stage for full independence; main independence party, Fteriulin, won 55 of 88 seats, putting it in position to dominate drafting; photo (M)

headline: Fox Trying to Give Mexico Bigger Role on World Stage
abstract: Pres Vicente Fox's determination to raise Mexico's profile on world stage is seen in exchanges of visits with Pres Bush, Prime Min Tony Blair and other leaders; photos; Fox will continue with former state visit to Washington and address to joint session of Congress, saying his country no longer has to be 'ashamed' of not having full democracy; US Amb Jeffrey Davidow says Mexico has opened up to world through trade and culture, but also through profound political change that Fox's election represents (M)

headline: A 'Functioning' Pentagon Bolsters Defenses on East and West Coasts : Nervous Reactions in Asia (folo)
abstract: Don Kirk of International Herald Tribune reported from Seoul:

headline: World Briefing
abstract: ASI

headline: In a Shift, an H.M.O. Rewards Doctors for Quality Care
abstract: Blue Cross of California, one of nation's largest health insurers, will pay bonuses to doctors serving its health maintenance organization members based on patient satisfaction and other quality standards; will also stop paying extra to physicians with best cost-cutting records; Blue Cross of California is subsidiary of Wellpoint Health Networks (M)

headline: Business Travel; In 'Airworld' and in real life, frequent fliers are struggling to keep their mileage accounts up.
abstract: Cutbacks in business traveler mean that some business fliers may not rack up enough mileage to stay in elite mileage clubs, which carry a lot of status for some people, but they will have easier time getting upgrades and free trips (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: India: Setback For Minister
abstract: Indian Supreme Court declines to overturn corruption conviction of Jayalalitha Jayaram, flamboyant chief minister of Tamil Nadu; photo (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Poland: Fight For Phone Company
abstract: Poland's largest mobile phone operator, Polska Telefonia Cyfrowa, is the object of a new battle between Vivendi Universal of France and Deutsche Telekom. Last week, the supervisory board of P.T.C.'s  majority owner in Poland, Elektrim, accepted an offer of 709 million euros ($603 million), which would give Vivendi control of the phone company as well as Elektrim's cable television and fixed-line telephone assets, and float the combined communication company on the Warsaw exchange. The supervisors had rejected an offer by Deutsche Telekom, which controls 49 percent of P.T.C. and operates the company. Deutsche said it would press ahead with arbitration for 3 percent of P.T.C. that it claimed Elektrim owed it from an earlier deal.   Peter S. Green (NYT)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: Afghan Refugees
abstract: Government of Pakistan and Untied Nations refugee agency sign agreement that sets up screening process for Afghans who have fled to Pakistan to escape war and drought; aid has been hampered by long dispute about how to separate economic refugees from political ones (S)

headline: Technology Briefing
abstract: Technology Briefing

headline: After Phone Call, British Minister Moves Up Planned Trip to Iran
abstract: British Foreign Secretary Jack Straw will visit Iran shortly, first visit to Tehran by minister of his rank since Islamic revolution in 1979; depicts trip as part of efforts to build coalition against terrorism since attacks against New York and Washington, DC (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: More Layoffs At Motorola
abstract: Motorola Inc will add 2,000 more workers to its previously announced job cuts, bringing total in last year to 32,000 (S)

headline: The Bondage of Poverty That Produces Chocolate
abstract: Ivory Coast's cocoa plantations said to employ child laborers recruited or smuggled from other African countries; line between slave trading and bondage of poverty is sometimes unclear, and child labor retains deep roots in West and Central Africa; parents send their children away to earn money or learn trade; but reports of widespread abuse in Ivory Coast, world's top cocoa exporter, have generated accusations and anger in Europe and United States; in Britain, groups try to organize consumer boycott of chocolate; in Washington, House passes bill calling for voluntary system of labeling which would identify origin of cocoa in chocolate and state 'no child slave labor'; photos; map (L)

headline: A First Line of Defense, Armed With Headsets
abstract: Vanguard telephone representatives field about 30,000 calls a day, selling mutual funds, solving customers' problems and holding their hands in panicky markets; normal complement of about 1,000 is augmented whenever necessary from force of several hundred trained reserves; representatives must watch what they say to investors, since they are not permitted to offer investment advice; photo (M)

headline: Ice Cream Makers Ask Washington to Help Cut Rising Costs
abstract: Ice cream producers use their annual party in Washington, DC, to lobby for lower prices for milk fat, key part of their product; they assert Agriculture Department's latest regulations for dairy prices pushed up cost of milk fat at least 50 percent in last year; ice cream makers have raised their prices about 4 percent this year, and more price increases are expected; photo (M)

headline: NATO Ministers Decide to Send Troops Into Macedonia
abstract: After hearing a favorable report from their top military commander, NATO ministers decided today to send 3,500 soldiers into Macedonia to help disarm Albanian insurgents

headline: World Briefing | The Americas: Peru: Ex-Official Arrested
abstract: Peruvian law enforcement officials arrest Victor Joy Way, cabinet chief for former Pres Alberto Fujimori, on corruption charges, as go-between for former intelligence chief Vladimiro Montesinos (S)

headline: 401(K) ACCOUNTS ARE LOSING MONEY FOR THE FIRST TIME
abstract: Average account lost money in 2000 for first time in 20-year history of popular 401(k) retirement savings plan, even after thousands of dollars of new contributions; estimates show declines persisted into first half of 2001, despite some strengthening of stock prices; trend exposes years of mistakes by employees; raises questions about proposals to permit Americans to manage part of their Social Security accounts; clouds future of many employees' nest eggs for retirement; survey of shifting account balances over last decade shows many people have grown overly dependent on stocks, do not contribute enough to retire when they expect to and put too much into single aggressive mutual fund or own company's stock; finds relatively few employers offer much useful help to workers in making crucial investment or other decisions; photo; graphs; charts (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Cattle Prognosis Mixed
abstract: Live cattle are auctioned in Britain for first time in six months, raising possibility that foot-and-mouth disease epidemic is subsiding; two new cases of disease are confirmed in Northern England; farmers protest government's handling of epidemic outside Prime Min Tony Blair's residence (S)d

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: BURGER KING CORP., Miami, part of Diageo P.L.C., named Bennett Nussbaum chief financial officer, succeeding Colin Heggie, who left the company last year. Mr. Nussbaum had been senior vice president and chief financial officer at Kinko's Inc.    LANDACORP, Atlanta, named Gene Miller chief operating officer, assuming responsibilities from Gene Cattarina, president and chief executive who had also served as interim chief operating officer since April. Mr. Miller had been executive vice president at CorSolutions, Buffalo Grove, Ill.

headline: World Briefing | The Americas: Mexico: Development Blocked
abstract: Mexican government bars Sol Melia from developing seaside resort hotel at Xcacel, saying water runoff from hotel could harm habitat of endangered green and loggerhead sea turtles (S)

headline: Private Sector; Pirate of Prague, or Comeback Kid?
abstract: Viktor Kozeny, emigre Czech financier who became known as Pirate of Prague over accusations of defrauding investors in Czech Republic, says from his home in Bahamas resort of Lyford Cay that he has done nothing wrong, and will make a comeback; photo (S)

headline: JOINT VENTURE IS FORMED TO MAKE SWISS ARMY WATCHES
abstract: Victorinox, maker of Swiss Army Knife, and Swiss Army Brands form Victorinox Swiss Army Watch to sell Swiss Army brand of watches outside United States, Canada and Caribbean (S)

headline: With Cost Cuts, MetLife Says Net Rose 12%
abstract: Second-quarter earnings at MetLife rise to $419 million, 12 percent increase from year ago; revenue falls 2 percent (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Myanmar: Opposition Leaders Freed
abstract: Myanmar authorities release from detention U Aung Shwe and U Tin Oo, leaders of opposition National League for Democracy (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Surprise Strike By Chechen Rebels
abstract: Chechen rebels surprise Russian troops with their strongest and most coordinated attack in months, downing helicopter in Grozny that carries 10 senior Russian commanders and mounting sustained attack by at least 300 guerrillas on government offices; map (S)

headline: Cease-Fire in Macedonia Stops the Guns but Not the Ethnic Distrust and Bitterness
abstract: Cease-fire appears to be holding in Macedonia, but that alone does little to overcome chasm of anger and distrust between two major ethnic groups: majority Slav Macedonians and ethnic Albanians who make up one-third of population; theirs is story of two peoples who lived side by side for centuries, if uneasily, and who now view same facts through different eyes; photo; map (M)

headline: Shares Rise on Semiconductor Study and Profit Forecasts
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average rises 102.76 points, to close at 10,276.80; Nasdaq composite index gains 28.71 points, to 1,860.01; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rises 8.05 points, to 1,165.31; graph; chart (M)

headline: SUMITOMO MITSUI SELLING SOME OF ITS STAKE IN GOLDMAN
abstract: Sumitomo Mitsui Banking Corp will sell about $500 million worth of shares in Goldman Sachs Group to raise funds to write off bad loans and cope with slowing business in its home market (S)

headline: Quetta Journal; Giving Proper Burial to Holy Books
abstract: Quetta Journal describes web of hand-dug tunnels that extend deep into mountains south of Pakistani city, burial place for millions of discarded copies of Koran; photos; map (M)

headline: Serbian Tells of Spiriting Milosevic Away
abstract: Serbian Prime Min Zoran Djindjic explains elaborate ruses and decoys he devised to thwart any army opposition and spirit Slobodan Milosevic out of country to face international war crimes tribunal; interview; photo; says police were ready for confrontation with army, which is controlled by Djindjic's rival, Pres Vojislav Kostunica, who opposed transfer (M)

headline: A 2nd Venture Set in On-Demand Film Rental
abstract: Walt Disney Co and News Corp will join forces to create Internet video-on-demand service, Movies.com (S)

headline: Bcom3 Agencies Merge and Plan Layoffs
abstract: Bcom3 Group merges two subdivisions and lays off 30 percent of its staff (S)

headline: Long-Range Justice Raises Fears for Sovereignty
abstract: Arm of international law is growing longer for national leaders, such as Slobodan Milosevic, who are accused of atrocities; trend is celebrated by human rights advocates, but is viewed by some lawyers and governments as alarmingchallenge to national sovereignty and potentially unpredictable political tool subject to political abuse (M)

headline: To the Navy Ranks, Add Webmaster
abstract: Web site of USS Kitty Hawk allows families of crew members to follow movements of aircraft carrier, as much as military security allows, and e-mail has proved to be real boon for crew during long months at sea; site is one of 2,000 unrestricted military ones on Web; Kitty Hawk's Web masters are Chief Petty Officer Lance Lindley and Petty Officer Third Class Jacob Hickman; photos (M)

headline: Ex-Ruling Party Challenges Result in Juárez Vote
abstract: Institutional Revolutionary Party, pressing fight for political control of Juarez, Mexico's largest city on northern border, files complaint to have recent mayoral election overturned; candidate Roberto Barraza accuses incumbent Gustavo Elizondo of violating campaign laws that prohibit candidates and elected officials from making any public comments about elections within five days of vote (S)

headline: Compressed Data; In Software Empire, the Sun Never Sets on 'Bespoke'
abstract: Bespoke, British term meaning custom-made, is increasingly being used in reference to computer software; drawing (M)

headline: Miscellany
abstract: Havas Advertising acquires Noonan/Russo Communications; Cohn & Wolfe forms strategic alliance with Circulation Experti (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Motorola Said To Want To Sell Unit
abstract: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc is in talks with Motorola Inc to buy its military communications unit (S)

headline: Doner Gets PNC, A $30 Million Account
abstract: PNC Financial Services Group names Doner ad agency to handle its account, which for two years was at Arnold Worldwide; billings estimated at $30 million (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Canadian Nest Eggs In a Nortel Basket
abstract: Plunge in Nortel Networks' stock is causing shock through many Canadians' retirement plans; stock has unusually large place in Canadian portfolios; shares are more than $80 off their level year ago; chart; photos (Market Place column) (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Foreigners Sell Stocks
abstract: Threat of military action in region after last week's terrorist attacks has foreign institutional investors cashing out their Indian equity holdings; benchmark Bombay index falls 5.25 percent, reaching eight-year low; value of Indian rupee also falls (S)

headline: Study Details Decline In Spending on Ads
abstract: CMR survey finds spending by advertisers in traditional media fell 5.9 percent in first half of 2001 compared with year earlier; says ad spending in first half totaled just under $47.5 billion, compared with $50.4 billion (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Cambodia: Stepping Up To Vote
abstract: Cambodian officials say 80 percent of eligible voters have registered to take part in first election for local leaders, scheduled for Feb 2002 (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Mcdata Acquires Sanavigator
abstract: McData Corp, vendor of networking products for data storage devices, will acquire SANavigator Inc, subsidiary of Western Digital Corp, for $29.75 million (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Japanese yen rises on speculation that Japanese banks and other investors are pulling back funds from abroad to cover investment losses at home; in New York, dollar settles at 118.80 yen, down from 119.47; graph; chart (S)

headline: G.O.P. Delays Effort to Give Bush Latitude On Free Trade
abstract: House Republican leaders delay until fall effort to give president broad authority to negotiate new trade accords that could not be amended by Congress; say they lack votes to pass measure; decision is setback for Pres Bush (M)

headline: Earnings Off Sharply At Samsung Electronics
abstract: Samsung Electronics says net income for second quap

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Economy Grows 2.7%
abstract: Bank of Korea says economic growth from April through June was 2.7 percent higher than in second quarter of 2000; graph (S)

headline: Nuclear Booty: More Smugglers Use Asia Route
abstract: Recent appearance of relatively large quantity of uranium on black market in former Soviet republic of Georgia, and possible involvement of army officer, underscores concerns within American government that trafficking in nuclear material has shifted from Europe to Caucasus, Central Asia and Turkey; region is gateway from Russia, which has huge stocks of nuclear material, to countries that are in market for weapons material--such as Iran, Iraq and Pakistan; US intelligence experts say few smuggling incidents involve materials that could be used to make bombs, and that they know of no successful attempt at smuggling weapons-grade material; concede, however, that scope of smuggling remains uncertain; rising number of incidents and strong belief that only fraction of shipments are intercepted have riased level of anxiety in Turkey; worries are heightened by slackness of border controls and economic instability that has left customs officers vulnerable to bribes; International Atomic Agency statistics show number of confirmed cases of nuclear smuggling have fallen in rest of world, but risen in Turkey, Caucasus and Central Asia; photo (M)

headline: CALLAWAY, MAKER OF GOLF CLUBS, ELECTS A CHAIRMAN
abstract: Callaway Golf Co elects Ronald Drapeau chairman to succeed its late founder, Ely Callaway (S)

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of Aug 5 article on Princeton Review, test preparation company

headline: At a time when many dot-coms are failing, Style.com opens its campaign with a flourish.
abstract: Style.com, fashion Web site owned by Advance Publications, introduces $11 million media ad campaign devised by Badger Kry; photo (M)

headline: Chinese Region Felled by Nature's Blows
abstract: BAYINDELIGAR, China — It doesn't quite match the 10 plagues of ancient Egypt — the pastures here have not been overrun by frogs or fleas, at least not yet.

headline: Biden Opens Wide Critique Of Bush Plan For a Shield
abstract: Senate Foreign Relations Committee chairman, Joseph R Biden Jr, says Pres Bush's plans for missile defense sacrifice national security for sake of 'theological' belief; says that effort to make system work would cost astronomical amounts of money and that administration would create greater insecurity than at any time 1960's if it proceeded; says system would undo arms control efforts of last 40 years and set US against its allies, without offering protection proponents promise; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | The Americas: Mexico: Bombs Outside Banks
abstract: Three small bombs explode outside several Banamex bank branches in Mexico City in apparent protest against sale of Mexico's most powerful financial institutions to foreign companies (S)

headline: AremisSoft Falls 91% as Trading Resumes
abstract: Shares of AremisSoft Corp resume trading after monthlong halt caused by Securities and Exchange Commission investigation; shares immediately fall in value 91 percent, closing at $1 from $10.19 (S)

headline: Sci-Fi Prescience
abstract: Patrick Lozito letter comments on Aug 2 article on computer fiction, noting pioneering work of late science fiction author Poul Anderson

headline: PERSONAL BUSINESS: DIARY
abstract: Ipsos-Reid study finds that many American workers feel as much stress on their days off as they do on the job, largely because they are either on call for their offices or dealing with work issues...Council of Public Relations Firms survey of 1,013 workers finds that 72 percent are 'not at all worried' about being laid off in this weak economy...Management Recruiters International reports that 68 percent of executives eat lunch at their desks at least once a week, 34 percent at least three times a week and 10 percent every day (M)

headline: Private Sector; Clinton White House Export: International Trade Lawyers
abstract: International trade lawyers who were members of Clinton administration have been returning to private practice of trade law, among them Robert T Novick, Mickey Kantor, Peter Scher and Charlene Barshefsky; photo (S)

headline: Maker of Phone Wires Considers Sale of Unit
abstract: Superior TeleCom Inc, maker of copper telephone wire, is considering putting its main business, communication cable unit, up for sale (S)

headline: Cast of Star Wars Makes Comeback in Bush Plan
abstract: Nearly every major element of Pres Ronald Reagan's original proposal to place weapons in space is back in center of Pentagon's plans for national missile shield; space-based defenses would be placed in orbit as permanent sentinels, waiting until enemy warhead rises above atmosphere before trying to obliterate warhead, missile carrying it or both; Pentagon's new plan calls for accelerated development of chemical lasers that would fly in space or high in atmosphere, fresh research on abandoned program to launch thousands of interceptors into space and expansion of project to place dozens of sensor-laden satellites into orbit; critics of new plan, like critics of Reagan's plan 20 years ago, fear it could transform space from placid zone into potential battlefield; diagrams (M)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Angola: Eviction Protest Banned
abstract: Officials in Luanda bar march to protest eviction of thousands of Angolan families from neighborhood where government contends homes are unsafe (S)

headline: Business; From a British Chain, Lunch in a New York Minute
abstract: Pret A Manger, British chain of shops serving prepackaged meals with great speed, opens second Manhattan store and anticipates 30 more within two years; McDonald's is part-owner of chain; photos (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Japanese yen declines after Moody's says it might cut Japan's credit rating because of deflation is making it hard for Japan to repay its debts; yen drops to 121.08 per dollar from 120.73 in New York (S)

headline: U.S. READY TO END SANCTIONS ON INDIA TO BUILD ALLIANCE
abstract: Bush administration moves on broad front to strengthen relations with India, nation it views as neglected and potentially important strategic ally and trading partner in Asia; is almost certain to ask Congress to lift economic and military sanctions imposed in 1998 for its test of nuclear weapon; some of most senior legislators, including Senate Foreign Relations Committee chairman, Sen Joseph R Biden Jr, back move; lifting of sanctions would remove significant irritant to closer ties, and would also signal that US has little choice but to accept India's membership in nuclear club; administration is likely to ask Congress to lift some sanctions against neighboring Pakistan, which detonated own nuclear weapon in tit-for-tat test; Sen Biden says he is not prepared to support request for Pakistan, which has since come under military rule (M)

headline: World Business Briefing
abstract: GLOBAL TRADE

headline: Airlines Are Cutting Back on Some International Flights
abstract: Airline industry analysts say decision by United Airlines to halt nonstop service between New York and Hong Kong after only three months may be harbinger of similar moves by other US carriers; demand among business travelers has been weak; similar cancellations by Delta Air Lines and American Air Lines, and decision by Cathay Pacific Airways to scratch plans for New York-Hong Kong service, discussed (M)

headline: A Generation in Flux, Or Caught Between Waves?
abstract: Craig Boreth letter comments on Abby Ellin's June 17 column on careers shifts among people in 'Generation X'

headline: Chinese Entry to Trade Group Stumbles Over Life Insurance
abstract: China's effort to win entry to World Trade Organization stumbles over access of foreign companies to country's vast life insurance market; issue pits European Union against Bush administration and centers on American International Group; AIG already operates in China without 50 percent local ownership required under China's WTO entry terms, and it wants to continue that arrangement when it expands its operations; Europeans maintain that gives American insurance giant unfair advantage and that playing field should be leveled; China insists on 50 percent requirement (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: India: Arrests In Death Of 'Bandit Queen'
abstract: Three men are arrested in connection with killing of Phoolan Devi, India's 'Bandit Queen' who became legislator (S)

headline: Business; Airlines Are Clearing a Nonstop Path to the Plane
abstract: Airlines and airports are using new technologies to reduce number of times travelers must interface with agents at airports, from optical scanning ID to boarding passes printed at home; technological advances coincide with major expansions at many airports to handle crowding on ground that has come with crowding in skies; photo; graph (M)

headline: CENDANT PREDICTS MARKETING DEAL WILL HELP NEXT YEAR
abstract: Cendant Corp expects its 2002 earnings to benefit from marketing agreement between its Trilegiant Corp affiliate and America Online unit of AOL Time Warner (S)

headline: Former Rebels in Colombia Take the Capitalist Road
abstract: Colombia's 'reinsertion program' encourages former Marxist guerrillas to assimilate into society and join legitimate economy; successes include Industrias Rof, venerable lighting company that got influx of capital from former guerrillas who pooled money they got for laying down arms; Maria Elba Salazar, who deserted rebel army two years ago, now runs seafood restaurant in Bogota; photo (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Brussels: Sabena At The Edge
abstract: Belgian airline Sabena says it may forced into bankruptcy by Sept 11 attacks on US; has not made profit in nearly two decades and is embroiled in fight with its unions over proposed $399 million bailout plan that calls for eliminating 1,600 jobs (S)

headline: Hitachi, Facing a Big Loss, Plans to Cut 14,700 Jobs
abstract: Hitachi Ltd, Japan's largest private employer, will cut 4 percent of its work force, or 14,700 jobs, by March--10,200 in Japan and remaining 4,500 overseas; says need for staff reductions stems from slump in high technology and from company's expected loss this year of $1.2 billion; photo (M)

headline: Private Sector; Celebrating a Shave, Quietly
abstract: Gillette Co commemorates founding in 1901; photo of King Camp Gillette (S)

headline: KEY3MEDIA GROUP LOWERS 2001 REVENUE FORECAST
abstract: Key3Media Group, producer of information-technology trade shows and conferences, pares its 2001 sales estimates and says it will cut 10 percent from its staff to reduce costs (S)

headline: Norwegians, Defying Protests, Will Sell Blubber to Japan
abstract: Norwegian whalers prepare to export hundreds of tons of edible minke whale blubber to Japan in face of widespread condemnation by nations that oppose whaling; exports will represent first international trade in whale products in more than decade; Norwegians minimalize plan, calling it normal and legal, but environmentalists say it could open floodgates to kind of large-scale hunting that drove blue whale and other species to verge of extinction in last century (M)

headline: How Long an Impact On Consumer Spending?
abstract: Britt Seemer, chairman of America's Research Group, predicts major cuts in consumer spending for at least two weeks after terrorist attacks on World Trade Center and Pentagon; Kurt Barnard, president of Barnard Retail Trend Report, says consumer confidence has been choppy and situation has not helped (S)

headline: Irving S. Shapiro, 85, Lawyer And Ex-Chairman of DuPont
abstract: Irving S Shapiro, lawyer, former chairman of duPont Companyand corporate liaison to Washington, dies at age 85; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Racketeering Suit
abstract: Mikom sues Russian Aluminum under American racketeering laws over 2000 takeover of Kochkanarsky GOK vanadium plant by company's associates; charges company and its agents with murder, extortion, bribery and other crimes linked to takeover (S)

headline: Compressed Data; Hand-Held Monitor Compiles Heart Data
abstract: Active Corp introduces portable heart monitor planned for use with Palm handheld devices; unit, called Active ECG, sends recorded heart data to Palm, where it can be viewed, printed or transmitted by wired modem to doctor or hospital emergency room; it was invented by Jeffrey and Karen Siegel; photo (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Financial Group Sees Loss
abstract: Switzerland's largest financial group, UBS A.G., warned that it expected losses of up to $234 million this year from investments by its private equity business, UBS Capital. The announcement came two weeks after the bank cited tough market conditions when it canceled plans to sell the unit to a management group led by its former chief executive, Pierre de Weck. After the Zurich-based company's first-quarter earnings slumped, it reduced the rate of investments in private equity.   Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

headline: Longtime Publisher Ends Era in Canada
abstract: Conrad Black's Hollinger Group sells its remaining 50 percent interest in The National Post of Toronto, which he founded three years ago to provide conservative voice for Canadian newspaper readers, to West Global Communications; photo (M)

headline: Violence Subsides in Jamaica, but Wounds Still Fester
abstract: Violence in Kingston, Jamaica, subsides, but squads of soldiers with rifles remain on streets as reminders that country has been shaken by its deadliest clashes in decades; 21 civilians died in gun battles with police after police entered neighborhood looking for illegal weapons; residents claim police fired indiscriminately at them; three police officers and soldier are also killed; photo; map (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Pressure On Japan
abstract: South Korea's National Assembly presses campaign against Japan's middle-school textbooks which critics say gloss over wartime atrocities by passing resolution asking government to block Japan's campaign for seat on UN Security Council (S)

headline: INVESTING WITH/John W. and John C. Thompson; Thompson Plumb Growth Fund
abstract: Carole Gould column profiles Thompson Plumb Growth fund and its co-managers, John W and John C Thompson, a father-son team; photo; table; chart (M)

headline: Hicks Muse Partner Quits Rather Than Move to Dallas
abstract: Michael J Levitt resigns as Hicks Muse, Tate & Furst partner rather than move to Dallas after firm closes New York and Buenos Aires headquarters (M)

headline: INSURANCE.COM STARTS SELLING ONLINE AUTO COVERAGE
abstract: Insurance.com unit of Fidelity Investments begins offering streamlined Internet sales of auto insurance in Florida and Georgia that allows drivers hours, rather than days, to obtain policy (S)

headline: Draping Newscasts With the Flag
abstract: Television has draped its coverage of terrorist attacks on US with American flag; CNN, Fox News Channel and MSNBC have incorporated screen images of American flags; red, white and blue ribbons and flag pins have at times adorned lapels of news anchors; critics say such actions undermine anchors' position as disinterested conveyers of news and can intensify public opinion in way that could push America into war footing; photo (M)

headline: SAFECO TO ELIMINATE 10% OF ITS JOBS BY THE END OF 2003
abstract: Safeco Corp plans to eliminate 1,200 jobs, or 10 percent of its work force (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: About.Com Replaces Top Executive
abstract: Primedia Inc names William Day chief executive of About, Internet media company (S)

headline: Laptops That Take A Licking
abstract: State of the Art column on ruggedized laptops, portable computers designed for rough treatment; testing standards include repeated drops onto hard surface, exposure to high heat and similated ride in military jeep; generally not available in standard computer stores, they can be found at trade shows that cater to military, police and other non-sedentary occupations; Panasonic's Toughbook and RuggedNotebooks.com offer full and semi-ruggeds; drawing (M)

headline: When Free Markets Leave Workers in the Dust
abstract: Dan Lyons letter replies to Tom Redburn's June 17 column defending Pres Bush for protecting jobs of US steelworkers from imports while allowing California energy crisis to run its course

headline: Technology Briefing | Economy: Cell Phone Shipments Slow
abstract: IDC says growth in cell phone shipments will slow to 3 percent this year from 43 percent last year, as makers like Motorola, Ericsson, and Nokia ship fewer phones (S)

headline: After Stocks Slump, Fund Fees Cause More Pain
abstract: Mutual fund fees that investors may have ignored when stocks were soaring are getting their attention as markets slump; bite is even more painful when returns turn negative; about half of all funds charge shareholders at least 1.4 percent of their assets each year, increase of almost 10 percent since 1995, and many charge well more than than; high-cost fund executive contend that total return, not costs, is real issue and that hiring best fund managers is expensive but worth it; photo; graphs (M)

headline: De Beers Wins and Loses Before Regulators in Europe
abstract: European Commission approves plan by De Beers Group of South Africa to establish diamond retailing venture with LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton of France; European regulators say they are opening antitrust case against De Beers plan to rearrange relationships with its trading partners in raw-diamond market (M)

headline: Weary of Gadgetmania? Just Dial M for Mockery
abstract: Jed Ela creates cell phone that resembles household steam iron; photos (M)

headline: Bank Loses Sway as Change Comes to Corporate Italy
abstract: Italy's Mediobanca is losing grip on byzantine brand of Italian capitalism it helped invent; Italian stock market regulators want bank to scrap characteristically indirect plan for retaining effective control of La Fondiaria, Italian insurer, and instead make full bid for company; squabble illustrates how Mediobanca's world is evolving and how it influence is eroding since death of chairman, Enrico Cuccia, in 2000; photo (M)

headline: Chrétien Under Pressure From Right and Left Over What to Give Washington
abstract: Canadian Prime Min Jean Chretien is under intense political pressure from right and left as he prepares to meet with Pres Bush in Washington to discuss terrorism and Canada's critical position with regard to US security; photos; conservativse want crackdown on loose immigration and asylum policies, while left resists following US into any kind of war (M)

headline: Survey Shows Approval Of Microsoft Ruling
abstract: Ipsos-Reid survey finds that by two-to-one margin, Americans endorse recent appeals court decision overturning lower federal court ruling that would have split Microsoft Corp into two companies (S)

headline: Merrill Regains Momentum in Underwriting
abstract: Merrill Lynch & Co regains momentum in underwriting American stocks and bonds less than three weeks afer attack on World Trade Center disrupted much of their business; Merrill, which as been leading underwriter, is competing for top spot with Salomon Smith Barney unit of Citigroup (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Microsoft Adds A Lawyer
abstract: Microsoft Corp hires Daniel K Webb, prominent trial lawyer, in preparation for new court battle with government antitrust enforcers over its Windows monopoly (S)

headline: Life Insurers Promise to Speed the Payment of Claims
abstract: MetLife and many others say they have decided to pay life insurance claims swiftly to families of victims of terrorist attacks on World Trade Center and Pentagon without insisting on usual documentation; though bodies of those first confirmed victims have not been recovered, they were listed on passenger manifests for hijacked jets; hard part for MetLife and other insurers is trying to identify and handle claims for about 5,000 people who are believed to have died as towers collapsed; life insurance claims are expected to run as high as $5 billion; photo (M)

headline: Doldrums For All Seasons On Wall St.
abstract: Excerpts from conversation with Anna M Dopkin, manager of T Rowe Price Financial Services fund, on securities industry's current slowdown and prospects for rebound; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: Wal-Mart Markets Camera Tied To Internet
abstract: Wal-Mart Stores has begun selling a disposable camera whose $6.84 price includes loading the developed photographs onto the Internet. When the single-use camera is returned to Wal-Mart for developing, the photographs are automatically loaded onto the Walmart.com Photo Center site, where the user can sign in and decide to order prints or share the pictures using e-mail.

headline: Agencies Are Acquiring Others Here and Abroad
abstract: Several agencies are making acquisitions.    The Cordiant Communications Group in London acquired Presentation Communications International in London, which designs and produces live events, exhibitions, videos and brand environments. Cordiant will acquire the agency for at least $19.6 million in stock, with an additional payment in stock based on the performance of the agency to December 2004.

headline: 2 Americans Allowed to See Their Jailed Daughters in Kabul
abstract: Two anguished American parents arrive, Kabul, Afghanistan, and meet with imprisoned daughters, who are among eight foreign aid workers charged with preaching Christianity; visit by John Mercer, father of Heather Mercer, and unidentified mother of Danya Curry lasts for almost two hours; both were joined by diplomats from others countries, US consular official and Taliban Foreign Ministry officials; detainees reported in good physical condition; photo (M)

headline: Minimum Wage Can Be Bumped Above Minimal
abstract: Nascent living-wage movement seeks to have municipalities and counties require their contractors to pay employees a wage that can actually pay for life's necessities, which might be over $10 an hour, compared with federally mandated minimum wage of $5.15 an hour; movement has its critics, who warn that it could lead to job losses for unskilled workers, saddle businesses with higher costs and worsen inflation; photo (M)

headline: New Security Webcam Has A Direct Line to the Net
abstract: Panasonic offers new security Web camera with built-in Web server, software and e-mail program; camera's video can be viewed from any remote computer and from any Web-enabled device if camera is wired to Internet; photo (S)

headline: Homebuilders' Index Is at a 9-Month High
abstract: National Association of Home Builders' housing market index increased to 62 in August, highest since November, from 56 in July; reading above 50 signals majority of builders are positive about market conditions (S)

headline: House Passes Broad Trade Pact With Vietnam
abstract: House votes to approve wide-ranging trade agreement with Vietnam that would end decades of economic sanctions imposed by United States against its former enemy; voice vote on agreement clears way for final approval in Senate, where trade pact has overwhelming support; agreement was reached during Clinton administration, and later endorsed by Pres Bush; efforts by handful of opponents to kill measure stalled final passage until now (M)

headline: MASSEY ENERGY OFFERS DETAILS ON LOWER PROFIT ESTIMATE
abstract: Massey Energy, coal producer, offers additional details on its earlier announcement that it will miss profit estimates in its fourth quarter (S)

headline: And Then There Were 9: A Shrinking Credit Club
abstract: Only nine US companies currently receive Moody's Investors Service's highest, triple-A credit ratings, down from 22 decade ago and 58 in late 1970's (M)

headline: Jupiter Media Hires Chief From Infosis
abstract: Jupiter Media Metrix names Robert Becker chief executive, succeeding Gene DeRose, who will remain as president (M)

headline: Israeli Missiles Miss Leader Of Uprising; Aide Injured
abstract: Israeli Army fires missiles at convoy carrying Marwan Barghouti, West Bank leader of Palestinian uprising, in what he calls attempt to assassinate him; Israelis later deny he was target, implying they were striking at his aide, Mohanad Abu Halawa, who was hurt in attack and is wanted for role in anti-Israel violence; Israelis fear new terrorist attacks in wake of recent arrests of two Palestinians carrying bombs (M)

headline: Rate Cuts Won't Spur an Economy Choked by Debt
abstract: Gretchen Morgenson column says rate cuts by Federal Reserve can have only minimal success boosting US economy or stocks because economy is already choked by corporate borrowing; notes that some technology companies have debt exceeding value of their enterprises; graph (M)

headline: Handheld2 + Calculator2 = A New Curve for Students
abstract: Texas Instruments offers new device that combines functions of graphing calculator and personal digital assistant; photo (S)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: AFRICA

headline: Private Sector; Comfortable With the Fast Track
abstract: Profile of Anne Stevens, vice president for North American vehicle operations at Ford Motor Co and easily most powerful woman in American automotive manufacturing; photo (M)

headline: The Power of Roundup; A Weed Killer Is a Block For Monsanto To Build On
abstract: Monsanto is propspering and will continue to prosper thanks to Roundup, herbicide that is best-selling agricultural chemical product ever; Roundup accounts for about half company's revenue; few competitors are willing to produce generic version of Roundup because Monsanto has protected its market dominance by cutting price while finding new uses; Monsanto markets genetically modified crops that are 'Roundup Ready,' which are immune to Roundup and allow farmers to spray herbicide on the fields, killing weeds but not the crops; photo; graph (M)

headline: Will U.S. Resume Aid? That Depends on Jakarta
abstract: In the months leading up to President Abdurrahman Wahid's removal as president yesterday, American State Department officials and the National Security Council developed a contingency plan that calls for the quick resumption of economic aid to Jakarta if his successor, Megawati Sukarnoputri, begins to carry out economic reforms.    ''Things have been essentially frozen because of the incompetence of the Wahid government,'' one senior American official said. ''Now the question is whether Megawati can execute promises that Wahid could not.''

headline: World Briefing | Asia: China: Powell Videotape
abstract: Chinese government denies that Chinese television violated promise to visiting Secretary of State Colin L Powell when it edited out sections of taped interview before it was broadcast by China Central Television; Powell's statements about human rights and Taiwan were omitted; photo (S)

headline: Defending a Merger
abstract: Executives from Hewlett-Packard, company synonymous with printers, and Compaq Computer, known for personal computers, defend their plans to merge into world's largest computer maker on ground that they would like to be known not for selling hardware, but for selling advice and service; many industry experts and competitors say new company would not easily make inroads into services market, cut costs or shift emphasis away from suddenly ailing personal and business computer businesses that forms its foundation; charts; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Cambodia: One Way To Get Out The Vote
abstract: Cambodian government gives 200,000 factory workers two days off to return to their homes to register to vote in local elections set for Feb (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Trade Talks Agenda
abstract: Prime Min Atal Behari Vajpayee says India opposes proposals that new round of global trade talks be started at next meeting of World Trade Organization; says disputed issues from previous round of trade talks should be resolved before moving onto nontrade issues like environment or labor standards (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   6.75   6.75   9.50       Discount rate   3.25   3.25   6.00       Federal funds   3.75   3.69   6.46       3-month T-bills   3.43   3.55   6.09       6-month T-bills   3.35   3.42   6.06       10-yr. T-infl.   3.36   3.36   3.97       10-yr. T-note   5.16   5.16   5.95       30-yr. T-bond   5.60   5.58   5.75       Telephone bd.   7.74   7.75   8.06       Municipal bds.   5.27   5.26   5.76          (Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Telerate; The Bond Buyer)

headline: CBS Reruns Dropped As Advertiser Balks
abstract: CBS has decided not to broadcast a handful of rerun episodes of ''Family Law'' after a big advertiser, Procter & Gamble, said it would withdraw its commercials because it deemed the content too controversial.    While advertisers often choose not to sponsor certain programs, industry executives said it was unusual for a network to shelve several episodes of a prime-time series in deference to a single advertiser. They also said CBS's action was a potentially worrisome example of the tastes of a large advertiser influencing a network's programming decisions.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Infineon Raises Cash
abstract: Infineon Technologies raises $1.1 billion in share sale to finance production and pay debt; graph (S)

headline: The Prints and the Pager: Software for the Blackberry
abstract: Research In Motion and Hewlett-Packard develop system that will allow Blackberry e-mail pagers to print out attached spreadsheets, letters and other documents; photo (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: Police And Protestants Clash
abstract: Police in Northern Ireland clash with more than 200 Protestant rioters at flash point in north Belfast; photo (S)

headline: More Changes Made At Interpublic Group
abstract: Interpublic Group of Companies continues to make changes, just days after announcing reorganization into four principal divisions; forms Magna Global Inc, separate entity to negotiate with media for its media planning and buying operations on behalf of their advertisers; combined worldwide billings estimated at $40 billion; Bill Cella will become chairman of new entity; Mick Perry becomes chairman of Magna Global UK (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Cable TV Acquisition
abstract: Deutsche Telekom AG has sold its remaining broadband cable holdings to Liberty Media Corp for about $5 million (S)

headline: Executive Changes at Media Firms
abstract: MaryAnn Capritti was named to the new post of executive vice president and managing partner at Adient, Wayne, N.J., part of the CommonHealth unit of the WPP Group. She had been freelancing for the pharmaceutical marketing industry.

headline: Hewlett-Packard in Deal to Buy Compaq for $25 Billion in Stock
abstract: Hewlett-Packard will acquire Compaq Computer for $25 billion in stock in bold move to grow as computer industry struggles with shrinking sales; merger would produce company with total revenues only slightly less than that of IBM; would create stronger competitor for Sun Microsystems and IBM in server computer market, while putting pressure on IBM, Dell and Gateway in personal computer business; Hewlett-Packard and Compaq officials say merged company would be in position to compete with IBM across virtually its entire product line; under deal, one Compaq share would be exchanged for 0.6325 Hewlett-Packard share, providing premium of about 18 percent; photos (M)

headline: Estrada Is Arraigned in Plunder Case
abstract: MANILA—  Defiant and angry, Joseph Estrada refused to enter a plea Tuesday on charges that he plundered tens of millions of dollars of government money during his two and a half years as president.

headline: U.S. Set to Oppose International Plan For Cleaner Energy
abstract: Bush administration officials say US will oppose international drive to phase out fossil fuel subsidies and increase financing for nonpolluting energy sources worldwide; proposals, contained in report commissioned by Group of 8 industrial nations, would commit rich nations to help one billion people around the world get their power from renewable energy sources, like wind, water and sun; White House says it wants to let marketplace, rather than government, decide how quickly renewable energy sources are adopted worldwide; critics say it is yet another instances of Bush administrattion's placing interest of oil and gas companies ahead of drive to reduce global warming (M)

headline: Early Winner in Online Food; Local and Simple Ways Work for British Grocer
abstract: Tesco, Britain's largest supermarket chain, takes go-slow approach to online grocery shopping, using its hundreds of supermarkets as bases for its Internet deliveries, rather than centralized warehouses; now that Webvan, most prominent of various stand-alone Internet food shopping companies has failed after investing $1.2 billion into venture, Tesco's approach to business is clearly more likely to succeed; graphs; charts; photos (M)

headline: Q&A / Jacques Rogge : Olympics Chief Aims to Cure Sport's 'Diseases'
abstract: EDMONTON, Alberta—  As Jacques Rogge talks, he draws on a small piece of paper: tiny geometrical designs, one by one, for this aficionado of cubist painting and geometrical art. A narrow rectangle here; a chunky triangle there, with occasional pauses when the conversation flows to an Olympic issue that is more complex than most.

headline: Australia Lowers an Overnight Interest Rate
abstract: Reserve Bank of Australia lowers its benchmark cash-rate target to 4.75 percent from 5 percent (S)

headline: Continental: Risky Deals and Insider Sales Precede Crisis
abstract: Floyd Norris column on risky deals and insider sales that help explain why Continental Airlines failed to make debt payments soon after terrorist attacks lies; suggests David Bonderman, controlling shareholder until 1998 and still director, made a fortune from Continental and should join government in bailing (M)

headline: Japan's Prime Minister Pledges Support for American Retaliation
abstract: In departure from Japan's generally pacifist position, Prime Min Junichiro Koizumi announces that armed forces will actively support American reprisals for attacks on World Trade Center and Pentagon; says legislation to assist in intelligence-gathering and delivery of supplies and medical services will be introduced when Parliament reconvenes (M)

headline: Negotiators Near Accord On Details of Climate Pact
abstract: Negotiators from 178 countries, meeting in Bonn, move step closer to agreement on final details of Kyoto Protocol, climate treaty rejected by Pres Bush; many longtime participants in effort to create binding limits on warming gases say momentum appears right for resolution; European Union and many developing countries say they will pursue ratification of treaty even without involvement of US, largest emitter of heat-trapping gases (M)

headline: Agencies Close Unit And Make Layoffs
abstract: Arnold Worldwide is closing its design unit, Cipriani Kremer Design; Arnold will try to find jobs at agency for as many of 18 full-time employees at Cipriani; chairman, Bob Cipriani, and president, Vic Cevoli, will leave to pursue other interests after unit closes on Dec 31; American office of Lowe Lintas & Partners Worldwide is dismissing about 45 employees, or 6 percent of its staff (S)

headline: Trade Panel Wants Global Economy's Riches Available to Poor Nations Too
abstract: UNITED NATIONS, June 29 — A panel of financial and development experts has called for a new round of international trade talks devoted primarily to helping countries too weak to reap any benefits from the growing global economy.

headline: Dutch Company Selects Shop for United States
abstract: ING Group names DDB Worldwide as its advertising agency of record to handle marketing and branding assignments in US; billings estimated at more than $20 million (S)

headline: CASCADES AGREES TO BUY 2 TISSUE MILLS FROM PLAINWELL
abstract: Cascades Inc acquires two tissue mills from Plainwell Inc for $62.4 million (S)

headline: The new president of BBDO North America reflects on life and business in the colonies.
abstract: WILL the executive recently named to head North American operations for BBDO Worldwide one day have colleagues and clients singing, ''And here's to you, Mr. Robertson''?    That's one question being asked as Andrew Robertson settles in as president and chief executive at BBDO North America in New York, a post he assumed in April after serving as chief executive at a sibling agency, Abbott Mead Vickers BBDO in London, the largest British agency.

headline: From a Bull and a Bear, Conflicting Forecasts
abstract: Conflicting investment advice is offered by the economists Robert J Shiller and Jeremy J Siegel (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Cambodia: Women's Aid Leader Honored
abstract: Chanthol Oung, 34, who leads women's aid group called Cambodian Women's Crisis Center, becomes first recipient of new annual Ramon Maysaysay Award for emergent leadership (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Goto.com Forecast Lifts Shares
abstract: Defying the slump in the Internet advertising market, GoTo.com, a pay-for-placement Internet search service, reported a narrower-than-expected loss and said it now expected to be profitable ahead of schedule. GoTo, based in Pasadena, Calif., reported a net loss of $2.9 million, or 6 cents a share, down sharply from the loss of $20.3 million, or 42 cents, a year earlier. Second-quarter revenue nearly tripled to $62.5 million from $21 million. Ted Meisel, chief executive of GoTo, said that in contrast to other advertising-supporting companies, GoTo has had an increase in spending by its advertisers over the last nine months. GoTo shares rose $3.40, to $24.55.     Andrew Zipern (NYT)

headline: G.M.-Daewoo Talks Said to Be Stalled
abstract: Negotiations between General Motors and bankrupt Daewoo Motor of South Korea are in danger of failure (M)

headline: Inventories Fell in July; Sales Gained
abstract: Inventories of unsold goods at US companies fell in July to 0.4 percent from revised 0.6 percent in June; graph (M)

headline: MediaTalk; Error in Quote Stirs Arguments Over Adams Legacy
abstract: Signature quotation from Thomas Jefferson in David McCullough's best-selling biography of John Adams was never said by Jefferson; McCullough says his mistake will be corrected in next edition of book; photo (M)

headline: South Korea Asks U.S. for Help in Peace Talks With the North
abstract: South Korea's president, Kim Dae Jung, says North-South Korean peace process is 'stalemated' and he calls on United States to help to resume talks; notes that South-North talks are inextricably related to North Korea-United States relations; differences center on North Korean demand for Korean 'confederation' that Seoul opposes as attempt to strip South Korean government of its authority to govern South (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Telephone Privatization
abstract: South Africa says long-planned public offering for Telkom South Africa will be in November; Telkom Malaysia and SBC Communications, which together own 30 percent of Telkom South Africa, are in talks with government, which owns remaining 70 percent, over which will sell shares and how much of company will go public (S)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: EUROPE

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Havas Quits Bid
abstract: Havas Advertising says it will not pursue $620 million offer for Tempus Group; move leaves WPP Group sole bidder (S)

headline: MediaTalk; Our Cover Article, Brought to You by . . .
abstract: Over the years, the line has blurred between news and advertising. Even so, a magazine in Nevada may have broken new ground: sponsorships of cover articles.    On the cover of the June 2001 issue of Nevada Woman was the article ''Women of Wells Fargo,'' a profile of three top executives at Wells Fargo Nevada bank. The subject matter might seem innocent enough. But the article was put on the cover because Wells Fargo paid for it. Nowhere does the magazine note that Wells Fargo paid for the coverage.   News of The Nevada Woman-Wells Fargo deal was published in lvcity life.com, a Web site about Las Vegas.

headline: Allies Bomb Iraqi Air Defenses In Biggest Attack in 6 Months
abstract: American and British planes bomb three air defense sites in southern Iraq; Pentagon cites Iraq's increasingly aggressive actions against allied pilots; raid comes as Bush administration begins formulating longer-term strategy against Saddam Hussein that is likely to include stronger air strikes and reinforced support for Iraqi opposition groups that favor dislodging him from power; map (M)

headline: Companies Change Shops for Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (M)

headline: LTV SAYS IT HAS REACHED AGREEMENT WITH STEELWORKERS
abstract: LTV reaches labor agreement with United Steelworkers of America that will help company avoid liquidation; under tentative agreement, which is to expire in 2006, LTV will lay off 1,300 workers, halt some raises, reduce costs for pension and health benefits and make employees part owners of company (S)

headline: MediaTalk; News Channel's New Look Works, in a Way
abstract: Audience for CNN Headline News does not increase much in its first week with supposedly hipper look and younger editorial emphasis, but ratings do show some modest improvement; critics complain of information-filled screen, moving graphics and pop-infused back ground music; photo (S)

headline: Israel Defends Missile Attack That Killed 8
abstract: Israel firmly defends its missile strike that killed eight West Bank Palestinians; says it would carry out more such assaults if it feels Israeli lives are at risk; rejects protests from United States and other countries that it has gone too far; in Nablus, tens of thousands of Palestinians demonstrate during funeral processions for eight victims of missile strike on office of Hamas; photo (M)

headline: Heinz is putting its money where the young mouths are to promote a line of frozen snacks.
abstract: H J Heinz's advertising campaign for its frozen foods division is aimed at children ages 9 to 14; was developed by DDB Worldwide; photo (M)

headline: The Twisting Path To a New Front Door
abstract: John Schwartz Online Shopper column on shopping for new front door on Internet; photo (M)

headline: Getting the Corporate Point Across to Employees
abstract: Major corporations, including General Motors Corp, Delta Air Lines, Nextel Communications and Sears, Roebuck, are hiring outside consultants from public relations firms to convey new management strategies to employees; photos (M)

headline: ROYAL BANK OF CANADA IS BUYING TUCKER ANTHONY SUTRO
abstract: Royal Bank of Canada agrees to buy Tucker Anthony Sutro Corp for $625 million in cash, its second purchase this year of US brokerage firm (S)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Whites' Land Offer Accepted
abstract: Zimbabwe government accepts offer from largely white Commercial Farmers' Union to sell more than two million acres to state for resettlement of landless blacks (S)

headline: How Rush to Manhood Scars Young Africans
abstract: Many young South African boys are dying, victims of traditional circumcisions gone awry as part of initiation into manhood; ritual in earlier generations was performed in early 20's, and called for boy to spend weeks away from home in tutelage of tribal elders after which circumcision was performed by traditional surgeon; in contemporary life age has come closer to 18, and sometimes much younger; where younger boys might once have been turned away by traditional surgeons, they now fall frequently into clutches of quack profiteers with few skills or scruples, or at mercy of well-meaning old hands, whose skills have faded; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Barclays Profit Slips
abstract: Barclays PLC, third-largest British bank, reports one percent drop in first-half profit, to $1.88 billion (S)

headline: An Uncommonly Spirited Campaign Roils British Tories
abstract: Iain Duncan Smith and Kenneth Clarke, vying to become leader of Conservative Party, are on opposite poles of argument over whether Britain should adopt euro currency, dispute that has left party deeply divided, dispirited and, for first time in its history, defeated twice in row by Labor; Clarke is most committed and vocal pro-euro person in the party; Smith is staunch opponent, and has sided in past with right-wing fringe that wants to go further and withdraw Britain from European Union altogether; photos (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: While Copies May Be Legal, Making Them Violates Law  The case of Dmitri Sklyarov, a Russian computer programmer arrested last month in Las Vegas, is drawing attention to a double bind in the Digital Millennium Copyright Act.     The law makes it illegal to make, distribute or use a device designed to bypass technology that protects copyright material -- even to make a backup copy of a book, movie or song, which is traditionally allowed under copyright law. That is where the double bind comes in. Making such copies for personal use is not illegal. But it is against the law to break through the copy-protection safeguards to make the legal copies. New Economy. [Page C4.]

headline: Compressed Data; Dueling Essay Contests in Fray Involving Intellectual Property
abstract: Wipout, newly formed group of academics, artists and advocates, sponsors essay contest to counter essay contest sponsored by World Intellectual Property Organization, which promotes worldwide respect for patents, copyrights and trademarks of its 177 member nations; group's founders argue that excessive intellectual property protection hurts public; drawing (M)

headline: AMERICAN ELECTRIC POWER BUYING 1,200 BARGES
abstract: The American Electric Power Company said yesterday that it had agreed to buy 1,200 barges and 30 towboats from Progress Energy Inc. for $270 million, tripling the size of its inland shipping fleet and enlarging its territory. The barges can handle coal, ore, grain or other dry-bulk commodities, said Pat Hemlepp, an American Electric spokesman. The transaction is expected to close in 60 days, immediately adding to earnings, he said. American Electric is buying Memco Barge Line, a St. Louis-based unit of Progress, which is based in Raleigh, N.C. Memco operates on the Mississippi River and its tributaries in Tennessee and Alabama, and along the Gulf of Mexico, Mr. Hemlepp said. Before the acquisition, American Electric owned 605 barges and 15 towboats on the Ohio River.

headline: Tracking Your Fitness, Every Step of the Way
abstract: Ian Austen assesses electronic pedometers, wildly popular in Japan as fitness monitor, whose sales are booming in United States; photos (M)

headline: G.M. Agrees to Buy Part of Daewoo Motor
abstract: General Motors Corp agrees to buy two-thirds of Daewoo Motor Co from Daewoo's creditors for about $1 billion, but leaves most troublesome parts on creditors' hands (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: 7 Held In School Protests
abstract: Seven Protestant men are charged in Belfast with starting fights during demonstrations near Roman Catholic girls' school (S)

headline: Donald Woods, 67, Editor and Apartheid Foe
abstract: Donald Woods, crusading white newspaper editor who championed black anti-apartheid activist Steve Biko, dies at age 67; photo (M)

headline: Europe Ends Bid by G.E. For Honeywell
abstract: European Commi

headline: Feeling the American Aftershock
abstract: Terrorist attacks on US threatens to send South America's two largest economies, Argentina and Brazil, into steep downward spiral; analysts say heavy reliance on foreign cash makes both nations especially vulnerable to economic aftershocks of attacks; both Argentine and Brazilian stock markets rebound; analysts say one reason markets rose is that months of economic crisis already dried up most of liquidity in markets, especially in Argentina; few people want to sell or buy; photo (M)

headline: Brazil Weighs Replacing Police Strikers With Troops
abstract: Facing a growing movement of strikes and other protests by police forces across the country, the Brazilian government is threatening to send in the army to replace the police

headline: AMERICAN STANDARD CUTS 1,000 JOBS AND TRIMS FORECAST
abstract: American Standard Companies, maker of Trane air-conditioning systems, says falling sales of some cooling systems are dragging profit below forecasts and have resulted in 1,000 job cuts at unit (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Recent account changes noted (S)

headline: E-Commerce Report; Online travel agencies brace to weather the air travel slump.
abstract: Sharp decline in air travel following terrorist attacks threatens future of online travel agencies; analysts say bigget online agents will probably sustain their businesses through next year; agencies had already begun diversifying their businesses to reduce reliance on airline ticket commissions before attacks; photo (M)

headline: F.B.I.'s Inquiry In Cole Attack Is Nearing Halt
abstract: FBI investigation of bombing of US destroyer Cole in port of Aden, Yemen, in October 2001 that killed 17 American sailors virtually grinds to halt; agency cites refusal by Yemen to heed US requests to broaden inquiry to include Islamic militant groups; says government's decision has frustrated efforts to link bombing conclusively to Osama bin Laden, fugitive Saudi, who has declared worldwide holy war against US; says Yemen has denied it access to prominent Yemenis it wishes to interview in bid to link attack to elements of bin Laden's network in Yemen, which became key base for him in early 1990's; photo (M)

headline: Landslide in Japan For Governing Party
abstract: Japan's governing Liberal Democratic Party roared to victory in a critical vote for the upper house of Parliament, clinging firmly to the coattails of Junichiro Koizumi, the most popular prime minister in postwar history. The party won more than half of the 121 contested seats in the 247-seat upper house.     Article, Page A6.

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Gasoline for September delivery rises nearly 6 percent, to 83.57 cents a gallon; graph (S)

headline: Management: Vigilance In the Face Of Layoff Rage; Employer Miscues Can Breed Retaliation
abstract: Workplace experts urge increased employer vigilance against 'layoff rage,' growing phenomenon of employee retaliation after being laid off; destruction of company property, including computer hardware and data stored on it, has become commonplace; security guard escorts for dismissed employees increases their resentment and likelihood of retribution; photos (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Sweden: Volvo Profit Falls
abstract: Volvo's second-quarter profit fell 28 percent, to 1.36 billion kronor ($127 million) (S)

headline: Southwest Manages to Keep Its Balance
abstract: Southwest Airlines is only airline with chance to post profit this year after terrorist attacks; carrier is reaping benefits of strategy that favors use of smaller airports; it has not announced layoffs or schedule cutbacks, though flights will be eliminated if business does not pick up; in effort to get travelers back, Southwest could begin national broadcasting ad campaign that will include new fare sales on some flights; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Dell Sets Sights On Server Market
abstract: Dell Corp will begin marketing switching equipment this fall for kinds of computer networks used by small and medium-sized businesses; estimates such switches account for about $5.3 billion of $19.5 billion market for all network switches (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Industrial Slowdown
abstract: South Korea's industrial output declined in July for second consecutive month, declining 5.9 percent from July 2000 and 1.4 percent from June; Korea Stock Exchange falls 3.1 percent, closing month at 546.95, lowest point since last day of July (S)

headline: From Beachside Mansions to Cold Jail
abstract: Vladimiro L Montesinos, Peru's former spy chief, has been confined to small, spare, dim jail cell since his arrest in Venezuela; faces 160 investigations into allegations that he smuggled drugs, trafficked arms to largest guerrilla group in Colombia, laundered money and traded favors and bribes with Peru's most powerful politicians, executives and military leadership; investigators also probe exact nature of his relationship with former Pres Alberto K Fujimori and whether he has more money stashed abroad beyond $264 million in bank accounts that they have found; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; More Setbacks For Investors Of AremisSoft
abstract: Market Place column examines financial irregularities at AremisSoft Corp, whose shares have been barred from trading on Nasdaq since disclosure that important financial documents related to its emerging-market business could be missing; documents appear to involve contract to sell computer software to Bulgarian government; company reported on July 31 that it was unable to obtain documents to support $5.4 billion in revenues reported on contract in 2000 (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: War's Toll On Children
abstract: In a grim accounting of the death toll for schoolchildren in war-torn Chechnya, a Russian official said today that 329 students were killed during the military campaign that began in September 1999, while 617 were disabled and more than 2,000 orphaned. Vasily Mizherikov, described by the Interfax news agency as in charge of the restoration of the republic's educational system, said that about 80 schools and 26 preschool facilities had been destroyed and that, despite the formal end of hostilities, there were no provisions for the ''upbringing or education'' of thousands of handicapped and orphaned children.   Patrick E. Tyler (NYT)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Airport Results
abstract: BAA, airport operator, reports first-quarter net income rose 1.9 percent, to 103 million pounds ($147 million) (S)

headline: Equity Offerings Planned This Week
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:      Activision, Santa Monica, Calif., six million shares. Merrill Lynch.

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Nigeria: Fighting Uproots 72,000
abstract: More than 72,000 people have been displaced by outbreak of two separate ethnic clashes in Nigeria in last month (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Nepal: Truce With Maoist Rebels
