abstract: The government and Maoist rebels said they would halt all offensive actions to pave the way for peace talks. The new prime minister, Sher Bahadur Deuba, took office on Sunday and appealed to the rebels to stop their violent uprising. He was chosen by the Nepalese Congress to replace Girija Prasad Koirala, who resigned last week under pressure from the opposition and his own party. The Maoists killed at least 17 policemen in a Sunday attack in Pandusen village in the western reaches of the country.      Barry Bearak (NYT)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Domain Rollout Is Delayed
abstract: Afilias, company that manages .info database, says Web addresses with new extension will become functional on Sept 22, three days later than planned (S)

headline: The Right Connections; The Simple BlackBerry Allowed Contact When Phones Failed
abstract: Survivors of terrorist attacks on World Trade Center were able to use BlackBerry pagers to send and get short e-mail messages at time when phones and cellphones worked only sporadically; BlackBerry, made by Research in Motion, functions on data system that held up remarkably well when phone networks were either damaged or innundated with traffic (M)

headline: World Briefing | The Americas: Argentina: British Leader Visits
abstract: Prime Min Tony Blair of Britain meets with Argentina's president, Fernando de la Rua, near Iguazu Falls; is first British leader to visit Argentina since Falkland War between two countries in 1982 (S)

headline: Article 2001070694145717632 -- No Title
abstract: Education: From Working in Mines, to Learning Online

headline: No Bailout Is Planned For Argentina
abstract: Bush administration and International Monetary Fund say no special assistance is being planned for Agrentina's beleaguered economy, despite threat of default on mostly foreign debt; IMF spokesman says agency will not speed up release of future aid or consider additional aid, and US national security adviser Condoleezza Rice says country is taking steps to deal with situation, which is best course of action; announcements put damper on early stock and bond rally in Argentina and other emerging markets (M)

headline: Technology Briefing
abstract: SOFTWARE

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: A New VW Chairman
abstract: Bernd Pischetsrieder will succeed Ferdinand Piech as Volkswagen's management board chairman; photo (S)

headline: Race Under Way to Winnow Down Genetic Data
abstract: Celera Genomics raced to determine the entire human genetic code. Now it is racing to winnow the information down.     Celera will announce today the next phase of its genomics strategy, an effort to sequence selected parts of the genomes of 40 to 50 individuals. The goal is to develop a map of just the important genetic differences between people, which could be used to speed the search for genes that contribute to disease.

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Sun Offers Details On ID System
abstract: Sun Microsystems and 33 other companies and organizations announce online identification initiative, Liberty Alliance; they say project is effort to make sure that technology for identifying customers for coming generation of Internet services is open and based on industry-standard technology; Liberty partners say their software technology will be jointly developed and freely distributed, providing standard they say will be crucial for growth of electronic commerce (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: Netpliance Fined By F.T.C.
abstract: Netpliance, which sells a small computer called the i-opener as a less expensive alternative to the personal computer for Internet access and e-mail, has settled with the Federal Trade Commission on charges that its advertising, sales and billing practices violated federal laws, agency officials said. The agreement with the commission requires Netpliance, of Austin, Tex., to reimburse an unspecified amount to consumers who were improperly billed and to pay the government a $100,000 civil penalty. Netpliance contended that the i-opener would allow very easy access to the Web, without special software or boot-up delays, for about $199. But the F.T.C. said the company failed to disclose extra costs and restrictions, including monthly Internet service fees and long-distance telephone charges. In addition, the commission said, the company, which still sells i-openers at Circuit City and CompUSA stores, billed some customers' credit cards without their consent.

headline: Investing; Stock Baskets Aim for the Mainstream
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission's ruling that investment vehicles called folios or baskets are different enough from mutual funds not to warrant regulation opens way for big financial services companies to enter personalized stock fund arena in earnest; Quick & Reilly, brokerage arm of FleetBoston Financial, plans to join forces with Foliofn, company that first introduced online trading of baskets of stocks last year; Fidelity Investments began offering its own version of folios through its online brokerage operation this summer; photo (M)

headline: Arnold Office Resigns From PNC Account
abstract: The McLean, Va., office of Arnold Worldwide, part of the Arnold Worldwide Partners unit of Havas Advertising, has ended its two-year relationship with PNC Bank, after taking on assignments from another banking client, the Citizens Financial Group. Billings for the PNC Bank account were estimated at $30 million.    Rebecca Sullivan, a spokeswoman for Arnold, said the agency was resigning from the PNC Bank account because of a conflict with the new Citizens assignments, which are in similar locations in the mid-Atlantic region.

headline: Sales of Condos and Co-ops Drop 2.7%
abstract: National Association of Realtors reports sales of existing condominiums and of apartments in cooperatives fell 2.7 percent in second quarter, sign that demand for less expensive homes may be softening; sales fell to seasonally adjusted annual pace of 722,000 from record 742,000-unit pace in first quarter; median price for condos and co-ops rose 4.1 percent to $122,200 from $117,300 in first quarter (S)

abstract: Hearst Magazines is closing Classic American Home mangazine because of weak advertising sales (S)

headline: Protestants In Ulster Kill Youth, A Protestant
abstract: Protestant paramilitary groups kill 18-year-old Protestant youth Gavin Brett and wound Catholic friend in drive-by shooting in North Belfast, Northern Ireland; Red Hand Defenders, banned guerrilla group, takes responsibility for killing (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: East Timor: Toward Reconciliation

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: EURO FALLS. The euro fell after stronger-than-expected growth in the money supply dampened speculation about a cut in interest rates. In New York, the euro settled at 87.78 cents, down from 88.10 cents on Wednesday.

headline: Indonesia Radicals Issue Threats of Holy War
abstract: indonesia radicals issue threats of holy war**Radical Islamic fringe groups among 210 million people of largely Muslim Indonesia have been threatening holy war against United States and against Americans who live in Indonesia; their appeals to Muslim solidarity fire hundreds of young men with a passion to fight to defend Afghanistan, many of them unemployed and aimless in broken economy; photos (M)

headline: A Hole Full of Promise and Now Pain
abstract: Alexandra Lebenthal, who heads Lebenthal & Co, writes The Boss column on terrorist attack on World Trade Center; she can see devastation from her office at 120 Broadway; photo (M)

headline: Al Qaeda: Sprawling, Hard-to-Spot Web of Terrorists-in-Waiting
abstract: Article describes emerging picture of Al Qaeda, terrorist network spawned by Osama bin Laden; young men get training in weapons, explosives and religious studies and are then sent where they are needed to await further instructions; Jamal Ahmed al-Fadl, early recruit of Osama bin Laden's, has been cooperating with United States authorities and describes inner workings of Al Qaeda's corporate type of structure as well as his training; background of Mohammed Saddiq Odeh, Mohamed Rashed Daoud al-'Owhali and Khalfan Khamis Mohamed, convicted in East Africa embassy bombings, discussed; photo (L)

headline: Gadgets to Pack for the Beach, for Work or Play; Audio and Video
abstract: Article suggests audio and video devices to take on beach outings; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Web Site Selling Id's Settles
abstract: Info World, Web site that offered software to produce false driver's licenses, fake birth certificates and other counterfeit identity documents, settles FTC charges that it violated law; Jeremy Martinez, who operated Web site, must relinquish $20,000 of illegal gains (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Portugal: Joint Auto Venture
abstract: Portugal's biggest oil and gas company, Galpenergia SGPS, and Midas Inc discuss joint venture to open as many as 60 car parts and service stores (S)

headline: Dollar Rallies; Interest Rates Rise Sharply
abstract: Interest rates rise sharply while dollar rallies against euro and yen; Treasury's 10-year note rises to 4.96 percent and price drops 1 1/32, to 100 10/32; dollar rises 3.3 percent as euro is quoted at 88.62 cents; US dollar is up 0.6 percent against Japanese yen at 119.52 from 118.80 yen; graphs on US Treasury securities; chart on US key interest rates (M)

headline: Facing Huge Loss, Toshiba Cuts 19,000 Jobs
abstract: The Toshiba Corporation said today that it would eliminate some 19,000 jobs, or 10 percent of its work force, and that it expected to lose almost $1 billion in the current fiscal year

headline: Dealt a Heavy Blow, A Commodities Dealer Struggles to Carry On
abstract: Carr Futures Inc has lost 69 of 143 people in its New York staff, who were at work on 92d floor of 1 World Trade Center when airliner smashed into building; chief executive, Didier Varlet, is planning memorial services, meeting with families of missing employees at grief center at Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, overseeing temporary trading operations in rented space in Long Island City and coordinating flow of employees from Carr's other offices to New York, primarily from its Chicago headquarters; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: ASI

headline: Familiar Voice Lifts the Market Before the Bell
abstract: Rose-Ann Sgrignoli, major in Marine Corp, sings God Bless America before New York Stock Exchange trading room before exchange re-opens for first time after terrorist attack on World Trade Center and Pentagon (M)

headline: Way Cleared for PepsiCo to Acquire Quaker
abstract: Federal Trade Commission votes to drop its investigation into PepsiCo's proposed acquisition of Quaker Oats, clearing way for $13.4 billion deal to go forward despite recommendations by agency's staff to oppose it; at issue is Quaker's Gatorade drink and beverage antitrust concerns (M)

headline: Income Rises 65% at Krispy Kreme; Its Shares Fall
abstract: Krispy Kreme Doughnuts Inc fiscal second-quarter profit rises nearly 65 percent, to $5.9 million; its shares fall 9.8 percent, to $32.11 (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: JDA Buys Rival Software Maker
abstract: JDA Software Group, which makes Internet-based software that helps retailers keep track of sales, inventory and distribution, will acquire E3 Corp for about $58.6 million; graph (S)

headline: Turning to the Internet To Give to Charities
abstract: Internet plays big role in collecting donations that pour into charities and relief funds for victims of Sept 11 terrorist attacks (S)

headline: I.M.F. Ready for Brazil and Argentina Rescues
abstract: International Monetary Fund says it is prepared to lend $15 billion to Brazil and speed financial aid for Argentina as concerns rise that two nations' financial problems have worsened and begun to spread through Latin America; long-term aid packages have blessing of Bush administration, which earlier criticized such international bailouts; Argentina, which receives pledge from fund to accelerate $1.2 billion in aid, is pushing fund to provide additional $6 billion in loans (M)

headline: United Resurrects Bid
abstract: At the insistence of US Airways and under an implied threat of litigation, United Airlines has reluctantly agreed to continue its proposed $4.3 billion bid to buy US Airways. The decision forces the hand of the Bush administration's Justice Department, which must take formal action if it wants to block the deal.      Business Day, Page C1.

headline: Business; A Company Faces a Calamity's Personal Side
abstract: Edmund English, president of TJX Companies, which owns TJ Maxx and Marshall's retail chains, tries to help company through loss of seven top executives and buyers who were aboard plane that slammed into World Trade Center; those lost were all women, including four mothers, and were crucial to company's business; company has hired counselors to help coach employees about dealing with newfound fear of flying; photos (M)

headline: The Persistence of Junk Mail
abstract: We now have protection against junk phone calls and junk faxes; what’s the holdup in putting an end to the most annoying scheme of all?

headline: Editors Rush to Revise Long-Made Plans
abstract: Magazine editors scramble to make next issues relevant in wake of terrorist attacks; task is hardest for monthlies, which usually send magazines to printers weeks before they hit newsstands; photo (M)

headline: No Big Rush To Buy or Sell By Wall Street Professionals
abstract: Intrepid bargain hunters begin to selectively buy stocks, but money managers say they will approach market more cautiously since fall following attacks on America; comments from portfolio managers (M)

headline: Pfizer's Profit in Second Quarter Rose 31%
abstract: Pfizer Inc's second-quarter profit rose 31 percent, to $1.89 billion; revenue rose 10 percent, to $7.69 billion (M)

headline: A Symbol Was Destroyed, Not America's Financial System
abstract: Floyd Norris column holds destroying World Trade Center, symbolically heart of world financial system, will not destroy America's financial system; says resumption of trading will show there are things terrorists cannot destroy; photo (M)

headline: Nasdaq Selects Marketing Agency
abstract: Nasdaq Selects Marketing Agenc

headline: Colombian Anticipating New Talks With Rebels
abstract: Pres Andres Pastrana of Colombia says he believes peace negotiations with leftist rebels could proceed in last year of his presidency, despite lack of tangible results so far; two years of talks and growing conflict have left many Colombians pessimistic; Secretary of State Colin Powell will visit Colombia on Sept 11 to meet with Pastrana, whose administration received $1.1 billion from Washington last year in mostly military aid for antidrug efforts (M)

headline: China Sends Labor Advocate Back to Jail
abstract: Li Wangyang, Chinese labor rights advocate who recently finished nearly 11 years in prison for 'counterrevolutionary crimes,' is sentenced to 10 more years after he makes contact with foreign dissidents and criticizes Chinese prison conditions to foreign media (S)

headline: RESTATEMENT BY PRE-PAID LEGAL REDUCES EARNINGS
abstract: Pre-Paid Legal Services restates financial statements for last two years, wiping out more than half its profit, after Securities and Exchange Commission says provider of legal insurance improperly recorded some commissions paid as assets (S)

headline: A Panel Backed by Bush Urges Higher Fuel Efficiency for Cars
abstract: Report by National Academy of Sciences panel recommends that government require automobile manufacturers to improve mileage of new vehicles; says significant improvements can be made using new engine technologies inexpensive enough to pay for themselves through savings of gasoline over typical life of vehicle; argues that considerably greater improvements can be made without penalizing drivers financially, if savings on gasoline are counted; does not recommend specific improvements in miles per gallon, but states that fuel economy of new vehicles--especially sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks--could be raised by as much as 8 to 11 miles per gallon over next 6 to 10 years, with extra cost offset by savings on gasoline over typical 14-year life of vehicle; its findings discussed; panel, which Pres Bush says will help him decide whether and how much to increase fuel economy standards, consists mainly of engineers and consultants who have worked for auto and oil industries, along with some economists and retired oil executives; does not include anyone from environmental movement; recent criticisms of panel by environmental and consumer groups, fearing it would be biased toward industry, noted; chart; photo (M)

headline: War's Legacy: Many in Guatemala Still Fear Army
abstract: Redefining domestic role of military in Guatemala has proved difficult; in regions of country decimated by massacres during civil war, increased visibility of military has brought fear and uncertainty; while military says it wants to improve its domestic image, many civilians fear that it is only trying to find way to go unpunished for past, given that report issued after peace accords were signed blames military for most of war's 200,000 deaths; photo; map (M)

headline: How to Enliven The Fields of Dreams
abstract: Judith A Handelman letter on August 12 article on baseball's declining popularity holds Major League Baseball must take back control from television czars who dictate starting times and lengthen games with endless commercials

headline: Privatizing Social Security
abstract: Ray Brady letter on Fred Brock's August 5 article explains why he opposes privatization of Social Security

headline: Learning to Speak Their Minds
abstract: Number of people with learning disability dyslexia, both students and adults, are using voice recognition software to transfer their ideas to print; learning disability researcher Dr Marshall H Raskind says speech recognition not only lets dyslexics communicate more efficiently but may even help them overcome condition; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: EUROPE NORTHERN IRELAND: SCHOOLGIRLS ATTACKED As they walked to their first day back at elementary school in northern Belfast, Roman Catholic girls and their parents faced a barrage of stones and bottles thrown by Protestant residents of homes near the school. Some 200 Protestants tried to block the street and clashed with the police, who cleared a path to the school entrance. Similar clashes in June forced the closing of the school for several days and were followed by sporadic episodes of violence that lasted through the summer.    Brian Lavery (NYT)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Seasoned Trial Court Judge Assigned to Microsoft Case  The government's landmark antitrust case against Microsoft was assigned to Judge Colleen Kollar-Kotelly, a seasoned trial court judge and a Clinton appointee to the federal bench, to determine how to penalize the company for abusing its monopoly power.    The selection of Judge Kollar-Kotelly to replace Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson marks an important point in the antitrust case. Two months ago, an appeals court removed Judge Jackson, but upheld many of his April 2000 findings that Microsoft had repeatedly violated the Sherman Antitrust Act. Shares of Microsoft rose $2.93, to $62.05. [Page A1.]

headline: Indonesia's Leader Outlines Her Ways to Cure Nation's Ills
abstract: Megawati Sukarnoputri, president of Indonesia, presented an outline of ways to deal with the country's many problems, stressing stability and human rights

headline: India-U.S. Fight on Basmati Rice Is Mostly Settled
abstract: US Patent Office narrows original broad patent granted Ricetec of Alvin, Tex, on several varieties of basmati rice, traditional staple grown in Indian region of Punjab; Indian basmati exporters dismissed these varieties as imitations of basmati, whose distinct aroma and texture, they argue, comes from Indian soil irrigated by waters from Himalyan rivers; India, which urged re-examination of patent, expresses satisfaction, but Indian scientists worry about future problems, and opposition politicians are agitating for further action (M)

headline: Sony Announces the Fate Of Its EVilla: Landfilla
abstract: Sony Electronics is withdrawing its eVilla Internet appliance from market after three months of sluggish sales; offers to buy back consumers' machines, refunding purchase price and monthly Internet service fee; photo (S)

headline: Personal Business Diary: Preparing Boomers for Long-Time Care
abstract: Retirement isn't too far in the future for many baby boomers, who grew up in the 1950's and 1960's. But while this generation may be thinking about more leisure days ahead, many are unprepared for their long-term health care needs, according to survey results released last week.

headline: Rescue Plan Advances; House to Act Today
abstract: US House expects to move ahead with financial relief package for nation's airlines that would give them $5 billion in cash and $10 billion in loan guarantees; Pres Bush plans to direct $3 billion to emergeny efforts to bolster security in airports and on planes; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: More Foot-And-Mouth Disease
abstract: Britain, responding to three new cases of f

headline: 'Web Bugs' Are Tracking Use of Internet
abstract: Cyveillance, which tracks Internet sites for corporate clients, says many people who have personal Web pages are unknowingly tracking people who visit and sending information to third parties; says use of Internet monitoring technology popularly known as 'Web bugs' has exploded on personal Web pages, especially those created free through online companies like America Online and Geocities, which is owned by Yahoo; says monitoring technology is invisibly added to Web pages as part of elements that sites offer to help create Web page (M)

headline: Trying to Fill Legend's Shoes Leading Afghanistan Rebels
abstract: Profile of Northern Alliance leader Gen Muhammad Fahim; photo (M)

headline: Wrong Tool for the Job
abstract: Seth Steinberg letter on Aug 30 article notes cell phones are not as valuable as conventional marine radios when boaters call Coast Guard for help

headline: U.S. and Japan Discuss Transfer of American Rape Suspect
abstract: US and Japan are close to defining legal guarantees for American Air Force sergeant suspected of raping Japanese woman on Okinawa; agreement could clear way for him to be handed over to local authorities before indictment; exact details of incident, in which 20-year-old Japanese woman was allegedly raped in parking lot of popular entertainment district in Chatan, remain unclear; suspect identified as 24-year-old Staff Sgt Timothy Woodland, who has denied raping woman but allegedly admitting having consensual sex with her (M)

headline: Drop in Profit At Emerson For First Time In 43 Years
abstract: Emerson Electric says its annual profit will drop for first time in 43 years; says profit for 2001 fiscal year will be down about 5 percent (M)

headline: A Shattered Nest Egg
abstract: George S Thomas letter holds July 22 article about losing $700,000 nest egg by following broker's advice underscores risks of investing in stocks

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: F.C.C. Expands Wireless Access
abstract: Federal Communications Commission will expand access to airwaves in range of 2500 megahertz to 2690 megahertz--currently used for fixed wireless services--so that they can be used for third-generation services like high-speed Internet access and music downloads (S)

headline: FLEETBOSTON ARRANGES $6 BILLION LOAN FOR FINOVA GROUP
abstract: FleetBoston Financial Corp arranges $6 billion securitized loan to be used by Finova Group, commercial lender that came out of bankruptcy court this week; FleetBoston arranged financing for Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway and Leucadia National, which formed joint venture to lend Finova money to pay off its creditors (S)

headline: Exodus Communications Hit by Bankruptcy Fears
abstract: Shares in Exodus Communications, provider of Internet services for businesses, plunge on bankruptcy fears; its troubles immediately affect Global Crossing, which sells capacity on its fiber optic network to Exodus and guarantees some of Exodus's real estate leases; Exodus may seek bankruptcy protection and may also be planning additional job reductions as part of restructuring plan (M)

headline: Sale of Ethanol To Be Widened
abstract: Archer Daniels Midland Co to begin selling fuel additive ethanol in New York area later this year, anticipating growing demand from Eastern states; additive is used to make cleaner-burning gasoline (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Big Loss At Chip Maker
abstract: Hynix Semiconductor says it had pretax loss of $976 million for second quarter, compared with pretax loss of $360 million in first quarter; also reports operating loss of $203 million in second quarter after posting profit of $52 million in first quarter; photo (S)

headline: LA-Z-BOY CREATES TWO NEW PRODUCT GROUPS
abstract: La-Z-Boy Inc., the maker of its namesake reclining chairs, created separate groups for its upholstery and casegoods to use manufacturing capacity more effectively and market more products together. The casegoods group makes dressers, chests and other wood furniture for bedrooms, living and dining rooms. La-Z-Boy, based in Monroe, Mich., has increased to 16 operating companies from 8 in 1999, the company said. The upholstery group includes the Bauhaus, Centurion, Clayton Marcus, England, HickoryMark, La-Z-Boy and Sam Moore brands. The casegoods group includes Alexvale, American Drew, Hammary, Kincaid, Lea, Pennsylvania House and Pilliod.

headline: Once-Thriving Sri Lankan Town a War Ruin
abstract: Recent events in Sri Lanka, where almost two decades of warfare have sent hundreds of thousands of people fleeing for their lives have stirred menacing sense of foreboding; effort to restart peace talks has failed, country has plunged into political turmoil and surprise rebel attack on country's international airport and adjacent military air base near capital of Colombo have almost completed collapse into despair; fighting in and around Chavakachcheri, once-tidy and bustling town located in heart of ethnically Tamil homeland that rebels have fought for over past 18 years, described; town stands as crumbled monument to fratricidal war that has killed more than 62,000 people and is destroying very land government and rebels claim they are fighting to save; map; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Protests Over Bombing Range
abstract: Villagers from Maehyang-ri, South Korea, stage protests over presence of bombing range in village, operated by Lockheed Martin for US and South Korean air forces (S)

headline: Small Towns Renowned For Small Pleasures
abstract: Web site called ePodunk displays and celebrates small towns and cities; photo (S)

headline: U.S.-Mexico Talks Produce Agreement on Immigration Policy
abstract: United States and Mexico agree in principle to expanded temporary worker program that would allow some of estimated three million Mexicans living in US unlawfully to earn permanent legal residency; Secretary of State Colin L Powell and Atty Gen John Ashcroft join Mexican counterparts, Jorge G Castaneda and Santiago Creel, to announce 'humane, family-friendly' migration policy; meeting of American and Mexican cabinet officers is to begin laying groundwork for meeting in Sept between Pres Bush and Pres Fox; aides on both sides seek to play down expectations of any quick accord (M)

headline: Initial Jobless Claims Rise as Unemployment Benefits Surge
abstract: Number of workers filing new claims for unemployment insurance benefits rises 8,000, to 393,000, in week ended August 18, from revised 385,000 previous week; increase in those continuing to receive payments suggests that laid-off employees are having trouble finding work; Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia's survey of economists forecasts slower economic growth and higher unemployment that previously expected (M)

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: A Boon to the Elderly To the Editor:

headline: Supreme Court's ruling in a tobacco case is hailed as a victory for commercial freedom of speech.
abstract: A RULING by the Supreme Court that overturned efforts by Massachusetts to restrict tobacco advertising is being hailed by the trade associations that represent agencies and major marketers, which have long pressed to have commercial speech more fully protected under the First Amendment.    Others, however, are wondering whether the implications of the decision, made on Thursday, are as far-reaching as they are being portrayed.

headline: FIVE QUESTIONS for TED WAITT; Gateway Awaits The Next Bounce
abstract: Ted Waitt, founder and chief executive of Gateway, answers Five Questions on future of marketplace for personal computers; photo (M)

headline: Treasury Chief: Tax Evasion Is on the Rise
abstract: Treasury Sec Paul H O'Neill says tax evasion by Americans using offshore accounts is rising and will increase, testimony before Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations; tries to persuade skeptical Democratic senatort, Carl Levin, that he is committted to vigorously pursuing tax cheats; says decades of efforts to catch money launderers and other tax criminals using offshore accounts has not worked; dismisses as meaningless a document, based on government data, presented by Levin, indicating that fewer than 6,000 or more than 1.1 million offshore accounts and businesses were properly disclosed and therefore legal; Manhattan district attorney, Robert M Morgenthau, citing previously secret Federal Reserve Bank data, says that more than $800 billion of American money is on deposit in just one tax haven, Cayman Islands (M)

headline: INVESTING WITH/David A. Katz; Matrix Advisors Value Fund
abstract: Investing With column interviews David Katz, who runs $42 million Matrix Advisors Value fund, on what he looks for in shopping for stocks; photo; chart (M)

headline: A new campaign for a fragrance tries to redefine glamour.
abstract: Ad campaign for Ralph Lauren Fragrances' Glamourous features actress Penelope Cruz; $15 million campaign was created by Carlson & Partners; photos (M)

headline: NAVIGANT, AIRLINE BOOKING SERVICE, TO CUT JOBS
abstract: Navigant International Inc, second-largest provider of airline booking services, will eliminate about 1,200 jobs, or fifth of its work force, because of lower travel demand after last week's terrorist attack; is also reducing salaries 5 percent to 12 percent and halting capital spending (S)

headline: Compressed Data; Password Protection With Prison Stripes
abstract: Federal prosecutors trying to convict Nicodemo S Scarfo Jr on gambling and loan sharking charges in Federal District Court in Newark reveal in court papers that password Scarfo allegedly used to encrypt and decrypt files was his father's prison identification number; Scarfo Sr, former head of mob in Philadelphia and South Jersey, is serving multiple prison terms; drawing (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Price of cotton falls after US government report predicts 15 percent increase in Chinese cotton crop from year ago; cotton for December delivery falls 1.17 cents, or 3 percent, to 38.41 cents per pound; graph; chart (S)

headline: A Mouse With No Tail And an Urge to Fly
abstract: GyroMouse Pro, from Gyration, guides computer's cursor using gyroscopes; photo (S)

headline: At The Hague, Bosnian Serbs Are Castigated Over Fugitives
abstract: Carla del Ponte, chief prosecutor at UN war crimes tribunal in The Hague, demands actions, not 'hollow promises or excuses,' from Bosnian Serb republic, openly accusing its government of sheltering most wanted fugitives, Radovan Karadzic and Gen Ratko Mladic; says Bosnian government knows, or is in position to know, whereabouts; says Mladic is enjoying protection of Bosnian Serb military; Bosnian Serb Prime Min Mladen Ivanic reiterates pledge to cooperate, but accuses del Ponte of being too critical and of having too high expectations; tribunal upholds 40-year sentence of Bosnian Serb, Goran Jelesic, who was in charge of detention camp in Brcko during war and is charged with killing more than 100 Muslim and Croatian men (S)

headline: Alltel in Hostile $6.1 Billion Bid for Phone Rival
abstract: Alltel Corp makes unsolicited $6.1 billion takeover bid for CenturyTel Inc, smaller rival that provides phone services in rural areas, suburbs and small towns; move represents company's latest move to capture more market share at time when valuations for telecommunications companies are considerably lower than in recent past (M)

headline: Taking a Breather on the Mideast
abstract: Analysis of Bush administration's reluctant involvement in Israeli-Palestinian conflict; says Secretary of State Colin Powell only agreed to visit area after receiving highly unusual cable from American ambassadors in Israel, Egypt and Jordan, as well as consul general in Jerusalem, appealing to him to come to Israel and Palestinian territories day after bombing of Israeli disco in Tel Aviv; says Powell's visit was not viewed as success by Israel or by friendly Arab countries that Bush administraion tried to please by Powell visit; says it is unlikely that administration will dispatch any more high-profile missions in near future (M)

headline: U.S. Diplomat Said to Protest China Actions On First Boston
abstract: US ambassador to China, Clark T Randt Jr, decides not to attend dinner with Chinese officials, apparently in protest over China's removal of Credit Suisse First Boston from list of underwriters for stock offering planned by China Unicom Group; China was apparently punishing bank for having invited Taiwan's finance minister, Yen Ching-chang, to give keynote speech at conference in Hong Kong in March; China has increasingly encouraged commercial ties with Taiwan, but has continued to retaliate against countries or companies that afford island's leaders official status abroad, or even refer to Taiwan as country (M)

headline: AN INVESTMENT FIRM OFFERS TO BUY ZANY BRAINY'S ASSETS
abstract: Waterton Management acquires assets of Zany Brainy, bankrupt specialty toy retailer, for $115 million; Thomas G Vellios will remain chief executive; Zany was forced into bankruptcy in May (S)

headline: Private Sector; On the Road Again, Happily
abstract: General Electric Co former chairman John F Welch Jr comments on life after GE and promotion tour for his book, Jack: Straight From the Gut; photo (S)

headline: New Campaigns
abstract: Mutual of Omaha Insurance Co will start running its first advertising aimed at consumers in more than decade, with corporate image campaign carrying theme 'Begin today'; campaign, with spending estimated at $30 million, is being created by Chicago office of Bozell Group (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Immigration Proposal
abstract: Interior Min Otto Schily presents outlines of new immigration law to Germany's parliament, intending to resolve national debate on how to balance Germany's need to modernize with some Germans' fear of increasingly multicultural society (S)

headline: For Some, Out of the Frying Pan Into a Classroom
abstract: Culinary Institute of America in Hyde Park, NY, is transforming itself from technical institution into full-scale liberal arts college for food studies, adding raft of academic courses in effort to win accreditation from Middle States Association of Colleges and Schools; efforts to strengthen and broaden institute's liberal arts program have led to new math and writing requirements, and even in food-related courses there is increased emphasis on scholarly approaches; photo (M)

headline: 2 Big Booksellers' Results Beat Wall St. Expectations
abstract: Barnes & Noble, nation's largest bookstore chain, posts fiscal second-quarter results that easily surpass Wall Street expectations; second-largest chain, Borders Group, modestly tops forecasts; both foresee rosy holiday trade ahead; Barnes & Noble reports loss in most-recent quarter of $1.7 million, compared with $8.6 million loss year ago; Borders reports earning $100,000 during most-recent quarter, up from $1.6 million deficit year earlier (M)

headline: At G.E., Whither The House Jack Built?; His Successor Faces Skeptics And a Market Less in Awe
abstract: Jeffrey R Immelt will face immense challenge when he takes over from John F Welch Jr as General Electric Co's chief executive on Sept 7; revenue, earnings and especially, GE's stock price, would have to soar over next two decades to equal their performance under Welch; graph; photos (M)

headline: Selection Made for Treasury Dept. Post
abstract: Bush administration names Richard H Clarida to be assistant secretary of Treasury for economic policy, filling last major slot in economic team; nomination is subject to approval by Senate (S)

headline: Roche Buys Drug Rights
abstract: Roche Holding, Europe's fifth-largest drug maker, said today that it had bought the rights to use an ICN Pharmaceuticals compound, levovirin, to help treat hepatitis C, which infects 170 million people worldwide. Roche, a Swiss company, did not say what it paid for the rights to levovirin. Roche will combine the therapy with its Pegasys drug. Roche said preclinical studies show that the combination may be better than Pegasys and ribavirin, the most successful treatment for hepatitis C. Roche has had a series of research setbacks and faces a delay for Pegasys, the only potentially top-selling medication it planned to introduce in 2001, analysts said. Roche will pay a one-time licensing fee, milestone payments and, if the drug gets regulatory approval, royalties to ICN, based in Costa Mesa, Calif.

headline: In Putin's Words: 'Ready to Contribute'
abstract: Excerpts of televised address by Russian President Vladimir V Putin (M)

headline: What's an Industry to Say To Skittish U.S. Travelers?
abstract: Airlines and their transportation industry competitors face biggest problems as advertisers in wake of terrorist attacks on New York and Washington; airlines are suspending regular advertising and not sponsoring any special advertising; competitors do not want to seem to be capitalizing on tragedy (M)

headline: As North and South Korea Open Discussions, the Issue of Terrorism Takes Center Stage
abstract: A ministerial delegation from North Korea arrived in South Korea today to begin a four-day series of meetings heavily dominated by the issue of terrorism.

headline: Another Stem Cell Debate; Ethics Aside, a Good Business Model Remains Elusive
abstract: Cell therapy, including treatments using embryonic stem cells, has proved extremely difficult to turn into viable business; people in biotechnology industry argue federal financing is needed because technology is still too early in its development to attract corporate interest; cells, as living things, are hard to manufacture to consistent standard like drugs and might do unpredictable things in body (M)

headline: Stocks Fall on Earnings Reports and Greenspan Comments
abstract: Stock prices fell today as investors digested another round of bleak corporate earnings along with downbeat comments from Alan Greenspan

headline: Traders Find Little Comfort In Dollar as Crises Deepen
abstract: PARIS—  It is an axiom in the currency markets that when tremors rattle the global economy, investors seek safety in the dollar.

headline: Reliant to Buy Orion Power For $2.9 Billion
abstract: Reliant Resources acquires Orion Power Holdings for $2.9 billion in cash; Goldman, Sachs, which owns 37 percent of Orion, stands to make more than $1 billion on deal (S)

headline: Sony to Take Charge to Pay For Cellular Phone Recall
abstract: Sony Corp to take charge of about 12 billion yen ($95 million) to pay for recall of 1.1 million cellular phones; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Belgium: Case Against Sharon To Proceed
abstract: A Belgian prosecutor said an investigation into Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel for possible crimes against humanity could proceed. The case was prompted by a dozen complaints filed against Mr. Sharon charging that he was responsible for the deaths of hundreds of Palestinians by Christian militiamen in Beirut in 1982 when Mr. Sharon was Israel's defense minister. A 1993 law allows Belgian courts to prosecute foreign officials for human rights violations committed outside Belgium.     Paul Meller (NYT)

headline: Keeping Up to Speed On Antivirus Protection
abstract: Q.  Less than a year ago I purchased a Dell computer with Norton 2001 installed. I have recently been getting messages telling me that my virus definitions update has expired and I should subscribe, which involves a fee. Isn't the free program already installed adequate? What is the virus definition update?

headline: GERMAN PROSECUTORS WIDEN MANNESMANN INVESTIGATION
abstract: German prosecutors widen investigation into payments made during Vodafone Group's takeover of Mannesmann in 2000; inquiry will include Vodafone's chief executive, Chris Gent, and chief executive-designate of Deutsche Bank, Josef Ackermann, who was on Mannesmann's supervisory board during takeover; seeks to determine whether Mannesmann's former chief executive, Klaus Esser, and other executives agreed to deal because Vodafone offered them payments, sometimes called golden parachutes (S)

headline: Market Place; Investment Bankers Smell Riches in AT&T Cable
abstract: Wall Street investment bankers that had been preparing pitches to underwrite AT&T's initial public offering of its cable business, AT&T Broadband, have been fiercely jockeying for position since Comcast made hostile bid for unit; are now vying for smaller, but still lucrative advisory fees for deal; Comcast acted pre-emptively, hiring cadre of top banks and bankers to advise it; table of banks aligned with players interested in AT&T unit (M)

headline: How to Enliven The Fields of Dreams
abstract: Rob Simmelkjaer letter on August 12 article on decline in baseball's popularity holds greatest threat is that American children are not playing

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Profit At Airline
abstract: Ryanair reports after-tax profit for quarter ended June 30 rose to 23.2 million euros ($20.4 million), up 28 percent (S)

headline: G.E. AND QWEST FORM JOINT VENTURE FOR HOSPITAL IMAGING
abstract: General Electric and Qwest Communications International form joint venture that will let hospitals store and retrieve digital images using high-speed fiber optic network; three-year agreement is expected to generate $250 million in revenue (S)

headline: GENOMIC SOLUTIONS TO CUT 25% OF ITS WORK FORCE
abstract: Genomic Solutions Inc will cut 25 percent of its work force and close Lansing, Mich, plant in attempt to achieve profitability in 2002; it will also purchase Cartesian Technologies Inc (S)

headline: Beijing Judge Jails 4 for Promoting Falun Gong's Public Suicides
abstract: beijing judge jails 4 for promoting

headline: Equity Offerings
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

headline: Mistakes Cited in Downing of Plane in Peru
abstract: Joint US-Peruvian inquiry finds that disastrous series of mistakes led to shooting down in April of small plane carrying missionary family in Peru by Peruvian fighter involved in joint US-Peruvian antidrug operation; cites language problems, poor communications and shortcuts in following established procedures; American missionary Veronica Bowers and her infant daughter Charity, were killed; pilot Kevin Donaldson was injured (M)

headline: The PC? That Old Thing?; An Industry's Founding Father Has Better Things to Do
abstract: H Edward Roberts, who as president of Micro Instrumentation Telemetry Systems introduced first inexpensive general-purpose microcomputer in 1975, now regards his pivotal role in personal computer revolution with certain bemused distance; sold MITS in 1977, went on to study medicine and is now doctor in rural Cochran, Ga; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: U.S. Serviceman Pleads Not Guilty
abstract: Sgt Timothy Woodland, United States airman, pleads not guilty to raping Okinawan woman; says sex was consensual (S)

headline: Philippine Armed Forces Helped Kidnapping Gang Escape, He Says : The Fighting Priest
abstract: LAMITAN, Philippines—  The Reverend Cirilo Nacorda, the Roman Catholic parish priest in this small seaside town, says he carries his .45-caliber handgun only when he's tending to his flock in nearby villages. Otherwise, when he's at home in his rectory here, his two bodyguards stand among the wooden pews of his church and keep watch.

headline: Judge Rejects Sale of Raytheon Unit
abstract: Washington Group International says bankruptcy judge in Nevada has agreed to throw out $503 million pact to buy Raytheon construction unit because of accusations of hidden costs (S)

headline: The New World Order Is a Clash of Civilizations
abstract: BERLIN—  The clash of civilizations that appears to have brought a monstrous terror attack to the United States has left no neutral corners where countries or individuals can hide from new choices in what is a suddenly different world.

headline: New Push to Get bin Laden To Agree to Quit Afghanistan
abstract: Efforts to get Osama bin Laden to leave Afghanistan appear to be moving forward; Afghanistan's ruling Taliban announces that courier has delivered their request to him to leave, and Pakistan, hoping to get Afghan leaders to expel him, is sending top general and several of country's most militant Islamic clerics to Afghanistan to urge Taliban to spare Afghanistan American military attack; Pakistani officials were deeply pessimistic after their earlier negotiations with Taliban, but senior military intelligence officials from Pakistan who remained behind report some change in Taliban position, perhaps related to emerging divisions in Afghan leadership; Pakistani officials are now hopeful that Taliban's leader, Mullah Muhammad Omar, can be influenced by Islamic clerics from Pakistan, many of whom have long and influential relationship with Taliban; photo (M)

headline: Executive Changes at Media Firms
abstract: Nikoloas Birbilis and Amy Roy have joined the Brownstein Group, Philadelphia, as art director and copywriter, respectively

headline: Stop and Shop Hires Mullen
abstract: Stop and Shop Hires Mullen The Stop and Shop Supermarket Company in Quincy, Mass., which operates grocery stores in the Northeast, has named Mullen in Wenham, Mass., part of the Partnership unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies, to handle its broadcast account, with spending estimated at $7 million to $10 million.

headline: Net Is Down 56% At Parker Hannifin
abstract: Parker Hannifin Corp reports net income for fiscal fourth quarter ended June 30 fell 56 percent to $49.4 million, down from $113 million a year ago (S)

headline: Flying a Flag, if You Can Find One
abstract: American flag has become symbol of resolve to carry on after terrorist attacks, but it is also in short supply in many parts of country (S)

headline: Real World Record:$64.5 Million for Zidane
abstract: LONDON—  CORRECTION PUBLISHED IN THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE DATED Wednesday July 11th, 2001:

headline: So a Home Equity Loan Would Be a Better Idea?
abstract: Four hundred and fifty people of Cashtown, Pa, vow not to use their credit cards for 100 hours in exchange from gift to local school of $10,000 from Champion Mortgage, purveyor of home-equity loans and other debt-management products (S)

headline: The Names Scream 'Value.' But the Portfolios Don't.
abstract: Mark Hulbert column urges investors to be skeptical of great number of advisers who have begun calling themselves value managers of late; notes Andrew Metrick's study of 153 investment newsletters, which found that even those that portrayed themselves as 'value oriented' recommended portfolios skewed toward growth stocks; chart (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Razorfish Reports A Loss
abstract: Razorfish Inc, Web design and Internet consulting firm, reports second-quarter net loss of $137.1 million, compared with earnings of $5.1 million a year earlier; sales dropped to $28.7 million from $76.6 million in year-earlier period (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: More Development Urged
abstract: Pres Kim Dae Jung of South Korea calls for overall economic development as best antidote to declining exports to US, Japan and European Union; warns of growing economic difficulties while welcoming new cabinet; photo (S)

headline: Connecticut Takes Action Against Rental-Car Tracker
abstract: Connecticut Department of Consumer Protection files complaint against Acme Rent-a-Car, New Haven car rental agency that used Global Positioning System equipment to track and fine speeding customers (S)

headline: Yahoo, Reporting a Loss, Looks for Joint Ventures
abstract: Yahoo says it lost $48.5 million in second quarter, modestly beating its financial goals; sales were $182 million, down from $273 million year ago and slightly higher than $180 million in revenue in first quarter (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Senate Committee Rejects Consumer Panel Nominee  The Senate Commerce Committee voted along party lines to reject President Bush's choice to head the Consumer Product Safety Commission, handing him his first nomination loss.    By a 12 to 11 vote, Democrats rebuffed the nomination of Mary Sheila Gall, saying her record as a current member of the commission showed an alarming disregard for children's safety and warning that her elevation to chairwoman would benefit manufacturers, not consumers. [Page A1.]

headline: Japan's Electronics Slump Takes a Toll on Southeast Asia
abstract: Slump in marketplace for electronics goods causes Japanese companies to slow production at or shutter their plants in other Southeast Asian countries as well as at home; Fujitsu is cutting production at its Thai, Vietnamese and Philippine factories; NEC dismisses workers in Malaysia, where Hitachi is closing plant in addition to its facilities in Singapore and at home; cutbacks highlight not only severe slump in demand for technology goods, but also retreat of Japan as South Asia's largest investor and financier and rapid-re-emergence of China as region's principal rival for investment and trade (M)

headline: European Central Bank Leaves Rates Unchanged
abstract: European Central Bank declines to lower interest rates and emphasizes that it will not relax its grip on monetary policy any time soon; US dollar rises to its highest level since October; graph (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Church Objects To Bullfight
abstract: Russian Orthodox Church leader objects to plans for stage bullfight in Moscow stadium (S)

headline: Stocks Close Lower Again; Dow Drops 14.3 Percent for Week
abstract: Stocks dropped today for their fifth straight loss on a day of volatile trading, as the Dow Jones industrial average posted its worst weekly decline since the Great Depression.

headline: Article 2001070290898329171 -- No Title
abstract: Lessons in Internet Plagiarism

headline: Scarcity of Afghanistan Targets Prompts U.S. to Change Strategy
abstract: Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld says difficulty in identifying bombing targets in Afghanistan is leading Pentagon to develop broader, more unconventional type of campaign; leaves door open to use of ground troops, including commando units; says US must use full spectrum of its capabilities; administration's consideration of military action beyond classic air campaign reflects recognition that terrorists are elusive, and that Afghanistan, which shelters them, is so impoverished that it offers scarce set of targets; map (M)

headline: In Contrarians' Eyes, the Bears Have Room to Run
abstract: Mark Hulbert column says investment advisory newsletters and options market provide evidence to support contrarian view that this bear market is not yet over; graph (M)

headline: New Charges Against Milosevic Tie Him to Croatia War Crimes
abstract: International War Crimes Tribunal issues second indictment against Slobodan Milosevic, charging former Serb leader with war crimes in Croatia in 1991 and 1992; prosecutors in The Hague are also focusing on Milosevic's finances, asking Greece to help examine family bank accounts (S)

headline: A Site Whose Riches Bob on the Surface
abstract: History Wired, new Web guide to Smithsonian Institution's National Museum of American History, is designed to produce alternatives to conventional methods for retrieving online information; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Middle East: Yemen: F.B.I. Is Back
abstract: Team of FBI investigators returns to Yemen to resume their inquiry into bombing of Navy destroyer Cole; inquiry was interrupted in June when agents left country because of terrorist threats (S)

headline: Series of Treasury Offerings Scheduled for This Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week include today's regular weekly auction of three-  and six-month bills and a nine-day cash management bill.    By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 3.52 percent, and a six-month bill was 3.46 percent.

headline: James A. D. Geier, 75, Ex-Chief Of Plastics Technology Company
abstract: James A D Geier, former chairman and chief executive of Milacron Inc of Cincinnati, dies at age 75 (M)

headline: U.S. Envoy Extols India, Accepting Its Atom Status
abstract: Robert D Blackwill, new American ambassador to India, offers fullest description yet of Bush administration's drive to turn India and United States into 'fast friends and international partners' after decades of strained relations; Blackwill's address to business leaders in Bombay is revealing for what he does not say: there is no criticism of India for beginning nuclear tests in 1998; instead, Blackwill strongly suggests that Bush administration would soon approach Congress on lifting of sanctions imposed during Clinton administration after tests; tenor and substance of his remarks signal calm recognition of India's nuclear status (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Titan Buys A Services Vendor
abstract: Titan Corp acquires BIG Inc, military technology advisory and systems company, for $142 million in stock and cash and assumption of $32 million of debt; Titan provides high-technology data, communications systems and products (S)

headline: Genoa's Protesters March Peacefully, but Vow Stronger Action
abstract: Tens of thousands of people march peacefully through Genoa on eve of meeting of leaders of industrialized nations; say meeting is symbol of globalization, capitalist exploitation and environmental insensitivity; earlier, leaders of more radical protest groups say they will tear down 'red zone,' high-security area in city center where leaders will meet; photos (M)

headline: Hong Kong Court Rules Boy Can Stay, in Snub to Beijing
abstract: In a bold reassertion of its independence, Hong Kong's highest court ruled today that a 3-year-old boy born here to a mainland Chinese mother has the right to residency

headline: Kebran Gabriel Journal; On Monks' and Nuns' Islands, 'You Have Only God'
abstract: Two decades ago, recalled Brother Gabriel Selassie, he was a 49-year-old farmer with a big family and a big midlife crisis. He was tilling his land one morning, as was his wont, when he threw down his plow, ran away from home and became a monk.    ''I told no one in my family I was leaving,'' said Brother Gabriel, 70. He is at peace with himself nowadays on this remote island monastery in northern Ethiopia, though his peaceful reading of a Psalm of David was interrupted on this particular morning by a stranger who knocked on the door of his mud shack.

headline: A Vow to Erase Terrorist Networks — bin Laden Is Singled Out
abstract: The Bush administration singled out Osama bin Laden as a prime suspect in Tuesday's catastrophic attacks and vowed a comprehensive military campaign to demolish terrorist networks.

headline: YELLOW SAYS IT WILL RAISE SOME TRUCKING RATES 4.9%
abstract: Yellow Corp will raise trucking rates 4.9 percent (S)

headline: North Korean Leader Departs Russia
abstract: Kim Jong Il, North Korea's leader, returns home from 24-day mission to Russia that he says had improved relations between two countries (S)

headline: MGM MIRAGE TRYING TO ACQUIRE ILLINOIS CASINO COMPANY
abstract: MGM Mirage says it negotiates to buy Emerald Casino, which seeks to build casino near Chicago (S)

headline: A Coffee Crisis' Devastating Domino Effect in Nicaragua
abstract: Steep drop in coffee prices on world market has led to crisis in Central America, forcing growers to scale back or close down, putting thousands of landless field hands out of work; Nicaraguan workers in places like El Tuma-La Dalia are reduced to begging by roadside for jobs or food; photo; map; most urgent call is for government to help farmers, who have gotten small amounts but complain that money goes to creditors (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: WebMD President Quits
abstract: Marvin Rich resigns as WebMD Corp president, and company creates office of president, made up of four executives (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Belarus: Race Tight, Police Move In
abstract: belaru

headline: Obscure Biotech Company Becomes Big Player in Stem Cell World
abstract: National Institute of Health list shows that CyThera Inc, which was not known to be working on human embryonic stem cells, has derived nine colonies of such cells, more than other organizations better known for stem cells, like University of Wisconsin, and second only Sweden's Goteborg University, which has 19; that could mean that CyThera will be sought out by scientists who are eager to begin work on cells; photo (M)

headline: Oil and Gas Prices Tumble, But Stocks Soar Worldwide
abstract: Oil and natural gas prices plunge on fears that sharp worldwide recession would reduce energy demand; but stocks worldwide soar on optimism that recession would be brief and that American economy, world's leader, would eventually shrug off terrorist attacks of Sept 11; price of barrel of crude oil drops 15 percent to $22.01, lowest level since Oct 1999; Dow Jones industrial average gains 368.05 points, or 4.5 percent, and stock markets in Britain, France, Germany, Italy, Hong Kong and South Korea also rise strongly; falling energy prices may actually aid economic growth worldwide by lowering costs for businesses and consumers; in short term, lower oil prices may make it easier for policy makers to respond to economic slump; in managing economies, governments and central banks must balance risks of inflation and recession; if oil prices remain low, keeping inflation in check, Federal Reserve and its counterparts worldwide can cut interest rates more aggressively, and governments may be more willing to spend; graphs (M)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: New Charges For 4 Journalists
abstract: Zimbabwe police file new charges against four journalists day after court dismisses earlier charges (S)

headline: No Failure at Talks
abstract: India and Pakistan, longtime foes,  emerged from two days of talks without even a joint news release to show for it. Yet ministers from both countries said that the meeting had not failed, but had helped them better understand each other.    Article, Page A7.

headline: Credit Suisse Shakes Up First Boston
abstract: Credit Suisse Group, which owns Credit Suisse First Boston, hires John J Mack, former president of Morgan Stanley, to replace Allen D Wheat; sudden dismissal of top executive is rare on Wall Street and usually occurs only after firm is caught in major scandal; First Boston is at center of federal investigation into how Wall Street firms sold shares of new stocks in late 1990's; photos (M)

headline: Court in Iran Detains Filmmaker On Charges of Political Crimes
abstract: court in iran detains filmmake

headline: Chinese Censors Shut Down Marxist Journal Critical of Jiang
abstract: Chinese censors shut down small but influential Marxist journal for attacking Pres Jiang Zemin's plan to bring capitalists into Communist Party; action seen as sign that Jiang will brook little dissent from any quarter as he tries to cement his place in pantheon of great leaders before his term as president expires in 2003; party insiders say Jiang is trying to adapt increasingly clumsy methods of Communism to world of social and technological complexity (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Worldcom Seeks Rhythms Assets
abstract: WorldCom Inc submits $40 million bid for some of assets of Rhythms NetConnections, bankrupt provider of high-speed Internet service (S)

headline: Henrietta Milstein, 72; Helped to Found Burlington Coat Factory
abstract: henrietta milstein, 72; helped to found burli4

headline: Countdown to the Great Labor Shortage
abstract: Bureau of Labor Statistics projects that gap between between number of jobs available in US and number of people to fill them will grow to six million in 2008 as baby boomers retire and that labor shortage will peak from 2015 to 2025, when bulk of workers born between 1946 and 1964, as many as 60 million, reach retirement age; occupations with large numbers of older workers like construction inspection and teaching in secondary schools are expected to suffer, as will fields creating jobs at fast pace, like computer engineering; experts say imbalance will mean opportunities for workers in fields like engineering or health care where shortages will be most acute; companies can be expected to move more jobs overseas and turn to immigrants to do work Americans cannot or will not do; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: Sinn Fein Leader's Warning
abstract: Gerry Adams, Sinn Fein president, says make-or-break talks aimed at achieving IRA disarmament would fail if they continue 'making all other issues secondary to the issue of IRA arms' (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Qwest To Supply Network Services To AOL
abstract: Qwest Communications International and AOL Time Warner signed a deal under which Qwest will become a primary provider of high-speed access and other network services to AOL Time Warner. Qwest will also purchase advertising across AOL Time Warner's portfolio of online, print and television outlets.

headline: Roxio Starts Campaign For its CD Creator
abstract: Roxio, which makes software to 'burn' compact discs, is beginning its first national branding campaign by encouraging younger consumers to 'burn everything' with its main product, Easy CD Creator 5; spending estimated at $20 million; campaign was created by Modernista (S)

headline: Imagining the Law of the Future
abstract: What will the world of law be like in 1,000 years?

headline: CISCO SYSTEMS TO BUY REST OF ALLEGRO SYSTEMS
abstract: Cisco Systems Inc will acquire the 60 percent of Allegro Systems Inc it does not already own for $109 million in stock (S)

headline: Medical-Pump Pricing Inquiry
abstract: Abbott Laboratories, Novartis AG, Zevex International Inc and Tyco International Ltd are among targets of federal investigation of businesses that sell products used to feed critically ill patients through tubes; probe centers around possible fraudulent billing of government healthcare programs (M)

headline: As Cambodia Prepares to Try Khmer Rouge Leaders for Massacres, They Deny Guilt
abstract: New Law passed by Cambodian government increases likelihood that Khmer Rouge leaders could face trial in coming months for atrocities committed during their rule, from 1975 to 1979; prospects also enhanced by show of support for trial by Prime Min Hun Sen, who formerly urged world to bury past; new law sets up framework for international tribunal, to operate in Cambodia under UN auspices, to try such leaders as Khieu Samphan and at least six other surviving Khmer leaders; photo (M)

headline: Shares of Marconi Plummet After It Projects Profit Shortfall
abstract: LONDON, July 5 — Shares of Marconi P.L.C., Britain's biggest telephone equipment maker, fell by more than half today in a vivid display of the spiraling decline in Europe's telecommunications industry.

headline: Qwest to Cut 4,000 Jobs And Reduce Its Expenses
abstract: Qwest Communications, operator of large fiber optic and local telephone networks, will eliminate 4,000 jobs, or 6 percent of work force, by beginning of next year; reduces its spending and sales estimates (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Automaker Profit
abstract: South Korea's Ssangyong Motor reports first-half net profit of $11.2 million sales of $850 million, up 39 percent, compared with loss of $117 million in first half of last year (S)

headline: Bank of England Joins Others in Cutting Rates to Fight Slump
abstract: The Bank of England cut interest rates by a quarter point today, to 4.75 percent, joining other central banks in fighting to keep the global economy from sinking into a deep recession.

headline: America's Economic Cloud Extends Across Europe
abstract: European corporations and consumers have been badly unnerved by terrorist attacks on US; European economy had already slowed considerably in last several months, and terrorist attacks dashed hopes in Europe that US will bounce back and pull rest of world along with it; France's economic research institute Insee reports that business confidence in September dropped to its lowest level since 1996; Prime Min Lionel Jospin goes so far as to declare consumer spending tantamount to civic duty; European corporations in last two weeks have been racing to revise their plans and prepare for more prolonged slowdown; economists expect European Union nations to grow at 1.5 percent or so this year and next, compared with earlier figures of 2 percent this year and 2.5 percent or more in 2002; European Central Bank's policy board decides not to follow emergency half-point cut in interest rates approved after terrorist attacks with any additional reduction; many economists are convinced that more rate cuts are to come; BASF's warning of earnings decline provides additional evidence that fallout from terrorist attacks is reaching heavy industry as well as consumer spending (M)

headline: Fed Cuts Rates and Says It Will Work to Stabilize Markets
abstract: The Federal Reserve cut its benchmark interest rate by half a percentage point today, and it promised that it would go to great lengths to keep financial markets operating smoothly.

headline: Money and Quicken Duel For the Consumer's Dollar
abstract: Intuit's 2002 version of Quicken and Microsoft's updated Money offer several new features for business-related software users; photo (S)

headline: A Fund Manager Who Had It Right on Energy Stocks
abstract: Merrill Lynch Growth Fund has lost 10 percent of value since death in 1998 of Stephen C Johnes, manager who invested 40 percent of fund's money in stocks of companies that drill for oil and produce natural gas; energy holdings were sold by new manager following Johnes's death, at time when technology issues were rage; analysts say if fund remained way Johnes left it, it would have risen more than 60 percent because of current energy shortages and would have been one of more successful funds at time when many have lost money; in 10 years as manager, Johnes built one of best long-term records of any manager of comparable funds; photo (M)

headline: E-Commerce Report; The possible sale of Blue Mountain Arts could lead to the end of the free online greeting card.
abstract: Financial woes of ExciteatHome threaten future of its Blue Mountain Arts unit, highly popular electronic online greeting card service; spur speculation that American Greetings will acquire Blue Mountain, giving it dominance that could hasten end of free online cards for consumers; photo (M)

headline: TRIBUNAL IN HAGUE FINDS BOSNIA SERB GUILTY OF GENOCIDE
abstract: United Nations war crimes tribunal in Hague finds former Bosnian Serb Gen Radislav Krstic guilty of genocide for his role in systematic execution of more than 7,000 unarmed Muslim men and boys near Srebrenica in July 1995; verdict is court's first conviction on charge of genocide in wars that broke up Yugoslavia; massacres in fields of Srebernica have become known as greatest atrocity in Europe since World War II; Krstic, 53, is sentenced to 46 years in prison, longest sentence yet issued by tribunal; during his 16-month trial, prosecutors set out to provide most thorough historical record yet of atrocities that took place in one week in July 1995; verdict is likely to affect current investigation of former Yugoslav president, Slobodan Milosevic, who is jailed in UN cell block on war-crimes charges related only to Kosovo; prosecutors want to include his support for Serb military offensives in Bosnia; photo; map (M)

headline: Rolim A. Amaro, 58, Dies; Built Up Brazil's TAM Airline
abstract: Rolim Adolfo Amaro, pioneering airline executive who played an important role in modernization of Brazil's aviation industry, dies at age 58, in helicopter crash; photo (M)

headline: Unemployment Rate Rises to Four-Year High in August
abstract: The U.S. unemployment rate surged in August to 4.9 percent from 4.5 percent as companies cut 113,000 workers from their payrolls.

headline: South Korean, Once Held as Spy, Plans a University in Pyongyang
abstract: YANJI, China—  Kim Chin Kyung was detained for six weeks in North Korea in 1998 and threatened with a death sentence by his interrogators.

headline: Kmart Falls After Posting a Second-Quarter Loss
abstract: A variety of retailers, including Kmart, reported declining sales today, reflecting consumers' increasingly cautious spending patterns

headline: Continental Airlines Reports a 72% Drop in Quarterly Profit
abstract: Continental Airlines reports 72 percent drop in second-quarter profit, to $42 million, which still surpasses Wall Street estimates; revenue dropped about 1 percent, to $2.56 million (M)

headline: World Briefing | The Americas: Argentina: Ex-President Accused
abstract: Argentina Pres Fernando de la Rua, struggling to contain economic and political crisis, accuses former Pres Raul Alfonsin of conspiring with opposition politicians to form new government after next month's congressional elections (S)

headline: NURSING HOME OWNER TO SELL SOME OPERATIONS IN FLORIDA
abstract: Beverly Enterprises agrees to sell 49 skilled nursing-home sites and four assisted living centers in Florida for $165 million in cash to NMC, affiliate of Vantage Medical and Formation Capital (S)

headline: DataBank; A Rally Undoes Some of the Damage
abstract: Roundup of week's financial markets; charts; table of rates and yields (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: September crude oil rises to $27.71 a barrel on expectations of strong summer motorist demand; graph; list of other commodity indexes (S)

headline: World Briefing | World: China Set To Join Trade Group
abstract: Negotiators on China's membership in World Trade Organization say major obstacles have been overcome, making it likely country can join group either this year or early in 2001 (S)

headline: Insurers Ask Help to Survive Future Losses
abstract: Insurance executives tell Congress that they have plenty of money to pay for about $40 billion of losses from terrorist attacks but that they urgently need help to provide coverage for possible future violence; some leading insurers argue that since terrorism has potential for enormous repeated financial blows, government should take responsibility for paying most expensive claims; say they are not seeking bailout but assistance in confronting immeasurable financial abyss; General Re chairman, Ronald E Ferguson, and Chubb Corp chief executive, Dean R O'Hare, comment; photo (M)

headline: Buy, Buy. Sigh.
abstract: Joan Mary Macey letter on June 14 article about eBay

headline: Macedonians Kidnapped By Guerrillas Tell of Abuse
abstract: Human Rights Watch releases detailed interviews with Macedonian road workers kidnapped and tortured by Albanian guerrillas; photo (S)

headline: A Gadfly, With or Without Hair
abstract: RANGOON—  His appetite for sex, drugs and revolution may pale in comparison with rockers elsewhere, but in Burma, Zaw Win Htut stands out as a rebel who must fight to keep the government out of his hair.

headline: Bush Flatly States U.S. Will Pull Out of Missile Treaty
abstract: Pres Bush says flatly that United States will withdraw from 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty but insists he has no specific timetable about when he would scrap agreement so his administration can begin testing missile defense system, which treaty forbids; Bush's strong wording may be tactic to pressure Russian Pres Vladimir Putin to begin serious negotiations or risk getting nothing in return for agreeing to treaty's demise; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing
abstract: AUSTRALIA NEW ZEALAND: WINERY PURSUIT DROPPED Australia's second-largest brewer, Lion Nathan, has abandoned a yearlong struggle to buy the Montana Group, one of New Zealand's largest wine companies. Lion Nathan will sell its 43 percent stake in Montana to Allied Domecq of Britain, which has been competing for control of the winery. Topping Allied's bid of 4.80 New Zealand dollars a share ($2.12) would have been too expensive, Gordon Cairns, Lion Nathan's chief, said yesterday. After the transaction, Allied will hold 70 percent of Montana, and Lion Nathan will make 127 million New Zealand dollars ($56.2 million) on the sale of its stake. Lion Nathan has identified other opportunities in the wine business, Mr. Cairns said.   Becky Gaylord (NYT) EUROPE FINLAND: SETBACK FOR SAMPO Sampo, Finland's largest insurer, suffered a setback in its $2.3 billion bid for its Norwegian rival Storebrand, when Norwegian regulators refused to lift a rule that requires financial companies to acquire more than 90 percent of a target's outstanding stock. Only 86.3 percent of Storebrand investors have turned over their shares to Sampo, not enough to secure a deal under the requirements. The Norwegian government was widely expected to enforce the rule, in part because it did not want the country's largest insurer to fall into foreign ownership. Den Norske Bank, Norway's largest bank, has hindered the deal by refusing to sell its almost 10 percent stake in Storebrand to Sampo.   Suzanne Kapner (NYT) FRANCE: TEST FLIGHT FOR CONCORDE Air France took a Concorde jet for a test flight for the first time since one crashed into a hotel shortly after takeoff on July 25, 2000, killing 113 people. A burst tire was blamed. To prevent similar accidents, the plane now has tougher tires and Kevlar-lined fuel tanks. The test plane broke the sound barrier on a two-and-a-half-hour flight over the Atlantic, but did not reach its Mach 2 cruising speed. British Airways has alr

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Dim Outlook By Central Bank
abstract: Bank of Japan lowers its assessment of country's economy, raising speculation that central bank may be forced to further ease monetary policy (S)

headline: Fighting Sex Harassment, and Stigma, in Japan
abstract: Interview with female university student who successfully sued Osaka prefectural governor Knock Yokoyama in 1999 for sexually molesting her while she worked on his campaign; her continued need for anonymity is indicative of ostracism and loss many Japanese women fear if they protest groping and other sexual harassment too vigorously in society where male power and privilege are deeply rooted; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: France: Meeting On Tunnel Migrants
abstract: The French interior minister and his British counterpart met in Paris to discuss the continuing rush of illegal immigrants from France into Britain, many of whom have sneaked through the Channel Tunnel as stowaways on trucks and trains. Britain has blamed France because it has allowed refugees to be housed in a Red Cross shelter near the tunnel while France says Britain's asylum  policy is the real magnet for them. Britain wants the French shelter closed; France proposes to set up another shelter farther from the tunnel entrance.     Marlise Simons (NYT)

headline: Bristol-Myers To Take Stake In Exelixis Inc.
abstract: Bristol-Myers Squibb will take one percent stake in Exelixis Inc, genomics company, and work with it to develop new class of cancer drugs; will pay $20 million for $10 million worth of stock (M)

headline: Stocks Fall on Consumer Confidence Report
abstract: Stocks closed sharply lower today after a new report showed that consumer confidence slid unexpectedly this month
