headline: Lost-Income Claims May Exceed $10 Billion
abstract: Insurance industry analysts say claims by businesses for lost income and relocation expenses may run to over $10 billion from terrorist attacks in New York City, possibly exceeding direct costs of damage to destroyed buildings and offices; extraordinary losses are expected to raise business insurance rates around US; lawyers have begun collecting data for clients' claims in anticipation of long battles with insurers (M)

headline: NATO Conditionally Approves Troops for Macedonia
abstract: NATO ministers approve sending full 3,500-soldier task force into Macedonia to help disarm Albanian insurgents; Gen Joseph W Ralsston recommends deployment, reporting that cease-fire is generally holding (M)

headline: Industry Standard Becomes Latest Casualty in Dot-Com Bust
abstract: The Industry Standard, a magazine that for much of its life chronicled and enjoyed the fruits of the dot-com boom, has published its last issue

headline: Interpublic Continues To Realign Operations
abstract: Interpublic Group of Companies merges agencies within one of its four main units, McCann-Erickson World Group (S)

headline: Spy Charges Still Puzzle Freed Chinese Scholar
abstract: Gao Zhan, Chinese citizen with permit for permanent residence in United States, returns home to McLean, Va, after being detained for more than five months in Chinese jail; she strongly denies charge by Chinese government that she committed espionage; she was released only after Pres Bush and Secretary of State Colin L Powell intervened with Chinese leaders; Gao's case is of particular concern to other scholars who do research in China because collecting photocopied materials, as Gao did, is one of their main activities; it is often unclear what China considers secret; photo (M)

headline: Egypt Seeking U.S. Monitors To Help End Mideast Violence
abstract: Egyptian envoy Osama el-Baz urges Bush administration to take more active role in Mideast and to weigh sending American monitors to defuse Israeli-Palestinian violence, meetings with Sec Colin L Powell and national security adviser Condoleezza Rice, Washington; seeks to salvage failed cease-fire in region; photo (M)

headline: XEROX ELIMINATES DIVIDEND TO SAVE $140 MILLION A YEAR
abstract: Xerox Corp eliminates its common-stock dividend to save $140 million per year (S)

headline: Japan's Figures Officially Show A Contraction
abstract: Japanese government reports that economy is again in recession, with second-quarter output of goods and services contracting at 3.2 percent annual rate; Prime Min Junichiro Koizumi announces package of emergency spending increases designed to contain economic slowdown; Japan's credit rating is slowly eroding because of continued buildup of government debt; opacity of its financial system and size of its bad-debt problem prevent analysts from gauging extent of Japan's economic troubles; benchmark Nikkei 225 stock index threatens to close below level of Dow Jones industrial average for first time since 1957; public management ministry estimates actual unemployment rate at 11 percent, despite government statistics indicating a 5 percent rate, still highest in nearly 50 years; some Japanese voice doubts that Koizumi's efforts are genuine or will be fruitful; graph; photo (M)

headline: Analysts' Fuzzy Math
abstract: Talk about bad-hair days: Palm Computing had one that lasted the entire month of March. As though the tech-industry slowdown weren't enough, the company shot itself in the foot, the knee and the belly button by announcing its 2001 palmtop models months before they were available. Sales of the existing models tanked, forcing Palm to slash prices and announce two waves of layoffs. I'll be the first to admit that the company's got some issues; too many talented employees have left for sunnier corporate pastures.

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Under pressure from a Dutch court, the fight over control of the Gucci Group may be resolved.
abstract: Dispute between Francois Pinault and Bernard Arnault for control of Gucci Group has proved embarrassment for Dutch legal system; Dutch investigators have been examining whether Gucci, which is incorporated in Netherlands, acted improperly when it issued shares to Pinault-Printemps-Redoute, which is controlled by Pinault, to thwart takeover by Arnault's LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Intelsat Names New Chairman
abstract: Intelsat Ltd names John V Sponyoe, chief executive of Lockheed Martin Global Telecommunications, as its chairman; photo (M)

headline: Putin, Sizing Up Bush, Says the Retinue 'Makes the King'
abstract: Russian Pres Vladimir Putin says he believes Pres Bush relies strongly on powerful aides, but that this circle is still struggling over its priorities, especially with regard to 1972 ABM Treaty; tells Finnish newspaper he finds Bush 'comfortable and substantive partner,' but that retinue 'makes the king'; expresses concern that US believes it does not need negotiations, but says Russia will not overreact if US does withdraw from ABM treaty; photo of Putin arriving in Finland (M)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: World Briefing

headline: United Business Buys Roper Starch
abstract: NOP World to acquire Roper Starch Woldwide for $88 million in cash (S)

headline: In Rome, O'Neill Plans To Laud U.S. Economy
abstract: Treasury Secretary Paul H O'Neill says he will carry message of optimism about US economy to meeting of Group of Seven in Rome, where main topic will be faltering world economy, news conference; suggests that Bush administration would like to see Europe and Japan do more to live up to their roles as 'locomotives' for world growth; photo (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: HALLMARK CARDS INC., Kansas City, Mo., acquired the rights to the American Girl brand of books and dolls from Mattel Inc., El Segundo, Calif. Terms were not disclosed.    WELLMAN INC., Shrewsbury, N.J., a maker of polyester for packaging and fabrics, said it had adopted a plan to ward off any hostile takeover attempt through Aug. 31. If any person or company acquires 20 percent or more of the company's shares, common stock purchase rights will be distributed as a dividend at the rate of one right for each share owned.

headline: World Business Briefing
abstract: EUROPE GERMANY: ECONOMY STALLS The German econ- omy stagnated in the second quarter in yet more proof that Europe has not been immune from the economic slowdown in the United States. The federal statistics office said gross domestic product in the second quarter had grown 0.6 percent from a year earlier, the lowest level in more than four years, from 1.4 percent in the first quarter. However, the office said, investment, particularly in construction, was stagnant and exports declined. Analysts said, however, that one positive number was the 0.9 percent increase in consumer spending.   (Reuters) BRITAIN: PROFIT UP AT ROLLS-ROYCE Helped by increased sales of commercial jet engines and spare parts, Rolls-Royce said its first-half profit rose more than fourfold. Net income increased to £85 million ($123 million), or 5.35 pence a share, compared with £18 million, or 1.15 pence a share, last year. Sales grew 15 percent, to £3 billion ($4.3 billion). Sales of commercial jet engines grew 40 percent, and the number of engines already on planes that require spare parts and servicing is on the rise, the company said. The No. 2 engine maker in the world, Rolls is winning market share at the expense of Pratt & Whitney, a unit of United Technologies, which is the industry's third largest. General Electric remains the market leader.   Suzanne Kapner (NYT) FINLAND: LAYOFFS AT SONERA Finland's largest mobile phone network, Sonera, plans to lay off about 1,000 people, or nearly 9 percent of its work force, to cut costs. The company said the moves would help reduce operating costs by about 60 million euros ($55 million), but no timetable was announced.   (AP) PORTUGAL: JOINT AUTO VENTURE Portugal's biggest oil and gas company, Galpenergia SGPS, and Midas Inc. are discussing a joint venture to open as many as 60 car parts and service stores. The discussions follow the successful opening of a test-store two mon

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Treasury bond prices fall on lessened expectations for further rate reductions; 10-year Treasury note yields 5.16 percent; list of key rates; graph of tax-exempt yields (S)

headline: Bush Senior, on His Son's Behalf, Reassures Saudi Leader
abstract: Bush administration official says former Pres George Bush, acting on his son's behalf, called Saudi Crown Prince Abdullah in June to reassure him that Pres Bush's 'heart' is in right place on Mideast; says he acted after Abdullah complained that administration is too close to Israeli Prime Min Ariel Sharon; photos (M)

headline: Investing; Two Faces Of a Bond That Beats Inflation
abstract: Type of Treasury bond intended to protect investors from inflation prompts turf war involving some of Wall Street's most prominent firms; at issue is whether Treasury inflation-protected securities, commonly known as TIPS, are too good a deal for investors; photo; graph (M)

headline: Pope, in Central Asia, Speaks Out Against Any Overzealous Military Response by the U.S.
abstract: Traveling in Kazakhstan, Pope John Paul II speaks out against overzealous military response to Sept 11 terrorist attacks; says religion must never be used as reason for conflict and is concerned about deepening divide between Christians and Muslims; photo (M)

headline: Microsoft Asks Court For Review
abstract: Microsoft Corp asks appeals court to reconsider important part of decision three weeks ago in antitrust case about product design that could have significant implications for new operating system company plans to begin selling soon; asks court to reconsider its conclusion that Microsoft improperly comingled software code between its Internet Explorer browser and its Windows operating system in such way as to make it functionally difficult to remove browser (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Redback Names New Chief
abstract: Redback Networks names Kevin DeNuccio, former executive at Cisco Systems, as president and chief executive (S)

headline: Australia's Tough Line on Refugees Reflects Policy Reversal
abstract: SINGAPORE—  When tens of thousands of Vietnamese fled by boat after the Communist takeover of South Vietnam in 1975, Australia was in the forefront of international moves to accept them and condemn action by some Southeast Asian countries to prevent the refugees from landing.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Bank's Profit Falls
abstract: Lloyds TSB, Britain's fourth-largest bank, reports fall in first-half profit of 12 percent, to $1.84 billion; increases its reserve for potential problem loans (M)

headline: Hip Implant Maker to Offer Shares to Litigants
abstract: Sulzer Medica, Swiss manufacturer of orthopedic appliances, offers new shares in company to people who received defective Inter-Op knee and hip implants and have needed corrective surgery; proposals is part of $780 million class-action settlement before federal judge in Cleveland (M)

headline: JEFFERIES GROUP TO ACQUIRE LAWRENCE HELFANT
abstract: Jefferies Group, securities firm specializing in institutional trading, acquires Lawrence Helfant LLC, expanding its trading capabilities on New York Stock Exchange (S)

headline: Article 2001080490913439223 -- No Title
abstract: Find a Job            Post a Job            Find a Home            Personals            All Classifieds                International          -     Africa          -     Americas          -     Asia Pacific          -     Europe          -    Middle East           National            Politics            Business            Technology            Science            Health            Arts            Sports            New York Region            Weather            Obituaries            NYT Front Page            Corrections                 Editorials/Op-Ed            Readers' Opinions

headline: PRAECIS PHARMACEUTICALS ENDS TESTS OF PAIN DRUG
abstract: Praecis Pharmaceuticals Inc says it will not proceed with trials of drug for chronic back pain after test fails to show it worked (S)

headline: Getting Away From It All, at Least for a Little While
abstract: It's summertime, and that means the beach and other vacation spots beckon workers away from the office. But with a weak economy, high gasoline prices early in the season and higher costs for meals and lodging, some vacations may be scaled b

headline: Webdenda: Executive Changes in Media
abstract: Rebecca Hill was named to the new post of international marketing manager at National Geographic magazine, Paris, owned by the National Geographic Society. She had been senior European media planner at the Media Planning Group France, Paris, part of Havas Advertising.

headline: US Air, Denied United Merger, to Sketch New Strategy
abstract: US Airways chairman, Stephen M Wolf, and chief executive, Rakesh Gangwal, will sketch out airline's future with group of Wall Street analysts, who have presented laundry list of things carrier could or should do to buttress its position in potentially lucrative East Coast markets against bigger carriers and lower-cost competitors; analysts seem less than confident that carrier can put together coherent strategy to pull it off (M)

headline: A Charge Results in a Loss at El Paso Gas
abstract: El Paso Corp reports loss of $93 million in second quarter, compared with profit of $261 million year earlier; profit from operations increased to $413 million from $294 million year ago; revenue increased 31 percent, to $13.4 billion (S)

headline: Setting Out The Snares For Hackers
abstract: Nonprofit Honeynet research project enlists expert volunteers to lay traps for predatory computer hackers and study their methods; was started as hobby by security engineer Lance Spitzner; hopes to raise awareness of risks posed by such hackers, even to home computers; has been sharing it research publicly, through series of papers released on Internet and in forthcoming book; Spitzner comments; photo (M)

headline: Train Hits Rebel Mine In Angola; Scores Die
abstract: At least 152 people die in rebel attack on train south of Angola's capital of Luanda; train, with about 500 people aboard, reportedly hit land mine; at least 150 more reported wounded; National Union for the Total Independence of Angola takes responsibility for attack; maps (M)

headline: EASTMAN CHEMICAL TO CLOSE ALABAMA PLANT WITH 75 JOBS
abstract: Eastman Chemical, largest producer of plastics used in soda bottles, will close plant in Moundville, Ala, eliminating 75 jobs, as it continues to cut costs (S)

headline: Economy Grew at Slowest Pace in Eight Years in 2nd Quarter
abstract: Economic growth in the second quarter of the year was even slower than the government had reported initially, the Commerce Department said today in a scheduled revision of its own estimates

headline: Korea to Ease Restrictions On Who Can Invest in Banks
abstract: South Korean government, in major concession to demands of South Korean business leaders, will remove some longstanding restraints on ownership of banks by nation's leading conglomerates; enterprises will have to shift their focus from manufacturing to finance if they wish to increase their stakes in banks; those stakes are now limited to 4 percent (M)

headline: A Day After Seeing Putin, a Harder-Line Bush Emerges
abstract: President Bush said today that ''time is of the essence'' in his new arms talks with Moscow and warned that he would move ahead with testing missile shield technology even if he did not reach an agreement that would scrap the Antiballistic Missile Treaty of 1972.    Mr. Bush's comments came only a day after he and President Vladimir V. Putin agreed to begin ''consultations'' that would tie deep cuts in the nuclear arsenals of both nations to the discussions on new defensive technologies. They were much more toughly worded than anything he had said publicly in Mr. Putin's presence in Genoa, Italy.

headline: A War on a Small Scale, Possibly Long and Risky
abstract: Putting the use of overwhelming force aside, Pentagon planners are focusing on commando raids and limited air strikes to root out Osama bin Laden's terrorist network in Afghanistan.

headline: Business Travel; The long-term market for corporate jets continues to look up.
abstract: Business Travel column on bright prospects for long-term market for corporate jets; says airplane makers will produce record 775 corporate jets in 2001; holds from this year through 2010, production of corporate jets will increase 80 percent over previous 10 years (M)

headline: Court Again Rebuffs Microsoft On Bundling of Its Software
abstract: Federal appeals court refuses to consider its ruling that Microsoft illegally blended Internet browsing software with its monopoly product, Windows operating system; next stage contains deliberations regarding sanctions to impose on company (M)

headline: BellSouth's Account Is Opened for Review
abstract: BellSouth Corp has begun review of most of its advertising account, with spending estimated at $150 million to $200 million (S)

headline: Chinese President Is Optimistic About Relations With the U.S.
abstract: Pres Jiang Zemin says he concluded after single telephone conversation with George W Bush that he was president 'I could do business with'; Jiang, in rare interview, meets with publisher of The New York Times, Arthur Sulzberger Jr, plus senior editors, columnist and China-based correspondents of The Times, at his seaside retreat in Beidaihe, China; says United States and China should work to find common ground; delivers message of friendship, but gives no ground on areas of difference with US, including Taiwan, Tibet or human rights; suggests that foreigners do not understand China's goals and why it must adapt Communist rule to changing society, rather than scrap it altogether, as many in West might prefer; says there would be great chaos, and 1.2 billion Chinese people would go hungry, if China applied parliamentary democracy of Western world; insists China is developing its own model of democracy and human rights and extolls country's village-level elections; says direct elections for provincial or national leaders would be unrealistic, partly because 100 million of country's 1.26 billion people are illiterate; calls Falun Gong 'out-and-out cult' and accuses it of harming people's physical and mental health; says recently arrested Chinese-born scholars are members of Taiwanese spy organizations; says Taiwan's formal status as part of China would never be up for negotiations; warns that China might be forced to increase its small force of nuclear missiles if it perceives United States missile defense as threat; says he looks forward to Pres Bush's visit to China in October; photo (L)

headline: A creative executive, formerly of Kirshenbaum Bond, moves to Ogilvy & Mather in New York.
abstract: Bill Oberlander, formerly of Kirshenbaum Bond & Partners, will join New York office of Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide Advertising as one of five senior partners and executive creative director; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Commitment On Farms
abstract: Zimbabwe Min Stan Mudenge repeats commitment to ending widespread land occupations (S)

headline: PolyMedica Cites Federal Inquiry
abstract: PolyMedica Corp, leading maker of diabetes test kits, says federal authorities conduct criminal probe of its Liberty Medical Supply unit; holds unit's operations comply with law; probe reportedly involves possible Medicare and investor fraud (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Argentina: Music Bankruptcy
abstract: Musimundo, Argentine music retailer, which is controlled by Exxel Group, buyout firm, seeks protection from creditors after sales dropped 50 percent and financing dried up (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Debate Over G-8 Meeting
abstract: Italy's interior minister, Claudio Scajola, survives vote of confidence in conservative-dominated Senate, while accusations continue over violence at G-8 summit in Genoa; lower house of Parliament approves independent investigation into events, in which police shot and killed protestor (S)

headline: Money Trail To bin Laden Is Focus Of Germans
abstract: German police probe financial ties between two hijackers who rammed planes into World Trade Center and Mamoun Darkazani, Syrian who controls Hamburg bank account of Mamdouh Mahmud Salim, one of founders of Osama bin Laden's Al Qaeda terrorist network who faces trial in New York for role in terrorism conspiracy and stabbing prison guard; say Darkazani met several times with hijacker Marwan al-Shehhi (M)

headline: Microsoft Asks Court for Rehearing
abstract: The Microsoft Corporation asked a federal appeals court today to reconsider an important part of its decision about product design that could have significant implications on its new operating system

headline: Hewlett-Packard to Reduce Its Work Force by 6,000
abstract: Hewlett-Packard, a bellwether of consumer spending, said today that it would cut 6,000 jobs and that its revenue for the current quarter would be markedly lower than expected, with the company attributing the changes to further deterioration of economic conditions worldwide.    Carleton S. Fiorina, the chief executive of Hewlett-Packard, said revenue during the third quarter would be 14 percent to 16 percent lower than in the period a year earlier, which puts sales more than $1 billion lower than the company expected, according to industry analysts.

headline: Article 2001070992871112822 -- No Title
abstract: Untangling the Online Gaming Web

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Airline Cutbacks
abstract: South Korean carrier Asiana Airlines is cutting 3 of its 14 weekly flights to Los Angeles and eliminating several flights in Korea; will cut 360 jobs (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Slight Economic Growth
abstract: Hong Kong's economy grew 0.5 percent in second quarter compared with second quarter of 2000, smallest gain since first quarter of 1999 (S)

headline: Palestinians Reclaim West Bank Town After Israelis Withdraw
abstract: Exhausted but exultant, Palestinians reclaimed neighborhoods today in Beit Jala, the town that had been taken over for more than two days by Israeli troops

headline: Untangling the Online Gaming Web
abstract: As game design has improved, gaming sites have grown more accommodating, and home computers have gained in speed and power, playing online is becoming more popular

headline: U.S. Asks Israel To Pull Troops From Town In West Bank
abstract: Bush administration urges Israel to withdraw forces from Beit Jala in West Bank, and also calls on Palestinians to stop months of attacks from Beit Jala on Gilo neighborhood of Jerusalem; Israeli Defense Ministry announces that troops will stay indefinitely; US also seeks to ensure that Syria will not exploit tensions that have boiled over since Israel killed Mustafa Zibri, leader of Popular Front for Liberation of Palestine (M)

headline: MOTION FILED IN SALE OF RAYTHEON CONSTRUCTION UNIT
abstract: Motion Filed In Sale of Raytheon Constrï

headline: A Sri Lankan Cabinet Minister Meets With Tamil Rebel Leaders
abstract: Sri Lankan Aviation Min Jeyaraj Fernandopulle makes rare trip into territory held by separatist Tamil rebels to meet with rebel leaders just weeks after their group carried out devastating attack on country's only international airport; rebels and government have not held peace talks since 1995, and many Sri Lankans have assumed that Norwegian-brokered peace effort died with airport attack (M)

headline: 3 Russian Officers Disciplined for Roles in Chechen Assault
abstract: The Russian Army commander for Chechnya relieved a deputy of his duties and suspended two others in the wake of "mopping up" operations in two Chechen villages west of Grozny

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: EURO RISES***Euro gains as slowing German inflation reinforces expectations that European Central Bank will reduce interest rates; in New York, euro settles at 87.64 cents, up from 86.96 cents; graph; chart (S)

headline: 2 Paper Companies Agree to a Merger
abstract: Mead Corp acquires rival Westvaca Corp for $3 billion in stock; transaction is being billed as merger of equals; combined concern will be called MeadWestvaco; Mead's chairman, president and chief executive, Jerome F Tatar, will become chairman of combined company; Westvaco's chairman and chief executive, John A Luke Jr, will become chief executive and president (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Austria: Payment In Nazi Case
abstract: Austria makes first payment of $36 million to former Nazi slaves and forced laborers who worked in country during World War II (S)

headline: World Briefing | Middle East: Turkey: Broadcast Ban
abstract: Turkish government's broadcasting watchdog orders Germany's Deutsche Welle and Britain's BBC to stop their Turkish-language radio broadcasts into country (S)

headline: In the Footsteps Of Their Parents?
abstract: Brown University philosophy Prof Felicia Ackerman letter on Abby Ellin's July 15 article on planning for retirement holds reality is that not everyone lives to be old and healthy

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Police Misconduct
abstract: Italy's top police official, Gianni De Gennaro, blames police for 'episodic and individual' cases of brutality during G-8 summit in Genoa in July, when one protestor was fatally shot; says unlawful acts will be rigorously prosecuted, but continues to blame protestors (S)

headline: Macedonia Peace Talks Are Revived, but the Fighting Rages On
abstract: Pres Boris Trajkovski says talks to resolve crisis in Macedonia are back on track, even though shelling and shooting continues around northern mountains, where government troops and Albanian rebels have been fighting for four months; talks are aimed at meeting demands of Albanians, who say they do not have full rights to use their language, receive higher education or take part in government; NATO officials are conducting separate talks with armed parties to secure cease-fire (M)

headline: War-Weary Kashmiris Contemplate the Price of Peace
abstract: Kashmiri Muslims, whose impoverished young people have fueled separatist conflict for years, are now confronting fact that peace which almost everybody craves may require accepting fact of India's presence; photo; map; shifting perspectives are key factor in Prime Min Atal Behari Vajpayee's coming meeting with Pakistani leader, Gen Pervez Musharraf (M)

headline: A Spicy Welcome to the White House
abstract: In their first state dinner, Pres and Mrs Bush offer Pres Vicente Fox of Mexico and his wife, Marta, spicy meal of upscale Tex-Mex cuisine; among revelers is sizable Texas contingent, including Sens Phil Gramm and Kay Bailey Hutchison and Gov Rick Perry (M)

headline: Article 2001080490323098371 -- No Title
abstract: The New York Times: Technology Text Version                                                                                                          Find a Job            Post a Job            Find a Home            Personals            All Classifieds                 International            National            Politics            Business           Technology          -     E-Business          -     Circuits          -     Columns            Science            Health            Arts            Sports            New York Region            Weather            Obituaries            NYT Front Page            Corrections                 Editorials/Op-Ed            Readers' Opinions

headline: Web Sales of Airline Tickets Are Making Hefty Advances
abstract: Sales of airline tickets on Internet are gaining ground as travelers are lured with discounts, last-minute specials and bonus miles; more than almost any other industry, airlines are still pushing their customers to buy online and are willing to reward them for doing so; travelers will spend estimated $14 billion online this year, or 14 percent of their total airline spending, up from nine percent last year; charts of online ticketing, Web sites and sample prices (M)

headline: Rumsfeld Says Iraq Has Improved Its Air Defenses
abstract: Iraq has rebuilt and improved its air defenses since American and British planes flew strikes against command centers in February

headline: ABBOTT ASKS FOR FORMAL APPROVAL OF THYROID DRUG
abstract: Abbott Laboratories asks Food and Drug Administration for formal approval of its Synthroid thyroid drug, one of most widely prescribed medicines, after more than 40 years of sales (S)

headline: ACCENTURE PLANS TO ELIMINATE 1,500 POSITIONS
abstract: Accenture, consulting firm formerly known as Andersen Consulting, will lay off 1,500 employees because of weak economic conditions and low worker turnover (S)

headline: World Briefing | United Nations: New War Crimes Tribunal For Sierra Leone
abstract: UN Security Council approves dispatch of planning delegation to Sierra Leone, which is going to form tribunal to prosecute about 20 leaders accused of atrocities during 10-year civil war (S)

headline: Executive Changes at Media Firms
abstract: Dave Chapman was named to head a new New York office of Wolfe/Doyle Advertising as vice president and director for client services. He had been vice president and account director at Foote, Cone & Belding, part of the FCB Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Record Labels Move To Short-Circuit Trial
abstract: Major record labels ask federal Judge Marily Patel to issue summary judgment in their copyright case against Napster (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Nuclear Plant Help
abstract: Japan's Mitsubishi Heavy Industries agrees to help build nuclear reactors for Westinghouse Electric, which is trying to revive orders for nuclear power plants; Westinghouse, which is owned by British Nuclear Fuels, hopes stricter environmental regulations on use of fossil fuels will revive interest in nuclear power; no reactors have been ordered in US in 20 years (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Nintendo Delays Gamecube Release
abstract: Nintendo delays North American release of its GameCube video game console until Sunday before Thanksgiving, but says it will ship about 25 percent more of them than originally planned (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Legislators Push For Action On Domains
abstract: House Energy and Commerce Committee calls for expedited process to add more extensions, known as top-level domains, to Internet's address system (S)

headline: The Apple Cube Entered The Museum as It Exited Stores
abstract: Museum of Modern Art's design collection acquires Apple Computer's G4 Cube computer, which has gone out of production because of disappointing sales; photo (S)

headline: U.S. Will Drop Objections To China's Missile Buildup
abstract: Bush administration will reportedly seek to overcome Chinese opposition to its missile defense program by dropping its objections to China's plans to build up its small fleet of nuclear missiles; senior official says that US and China might also discuss resuming underground nuclear tests to assure safety and reliability of their arsenals; this appears to mark significant change in American policy, which for years has been to discourage China and all other nations from increasing size or quality of their nuclear arsenals, and from nuclear tests of any kind; officials say purpose of new approach is to convince China that administration's plans for missile shield are not aimed at undercutting China's arsenal, but rather at countering threats from so-called rogue states; word of new approach draws scathing criticism from Sen Joseph R Biden Jr, chairman of Senate Foreign Relations Committee, who says administration is willing to jeopardize 50-year policy of trying to control nuclear weapons in order to build national missile defense (M)

headline: Business Travel; Some changes in corporate policies could have long-term consequences for airlines and hotels.
abstract: Business Travel Coalition head Kevin P Mitchell holds convergence of outrages against business travelers are hurting airlines; cites anger at last year's record air delays, sharp rise in business air fares since 1996 and poor passenger service; says companies have begun reviews likely to have long-term effects on freewheeling business-travel market (M)

headline: Cisco Earnings Drop Sharply But Match Expectations
abstract: Cisco Systems reports fiscal fourth-quarter net income of $163 million on $4.3 billion revenue, in line with expectations; earned $1.2 billion a year ago; company's assessment of likelihood of recovery is imprecise; shares slip in after-hours trading, following release of report; photo (M)

headline: Group Honors Actors and TV Shows
abstract: Coalition of advertisers interested in spurring production of prime-time television shows intended to appeal to multigenerational audiences present Family Television Awards; winners include The Miracle Worker, Gilmore Girls, Survivor, Malcolm in the Middle and The West Wing (S)

headline: Mowing Lawns Wasn't Enough
abstract: Callidus Software president-chief executive Reed Taussig's My First Job column on doing landscaping in 1970's; photos (M)

headline: Sri Lankan President Makes a Deal to Save Her Government
abstract: Sri Lanka's president, Chandrika Kumaratunga, makes deal for support of small leftist party, People's Liberation Front, in effort to save her government from collapse; deal could curtail her ability to undertake peace initiatives in conflict that has killed more than 62,000 Sri Lankans; historians and political analysts say her decision to strike bargain with People's Liberation Front is latest sign of her desperation to cling to power; note that group is generally held responsible for assassinating her husband in late 1980's (M)

headline: JAKARTA ASSEMBLY MEETS TO REMOVE CHIEF FROM OFFICE
abstract: Indonesia's legislature begins proceedings to remove Pres Abdurrahman Wahid from office and end short, tempestuous rule of country's first democratically elected leader in generation; Vice Pres Megawati Sukarnoputri, daughter of country's founding president Sukarno and country's most popular politician, will be successor; Wahid defiantly remains in palace, refusing to recognize validity of parliamentary action; tanks and troops surround presidential palace in Jakarta; confrontation caps six months of political turmoil that began with charge of corruption and evolved into general condemnation of Wahid's term; assembly's aggressive stance signals emerging new political order in which legislature asserts its constitutional role as highest government institution after nearly half-century of strongman rule; photos (M)

headline: Couples Looking to Adopt Find a Shifting Spotlight
abstract: Internet is altering way babies are adopted even if most adoptions are still done through agencies; mothers who once gave up their babies without much say are playing active roles, interviewing adoption agencies, screening and often meeting prospective parents; prospective parents use Internet to maximize their exposure, knowing that adopting depends less on having impeccable qualifications than on being known; tips for navigating online adoption process; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Japan Relations 'Damaged'
abstract: Foreign Min Han Seung Soo of South Korea says Japan must take 'sincere steps' to mend relations before Prime Min Junichiro Koizumi can expect to meet Pres Kim Dae Jung; cites Koizumi's visit to war shrine and refusal to demand textbook revisions; latest incident is patrol boat battering Korean fishing vessel allegedly fishing in Japanese waters (S)

headline: Drug's Removal Exposes Holes In Europe's Net
abstract: Bayer AG's recall of its cholesterol drug Baycol startles regulators in Europe and exposes considerable confusion there over who is responsible for dealing with such issues; as recently as June, regulators from countries in European Union decided that problems with drug could be handled through new warnings to doctors and patients; Bayer is German company, but its drug is licensed in Europe by British authorities, with neighboring countries adopting its decision; Britain's Medicines Control Agency does not have main responsibility for monitoring drug's safety after it has been approved; that is supposed to be shared by each government in European Union (M)

headline: Internet Cash Company Suspends Its Operations
abstract: Flooz.com, Internet company that allowed customers to buy online currency and use it at various Web sites, closes its Web site and weighs ceasing operations (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: North Korea: Peace Group Alleges Pressure
abstract: Delegation of South Korean peace activists reports North Korean officials have pressed them to attend ceremonies at new monument dedicated to Korean reunification on terms not acceptable to South (S)

headline: Some Families Doubt Sincerity of Cantor
abstract: Cantor Fitzgerald dropped its missing employees from payroll on Sept 15, and whether that was prudent or crass depends in large part on one's view of Howard W Lutnick, chairman of firm, which lost almost 70 percent of its New York staff in attacks on World Trade Center; Lutnick's gritty reputation at first was largely obscured by halo effect of his tearful public pledge to keep devastated firm alive so that it could care for more than 600 families bereft by disaster; Cantor families are starting to match those televised promises against details of firm's benefits and are smudging Lutnick's new image with rancor and suspicion; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; N.A.S.D. Rule Would Oversee Analysts on TV
abstract: The National Association of Securities Dealers said yesterday that it had proposed a rule requiring that equity analysts at the nation's brokerage firms clearly and prominently disclose to investors the potential conflicts of interest that may influence their stock recommendations.     The proposal requires, for the first time, detailed disclosure of personal holdings and investment banking relationships by analysts promoting stocks on television or radio broadcasts, in speeches or other public appearances. The same disclosure requirements would also apply to any sales materials produced by a brokerage firm, including advertisements and research reports.

headline: Rescuing Sri Lankan Heritage From War's Ashes
abstract: Jaffna Public Library, one of great depositories of Tamil people's history and culture, burned 20 years ago by Sinhalese police officers, is being rebuilt; until recently, library stood as gutted monument to wrongs done to Tamils, who are mostly Hindu, by Sinhalese, who are mainly Buddhist and make up almost three-quarters of Sri Lanka, island nation south of India; photo of library; map (L)

headline: Troubled Ansett Airways Files For Bankruptcy Protection
abstract: Ansett Airways, the only national competitor to Qantas, Australia's biggest airline, filed for the Australian equivalent of Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection today as its financially troubled principal owner, Air New Zealand, searched with growing desperation for a buyer or new financing for it.

headline: MAYTAG TO SELL COMMERCIAL COOKING UNIT TO MIDDLEBY
abstract: Maytag Corp sells its commercial-cooking business, G S Blodgett, to Middleby Corp for $95 million in cash and notes, less than Maytag paid for it four years ago (S)

headline: U.S. BALKS ON PLAN TO GET PLUTONIUM OUT OF WARHEADS
abstract: Program conceived by Clinton administration to rid world of 100 tons of American and Russian weapons-grade plutonium is likely to be abandoned by Bush administration; under plan first proposed in mid-1990's, 50 tons of American plutonium and 50 tons of Russian plutonium would be taken out of nuclear weapons and either converted into fuel for nuclear reactors or rendered useless for weapons by mixing it with highly radioactive nuclear waste; Bush administration denies program is dead but acknowledges it has difficulties, primarily financial; says issue is under review (M)

headline: Compressed Data; Travel Advisory for Russian Programmers
abstract: Russia, responding to July arrest of Dmitri Sklyarov in Las Vegas, warns Russian computer programmers that they could face arrest while in United States for violating abroad US 1998 digital copyright law; Sklyarov's lawyers hold his program for disabling electronic book encryption software is legal in Russia; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: India: Minister Resigns After Setback
abstract: Indian Supreme Court rules that appointment of Jayalalitha Jayaram as chief minister of Tamil Nadu State in May violated constitution; photo (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Steel Sales Decline
abstract: South Korea's Pohang Iron and Steel says sales in first half of year totaled $4.26 billion, drop of 4.8 percent from year earlier; says net profit was $271 million, down from $748 million year ago; chairman, Yoo Sang Boo, says he has no hopes of recovery this year (S)

headline: Enron Net Rose 40% in Quarter
abstract: Enron Corp says second-quarter profit rose 40 percent; net income rose to $404 million from $289 million year earlier; revenue almost tripled to $50.1 billion (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Holocaust Denier's Appeal Fails
abstract: British three-judge panel rejects appeal by hï

headline: Chief Is Selected For Crispin Office
abstract: Crispin Porter & Bogusky's new office in Los Angeles will be headed by Sally Hogshead (S)

headline: NEWPOWER SHARES PLUNGE AFTER REVENUE ESTIMATE IS CUT
abstract: Shares of NewPower Holdings fall 31 percent after venture, formed by Enron Corp to compete with other gas and electric utilities, lowers revenue predictions (S)

headline: Annual Reports, 2001: Scissors Not Required
abstract: National Investor Relations Institute reports that number of free samples, coupons and discount offers mailed to shareholders with annual company reports will decline below 2000 levels (S)

headline: Lenders Cancel
abstract: International Monetary Fund and World Bank cancel annual meetings, citing security concerns about event that attracts many financial ministers and heads of government to Washington (S)

headline: A Bicycling Mystery: Head Injuries Piling Up
abstract: New data from Consumer Product Safety Commission shows number of head injuries among bicycle riders has increased 10 percent since 1991, in period when bicycle helmet use has risen sharply and ridership has declined; given ridership decline, rate of head injuries per active cyclist has increased 51 percent just as bicycle helmets have become widespread; safety experts say helmets do not prevent accidents from happening, but are extremely effective at reducing severity of head injuries when they do occur; say helmets can reduce severity of brain injuries by as much as 88 percent; experts are mystified as to why injuries are on rise; some cycling advocates contend that rising numbers of aggressive drivers are at fault; others suggest that many riders wear helmets improperly; specialists in risk analysis say riders using helmets may feel inflated sense of security and take more risks; photos; chart (L)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Holocaust Memorial Campaign
abstract: Newspaper and billboard advertising seeking donations for Berlin Holocaust Memorial underlines importance of undertaking by warning that many people believe Holocaust never happened and that even more could in 20 years (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Suharto Son Accused
abstract: Indonesia police declare that Hutomo Mandala Putra, fugitive son of former Pres Suharto, is a suspect in recent assassination of judge who sentenced him last year to 18 months in prison for corruption (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Natural gas prices fall almost 7 percent, to $2.971 per million BTU's; graph (S)

headline: Closing the Window On Pop-Up Advertising
abstract: Q. How can I disable or block those pesky pop-up advertisements from Web pages?    A. The persistence of pop-up advertisements, those extra little windows that pop up on top of or under your Web browser as you try to surf, seems to have inspired many programmers to write free software that stifles the popping.

headline: Return of Computer 'Worm' Feared Today
abstract: Computer security experts and federal officials warn rogue computer program Code Red, dormant since it infected some 350,00 computers July 19, is about to strike again; say attack could slow Internet speed; program, known as worm, attacks IIS Web server software on machines running some versions of Microsoft's Windows operating system; few users seem to have installed patches offered by Microsoft and others to fix problem; photo (M)

headline: Oracle Sees Sales Off 15% In Key Software Category
abstract: Oracle Corp, maker of business software, says threat of war could drive sales of its software licenses down 15 percent, sharper decline than company expected before terrorist attacks last week (M)

headline: Western TV May Be Nearer For Chinese
abstract: AOL Time Warner and News Corp move closer to long-sought goal of receiving permission from Chinese government to broadcast their television programs in China; Star TV, which is owned by News Corp, is already seen by many Chinese viewers who have illegal satellite dishes; Hong Kong-based Phoenix Satellite Television, in which Star TV holds stake, is already allowed to broadcast over cable television systems in Pearl River Delta region of Guangdong province; AOL Time Warner has stake in China Entertainment Television, satellite TV station based in Hong Kong, which broadcasts over cable systems in smaller area of Guangdong; China is considering giving limited rights to AOL and News Corp, which would allow them to reach millions of cable subscribers in Guangdong; Chinese government wants assurances that Chinese-run channel carrying government-approved English-language news broadcasts, as well as Chinese cooking programs and Mandarin-language classes, will be available to viewers in US (M)

headline: Northrop Grumman Hires New Agency
abstract: Northrop Grumman Hires New Agenc

headline: Fidelity Has Reassigned Certain Agency Duties
abstract: Fidelity Investments has divided advertising duties handled for several years by Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos among its other agencies, including Arnold Worldwide and Gotham, part of World Group division of Interpublic Group of Companies; Fidelity is estimated to spend $120 million to $150 million annually (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Microstrategy Settlement Is Approved
abstract: Delaware Chancery Court approves settlement of shareholder suit charging MicroStrategy directors misled shareholders about company's financial health; settlement calls for company to add independent directors with finance experience to board audit committee and for three officers to contribute $10 million in stock (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Deep Cuts At Excite
abstract: At Home Corp, beleaguered high-speed Internet access and Internet portal company, will eliminate 500 jobs, or 27 percent of its work force; will also eliminate 300 employees working on Excite portal (S)

headline: When You're Cooking More Than a Meal
abstract: Bingham Dana, law firm, seeks to build stronger relationships among its employees by holding cooking workshops conducted by Loyalty Factor, Boston consulting firm (M)

headline: Colombian Cattle Ranchers Set to Exploit a Big Break
abstract: Colombian cattle ranchers begin major push toward increasing beef exports, exploiting their herds' certification as free of foot-and-mouth disease, unlike rival nations'; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Compaq to Miss Forecasts And to Cut 1,500 More Jobs  Compaq Computer said it expected to report lower-than-projected earnings and sales for the second quarter and that it would eliminate 1,500 more jobs than previously announced.    Compaq blamed a sharp slump in the European business market for a 9 percent drop in worldwide sales. Profits and gross margins also suffered because of price competition at home, the company said. [Page C8.]

headline: Union Moves To Hold Vote At Nissan Plant In Tennessee
abstract: United Automobile Workers asks federal officials to hold vote on unionization among workers at Nissan factory in Smyrna, Tenn, setting up nation's first such election in dozen years at foreign-owned auto plant; workers at factory voted by 2-1 ratio in 1989 not to join union (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Kyrgyzstan: Clean-Up At Uranium Sites
abstract: European Union starts work to reduce exposure to radiation and prevent pollution from estimated 3.2 million cubic yards of uranium tailings from Soviet-era processing plant on Malii-Suu River in Kyrgyzstan (S)

headline: World Business Briefs
abstract: EUROPE BRITAIN: BANK'S PROFIT IS UP First-half profit at Stand- ard Chartered P.L.C. rose 11 percent as the bank increased profit from its credit cards and from new units in India. A slowdown in Asia may hurt second-half earnings, the company said. Net income rose to $404 million, or 40 cents a share, from $363 million, or 36 cents, a year earlier. Slumping Asian economies forced the bank to earmark a greater-than- expected $269 million for possible loan defaults. The chief executive, Rana Talwar, bought credit card assets in Hong Kong and businesses in South Asia and the Middle East to diversify away from mortgage lending in Hong Kong and eastern Asia.   (Bloomberg News) BELGIUM: TRAVEL ACQUISITION The European Commission has asked the Cendant Corporation to resubmit its notification of the proposed acquisition of the electronic travel reservation firm Galileo International Inc., because its first notification omitted information about the car rental market in Europe, a commission spokesman said. Competitors fear Cendant will be able to use information about them gathered on Galileo, which makes reservations in 200 hotel chains and 40 car rental agencies around the world.   Paul Meller (NYT) BRITAIN: SPINOFF INCOME The home-improvement retailer Kingfisher said it expected to earn £1.1 billion, or $1.57 billion, from the spinoff of its Woolworth's stores, the sale of Superdrug and a sale and leaseback of 180 stores. Kingfisher is shedding businesses to focus on home- improvement and consumer electronics. Last month, the company sold the Superdrug chain to Kruidvat Beheer of the Netherlands for £310 million ($442 million). Shareholders are expected to vote on the spinoff of Woolworth's on Aug. 24. If approved, the shares are scheduled to begin trading on Aug. 28.   Suzanne Kapner (NYT) AMERICAS ARGENTINA: LOAN SWAP AGREEMENT Argentina reached agreement with banks to exchange $1.32 billion of maturing governme

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Analog Devices Warns On Sales And Profit
abstract: Analog Devices Inc, maker of high-speed communications chips, is reducing its estimates for third quarter because of canceled orders (S)

headline: Executive Changes at Media Firms
abstract: Rene Huey-Lipton was named marketplace planning director at GSD&M, Austin, Tex., part of the Omnicom Group. She had been vice president and planning director at the San Francisco office of FCB Worldwide, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Brazil's real declines, settling at 2.4725 to the dollar; graph (S)

headline: New Delhi Journal; Modern India Gazes in Wonder at Its Gaudy Past
abstract: Exhibition of fabled jewels of Nizam of Hyderabad opens to public in New Delhi, India; collection was purchased by Indian government in 1995 after two decades of litigation with heirs of the princely state, which merged with India in 1948; collection is estimated to be worth more than $2 billion; map; photos (M)

headline: Four Villages Are Seized By the Rebels In Macedonia
abstract: Albanian rebels in Macedonia have taken control of four villages in the western part of the country, not far from the border with Kosovo, an army spokesman said today, and are apparently preparing for a new fight with government forces.     The rebel advance came as new international peace negotiators arrived in the Macedonian capital, Skopje, warning that Macedonia's Albanian and Slav leaders must take charge and prevent the rebellion from exploding into a full-blown civil war.

headline: Added Rights For Indians In Mexico Take Effect
abstract: Law originally intended to expand rights of 10 million Indians in Mexico takes effect, but Congress waters down law so much that it pleases few people and infuriates many; law was at first intended to settle Zapatista uprising in Chiapas and grant measure of legal and social autonomy to indigenous people; lawmakers erase most of clauses that call for Indian autonomy over land and natural resources, leaving only general ban against racism (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Croatia: Deutsche Telekom Expands
abstract: Croatia agrees to sell Deutsche Telekmon added 16 percent of nation's fixed-line phone monopoly, Hrvatske Telekomunikacije, for $850 million (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Cray Wins A Big Contract
abstract: Cray Inc, supercomputer maker, and Government Micro Resources Inc, which provides computer systems for NASA, are awarded five-year NASA contract worth as much as $4 billion (S)

headline: Rancor and Powell's Absence Cloud Racism Parley
abstract: Delegates from around world gather in South Africa for United Nations conference on racism, ethnic hatreds and intolerence, but Sec of State Colin L Powell is notably absent; only mid-level United States diplomats will attend conference because of American objections to proposed language in conference texts; some documents describe Israeli presence in West Bank and Gaza as 'new kind of apartheid'; Palestinians and Jews stage competing demonstrations and Arab participants are accused of harassing Jewish delegates; photo (M)

headline: My Favorite Shortcuts
abstract: After having written books with a certain publisher, I actually got to meet my editor face to face at her office-a rarity in these days where every aspect of computer-book creation is conducted via e-mail.

headline: THE BOSS; I've Had a Very Sporting Life
abstract: The Boss column by Philippe Stern, president and owner of Patek Philippe watchmakers, describes his life as avid sportsman; photo (S)

headline: Investors Resume Sell-Off of Stocks
abstract: Stocks plunged as investors grew fearful that the economy is falling into a recession in the wake of last Tuesday's attacks.     The Dow Jones industrials lost 4.4 percent, and other major market gauges dropped more than 3 percent. The Dow has dropped 1,220 points this week, or 12.8 percent. The Nasdaq is down 13.3 percent.

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Solectron Buying C-Mac For $2.7 Billion
abstract: C-MAC, Montreal-based supplier of electronics manufacturing systems, will be acquired by Solectron of Milpitas, Calif, in stock swap valued at $2.7 billion, including assumption of debt (S)

headline: Moscow Journal; Red Square Is Suddenly Catching Up With Times
abstract: Huge billboard dominates Red Square, part of increasing thicket of signs lining Moscow streets; explosion of street advertising in Moscow and other Russian cities belies belief that two fiscal collapses during 1990's left Russians destitute; outdoor advertising has become $150-million-a-year business in Russia, luring big American and European companies into market; map; photo (M)

headline: After One Day, British Restore Home Rule in Northern Ireland
abstract: Britain restores Northern Ireland's power-sharing authority after one-day suspension, hoping for platform to go forward on peace efforts (S)

headline: REUTERS RECEIVES CLEARANCE TO BUY ASSETS FROM BRIDGE
abstract: Reuters Group receives regulatory clearance from Justice Department to buy certain assets of Bridge Information Systems (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Taiwan: Trade With China
abstract: Six of Taiwan's most powerful executives urge government to relax restrictions on trade with China in effort to bolster Taiwan's economy (S)

headline: Indonesia's President Threatens Parliament Over Its Effort to Remove Him
abstract: Indonesia's president, Abdurrahman Wahid, reiterates threat to declare state of emergency unless Parliament drops plans to begin proceedings to remove him from office because of allegations of corruption; threat, with July 20 deadline, demonstrates Wahid's desperation as he loses support in political and military establishments and among Indonesians at large; military leaders have stated they will not obey order for state of emergency (M)

headline: Metro Business Briefing
abstract: FED APPROVES CITIGROUP DEAL The Federal Reserve Board approved the purchase of European American Bank by Citigroup Inc. yesterday. Citigroup, which hopes to increase its commercial banking presence in New York City and on Long Island, agreed in February to buy European American, which is based in Uniondale, N.Y., for $1.6 billion, from ABN Amro Bank of the Netherlands, and to assume responsibility for $350 million in E.A.B. preferred stock. European American has 97 branches in New York City and on Long Island. Citibank has 96 branches in New York City and 27 branches on Long Island. Citigroup announced in May that it would close 19 E.A.B. branches and 5 Citibank branches if the sale was approved, and convert the remaining E.A.B. branches to Citibank branches.    (Reuters)

headline: In Russia, Capitalism Of a Certain Size
abstract: Nikolai Shilin owns 13 stores in Russia, called 'Three Fat Men' after Russian fairy tale, that sell clothing to large and tall men; photo (M)

headline: S.E.C. Nominee Says Rules Need a Review
abstract: Harvey L Pitt, nominee to head Securities and Exchange Commission, says at Senate confirmation hearing that he will undertake comprehensive review of agency's rules and regulations with aim of simplifying and reducing them; says he has decided to conduct review with goal of decreasing costs and discouraging investors from taking their transactions offshore, where they 'often lack protection of the laws the commission enforces'; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Compaq Gets $100 Million Contract
abstract: Sabre Holdings, largest distributor of airline reservations data and travel services, will switch about a third of its computer operations from IBM mainframes to Himalaya line from Compaq Computer over next three to four years; expects to install 192 Himalayas in first phase of deal, which will generate more than $100 million in revenue for Compaq over next few years (S)

headline: Investing; An Online Auctioneer That Helps Cut Costs
abstract: FeeMarkets Inc is pulling away from competition by running online auctions that help its own customers cut costs; its stock has fallen sharply in dot-com crash, but since its early April low it has risen by 188 percent, and is listed as 'strong buy' by several analysts; graph (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Research: Oak Ridge Joins I.B.M. Project
abstract: IBM is signing up government's Oak Ridge National Laboratory to join in pursuing next step in company's Blue Gene supercomputing project, which seeks to learn how amino acids fold into proteins; IBM and laboratory will work together mainly on software required to solve complex scientific problems on supercomputer with thousands of microprocessors linked together (M)

headline: Roche Reaches Accord on Drug With Brazil
abstract: Roche Holding reaches agreement with Brazilian health authorities to reduce price of AIDS drug Viracept by further 40 percent; this puts end to government threat to break patent and produce drug locally; drug will now cost about 30 percent of what Roche charges in US (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: GEN-X SPORTS INC., Toronto, which makes snowboards and golf accessories, said it would buy First Team Sports Inc., Anoka, Minn., which manufactures in-line skates and hockey equipment, for $10.4 million.    AMERICAN SKIING CO., Newry, Me., an operator of ski resorts, said that its biggest investor, Oak Hill Capital Partners, Menlo Park, Calif., had agreed to pump an additional $30 million into the company as part of a financial revamping package.

headline: Early Rally Mostly Fades As Tech Shares Stumble
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average gains 47.74 points, to 9,997.56; Nasdaq composite index drops 34.65 points, to 1,770.78; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index falls 0.64 of point, to 1,132.94; graph; chart (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Surveillance Deadline Extended
abstract: Federal Communications Commission will give telephone companies extra seven weeks to comply with requests for access to packet-mode communication, transfer of data in small pieces or batches; proposed regulations have been challenged by Cellular Telecommunications and Internet Association (S)

headline: China Grins and Bears It
abstract: With Secretary of State Colin L. Powell's visit here this weekend, and in anticipation of President Bush's planned visit in October, the Chinese have begun putting on their most charming face.    In recent meetings of all kinds, diplomats say, Chinese officials have suddenly sounded more accommodating -- or more willing to talk seriously, at least -- about sensitive subjects like sales of missile technology, human rights and America's plans for a missile defense.

headline: OBITUARY : Jack Monet, Former IHT Editor
abstract: PARIS — Jack Monet, 70, a former editor for the International Herald Tribune, died here Wednesday of complications from a lung infection. He had been suffering from multiple systems atrophy, a rare neurological disorder.

headline: I.B.M. Realigns Global Assignments
abstract: IBM is realigning its roster of advertising agencies handling direct marketing and interactive assignments that are part of it worldwide integrated marketing communications account by naming offices of Ogilvy One Worldwide and Wunderman as its 'global partners' for those tasks; billings undisclosed (S)

headline: A Gradual Return for Mutual Funds
abstract: DIARY A Gradual Return For Mutual Funds.

headline: As Demand Soars, Flag Makers Help Bolster Nation's Morale
abstract: Annin & Company in Verona, New Jersey, nation's oldest and largest flag company, has tripled production of American flags since Sept 11 terrorist attacks to meet huge demand across country; photos (M)

headline: NATO and Macedonians Agree on Scope of New Force
abstract: NATO and Macedonian officials agree on scope of new military force to take over as initial NATO mission ends; new NATO force will have 700 troops and three-month mission to provide security for unarmed international monitors; NATO commanders report completion of 30-day program to collect weapons from ethnic Albanian rebels as part of peace plan (S)

headline: Terror Experts Use Lenses of Their Specialties
abstract: Small cadre of journalists specializing in covering terrorism rely on unruly array of disciplines and political and commercial interests as primary sources; face difficult task of sorting out what is known from what is believed or wished and then trying to make sense of events; they, like their sources, arrived at hybrid beat through variety of doors; photo (M)

headline: Palm (the Butter Version) Is Up for Auction at EBay
abstract: Model of Palm personal digital assistant carved in butter that was displayed at Minnesota State Fair is for sale at eBay; was sculpted for Gearworks, wireless applications company, by Linda Christensen; photo (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Linens And Knot Form Alliance
abstract: Linens'n Things announces partnership with Knot, popular wedding registry Web site that provides content to America Online and MSN (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Plane Production Plan Dropped
abstract: European Aeronautic, Defense and Space Co drops plans to increase Airbus SAS aircraft production and cuts expected plane deliveries for three years; freezes hiring and curtails investments, but hopes to raise profit margins to 10 percent by 2004 (S)

headline: A Quarter Of Gains, But Doubt Persists
abstract: Major stock market averages rally in second quarter, buoying most mutual fund sectors along with them but not erasing doubts among investors; some analysts believe market will retest lows of March, and even bullish analysts are muted; graph; photo (M)

headline: Saudis Criticize the Taliban And Halt Diplomatic Ties
abstract: Saudi Arabia breaks diplomatic ties with Afghanistan's Taliban government, leaving Pakistan as sole nation still formally recognizing Taliban; scores Taliban for turning Afghanistan into center for recruiting and training young men from Saudi Arabia and other nations to carry out criminal acts that violate all religions (M)

headline: Digitally Disenfranchised; Bell Companies Are Blamed For the Slow Start Of a Fast Internet Service
abstract: Four big regional telephone companies dominate market for digital subscriber lines, or DSL, type of fast connection to Internet that uses telephone lines; small Internet service providers, last vestige of Internet's original homespun character, are struggling to match lower prices of Bell companies; many of them blame regional Bell operating companies for their endangered status; many businesses and consumers complain that DSL remains too costly and too difficult to obtain simply to cede field to Bell companies; Internet service providers around country say big phone companies unfairly use their market dominance and control of local phone networks to make it difficult for them to provide DSL; photos; charts (L)

headline: Toy Story 3: A Shrinky Dink Comeback
abstract: Spin Master Toys, Toronto, introduces child-operated oven for making Shrinky Dinks (S)

headline: LEVEL 3 BUYS BACK TRANS-ATLANTIC NETWORK FROM VIATEL
abstract: Level 3 Communications buys back trans-Atlantic fiber optic network it sold to Viatel Inc more than year ago; Viatel is under bankruptcy court protection (S)

headline: P.& G. AND COKE SCALE BACK JOINT VENTURE
abstract: Procter & Gamble Co and Coca-Cola Co scale back plans for joint venture to sell Minute Maid and Sunny Delight juices and Pringles potato chips after Coca-Cola balks at giving up its faster-growing lines; each company will keep its individual brands instead of contributing them to venture as announced in February (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: Blair and Ahern Meet
abstract: Prime Mins Tony Blair of Britain and Bertie Ahern of Ireland meet at secluded site in England with leaders from Northern Ireland to push for resolution of impasse over Irish Republican Army disarmament that threatens power-sharing government; photo (S)

headline: India Vows to Halt Terrorism Tied to Pakistan
abstract: Prime Min Atal Behari Vajpayee of India says his government would not hesitate to crush Pakistan-sponsored terrorism; scoffs at Pakistani president, Gen Pervez Musharraf, for characterizing violence in Kashmir as freedom struggle; Vajpayee's remarks are his first direct address to nation since breakdown of peace talks with Pakistan month ago; India blames Pakistani-backed Islamic militants fighting Indian rule in Jammu and Kashmir for attacks in recent weeks on Hindus and other civilians; despite harsh words, Vajpayee has accepted invitation to go to Pakistan for talks, although no date has been set (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: US dollar rises against euro on optimism US stock gains and better-than-expected company earnings may bring rebound in economic growth; in New York, euro falls to 85.34 cents, from 85.91 cents; graph; chart (S)

headline: Compressed Data; Painting Some Pictures Of the Online Shopper
abstract: Study by Brigham Young University of attitudes underlying behavior of people with home Internet access who do and do not like to shop online finds those who do not are fearful of computers and afraid they won't get merchandise or that their credit card will be stolen (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: PERFORMANCE FOOD GROUP CO.,  Richmond, Va., won a contract valued at $110 million a year to supply 250 restaurants operated by Ruby Tuesday Inc. and SRG Inc. of Maryville, Tenn.    HALLIBURTON CO.,  Dallas, the oil field service company, said that a joint venture between its Kellogg Brown & Root unit and JGC Corp., Yokohama, Japan, had signed a $620 million contract for the engineering and construction of the In Salah gas reserves in Algeria.

headline: Intel Says Sales For the Quarter Are on Track
abstract: Intel Corp says sales will remain on target for third quarter; expects to report revenues 'slightly below the midpoint' of its July forecast of $6.2 billion to $6.8 billion; National Semiconductor Corp reports $54.6 million net loss for quarter; Motorola Inc will cut 2,000 jobs amid another revenue shortfall (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Justice Dept. Is Cool On Verizon Plan
abstract: The Justice Department said it would not endorse Verizon's application to offer long-distance service in Pennsylvania because of problems with the company's electronic billing system. Verizon has made progress in opening the market, said Charles A. James, assistant attorney general in charge of the antitrust division. ''But the absence of a commercially proven electronic billing system was a continuing concern,'' Mr. James said. A ruling by the F.C.C. is due Sept. 21.

headline: Investors Try To Adjust To a New Set Of Realities
abstract: Individual investors are adjusting to new set of realities in wake of terrorist attacks; seem hesitant, uncertain and noncommittal (M)

headline: Executive Changes in Media and Marketing
abstract: Steve Bryant, chief creative officer for public relations for Publicis in the United States, based in Seattle, was named to the additional post of president at the Seattle office of Publicis Dialog, part of the United States Publicis operations. He takes on the president's post from Jeff Hasan, who is leaving, the agency said, to pursue other interests. The United States Publicis operations are part of the Publicis Groupe.

headline: U.S. Investor Wins Legal Ruling Over Czech TV Station
abstract: Ronald S Lauder, New York cosmetics heir, wins arbitration ruling against Czech government for failing to protect Lauder's company, Central European Media Enterprises, from being squeezed out of TV Nova, Czech Republic's most popular television station; international arbitration panel orders government to pay Lauder's company, known as CME, 'fair market value' of TV channel, amount that CME put at $500 million to $550 million; case was heard in Stockholm (M)

headline: Some Flawed Information Occasionally Creeps In
abstract: Live television coverage of aftermath of terrorist attacks, in which raw reporting process unfolds before audience, has led to some erroneous reports; various law enforcement branches are operating with damaged communications systems, adding to problem; photo (M)

headline: Technology Rallies as Semiconductor Shares Get a Lift
abstract: Technology stocks rise after Merrill Lynch upgrades its ratings on some companies in semiconductor sector; Dow Jones industrial average slips 12.80, to 10,510.01; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gains 4.70 to close at 1,215.93; Nasdaq composite index's 41.25 rise takes it to 2,068.38; graph (M)

headline: Robots Tested in Mock Search for Urban Disaster Victims
abstract: Annual Robocup competition in Seattle includes earthquake simulation in which search-and-rescue robots are used to locate victims; photos (M)

headline: Editor of The Financial Times Will Step Down
abstract: Richard Lambert will step down in September as editor of The Financial Times; will be succeeded by Andrew Gowers, head of Financial Times Deutschland; photo (M)

headline: For Insurers, Some Failures And Rate Jumps
abstract: Insurers and analysts say terrorist attack on World Trade Center will cause cost of commercial insurance coverage to rise by at least 20 percent as insurers struggle to recoup losses; they say some insurance companies will fail under burden of claims that may run as high as $30 billion to $40 billion; Fox-Pitt Kelton, investment firm specializing in insurance, says losses to just 13 of dozens of insurance companies that provided coverage at World Trade Center will exceed $7 billion; Metropolitan Life Insurance expects to pay claims of as much as $460 million on lives lost, mostly covered by group insurance paid for by corporations; Employers Reinsurance Corp, unit of General Electric Corp, expects to pay out $600 million in claims and other expenses at twin towers; experts say besides need to make up losses, prices will be driven up by demand for more coverage from business executives (M)

headline: Me-Zine Journalism for Fun and (Sometimes) Profit
abstract: Growing Internet format now know as 'me-zine,' electronic magazines that feature opinions of one journalist, writing alone, often late at night, is sometimes proving slightly profitable; writers are increasingly choosing me-zine as bully pulpit rather than, or in addition to, column in local newspaper or political magazine; table of financial data on writer Mickey Kaus's Web site; photos (M)

headline: Critic of China Flees to U.S., Fearing Arrest In Crackdown
abstract: A maverick Chinese economist who is an outspoken critic of China's endemic corruption has fled to the United States, fearing that she was about to be arrested in a crackdown on dissidents and scholars with ties to the West.    The economist, He Qinglian, 44, was already planning on leaving China on June 26 for a year's sabbatical at the University of Chicago.

headline: Business; Corporate Planes: Perks or Necessities?
abstract: Sept 11 hijackings, which paralyzed commercial airline industry, also injected energy into business aviation -- private jets increasingly used by corporate executives; more than 9,317 companies already own at least one jet aircraft; business aviation is likely to grow, thanks to safety and security as well as convenience it offers; photos; graph (M)

headline: PaineWebber's Longtime Chief Steps Aside
abstract: Donald B Marron, 67, steps down as chairman of UBS PaineWebber, brokerage firm he sold to Swiss bank UBS in 2000; Joseph J Grano, who has served as president and chief executive, becomes chairman; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: India: Monsoons Batter Millions
abstract: india: monssons batt

headline: The Building Of a Network That Is Global And Reliable
abstract: US is sending bulletins to police and intelligence services around world, trying to create global network that could help round up 3,000 people in 30 countries who are suspected of working with Osama bin Laden's terrorists; Interpol, set to meet, will seek cooperation of member forces and FBI to bring in suspects (S)

headline: REGENT COMMUNICATIONS MAKES A DEAL WITH COMCORP
abstract: Regent Communications Inc agrees to buy seven radio stations in Louisiana from ComCorp of Lafayette Inc for $39.6 million in cash (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Thailand: AIDS Is Top Killer
abstract: Thailand reports AIDS has become leading cause of death, accounting for 16 percent of all deaths in 1998 (S)n

headline: Russians Treat Chechen Children To a Summer Vacation From War
abstract: Bolshaya Yelnya, Russian village near city of Nizhny Novogorod, is summer host to children from war-torn Chechnya; children have been brought to city for third time in year through combined efforts of human rights groups and regional government; city is center of quiet protest against two Chechen wars, in which 250 soldiers from region have died; map; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Soldier From North Seeks Return
abstract: North Korean soldier Cpl Ri Sung Hun returns to Panmunjom after he is washed from North to South Korea by swift current in flooded stream (S)

headline: Ex-Alcoa Boss May Become A Man of Steel; Paul O'Neill Leads Effort For Bush Administration As It Weighs Trade Curbs
abstract: Treasury Sec Paul H O'Neill is at forefront fo effort by Bush administration to aid ailing US steel industry and is promoting idea of international agreement to reduce global production; he is behind administration's effort to investigate whether steel imports are hurting domestic steel makers, first step to any steel-import restrictions; graph; photos (M)

headline: BOEING PICKS 3 COMPANIES TO HELP WITH COAST GUARD BID
abstract: Boeing Co picks European Aeronautic Def

headline: First Voting In East Timor Gives a Taste Of New Rights
abstract: People of East Timor are holding first democratic election in their history, two years after they voted, at great cost, to break away from Indonesia; vote will be held on Aug 30 for constituent assembly that will draw up constitution in preparation for full nationhood some time next year; vote, like referendum in 1999, is being organized by United Nations, which continues to administer East Timor as it struggles to its feet economically and politically; about 80 percent of eligible residents have registered to vote; almost everybody expects Jose Alexandre Gusmao, East Timor's independence leader, to be elected president; photo; map (M)

headline: Speed Traps
abstract: Apple Computer has long been the victim of a public perception problem. Now, as it turns out, Apple may finally have solved the problem rather neatly.

headline: Taking On the Curmudgeons
abstract: Cantakerous observers may lament the surfeit of technology in our personal lives, but most people get pleasure, excitement or productivity from gadgets. Why begrudge them their pleasures?

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: ASML Reports A Loss
abstract: ASML Holding, Dutch manufacturer of chip-making tools, says it lost 96 million euros, or $83.9 million, in first half of year on revenue of 1.02 billion euros, or $891.3 million (S)

headline: PRUDENTIAL SETTLES HAITIAN WORKERS' COMPLAINT
abstract: Prudential Financial is paying $300,000 to settle complaint by four Haitian employees in New York that they are barred from speaking Creole among themselves, even though their duties include dealing with Haitian customers in Creole, main language of Haiti (S)

headline: New Guards to Lessen Liability
abstract: Companies are using computers to educate their workers about policies against sexual harassment and age and racial discrimination

headline: Technology Briefing
abstract: EARNINGS ALLOY POSTS 2ND-QUARTER LOSS Alloy Online Inc., a New York Internet company and retailer focused on the teenage market, announced pro forma losses of $2.3 million, or 10 cents a share, yesterday for its fiscal second quarter, ended on July 31. Including good-will amortization, stock-based compensation and other charges, the company lost $11.3 million, or 51 cents a share. Revenue for the second quarter was $28.7 million, up from $12.3 million in the second quarter of fiscal 2000.
