The company, which sells merchandise over the Web and through catalogs, revised its financial estimates upward for the full fiscal year, expecting revenue of $157 million to $160 million.   Susan Stellin (NYT)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Taiwan: Economy Shrinks
abstract: Taiwan's economy shrinks for first time in 26 years, prompting central bank to cut interest rates for eighth time since Dec; gross domestic product falls 2.4 percent in second quarter (S)

headline: More Experts Grow Wary As the Dollar Keeps Rising
abstract: Analysis of growing concern about rise in dollar against euro and Japanese yen; key arguments for intervention to bring down dollar are that strong dollar makes exports noncompetitive and hurts earnings of multinational corporations when profits earned abroad are translated into dollars and that eventual collapse of market confidence in dollar should be forestalled by pushing dollar down in controlled and gradual way; graphs; table (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Qantas Surges
abstract: Shares in Qantas Airways rise 15 percent on optimism that airline will buy portion of Ansett and take control of Australia's $2.6 billion aviation market; Qantas and discount carrier Virgin Blue are in talks to take over assets of Ansett; graph (S)

headline: Motorola to Announce Advance in Chips
abstract: Motorola achieves breakthrough in manufacture of semiconductors that allows high-performance materials like gallium arsenide to reside on top of standard silicon, making it possible to make specialty chips like power amplifiers in cell phones more cheaply (M)

headline: Theater, Old Friends and Merit Badges
abstract: David Rockwell, president of Rockwell Architectural Group, writes The Boss column in which he recalls his years growing up in Deal, NJ; hoto (M)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Unhappy With Zimbabwe
abstract: South African bank governor Tito Mboweni lashes out at Pres Robert Mugabe and Zimbabwe government and demands orderly resolution of problems (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: TradeCard To Operate In Japan
abstract: Technology Bri

headline: World Business Briefing | The Americas: Canada: Rate Lowered
abstract: Bank of Canada lowers its target for overnight interest rates a quarter percentage point, to 4.25 percent, citing slowdown in economy; commercial banks cut prime lending rate by similar margin, to 6 percent (S)

headline: Law Firms Cut Partners In Slowdown
abstract: Last year was a banner year for many law firms, but an increasing number of partners did not partake directly of the profits.    In an effort to increase per-partner profitability, many large firms have quietly demoted partners, putting them on salaries again instead of giving them a share of net income. And industry analysts say the trend will accelerate this year, as big businesses cut back spending on legal services.

headline: Pentagon Sets Fourth Test Of Missile For July 14
abstract: Pentagon will try to shoot down mock warhead high over Pacific on July 14 using prototype interceptor; test, virtual replay of failed interception, will be fourth attempt to shoot down long-range missile with high-speed interceptor; two previous attempts failed; third was successful but test was called flawed by missile critics; Pentagon says Bush administration will move forward with program regardless of outcome of test, but another failure could strengthen hand of critics in Congress who accuse Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld of trying to rush system into operation before it has proved effective (M)

headline: Interpublic Unit Makes Personnel Shifts
abstract: TN Media is folded into Initative Media Worldwide; eighty-nine employees who had worked for TN Media are being dismissed; 151 former TN Media employees are being shifted to Initiative Media North America, which is dismissing about 80 of its own employees; TN senior vice president Larry Blasius is named senior vice president and director for US broadcast negotiations at Magna Global USA; TN senior vice president Steven Sternberg is named senior vice president and director for audience analysis at Magna Global (M)

headline: China Has Held American 18 Months Without Charges
abstract: Fuming Fong, 68-year-old naturalized US citizen, has been jailed in China for 18 months on suspicion of gathering state secrets, but has not been formally indicted, in violation of Chinese legal procedures; family, which also reports Fong is deprived of eyeglasses and hearing aid, is taking case public as Pres Bush prepares for first official visit to Beijing; accusations center on technical documents Fong assembled on laptop computer as consultant to American power companies; he was senior engineer and electric-power official before moving to US in late 1980's (M)

headline: Fugitive Fujimori Relative is Shielded by Japan
abstract: Japanese government says it granted citizenship to former Peruvian Pres Alberto Fujimori's brother-in-law, Victor Aritomi Shinto, who is wanted in Peru on suspicion of embezzling public funds; move effectively shields Aritomi from being sent back to Peru, since Japan does not extradite its citizens; Japan has already said it would not honor request to extradite Fujimori because he is Japanese citizen by ethnic heritage; legal scholars say both Fujimori and Aritomi are now legally protected from prosecution for crimes committed abroad as long as they remain in Japan (M)

headline: Race Talks Finally Reach Accord On Slavery and Palestinian Plight
abstract: Delegates to UN's Durban conference on racism agree after nine days of negotiations to condemn slave trade from Africa to Americas and to voice concern for plight of Palestinians; photo; declaration is almost undone by last-minute Arab attempt to single out Israel as 'racist,' but final version is considerably toned down from language that prompted US and Israeli walkout; wording falls short of African demands for explicit apology on slavery and compensation promise (M)

headline: MYKROLIS CUTS REVENUE ESTIMATE AND POSTS LOSS
abstract: Mykrolis Corp says it will post third-quarter loss and revenue will be lower than previously forecast (S)

headline: A Gradual Return For Mutual Funds
abstract: Mutual fund companies begin reopening money market and bond funds, and equity funds are scheduled to resume operations Sept 17; many people lost access to their money after terrorist attacks (S)

headline: Why Netflix Is Cool
abstract: This week’s e-mail column is, at its core, a blatantly self-interested missive. It's about Netflix. Listen up.

headline: Telecom Italia Falls to Pirelli and Benetton : Redrawing the Map Of Italian Capitalism
abstract: ROME—  Italian capitalism was hit by its second earthquake of the summer this weekend as Pirelli and the Benetton family moved to take effective control of Telecom Italia, the heavily indebted phone, Internet and television company, in a deal worth €7 billion.

headline: Belgrade Journal; Rakish City of the Serbs, Fighting Back the Tears
abstract: Former Serbian Pres Slobodan Milosevic was handed to war crimes tribunal in The Hague two weeks ago, but there is little sense in Belgrade that many people are in mourning for him; of more concern are pensions still largely unpaid, 40 percent unemployment and impact of hundreds of thousands of refugees from lost wars who loiter or hawk wares on streets; photo (M)

headline: Furor at Berlusconi Remark on West's Superiority
abstract: Italian Prime Min Silvio Berlusconi's declaration that Western civilization is superior to culture of Islamic world draws furious outcry in Italy, Europe and beyond; spokesman for Berlusconi notes that he fought for participation of moderate Arab countries in alliance against terrorism (M)

headline: Laptop Learning
abstract: James A Ferguson letter on Aug 23 article hails educational value of laptop computers for high school students

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Business-to-Business Sites Find Strategies for Survival  The rate of mergers and failures among business-to-business marketplaces is picking up where the consumer sector left off. But just as some survivors have begun to emerge from the consumer e-commerce rubble, so, too, have some of the so-called B2B marketplaces started to show some staying power.    These companies have managed to attract buyers and sellers by broadening their features beyond the typical marketplace site, which had focused mainly on buyers. Bob Tedeschi: E-Commerce Report. [Page C4.]

headline: Treasury Offerings Scheduled for Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three-  and six-month bills.    By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 3.53 percent, and the six-month bill was 3.34 percent.

headline: After Three Unavailing Days, Ulster Negotiators Take a Breather
abstract: Efforts to rescue faltering Northern Ireland peace accord are put on hold after three days of intensive talks led by Prime Min Tony Blair and his Irish counterpart, Bertie Ahern, fail to make progress on central issue of Irish Republican Army weapons; current crisis was caused by resignation of David Trimble, first minister of Northern Ireland Assembly, in protest over IRA inaction (M)

headline: Tajik Journalist Is Held in Moscow
abstract: In a move denounced by human rights advocates Friday, the Russian authorities have detained a dissident Tajik journalist at the request of Tajikistan's government, which is charging the journalist with insulting the president, a crime in the Central Asian country.    The journalist, Dododjon Atovulloyev, 46, was detained on Thursday night at a Moscow airport as he was boarding a plane for Central Asia. If extradited to Tajikistan, he could face the death penalty.

headline: A Shattered Nest Egg
abstract: Selvin Gootar letter holds July 22 article on losing $700 nest egg based on brokers' advice is cautionary tale for all investors

headline: Screaming Media to Acquire Stockpoint
abstract: ScreamingMedia agreed to buy Stockpoint, a financial data provider, for $21.6 million in stock, cash and debt

headline: Failure to Acquire Honeywell Is Sour Finish for G.E. Chief
abstract: John F. Welch Jr. was supposed to be retired from General Electric by now, his legacy as corporate America's most-admired manager firmly intact.    But his final act as chairman of G.E., to bid for the industrial conglomerate Honeywell International and postpone his retirement, is turning out to be a case study in miscalculations.

headline: Stocks Close Down Sharply on Economic Fears
abstract: Stocks fell today in a broad-based decline after the government said that United States economic growth for the second quarter remained weak.

headline: World Briefing | Asia/Pacific: Nauru: Tiny Haven Takes On More
abstract: Tiny Pacific island nation of Nauru--eight square miles--says it is prepared to accept hundreds of refugees turned away from Australia after being rescued at sea by Norweigian freighter (S)

headline: British Immigration Aides Accused of Bias by Gypsys
abstract: Richard Samko, Gypsy and reporter at Czech television, has stirred political storm, exposing in broadcast what he calls bias by British immigration officials at Prague airport against darker-skinned Gypsies; Czechs agreed to let British set up office at airport after Britain threatened to reimpose visa requirement because 2,000 Czech Gypsies applied for asylum last year; Britain has granted asylum to few Czech Gypsies, despite widespread discrimination against them in Czech Republic; photo (M)

headline: Punishing Plagiarists
abstract: Ruth F Block letter on June 28 article on student plagiarism from Internet holds students learn to cheat from parents

headline: ROHN STOCK DROPS AS IT EXPECTS TO MISS TARGETS
abstract: Shares of Rohn Industries drop 33 percent, to $2.80 a share, after company predicts that it will not meet already-lowered earnings target and declines to project farther into future (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Air Treaty Challenge
abstract: BMI British Midland, Britain's third-largest airline, will file complaint with European Union regulators in attempt to nullify British-American treaty that permits only two airlines from each country to fly trans-Atlantic routes between Britain and US (S)

headline: Powell Finds Setting Timetable for Mideast Peace Confounding
abstract: Sec Colin Powell, ending first intense immersion in Israeli-Palestinian diplomacy, acknowledges that goal of initial seven-day cease-fire, followed by six weeks of 'absolute calm' may well fall apart, and quickly (M)

headline: Private Sector; Knowing Where to Eat in New York
abstract: New York Stock Exchange chief executive, Richard A Grasso, entertains Michael Dell of Dell Computers and John Chambers of Cisco, who were respectively named chief executive of year this year and last year by Chief Executive magazine, and expresses wish that they might move their stocks from Nasdaq to Big Board; photo (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Natural gas falls on speculation that mild weather helped distributors store more fuel for winter; in New York, gas for September delivery falls 11.6 cents, or 3.5 percent, to $3.187 per million BTU's; graph; chart (S)

headline: No Need to Mince Words With This Phone Accessory
abstract: Think Outside and Motorola design folding keyboard for text messaging via mobile phone; photo (S)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: A Victory For Mugabe
abstract: Robert Mugabe's government in Zimbabwe wins special parliamentary election (S)

headline: Business; An American Directs Mexico City's Cinema Revival
abstract: Matthew D Heyman is an American who has helped revitalize Mexico City's antiquated network of movie houses; his company, Cinemex, attracts customers by making its theaters relatively luxurious; photos (M)

headline: CNN Aims at Young Viewers As It Revamps News Format
abstract: CNN is revamping its Headline News in aggressive bid to meet advertisers demands for younger audience; is promising splashier graphics, multisectioned screen and rock background music; has hired Andrea Thompson, actress with little news experience, as anchor; Jamie Kellner and Garth Ancier helped develop approach; photos (M)

headline: Two Trade Groups Cancel Conferences
abstract: Association of National Advertisers will cancel what was to have been its annual meeting set for Oct 10-14 at Ritz-Carlton Hotel in Naples, Fla, after terrorist attacks; American Association of Advertising Agencies postpones creative conference that was to have taken place Oct 17-19 at Grant Hyatt Hotel in San Francisco (S)

headline: Reaction From Around the World
World Briefing | Asia: Cambodia: Law On Khmer Rouge Trials Approved
abstract: The Senate unanimously approved a law that would allow creation of an international tribunal to try surviving leaders of the Khmer Rouge, the Communist movement responsible for the deaths of more than a million people from 1975 to 1979. The law needs final approval by the Constitutional Council and King Norodom Sihanouk. It would then be reviewed by the United Nations, which must approve it before agreeing to take part in a Cambodian trial.   Seth Mydans (NYT)

headline: A PC for Teacher, Too
abstract: Shelly Lowe letter responding to article about buying online school supplies, says local mom-and-pop stationery store is good resource

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Bank Merger Bid
abstract: United Overseas Bank wins support from investors holding 67.5 percent of shares of its rival, Overseas Union Bank; extends offer, which would put it in line to surpass DBS Group Holdings as Singapor's biggest lender (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Executive Leaves Invensys
abstract: Britain's Invensys says its chief executive Allen Yurko will resign in January; Rick Haythornthwaite will succeed him; graph (S)

headline: Gene Data to Be Kept Private So Company Can Make Drugs
abstract: A pioneering database of human genes is now available for licensing again. But Human Genome Sciences, which controls the database, no longer plans to offer broad access to the data, the company's chairman and chief executive, William A. Haseltine, said over the weekend.     The genomics business came of age in 1993, when SmithKline Beecham agreed to pay $125 million for access to Human Genome Sciences' database of human genes. Access was subsequently provided to four other pharmaceutical companies, bringing nearly $150 million in additional payments to Human Genome Sciences, based in Rockville, Md.

headline: As Midway Airlines Retrenches, the Competition Intensifies
abstract: Midway Airlines, regional airline that operates out of Raleigh-Durham International Airport in North Carolina, files for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection; Midway is droppging service to 9 of 28 cities on its system; is also cutting its work force to 1,700 from 2,700 and grounding 17 of its 40 planes (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Construction Spinoff
abstract: John Laing, British company that built Millennium Dome in London, will sell one of its troubled construction units for symbolic 1 pound ($1.47) to O'Rourke Group; Martin Laing will step down as chairman; company lost 56 million pounds ($82.6 million) in first half of year, compared with profit of 14.5 million pounds ($21.4 million) year earlier; graph (S)

headline: Wishing on a Satellite
abstract: Tina Isenberg letter comments on frustrations of satellite television (Aug 9 article)

headline: Bush and Putin Tie Antimissile Talks to Big Arms Cuts
abstract: President Bush and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia agreed to link discussions of missile defense with large cuts in nuclear arsenals.

headline: Putting Your Face Inside a Video Game
abstract: Video game players can now use 3-D technology to put their own faces on their on-screen avatars. One day, people may shop or conduct business meetings this way

headline: Great Expectations Of Mexico's Leader Sapped by Reality
abstract: Mexico's Pres Vicente Fox admits in interview that pledges to transform nation economically and socially, which propelled his stunning rise to power in 2000 election, have been deferred; countervailing political and economic forces have hit government particularly hard with recession, tied to downturn in US economy, dashing hopes of financing his social programs through economic growth; pledged 7 percent economic growth and creation of more million new jobs in 2001, but more than 300,000 jobs have been lost he took office on December 1; photo; chart (M)

headline: INSTINET SAYS CLOSING OF MARKETS REDUCED PROFIT
abstract: Instinet Group, Reuters Group's automated stock trading network, says third-quarter profit will fall because of lost revenue after terrorist attacks closed stock markets in US for four days (S)

headline: In Historical Games, Truth Gives Way to Entertainment
abstract: Computer strategy games set in historical periods are among best-selling titles; some critics fault games for departing from historical accounts of world events; makers admit games ignore some aspects of history, but say they may spur players to learn more about particular subject; game designer Sid Meier comments, interview; table of popular historical games; photos (M)

headline: Sales Drop and Spending Waits as Uncertainty Grips Economy
abstract: Sales fall in nearly every sector of economy in wake of Sept 11 terrorist attacks; gloom is spreading beyond airline and travel industries; executives in many industries postpone whatever spending they can until clearer picture emerges about how consumers are reacting to crisis; forecasters expect contraction in economic activity in third quarter, ending Sept 30; say outright recession could emerge if downturn continues through Christmas; immediate economic harm from attacks is felt by airlines shut down and air traffic that is way off; industries directly linked to airline travel also suffer; beyond that, terrorism and reaction to it appear to be rippling through most of economy, unchecked so far; consumer confidence, chief gauge for determining how willing people are to spend, has twisted up and then down in last three weeks; confidence has fallen more sharply than at any time since oil embargo in 1973 and Iraqi invasion of Kuwait in 1990; photo; graphs (M)

headline: NTELOS WILL BUY CONESTOGA FOR $408 MILLION
abstract: Ntelos Inc, provider of telecommunications services, acquires Conestoga Enterprises Inc for $408 million in stock and cash; will assume $73 million indebt (S)

headline: Welch's Way On the Issues
abstract: Excerpts from Jack: Straight From the Gut, by John F Welch Jr (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: 2 Settle Fraud Charges
abstract: Hillary Sheinkin and Charlo Barbosa, operators of pornographic Web sites that advertised memberships for less than $50, or free, but billed consumers for hundreds of dollars in international long-distance telephone calls, agree to settle FTC charges that they violated federal law (S)

headline: BERKSHIRE PARTNERS TO ACQUIRE CLOTHING MAKER
abstract: Berkshire Partners will acquire William Carter Companies, children's clothing maker and retailer, from Investcorp for $450 million (S)

headline: Ronald Monchak, 65, Advertising Executive
abstract: Ronald Monchak, longtime creative executive in Detroit advertising industry, dies on June 26 at age 65 (S)

headline: Asahi and Daiwa to Merge, Cutting Jobs
abstract: Asahi Bank Ltd and Daiwa Bank Ltd will merge, closing one third of their branches and cutting staff by one quarter as two banks battle slowing economy and rise in bad loans; banks, which are joining with Kinki Osaka Bank Ltd and Nara Bank Ltd to form holding company by March 2002, plan to cut 6,307, or 27 percent, of their total staff and 227 branches, or 29 percent of their outlets, by March 2005; new holding company will be called Daiwa Bank Holdings and will be based in Osaka (S)

headline: Market Place; Conseco's Performance Isn't the Stuff of Sonnets
abstract: Floyd Norris Market Place column on Conseco's second-quarter report, which claimed earnings of 21 cents a share, and skepticism voiced by analysts in conference call with Gary Wendt, president; graph (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Georgia: Kidnapped Businessman Freed
abstract: Charbel Aoun, Lebanese businessman kidnapped in Georgian republic in June, is released (S)

headline: World Briefing | Middle East: Iran: Riot Over City's Fate
abstract: Violence erupts in Sabzevar, Iran, after city is passed over as possible provincial capital; parliament is dividing Khorasan Province in three; map (S)

headline: Europe's Ties With America:New Cause For Concern
abstract: "The problem with allies," Winston Churchill said, "is that they sometimes develop opinions of their own."

headline: Executive Changes at Media Firms
abstract: The American Advertising Federation, Washington, named two executives to head the organization for 2001-2002. David A. Park, chief executive at the Los Angeles office of DDB Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group, becomes chairman. He succeeds Arthur C. Liebler, who until his recent retirement was senior vice president for global brand marketing at the Chrysler Group unit of DaimlerChrysler, Auburn Hills, Mich. And Paul C. Atkinson, vice president for integrated sales at AOL Time Warner, New York, becomes vice chairman of the organization. He will become chairman for 2002-2003, succeeding Mr. Park.

headline: ITALIAN PROTESTER IS KILLED BY POLICE AT GENOA MEETING
abstract: Italian protester Carlo Giuliani is shot and killed by police officer during anti-globalization demonstration by several thousand protesters at Group of Eight economic summit in Genoa; victim is one of several young men who attack police van with rocks and other weapons; Italian Pres Carlo Azeglio Ciampi, appearing with Prime Min Silvio Berlusconi, expresses sorrow over death; Berlusconi suggests that venues for such high-level meetings be reconsidered; Vittorio Agnoletti, head of Genoa Social Forum, umbrella association of more than 700 groups protesting meeting, calls for immediate suspension of sessions; deplores violence by small group of protesters that most demonstrators does not condone; map; photos (M)

headline: A Fate Worse Than Procrastination
abstract: Lisa Belkin column on hiring a consultant, Sande Nelson, to help her organize the expense-account report and other paperwork involved with her work as writer for various publications; drawing (M)

headline: Turkish Amnesty Draws Fire as Freed Man Is Linked to Killing
abstract: Rashan Ecevit, ruling party officials and wife of Prime Min Bulent Ecevit has been under attack in Turkey since discovery that man suspected of killing prominent businessman Uzeyir Garih is one of 35,000 prisoners freed by Parliament at her proposal in Dec amnesty; she defends self against critics who question pardoning of violent criminals, but not political prisoners (M)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: AFRICA.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Exports Slow
abstract: China's exports rose 0.9 percent in August from year earlier to $23.5 billion; exports have slumped this year after increasing 28 percent last year (S)

headline: It's Still a Plain Gray Box, but the Innards Are Changing
abstract: Major overhaul is in store for Peripheral Component Interconnect standard, or PCI, path that data follows between processor and other components inside the computer; PCI has remained unchanged for nearly 10 years and is considered major bottleneck to efficient flow of data; successor technology, developed by Intel Corp, as PCI was, is expected to appear by late 2003 and promises better video quality and ability to attach peripherals without ever turning off the computer, all at lower cost; old software will be compatible but not upgradeable; photo (9M)

headline: Bayer Won't Sell Drug Unit And Picks Insider as Chief
abstract: Bayer AG, defying expectations, says it will sell its embattled pharmaceuticals unit after all; names chief financial officer Werner Wenning to succeed chief executive Manfred Schneider (M)

headline: Executive Changes at Media Firms
abstract: Josh Dare was named vice president for corporate communications at the Martin Agency in Richmond, Va

headline: E-Commerce Report; Online retail profits have not materialized, so sites are offering information as a substitute for sales.
abstract: Internet divisions of traditional retailers, while largely failing to produce profits for parent companies, are starting to redefine criteria by which they are judged; Web sites are being used by companies to test and monitor customers' purchase patterns, gauge early demand for items and provide data to make retail operations more efficient; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing
abstract: AMERICAS BRAZIL: PROFIT FOR JET MAKER Despite an energy crisis that is expected to shave at least 2 percentage points off Brazil's economic growth, the aircraft maker Empresa Brasileira de Aeronáutica S.A., or Embraer, said its second-quarter profit tripled to $135.9 million compared with the period last year. The company, the country's largest exporter, benefited from a nearly 7 percent devaluation in Brazil's currency this quarter.   Jennifer L. Rich (NYT) EUROPE BRITAIN: BID FOR PUBS FAILS Pubmaster, which operates a chain of pubs in Britain, said its hostile bid for its rival Wolverhampton & Dudley Breweries had failed. It said its offer had lapsed after receiving support from only 47 percent of Wolverhampton's shareholders. Pubmaster's chief executive, John Sands, has said he wants to add 3,000 pubs to the 2,000 the company already owns. Pubmaster's bid of 513 pence a share valued the company, one of Britain's largest regional brewers and owner of 1,770 pubs, at £485 million ($690 million), a price that Wolverhampton had called too low. If left independent, Wolverhampton had promised to buy back shares and streamline operations.   Suzanne Kapner (NYT) ITALY: INSURANCE BID RULING Shares in the Ital- ian insurance company La Fondiaria Assicurazioni rose more than 8 percent after the Italian stock market regulator ruled that a domestic rival, Societá Assicuratrice Industriale, must make a bid for all of Fondiaria after acquiring a minority share. The regulator argued that Industriale cooperated with the Italian investment bank Mediobanca when it agreed last month to acquire a 29 percent stake in Fondiaria from the Montedison chemical and energy conglomerate. The purchase was agreed on the eve of a hostile takeover of Montedison by the Fiat group. Mediobanca owns 14 percent of Fondiaria, and under Italian stock market rules a bidder for more than 30 percent of a company's shares must make a public offering

headline: Europe Moves to Speed Up Approval of New Drugs
abstract: European Commission proposes acceleration in approval of new drugs that could reduce up to half time it takes for new medication to reach markets and patients; move would bring European drug approval practices neaer those of US; plan calls for reducing time for drug companies to win approval for drugs offering major advances in treatment from 18 months to 9 to 12 months, shorter than average 14-month approval process in US last year (M)

headline: BMW's Warning Kit For Soon-to-End Leases
abstract: BMW mails packet to customers with soon-to-end car leases to help them estimate amount of extra money they will be required to pay for repairs to vehicles when leases expire (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Group To Attend Northern Festivities
abstract: South Korean government reverses itself and decides to allow 360 civic and religious activists to go to North Korea for celebration marking 56th anniversary of end of Japanese colonial rule over Korean Peninsula (S)

headline: MEXICO PRESIDENT URGES U.S. TO ACT SOON ON MIGRANTS
abstract: Pres Vicente Fox of Mexico, in first state visit of Bush administration, urges United States to commit to speedy timetable for agreement this year on broad, politically sensitive proposals for treatment of millions of illegal Mexican immigrants; high-level officials in both governments are discussing proposal that would give legal status to some of 3.5 million Mexicans working illegally in US: Fox's challenge comes as no surprise to Bush's top aides, but it does add new sense of urgency to issue that faces significant fight from conservative political forces in US; Bush, in welcoming Fox to White House, speaks only in general terms about negotiations; later, at press briefing, national security adviser, Condoleezza Rice, stops short of committing White House to deal this year; notes that Bush must negotiate any immigration agreements with Congress and various political and business sectors; photo (M)

headline: The Persistence of Junk Mail
abstract: We now have protection against junk phone calls and junk faxes; what’s the holdup in putting an end to the most annoying scheme of all

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Costly Epidemic
abstract: brØ

headline: Investors in Russian Oil Are Lured With Dividends
abstract: Russian oil companies, eager to live down their poor reputations, are paying shareholders rich dividend; dividends are tool of choice to woo investors; oil companies that pay hefty dividends include Sibneft and Yukos (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Caviar Crackdown
abstract: Russian border guards arrest two men in Dagestan region trying to leave country with 54 sturgeon; Russia has halted commercial sturgeon fishing in Caspian Sea to protect dwindling black-caviar supplies (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Vietnam Leader Visits
abstract: South Korea's Pres Kim Dae Jung will receive Tran Duc Luong, president of Vietnam, in Seoul; visit it first by leader of Vietnam; photo (S)

headline: States Are Following the Money
abstract: Growing number of states remodel and expand their false-claims laws, under which individuals or companies found to have defrauded government must pay heavy penalties (S)

headline: With Pressure Growing, Zimbabwe Agrees to Stop Land Seizures
abstract: Zimbabwe bows to growing international pressure, and agrees to stop land occupations that have fed country's political turmoil and fueled its economic crisis for more than year; in exchange, Britain agrees to provide money for Zimbabwe's efforts to resettle poor blacks on much of country's fertile land, most of which is owned by small white minority (M)

headline: CBS hopes new slot for 'Big Brother 2' soothes sponsors.
abstract: CBS moves starting time of Big Brother 2 from 8 PM to 9 PM due to show's extreme sexual orientation; move is aimed at soothing worried sponsors (M)

headline: Milosevic Refuses to Enter Plea
abstract: THE HAGUE, July 3 — Slobodan Milosevic, who plunged the Balkans into the worst European violence since World War II, appeared today before an international tribunal that has accused him of crimes against humanity and dismissed the court with disdain as an "illegal organ."

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   6.75   6.75   9.50       Discount rate   3.25   3.25   6.00       Federal funds   3.81   3.75   6.64       3-month T-bills   3.48   3.45   6.09       6-month T-bills   3.38   3.36   6.11       10-yr. T-infl.   3.39   3.40   4.00       10-yr. T-note   5.10   5.09   6.03       30-yr. headline: Beck Brewery Up for Sale; Foreign Bids Are Expected
abstract: Beck's, Germany's top-selling export beer, says company is for sale; insists that is pilsner beer, much of it exported to US, will still be made in Germany, where law dating almost 500 years insists purity of product; company does not specify price or probable suitor; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | The Americas: Canada: Marijuana Fields
abstract: Canadian Health Minister Alan Rock tours country's first legal marijuana farm; it is operating under new law allowing Canadians suffering from life-threatening or chronic illnesses to use marijuana for medical purposes (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Finland: Nokia's Sales Falling
abstract: Nokia says it will meet its forecast for third-quarter profit, helped by cost reductions, even though sales are declining (S)

headline: Japan's Budget Deficit Has Soared. It's Time for a Tax Cut.
abstract: Floyd Norris column on Japan's soaring budget deficit urges Prime Min Junichiro Koizumi to consider tax cuts; graph (M)

headline: Article 2001070693627623808 -- No Title
abstract: July 2, 2001

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Amazon Starts A Travel Venture
abstract: Amazon.com introduces department where its shoppers can book travel and buy travel-related merchandise; section includes links to reservations from Expedia.com, big travel site controlled by Microsoft Corp; it also has links to Hotwire.com, which offers restricted discount tickets, and tour packages from National Leisure Group; graph (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: No Risk From Animal Pyres
abstract: British Food Standards Agency says levels of dioxin from animal pyres do not pose health hazards; almost 3.5 million animals were killed to halt foot-and-mouth disease (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Cisco and Verizon In Deal
abstract: Cisco Systems and Verizon are teaming up to provide high-speed Internet services for people who work at home; company say they will focus on Fortune 1000 companies and governments seeking network access at home and office (S)

headline: Iran's Reformers Set Out to Save the Economy
abstract: Iran's reformers hope to pry open economy that is in shambles after 22 years of hermetic trade and investment rules, mismanagement and corruption; state can no longer rely on its oil revenues to close budget shortfalls as children of baby boom in 1980's come of age; Pres Mohammad Khatami's government and its supporters introduce 26-article bill that would allow imports of modern technology, take measures to try to stem capital flight and open new parts of economy to foreign investment; bill is rejected and returned to Parliament by conservative Guardian Council, upper legislative body that rules whether bills comply with Constitution and Islamic law; reformers' hopes now hang on second body whose approval would allow measure to take effect; even if bill passes, there is almost unanimous agreement that, by itself, it is not sufficient to breathe life into economy (M)

headline: Pelotas Journal; Of Gays and Gauchos (and Brazilian Gaucherie)
abstract: Residents of Brazilian city of Pelotas are victims of peculiar prejudice: for more than century, Brazilians of every class and in every part of country have believed that men there are all homosexuals; city is treated as something of national joke, and to make matters worse, it is in state of Rio Grande do Sul, famous for its rough-riding cowboys and rugged, hyper-masculine image; historians trace bias to early 19th century, when Pelotas emerged as prosperous export center and newly wealthy families sent their sons off to be educated in France, where they acquired manners, habits and dress styles that caused them to be regarded at home as dandified intellectuals; annual carnival with long tradition for men to dress up as women has only reinforced city's image; map; photos (Pelotas Journal) (M)

headline: A Panopticon for Plagiarists
abstract: Pillarisetti Sudhir letter replies to June 28 article about students' online assistance with term papers

headline: Fortune in Hand, Russian Tries to Polish Image
abstract: Mikhail Khodorkovsky, chairman of Yukos, Russia's second-largest oil company, and by some estimates the nation's richest man, says he has seen the light.    At the company's headquarters, a 19th-century mansion in central Moscow, Mr. Khodorkovsky sat under a sign saying ''Honesty, Openness, Responsibility'' in late June to discuss the company's latest financial results with reporters with an air of friendly candor.

headline: A Speedier Way to Run Mac Programs on Windows
abstract: SoftMac Xpress software from Emulators Inc allows Windows users to run Macintosh programs and open Mac files on their PC-based machines; photo (M)

headline: Smoothly, NATO Collects More Arms in Macedonia
abstract: Hundreds of ethnic Albanian fighters line up to hand in weapons to NATO troops at rebel training camp in Brodec, Macedonian village in hills above Tetovo; photo; map (M)

headline: Typhoon Deals New Blow to Taiwan Manufacturers
abstract: Typhoon Nari has disrupted production in Taiwan, one of most important supplier of computers, semiconductors and other electronics to US technology industry; will aggravate disruptions in production and shipping that began after terrorist attacks in US last week; photo (M)

headline: National Briefing | South: Alabama: Hospital For Ex-Klansman
abstract: Judge James Garrett of Birmingham, Ala, orders former Ku Klux Klansman Bobby Frank Cherry committed to state psychiatric hospital or further evaluation three weeks after declaring him mentally incompetent to stand trial in 1963 bombing of church which killed four black girls; photo (S)

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Shortchanging Dyslexics To the Editor

headline: Stock Markets Hold Steady a Day After the Big Sell-Off
abstract: US stock market moves little lower but still seems to indicate that many traders are hoping economy will start to recover relatively soon; Dow Jones industrial average falls 17.30 points, to 8,903.40, and Standard & Poor's 500-stock index dips 6.03 points, to 1,032.74; Nasdaq composite index drops 24.47 points, or more than 1.5 percent, to 1,555.08; yield on benchmark 10-year Treasury bond rises to 4.72 percent, still below where is was before terrorist attack but up from 4.55 percent it fell to on Sept 14; euro is worth 92.68 cents, up 0.3 percent from 92.44 cents on Sept 17, and dollar declines 0.4 percent against yen, to 117.23 yen from 117.73; dollar is off 3.1 percent against both currencies since terrorist attack; crude oil for October delivery falls $1.11, to $27.70 per barrel on New York Mercantile Exchange; graphs; charts (M)

headline: Official Hints Israel May Allow U.S. Monitors of Mideast Truce
abstract: Israel's defense minister seemed to open the door to the idea of foreigners monitoring the worsening Israeli-Palestinian conflict

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Unions Call Two-Day Strike
abstract: Zimbabwe workers protesting increase in gasoli

headline: At One Resort in China, Two Distinct Worlds
abstract: Jiang Zemin is latest in long line of China's top leaders over last 40 years to take up residence each summer in West Mountain Compound in resort city of Beidaihe; Beidaihe's beauty was immortalized in well-known poem by Mao Zedong in 1950's, and supreme leader Deng Xiaoping took much publicized swims there in Bohai Sea; many seminal events in modern Chinese history are known to have taken place in Beidaihe; photos; map (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Cambodia: Khmer Rouge Apology
abstract: cambodia: kh

headline: Nervous Traders Push European Shares Sharply Lower
abstract: Europe's leading stock markets drop sharply amid uncertainty about reopening of US markets on Sept 17 and effect of terrorist attacks on World Trade Center and Pentagon; Financial Spreads, financial betting company, is forecasting that Dow Jones industrial average could fall 500 points, to about 9,100, on opening day; euro trades at 91.94 cents in late European trading, up from 90.75 cents; it trades at 92.16 cents, up from 91.16 cents in late trading in New York; dollar trades at 117.48 yen in Europe, down from 119.20 yen; it trades at 117.29 yen in New York, down from 118.79; yields on two-year Treasury notes drop to 2.86 percent from 2.98 percent in New York trading; price rises 7/32, to 101 14/32; yield on 10-year note falls to 4.55 percent from 4.64 percent; price rises 21/32, to 103 17/32; yield on 30-year bond falls to 5.36 percent from 5.39 percent; price rises 17/32, to 100 9/32; graphs (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: CREDIT SUISSE GROUP, Zurich, Switzerland's second-largest bank, agreed to buy Frye-Louis Capital Management Inc., Chicago, a fund manager that overseas about $1.5 billion, to increase its business of running accounts for wealthy families. Terms were not disclosed.    HARRIS CORP., Melbourne, Fla., a maker of satellite communications equipment, said it had won a $222 million contract from the U.S. Army to provide 205 terminals which transmit information between the ground and satellites.

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Argentina: Debt Default
abstract: Alimentos Fargo misses $1.5 million foreign loan payment in what may be start of string of defaults by revenue-squeezed Argentine companies; is renegotiating terms of $30 million loan (S)

headline: Arab Allies Not Jumping to Join U.S. Side
abstract: Only Iraq, among all Arab countries, has so far failed to condemn strikes on World Trade Center and Pentagon; but not even close American allies in region, such as Egypt and Saudi Arabia, have said clearly that they would enlist in American-led campaign against terrorism; this caution reflects difficult choices confronting volatile region; one one hand, there is alarm and outrage at very brazenness of Sept ll attacks; on other, there are clear signs of worry that American-led crackdown could lead to deeper animosities and dangerous backlash (M)

headline: AT&T to Weigh Comcast Offer For Cable Unit
abstract: AT&T Corp chairman, C Michael Armstrong, offers defense of his tenure and strategy, even as he says his company will carefully consider Comcast Corp's unsolicited bid to acquire AT&T's cable television unit; says his plan for overhauling conmpany and spinning off cable business, AT&T Broadband, is on course; rebuts critics who say AT&T's cable assets are being mismanaged; photo (M)

headline: Text of Fed Statement on Interest Rate Reductions
abstract: The Federal Reserve released the following statement following its decision to reduce two key interest rates today:

headline: Some Prefer Online 'A.I.' Tie-In to the Movie
abstract: Some players of an ambitious Internet game that is part of the marketing push for the film "A.I." say it is a more absorbing experience than watching the much-anticipated movie.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Cap Gemini Profit
abstract: Cap Gemini reports first-half net income rose to 110 million euros ($97 million), up 15 percent from 96 million euros a year earlier (S)

headline: South Koreans Challenge Northerner on U.S. Troops
abstract: South Korea rebuffs statement by North Korea's leader Kim Jong Il, issued jointly with Russia's Pres Vladimir Putin in Moscow, demanding that US troops be withdrawn from Korean peninsula since it would speed talks on reunification; Foreign Ministry says presence of American troops is bilateral issue betweenUS and Republic of Korea; Kremlin, in declaration, expressed understanding of North Korean position but did not endorse it (M)

headline: U.S. Seeks Afghan Coalition Against Taliban
abstract: Bush administration backs efforts to build internal coalition in Afghanistan against Osama bin Laden and his Taliban supporters; United States has stepped up contacts with Northern Alliance, also known as United Front, which has been fighting Taliban; group controls only sliver of territory in northern Afghanistan, and it suffered grievous setback when its military leader was assassinated days before attacks in New York and Washington; US has also initiated contacts with Pashtuns, dominant tribe in south; effort to meld together different tribes and factions in country that has long been at war could be very complex, but also crucial to provide help in tracking bin Laden and those Taliban leaders who harbor him; politically, administration wants to counter impression that fight against bin Laden is war against Afghanistan or Islam; Washington will offer those groups that cooperate a role in governing Afghanistan after conflict; plan for bringing stability for nation is important to persuade Pakistan and other neighbors to cooperate; photos (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Philippines: Inflation Slows
abstract: Philippine inflation slowed in August, opening door for interest cut by central bank (S)

headline: Through the Looking Glass, to Holographic Data Storage
abstract: Researchers from Spain and Canada perfect glass compound capable of storing tremendous amount of data holographically, not magnetically; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Pilots Fight Coca in Colombia
abstract: Dozens of private citizens are engaged in Colombia's drug war; American pilots working under State Dept contract in Colombia speak of their experiences spraying fields of coca and heroin poppies that are often guarded by leftist rebels; pilots play down risks, saying danger is minimal because their missions are well-planned operations using high-tech aircraft, advanced electronics systems and armed escorts; there has been harsh criticism among some lawmakers on Capitol Hill who feel US-financed anti-drug program is too heavily reliant on private contractors, particularly pilots who fly spray planes and helicopters serving as escorts (M)

headline: All Aboard, Vladivostok! A Dream Is Growing
abstract: Renewed talk of railroading in far north Yukon territory includes proposal to build 900 miles of track between northern British Columbia and Fairbanks, Alaska; old rail town of Whitehorse also debates maps showing how rail link could arc from British Columbia to Siberia (M)

headline: China Riled Over Planned Visit to Japanese War Shrine
abstract: A controversy over a planned prime ministerial visit next month to a Shinto shrine honoring Japan's war dead escalated sharply today with a stern warning by China to call off the ceremony

headline: Got sticking power? A tagline and a mustache stop a slide in milk consumption.
abstract: BARELY eight years have passed since the campaign first started. But the dairy industry's ads, with the ''Got milk?'' tagline, have made a lasting mark on the American consumer landscape.    A recent study by the California Milk Processor Board indicates that the ads have been instrumental in stemming an erosion in domestic milk sales that seemed pretty much unstoppable back in the early 1990's, when ''Got milk?'' was first devised by Goodby, Silverstein & Partners in San Francisco, a unit of the Omnicom Group.

headline: Sell-Off Eases Late
abstract: Investors jettisoned stocks as too risky and sought relative safety in bonds, sending share prices down sharply for much of the day. But stocks regained much of their losses in the final hour of trading.    Business Day, Page C1.

headline: Honeywell Regroups as Chief Resigns
abstract: Michael R Bonsignore resigns as Honeywell International chairman and chief executive in wake of European Commission rejection of company's acquisition by General Electric; Honeywell names Lawrence A Bossidy to succeed him; sets pretax revamping charge of $575 million to $625 million in second quarter; forecasts lower-than-expected full-year results; Bossidy comments; photo (M)0

headline: Intel Insists Faster Chips Can Aid Sales
abstract: Intel Corp executive vice president, Paul S Otellini, says faster computer chips will help increase computer sales, speech to hardware and software developers one day after Intel introduces Pentium 4 processor, San Jose; acknowledges that rapidly increasing 'clock speed' of company's computer chips will not be enough to spur sluggish computer industry; Microsoft Corp vice president, Jim Allchin, says he expects Windows XP, newest operating system, which goes on sale in September, to spur demand (M)

headline: Big Insurance Brokers Need Help After Trade Center Blast
abstract: Hundreds of corporations that had offices in World Trade Center need help with insurance claims for loss of lives and property, but their brokers are in crisis themselves; Aon Corp, which had one of largest work forces in Trade Center, says that of its 1,100 employees who worked there, about 200 are still missing; Marsh & McLennan Companies says 313 of its employees are missing (M)

headline: Cendant Purchase Is Cleared in Europe
abstract: Cendant Corp's $3.5 billion purchase of travel reservation company Galileo International Inc is approved by European Union regulators (S)

headline: Schröder Urges Milder View Of Moscow Role in Chechnya
abstract: German Chancellor Gerhard Schroder, in first indication of price West may be ready to pay for Russian support in fight against terrorism, holds world should moderate its views of Russia's moves in Chechnya, meeting, Berlin, with Russian Pres Vladimir V Putin; lauds him for aiding battle against terrorism; Putin, speaking in German, is first Russian leader to address German Parliament; calls for international cooperation to isolate terrorists; holds Chechnya rebellion is also sponsored by Islamic militants and terrorists; Egyptian Pres Hosni Mubarak, also meeting Schroder in Berlin, cites need to solve Palestinian problem to end global terrorism, news conference; again backs United States drive against terrorism (M)

headline: Sales and Rising Prices Rouse Housing Market
abstract: National Association of Realtors says resales of homes fell 0.6 percent in June, to annual pace of 5.33 million houses from 5.36 million in May; demand for more expensive houses drove up median price of home to record $152,600 from $145,000 in May; price is 8.8 percent higher than in June 2000, biggest annual increase since 1991; average rate on 30-year mortgage dropped last week to 7.08 percent; rate was 8.21 percent year ago (M)

headline: You Don't Bring Me Chocolates Anymore
abstract: Ogden Nash once wrote that "candy is dandy, but liquor is quicker." Now a marketer of a well-known candy brand is seeking to quicken sales growth with ambitious plans to remake its advertising.

headline: Business Travel; The low-fare airlines fly profitably above the turmoil as the giants struggle with the downturn.
abstract: Business Travel column examines move by aggressively small, low-fare airlines to snatch customers from bigger carriers, struggling with downturn because of decline in business travel spending (M)

headline: Zimbabwe Arrests 4 Over News About Police
abstract: Authorities in Zimbabwe arrest three senior editors and one reporter from nation's only independent daily newspaper, The Daily News, one day after paper reports that militants used police cars during recent looting of white-owned farms; journalists are charged with publishing 'false news' and are eventually released but warned they may be called in for further questioning; arrests mark Zimbabwean government's latest effort to stifle independent news media, which have sharply criticized authorities for condoning political violence, disregarding its courts and encouraging invasion of white-owned farms (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Korea: Contract At Automaker
abstract: South Korea's Kia Motors Corp reaches agreement with union representatives on wage increase for this year; terms include 7.6 percent increase in monthly wages and extra incentives (S)

headline: Gates to Invest $100 Million in Gabelli Asset
abstract: Cascade Investment, personal investment company of William H Gates, Microsoft Corp chairman, will invest $100 million in $26 billion funds management business of Mario Gabelli, helping finance firm's push into Europe (S)

headline: NATION SHIFTS ITS FOCUS TO WALL STREET AS A MAJOR TEST OF ATTACK'S AFTERMATHS
abstract: Informal coalition of government and business implores Wall Street leaders to do what they can as patriotic duty to keep stock markets from tumbling when they reopen on September 17 following terrorist attack on World Trade Center; Bush administration and officials from Federal Reserve and Securities and Exchange Commission mount campaign to bolster investor and consumer confidence and win cooperation from executives of nation''s major banking and investment companies; make clear government expects industry to put need for smooth opening in stock market ahead of short-term trading strategies or other business decisions that might drive share prices down; Pres Bush says incident has affected economy but expresses 'great faith' in nation's economic and financial resiliency; photo (M)

headline: PRUDENTIAL AND AN ITALIAN BANK PLAN FUND VENTURE
abstract: Prudential Financial is joining with Italy's Banca Popolare di Bergamo Credito Varesino to set up new mutual fund company (S)

headline: Texas Jurors Deliberate in First Tire Lawsuit Since Big Recall
abstract: Texas jury begins deliberating whether tire made by Bridgestone/Firestone Inc was to blame for crash in March 2000 that left Marisa Rodriguez paralyzed and brain-damaged; outcome of case could foreshadow Firestone's ability to battle number of other defective-tire lawsuits and show whether its attempts to shift blame for crashes involving its tires to Ford Motor Co will be accepted by jurors; photo (M)

headline: BP'S OIL AND GAS PRODUCTION FALLS 4% IN LAST QUARTER
abstract: The oil company, BP P.L.C. said yesterday that oil and gas production in the second quarter fell some 4 percent from a quarter earlier because of maintenance work at certain fields. Natural gas production from April to June declined to 8.57 billion cubic feet a day from 8.9 billion in the previous quarter, while oil supplies fell to 1.87 million barrels a day in the similar period from 1.94 million barrels, the company said. BP, based in London, has pledged to raise petroleum production by at least 5.5 percent this year.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Sumitomo Lowers Outlook
abstract: Sumitomo Electric Industries says full-year profit might fall more than 20 percent short of projections (S)

headline: Putin Offers Backing to U.S. for Anti-Terror Operations
abstract: President Vladimir V. Putin offered the United States broad support for antiterrorist operations in Afghanistan.

headline: Slaying of Jewish Settler Deals New Blow to Israeli Cease-Fire
abstract: JERUSALEM, July 3 — The body of a Jewish settler shot and stabbed by Palestinians was found early today in the West Bank, dealing another blow to a cease-fire that has all but collapsed in a surge of violence.

headline: Rights Leaders Urge Powell to Attend U.N. Racism Conference
abstract: Group of American civil rights leaders is pressing Sec Colin Powell to go to UN conference on racism and discrimination to make strong showing for US at time when Bush administration has been withdrawing from some international activities; Leadership Conference on Civil Rights asks Powell to lead delegation to Durban, South Africa (M)

headline: WESTVACO IS SET TO CLOSE TWO PACKAGING PLANTS
abstract: Westvaco Corp will close two packaging plants in Richmond, Va, and Memphis, Tenn, eliminating 430 jobs, and take $65 million pretax charge in fourth quarter (S)

headline: Madugahawatte Journal; As Sri Lanka War Brings Ruin, Villages Live Off It
abstract: Eighteen-year ethnic conflict that has set Sri Lankan against Sri Lankan has brought better standard of living to families of many of more than 200,000 men and women, mostly from Sinhalese majority, who have signed up to fight rebels seeking separate Tamil homeland; country's security forces employ five times as many people as tourism industry; as military spending grows to 6.8 percent of economy, more and more people are making living from conflict; in villages like Mudagahawatte, crucial economic role of military as employer saps organized opposition to war; photos; map (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Daewoo Stalled
abstract: Two of three plants of Daewoo Motors in Korea suspend operations after parts suppliers stop sending their products while demanding more than $600 million in overdue payments from bankruptcy court (S)

headline: KIDS HOLDINGS TO BUY CHILDREN'S COMPREHENSIVE
abstract: Children's Comprehensive Services Inc, juvenile-justice services provider, will be acquired by Kids Holdings for about $43.3 million (S)

headline: Investing; Polaroid Makes a Digital Leap, but Is It Enough?
abstract: Polaroid Corp's introduction of two digital printing technologies--Opal, for multicolor images, and Onyx, for monochrome--may not be enough to lift company's stock, which has dropped 55 percent this year and 90 percent over last four years; most pressing concern for investors is company's $549 million in short-term debt; photos (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | The Americas: Brazil: Interest Rate Increase
abstract: Brazil's Central Bank raises basic interest rate to 19 percent from 18.25 percent (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: Stalemate In Religion Case
abstract: Diplomats from US, Germany and Australia press efforts to win release of foreign aid workers arrested in Afghanistan on charges of preaching Christianity (S)

headline: Mandela Is Being Treated for Prostate Cancer
abstract: Nelson Mandela, South Africa's revered black leader, is undergoing treatment for prostate cancer; he is 83; photo (S)

headline: France Refuses To Shut Shelter Near Tunnel
abstract: French court refuses to shut down Red Cross shelter near Channel Tunnel, where growing number of refugees have been massing in hope of sneaking through tunnel to Britain; shelter has caused outrage in Britain, where it is seen as staging area for illegal immigrants, and frustration in France, where officials believe that Britain's liberal asylum policy, not the shelter, is prompting refugees to gather (M)

headline: CORNELL, A PRISON OPERATOR, TO LEASE BACK PROPERTY
abstract: Cornell Companies, which operates 70 prisons in 13 states and District of Columbia, has sold and agreed to lease back 11 of its properties, giving company $173 million to repay debts; company earned $2.13 million in its second quarter, down from $2.19 million year earlier; revenue rose 19 percent, to $65.7 million (S)

headline: In Cable TV, Programmers Provide a Power Balance
abstract: Analysis of intense consolidation of cable television industry in light of possible sale of AT&T's cable assets; top seven cable operators now control over 80 percent of nation's subscribers, up from under 65 percent in 1996 and 44 percent in 1991; mergers among cable companies, which all hold local monopolies, do little to directly enhance power of cable companies over consumer or over their direct competitors: satellite television providers; mergers give cable companies expanded power in their dealings with programmers, also parts of big powerful companies (M)

headline: Terrorists Are Sought in Latin Smugglers' Haven
abstract: FBI agents and police officers from Paraguay, Brazil and Argentina are scouring Ciudad del Este, Paraguay, and other parts of three countries' common border for evidence that region, long notorious as contraband capital of South America, may also be haven for Islamic terrorists; Triple Frontier is home to estimated 12,000 people of Arab descent, most of them members of Lebanese immigrant families; photos; map (M)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: Russian President Vladimir V. Putin signed a law requiring that political parties have national membership

headline: Fans Have Their Say
abstract: EVEN many baseball die-hards believe the game needs improvement. Money & Business asked several prominent fans to play commissioner for a day. Excerpts from their comments follow.    MAYOR RUDOLPH W. GIULIANI , a lifelong Yankee fan, attended the 1961 game in which Roger Maris broke Babe Ruth's single-season home-run record.      Baseball is a better game without the designated hitter. When the pitcher has to bat, it reintroduces the bunt into the game and there's more strategy. Are you going to bat for the pitcher? Are you going to take a risk and leave him in for one more inning? I played the game with the pitcher batting, and I enjoy watching it when he bats. It also seems more natural -- that everyone has to take a turn at the plate.

headline: Six Arab States Offer Support
abstract: Six Gulf Arab states--Saudi Arabia, Bahrain, United Arab Emirates, Kuwait, Oman and Qatar--promise total support and cooperation for effort to find and punish those responsible for attacks in New York and Washington but pointedly couple pledge with call for action against what they call terror attacks by Israel against Palestinians (M)

headline: Pirate Militias From Somalia Spill Into the Gulf of Aden
abstract: Somalia's political instability spills into surrounding seas, where armed militias have been terrorizing ships in the waters off Horn of Africa; research vessel operated by Columbia University's Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory that was monitoring ocean currents narrowly escapes capture; crew of fishing vessel has been held hostage since early August; International Maritime Bureau in London adds Gulf of Aden and other stretches of Somali shoreline to its list of ocean trouble spots (M)

headline: Rate Cuts Translate Into Gains for Bank Sector Funds
abstract: Investors in bank stocks owe a lot to Alan Greenspan. Despite a gloomy stock market, banks are showing positive returns in the last few months, thanks to repeated cuts in interest rates by the Federal Reserve.

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: AOL Alters Pager Pricing
abstract: AOL Time Warner reduces price of its America Online e-mail pager to $99.95 from $329.95, but raises monthly access fee $10, to $29.95; also revamps AOL Mobile Communicator software (S)

headline: Havas Makes Bid For Stake in Tempus
abstract: Havas Advertising buys 3.6 percent of outstanding shares of Tempus Group (S)

headline: Demonstrations Held Outside U.S. Embassy in Indonesia
abstract: With hundreds of protesters burning American flags outside the gates of the United States embassy, the State Department said that most of the embassy staff members could leave the country if they choose.

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Napster Suspends Service During 'Upgrade'
abstract: Napster users were unable to access the file-swapping service for much of the weekend and yesterday while the company worked to transform itself into a fee-based business. A notice posted on the site said: ''File transfers have been temporarily suspended while Napster upgrades the databases that support our new file identification technology. All previous versions of Napster have been disabled. We're making this change as part of our ongoing effort to comply with the court's orders.'' Napster is trying to adhere to a court order issued in March that bans the trade of most copyrighted works. The company has said it will begin its fee-based subscription service later this summer, but has not set an exact date. Use of the service has fallen sharply, to 320,000 users sharing an average of 1.5 songs each recently, down from 1.6 million people sharing 220 songs each in March according to the Webnoize Web research company.   Andrew Zipern (NYT)

headline: Angel Investors Fill Void Left By Risk Capital; Impressing Private Financiers Becomes Crucial to Start-Ups
abstract: Venture capital financing falls from $26.1 billion in first quarter of 2000 to $10.2 billion for first quarter of 2001; cash available went mostly to struggling mid-stage companies already in venture capitalists' portfolios; seed-stage financing plummeted to $32.9 million, down 75 percent from year earlier; group called Band of Angels invested about $25 million in 23 companies in 2000, making it one of most active of many angel networks in US; Center for Venture Research at University of New Hampshire puts number of active angels in America at around 400,000; angel investors are required by Securities and Exchange Commission to have assets of at least $1 million to be accredited; chart; photos (M)

headline: El Bolsón Journal; Patagonian Woodstock Suffers From Popularity
abstract: El Boson, Argentina, which has attracted artsy crowd since 1970's as mecca of Argentina's counterculture has become victim of its own success; development and explosive and unplanned population growth has caused overcrowding, pollution and unemployment; current population of 22,000 compares with 4,000 when flower power bloomed in 1970's, making town one of fastest growing in Argentina; map; photo (M)

headline: Rate Cuts Translate Into Gains for Bank Sector Funds
abstract: Mutual funds focused exclusively on banks are strong performers second quarter, riding upswing in bank stocks that began in March 2000 (M)

headline: Canadian Phone Giant Reports Loss in Quarter
abstract: BCE, Canada's telecommunications and media giant, reports net loss of 31 million Canadian dollars ($20.2 million) in second quarter; revenue rose to 5.71 billion Canadian dollars ($3.72 billion) from 5.36 billion (S)

headline: GoCard Starting A New Division
abstract: GoCard opens new division, GoGorilla, to offer nontraditional marketing methods to clients (S)

headline: Miscellany
abstract: Donald J Holtz and Andrea D Shantz opens Benchmarketing Analytics in Fairfield, Conn, which offers data analysis and communications planning for customer relationship management programs of marketers (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Spain: Bank's Co-Chief Steps Down
abstract: Banco Santander Central Hispano SA says Jose Maria Amusategui, one of two co-chairmen, has resigned, capping months-long dispute with other co-chairman, Emilio Botin, over sharing power; Amusategui also steps down as chairman of executive committee and as director at special board meeting; photo (S)
