headline: Chip Maker In Korea Is Battling Over Loan
abstract: South Korea's Hynix Semiconductor opens public battle with foreign creditors who have threatened to declare it in default of its loan agreement if it fails to repay $46 million debt ahead of schedule; Societe Generale contends Hynix broke its loan agreement when it left Hyundai group; Korean bankers consider rescue plans that would provide combination of more than $3 billion in new loans and stock swaps (M)

headline: Technology Briefing
abstract: INTERNETRUSSIAN SEEKS TO HAVE CHARGES DROPPED Defense law- yers are negotiating to have charges dropped against Dmitri Sklyarov, left, a 26-year-old Russian cryptographer accused of violating a 1998 digital copyright law. A court hearing scheduled for yesterday in San Jose, Calif., was delayed for a week until Aug. 30

headline: Seoul Defends Itself Against I.M.F. Criticism
abstract: South Korea's Financial Supervisory Commission chairman Lee Keun Young defends government's record against criticism that it unwisely pressured Korean banks to extend credit to troubled companies; responds angrily to criticism from International Monetary Fund senior official Stanley Fischer of government's role in approving huge loans; Fischer, in Japan, calls for more expansionary monetary policy that would lower value of yen, making it easier for Japanese companies to export, bringing money into Japan and improving economy of region by increasing imports (M)

headline: On Television; Viewers flee summer reruns, and networks grow alarmed.
abstract: On Television column on sharp falloff in advertising dollars for this fall's programs; executives are also finding that reruns of even most popular serialized dramas have smaller audiences this summer than in past; demise of summer rerun means that economic model for network television, which has always been based on getting two runs of every series episode, is facing collapse; photo (M)

headline: The Fiber Optic Network: Not Exactly a Railroad
abstract: Scott Wedel letter holds Daniel Akst's September 2 article failed to discuss how fiber optic overcapacity is largely result of greater-than-expected advances in increasing data capacity of individual fibers

headline: World Briefing | The Americas: Mexico: Official Is Returned
abstract: Oscar Espinosa is returned from Nicaragua to Mexico to face charges of embezzling more than $45 million in government money during his time as mayor of Mexico City (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Military Funds To Increase
abstract: Min Rudolf Scharping says German military spending will increase over next few years, with army getting added $700 million per year (S)

headline: Salomon Settles Lawsuit on Discrimination
abstract: Equal Employment Opportunity Commission and Salomon Smith Barney settle lawsuit filed in September that accused firm of discrimination against some Haitian, Nigerian and West Indian employees at its data center in New York; agrees to pay $635,000 to victims and to treat more fairly four who remain employed as computer operators; will also develop specific criteria for promotion of other computer operators in data center (S)

headline: People
abstract: Leo Burnett Technology names Steffan Postaer chief creative officer, succeeding Jamie Pfaff, who is leaving; names Mark Faulkner executive creative director, new post; Cartel Creativo names Pablo Muniz to new post of chief strategist (S)

headline: Private Sector; Is There a Decorator in the House?
abstract: Architectural Digest magazine editor in chief, Paige Rense, choses Ralph Lauren Interiors to redecorate her office; photo (S)

headline: Insurer Says Hyundai Deal Could Falter
abstract: Consortium led by American International Group signs $1.16 billion deal to take over financial units of crumbling Hyundai empire could collapse, but AIG warns just hours later that deal could collapse; consortium is to take 55 percent of Hyundai Investment Trust and Securities, nearly 30 percent of Hyundai Trust Management and a stake in Hyundai Securities; AIG contends that Hyundai Securities shares are overvalued (M)

headline: F.A.A. Denies Airline Plea on Pilot Rest
abstract: Federal Aviation Administration, in letter to Air Transport Association, denies request from major airlines to suspend its enforcement of rule limiting how many hours each day commercial pilot can work; association says it is likely to seek court-ordered stay (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Hospital Equipment Unsafe
abstract: British Medical Journal publishes reseach finding that nearly 30 percent of anesthetic machines in British hospitals are unsafe; study follows death of child in February (S)

headline: Neighbors Press Zimbabwe to Solve Its Land Reform Crisis
abstract: Regional African leaders attending two-day meeting in Harare press Zimbabwe government to settle land reform crisis; Bakili Muluzi, president of Malawi, opens conference with unequivocal denunciation of government, saying turmoil of country's own making (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Judge Demands 'Key Logging' Explanation
abstract: Judge Nicholas H Politan orders Justice Dept to reveal technical information about 'key logger' system used to procure password used by Nicodemo S Scarfo Jr, who faces charges of illegal gambling and loansharking; seeks to determine whether government violated Scarfo's constitutional rights by installing key logger without wiretap order, which would be necessary if online communications were recorded (S)

headline: Graves of the Missing Haunt Sri Lanka
abstract: Since the late 1980's, more than 20,000 people have vanished after being taken into government custody during two violent rebellions.

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Slide In Chip Sales Continues
abstract: Semiconductor sales extend their sharp decline into June, tumbling 9 percent from May and 31 percent year over year; chipmakers' June worldwide revenue is $11.6 billion (S)

headline: Hypothesis: Science Gap. Cause: Japan's Ways
abstract: Japan creates new national commission, headed by Nobel laureate Hideki Shirakawa, to revitalize Japanese science; commission will evaluate why Japan, immensely rich with more than century of universal education and world's second largest economy, performs more like modestly endowed middle-ranking country; disillusioned scientists cite as most major obstacle fact that research community has never managed to fully embrace peer review and criticism, whose sparks have always served to light creative fires in West; Shirakawa comments; photo (M)

headline: Stop and Shop Hires Mullen
abstract: Stop and Shop Supermarket Co names Mullen Advertising to handle its broadcast account; spending estimated at $7 million to $10 million (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Foreign Reinsurance
abstract: State-owned People's Insurance Co of China

headline: Executive Changes at Media Firms
abstract: Lynette Harrison was named publisher at InStyle magazine, New York, part of the Time Inc. unit of AOL Time Warner

headline: AMERITRADE PROFITS FALL 98% AS ONLINE TRADING DECLINES
abstract: Ameritrade Holding Corp says profit fell 98 percent in fiscal third quarter, to $70,000; sales fell 26.5 percent, to $112.6 million (S)

headline: European Union Stalls Coke-Nestlé Venture
abstract: European Commission asks Coca-Cola Co and Nestle SA to resubmit proposal to expand their joint venture for ready-to-serve beverages because original submission was incomplete (S)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: MONDAYNon

headline: F.D.A. Issues a Safety Warning On Imported Jelly Cup Candies
abstract: Food and Drug Administration warns that bite-sized jelly cup candies imported from Asia may pose choking hazard, especially to children (M)

headline: INVESTING WITH/Matthew P. Ziehl; Salomon Brothers Small Cap Growth Fund
abstract: Matthew P Ziehl, lead manager for Salomon Brothers Small Cap Growth fund, reveals team's investment strategy; photo; chart; list of data (M)

headline: On Television; 'Six Feet Under,' a morbid new comedy, tugs at HBO's evolving identity.
abstract: IS ''Six Feet Under,'' the dark new HBO comedy about a family in the undertaking business, ready to stake a claim as successor to ''The Sopranos'' and ''Sex and the City'' as the next breakthrough, high-quality, award-worthy hit series for that cable network?    Or, as several devoted fans of HBO's increasingly influential Sunday night lineup put it last week, is the series at best an interesting show that does not yet absorb them in the way those other HBO hits do, or at worst, a massive miss that, in the words of one viewer, ''is so grim and depressing that I totally hate it?''

headline: Slowdown Is Seen In U.S. Retail Sales
abstract: National Retail Federation says retail sales will rise about half as much as forecast in fourth quarter; expects 2.2 percent gain from year-earlier period, instead of 4 percent increase (S)

headline: Bertie Felstead, 106, Soldier Who Joined a Timeout in War
abstract: Bertie Felstead, the last known surviving member of the British battalion in World War I that laid down its weapons to play soccer with the Germans in a spontaneous and long-remembered Christmas truce of 1915, died July 22 in Gloucester, England. He was 106.    The truce lasted perhaps half an hour and it meant nothing in the grand schemes of the Western Front generals. But the gesture by Private Felstead's Royal Welch Fusiliers and the Bavarian infantrymen who faced them resonates in the British consciousness as a poignant interlude of civility during a time of  unrelenting carnage.

headline: Khmer Rouge Suspects Feel Pressure Is Building for Trial
abstract: In a sure sign that the trials of former Khmer Rouge leaders in Cambodia are really coming, the accused are all preparing their defenses

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Colombia: Congressman Slain
abstract: Colombian congressman Jairo Rojas is shot to death outside home, second member of peace commission to be murdered in nine months (S)

headline: OPEC Holds Informal Talks; Decision on Output Likely Today
abstract: OPEC ministers end informal talks in Vienna without announcing decision on daily production levels, but delegates at meetings say group plans to leave output unchanged; crude oil for November delivery rises 57 cents, or 2.6 percent, to $22.38 on New York Mercantile Exchange; oil prices have dropped more than 20 percent since terrorist attacks on US; graph; chart (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Rightist Denies Immigrant Slur
abstract: Umberto Bossi, leader of Italy's Northern League, denies responsibility for anti-immigrant flyer that was distributed at party's annual gathering in Venice (S)

headline: Agile in a Crisis, Robots Show Their Mettle
abstract: Robots used in clean-up operation of World Trade Center site are able to search in places where human rescuers cannot or dare not go; they are mostly prototypes financed by National Science Foundation and Office of Naval Research and, rather than Star Wars-like androids, they are squat, utilitarian machines resembling tanks; rescuers use images relayed by robots to determine if further exploration of specific area appears worthwhile; photos (M)

headline: A Perilous Road in Israel Becomes a Death Trap Again
abstract: Israeli-Palestinian violence continues across West Bank; eight people, including six Israelis, die during weekend of clashes; three soldiers die in raid by Palestinian attackers on Army base in Gaza Strip; three members of one family are slain on Modiin road, which links outskirts of Jerusalem with town of Modiin in West Bank and has become target for Palestinian gunmen and death trap for Israeli travelers; unidentified Israeli man from coastal town of Netanya is shot to death on little-traveled road north of Tulkarm, in West Bank; little-known Aksa Martrys Brigade claims responsibility; Israeli forces launch reprisal assaults; demolish police stations in four Palestinian towns; some right-wing Cabinet members within coalition government of Prime Min Ariel Sharon begin expressing frustration with policy of tit-for-tat retaliation; maps; photos(M)

headline: World Business Briefing
abstract: AMERICASBRAZIL: BANKER'S DEATH The death of Gastáo Eduardo de Bueno Vidigal, the 82-year old chairman and majority shareholder of Banco Mercantil de São Paulo, caused shares in the bank to jump sharply on speculation that it would quickly be sold. Under pressure from minority shareholders who disagreed with his conservative investment style, Mr. Vidigal had started searching for buyers for the bank, Brazil's 22nd largest in terms of assets, but was not eager to sell the family-controlled business. Last month, Mr. Vidigal held talks with Citigroup, which has expressed interest in expanding its branch network.   Jennifer L. Rich (NYT) EUROPE BRITAIN: BANK PROFIT RISES First-half profit at the Royal Bank of Scotland rose 42 percent after last year's takeover of NatWest, which reduced costs and increased revenue. The increase fell short of analysts' expectations, but the bank's shares gained as much as 1.7 percent. The bank said earnings rose to £1.1 billion ($1.6 billion) in the first half compared with £779 million in the first half of 2000. Fred Goodwin, the chief executive, said the bank, based in Edinburgh, planned to acquire a small European bank. Last month, it agreed to buy the retail business of Mellon Financial in the United States. It also owns the Citizens Financial Group, the No. 2 New England banking company.   Alan Cowell (NYT) IRELAND: PROFIT AT AIRLINE As major airlines report slumping business, Ryanair, Europe's biggest low-cost carrier, said it bucked the trend with a 28 percent profit increase in the quarter ended June 30. But the Dublin- based airline, modeled on Southwest Airlines of the United States, said its outlook for the future was cautious. Major European airlines have announced lower profits or curbed expansion plans. Ryanair said after- tax profit rose to 23.2 million euros ($20.4 million) after it expanded its European network with 13 new routes. Its shares retreated.

headline: A Crisis Response: Buying American
abstract: Survey by Insight Express finds that more Americans are likely to 'buy American' than before World Trade Center terrorist attacks (S)

headline: Agency Layoffs and a Closing
abstract: Agency Layoffs And a Closin

headline: Government Is Wary of Tackling Online Privacy
abstract: Last article in three-part series Tracks in Cyberspace, on online privacy, focuses on US government's reluctance to tackle issue; momentum has dissipated in federal government for new laws and regulations that might restrict use of cookies and other high-technology tools by businesses to monitor Internet users' activities; holds some lawmakers say that politics of privacy is so sensitive and complex that deliberate approach is best, but there is growing agreement that some kind of government action will eventually have to emerge; Mozelle W Thompson, member of Federal Trade Commission appointed by Pres Clinton, says companies will have to prove to consumers that giving up privacy is trade that will have negative repercussions; Marc Rotenberg of Electronic Privacy Information Center says nation needs legal framework on how these technologies are used; photos (M)

headline: French Court Backs Chirac On Elements Of Graft Case
abstract: French court hands Pres Jacques Chirac victory, annulling central elements of case that had implicated him in illicit fund-raising scheme when he was mayor of Paris; rules proper procedures were not followed (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia/Pacific: Sri Lanka: Politics Won't Stop Peace Effort
abstract: Sri Lankan government says deal it made for support of small Marxist party will not hamper its efforts to start talks with separatist Tamil rebels (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: U.S. Agency Asks Firestone To Recall Additional Tires  The Transportation Department said it had asked Bridgestone/Firestone to recall additional tires but the company insisted that its tires were safe and that it would state its case at a public hearing and in court.    As a result, the government said it would begin a proceeding to start a mandatory recall, only the 10th time since 1966 that it has done so. [Page C4.]

headline: Price-Fixing Indictment
abstract: Justice Department says Japan's Ishihara Sangyo Kaisha Ltd has been indicted by grand jury in Philadelphia on a charge of conspiring to fix prices of magnetic iron oxide particles (S)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: ASIA CHINA: U.S. SHIPS ENTER HONG KONG Two United States warships sailed into Hong Kong's harbor in a resumption of port calls that had been halted by the Chinese government after the mid-air collision between Chinese and American military planes last April. The Guardian and the Patriot, both minesweepers, will anchor in Hong Kong until Monday. In May, when relations between the countries were tense, China denied a request by the Inchon to call at the former British colony    Mark Landler (NYT) JAPAN: BOW TO SHRINE'S WAR LEGACY The foreign minister, Makiko Tanaka, said she would urge Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi to cancel plans to visit the Yasukuni Shrine in Tokyo next month where criminals from World War II are enshrined. Ms. Tanaka told reporters in Hanoi where she was attending a meeting of foreign ministers: "I don't want him to visit there. This is my consistent view." Mr. Koizumi's plans to visit the shrine have drawn heavy criticism from China and Korea, which suffered atrocities by Japan during the war.    Howard W. French (NYT) SOUTH KOREA: PROTESTS OVER BOMBING RANGE Villagers protested against an American bombing range on two fronts. In Seoul, 30 people from Maehyang-ri, by the Yellow Sea southwest of the capital, protested at the offices of Lockheed Martin, which makes the F-16 planes used by American and Korean air forces and operates the bombing range in their village. At the range, villagers tried to break through rows of policemen, demanding that the range be closed.    Don Kirk (NYT) NORTH KOREA: LEADER ON THE ROAD Kim Jong Il roared through Russia on the Trans-Siberian Railroad with no time off to look at the city where historians say he was born. His train paused just 20 minutes in Khabarovsk, then resumed his official journey to Moscow. His official biographies insist that Mr. Kim, 59, was born in a hut on Mount Paektu, the sacred mountain on the North Korea- China border.    Don Kirk (NYT) INDIA: `BANDIT QUEEN' IS CREMATED With a manhunt on to find her killers, Phoolan Devi, India's "bandit queen" was cremated on the banks of the Ganges in Uttar Pradesh, her home state. A mourner was killed as throngs grieved. Ms. Devi, one of India's best-known women, had been a robber, murderer and member of Parliament.    Barry Bearak (NYT) PAKISTAN: DEATH SENTENCE UPHELD The Lahore High Court has rejected the appeal of Ayub Masih, who was condemned to death in 1998 for violating blasphemy laws. He is accused of making derogatory remarks about the Prophet Muhammad. When he was originally sentenced, a Roman Catholic bishop, John Joseph, apparently killed himself in protest. Mr. Masih can now appeal to the supreme court.    Barry Bearak (NYT) EUROPE

headline: Investing; A Jolt at Callaway Golf, But a Firm Foundation
abstract: Article assesses prospects for Callaway Golf in wake of death of founder, Ely Callaway; graph (M)

headline: Rebel Chief Who Fought The Taliban Is Buried
abstract: Ahmed Shah Massoud, legendary commander who held together last remaining resistance to Afghanistan's Taliban government, is buried after succumbing to wounds sustained in assassination attempt week ago; Massoud's death causes confusion among anti-Taliban forces; he was charismatic guerrilla fighter who kept remaining anti-Taliban forces together; Burhanuddin Rabbani, Afghan leader deposed by Taliban in 1996, claims, without citing evidence, that assassination was conspiracy involving Pakistan, terrorist group of Osama bin Laden and Taliban; Mohammad Fahim is named new defense chief of anti-Taliban rebels; photo of some of thousands of anti-Taliban Afghan fighters gathered to honor Massoud (M)

headline: MICROSOFT TO GIVE COMPUTER MAKERS GREATER FREEDOM
abstract: Microsoft Corp says it will give personal computer makers more freedom to choose what software and services they offer on machines they sell; concession by Microsoft is in response to federal appeals court decision that many of Microsoft's licensing deals with computer makers are an illegal abuse of its monopoly power; industry analysts and company's opponents in antitrust suit consider this a limited step, but do not expect it to have much impact on industry and competition; antitrust suit filed by Justice Dept and several states did focus on market for Internet browsing software, but it raised broader competitive issues as well; what is unclear is whether Microsoft's measured step is initial signal that company is willing to accept court decision, modify its behavior and take significant further steps to settle suit; chart (M)

headline: A Fatal Battle Worsens in Colombia: The War on Journalists
abstract: Colombia has long been one of most dangerous countries in world for journalists; New York-based Committee to Protect Journalists says six Colombian journalists have been slain this year, and last year seven journalists were killed, at least three as reprisals for their work; press freedoms are being attacked as country suffers wave of political violence; although rights groups say paramilitary groups are most responsible for journalists' deaths, rebels have also killed reporters (M)

headline: Kmart Diversity Officer
abstract: Kmart Corp names Randy Allen to newly created positions of executive vice president for strategic initiatives and chief diversity officer (S)

headline: AT&T UNIT SELLS $2.6 BILLION OF ASSETS TO PAY DOWN DEBT
abstract: AT&T Broadband has completed the sale of $2.6 billion of cable systems to three companies to pay off debt, which the company said was $47.5 billion on March 31. AT&T said it sold systems in St. Louis, Reno, Nev., and parts of Alabama to Charter Communications for $1.75 billion and a cable system in Sebastian, Fla., valued at $24 million. It also sold a system in Baltimore to Comcast for $518 million and one serving parts of Missouri to Mediacom Communications for $309 million. Charter is based in St. Louis, Mediacom in Middletown, N.Y., and Comcast in Philadelphia.

headline: Executive Changes in Media and Advertising
abstract: Larry Davis, senior vice president for advertising and marketing at the Kmart Corporation, Troy, Mich., resigned. A successor is being sought. He was the second top marketing executive to leave Kmart recently, after Brent Willis, chief marketing officer for six months, resigned in May.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Bank Profit Falls
abstract: Commerzbank AG reports 87 percent decline in second-quarter 2001 net, to $83 million, compared with year-earlier period; photo (S)

headline: Brazil Weighs Replacing Police Strikers With Troops
abstract: Brazilian government, facing growing movement of strikes by police forces across country, threatens to use army to replace police and maintain public order; confrontation stems from 13-day police strike in Bahia state, which ended after state gave 21 percent pay raise to strikers; police have since walked out or threatened strikes in several other jurisdictions (M)

headline: Investing; Turnaround Odds on a Fallen Highflier
abstract: Analysts discuss investment potential of JDS Uniphase, optical equipment maker that has written down value of its acquisitions by $44.8 billion and whose stock, which hit high of $153.42 a share in March 2000, is now at $9.47; cartoon; graph (M)

headline: Leading Index Fell in August For First Time Since March
abstract: Conference Board's index of leading economic indicators fell 0.2 percent in August, after rising 0.4 percent in July; decrease reflects fewer hours worked in factories and decline in consumer expectations; graph (M)

headline: Executive Changes at Media Firms
abstract: Colle & McVoy, Minneapolis, named three executives to posts and promoted two

headline: Nuclear Tests Not Planned, China Diplomat Says
abstract: Chinese diplomat says China has no plans to test its nuclear weapons; makes statement in response to claims by Bush administration officials that tests are likely; diplomat says China is signer of Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty and would stand by intent of treaty (S)

headline: Macedonia Talks Are Moved Away From Heated Emotions
abstract: Western diplomats shuttle among leaders in Macedonia, laying groundwork for direct talks to be held in resort area far from heated emotions that have prodded country ever closer to outright war (M)

headline: Excerpts From Justice Dept. Decision on Microsoft
abstract: Excerpts from statement by Justice Department announcing that it will not seek breakup of Microsoft Corp (M)

headline: Rights Desired By Albanians Appear Closer In Macedonia
abstract: Macedonia's Parliament votes in favor of constitutional changes to grant ethnic Albanian minority more rights, allowing NATO to resume its collection of weapons from ethnic Albanian rebels and setting peace process back on track; Parliament's drawn-out debate had threatened to delay NATO operations beyond its planned 30 days (M)

headline: Terror Strikes America / Political Strategies: Schroeder Urges Europe To Stand Against Foes
abstract: PARIS—  Germany is ready to take military risks to back up its commitment of unlimited solidarity with the United States, Chancellor Gerhard Schroeder said on Wednesday, and called on Europe to strengthen its cooperation in a battle against terrorism.

headline: A Company Credo, as Applied or Not
abstract: Johnson & Johnson, which won plaudits for corporate values displayed in 1982 when it decided to pull Tylenol off shelves, at cost of $100 million, after seven deaths were linked to bottles that had been tampered with, raises some concern among its customers and employees by its its conduct in failing to notify Food and Drug Administration of glitch in software for SureStep diabetes diagnostic device LifeScan makes; drawing (M)

headline: Article 2001080493912461317 -- No Title
abstract: Find a Job            Post a Job            Find a Home            Personals            All Classifieds                 International            National            Politics            Business           Technology          -     E-Business          -     Circuits          -    Columns           Science            Health            Arts            Sports            New York Region            Weather            Obituaries            NYT Front Page            Corrections                 Editorials/Op-Ed            Readers' Opinions

headline: Perhaps the Revenge of Candlestick Park?
abstract: DIARYPerhaps the Revenge Of Candlestick Park?  The San Francisco Giants have relatively few worries. They are strong contenders for the National League playoffs. Their star slugger Barry Bonds is closing in on the record season of 70 home runs by Mark McGwire of the St. Louis Cardinals in 1998. Their year-old, $255 million Pacific Bell Park, which seats 41,059, is one of the Bay Area's biggest attractions. But the Giants have a potential problem: the lights could go out, and at just the wrong moment

headline: World Business Briefing
abstract: AMERICAS BRAZIL: TELECOMMUNICATIONS DEAL Portugal Telecom withdrew a $2.4 billion offer to buy the shares it did not own of the Brazilian cellular provider Telesp Celular Participações, after the stock dropped below a level set as a condition for the bid. Portugal Telecom said it might make a new bid once market conditions improved. In May, Portugal Telecom offered to buy the remaining 58.8 percent of Telesp Celular in a stock swap. The move was intended to strengthen Portugal Telecom's position in a joint venture with Telefónica of Spain that combined both companies' holdings in Brazil.   Jennifer L. Rich (NYT) CANADA: GAS PIPELINE PLANNED TransCanada Pipelines and National Fuel Gas plan to build a 215-mile natural gas pipeline from Ontario to Pennsylvania to profit from growing demand for fuel in the Northeast United States. The project will cost $350 million to $400 million and is expected to be completed in late 2004, said TransCanada Pipelines, based in Calgary, Alberta, and National Fuel Gas, based in Buffalo. The line would start in Kirkwall, Ontario, enter the United States near Buffalo and end in the Ellisburg-Leidy area of Pennsylvania. The capacity would be 500 million cubic feet a day.   (Bloomberg News) EUROPE ITALY: OLIVETTI FINANCING Olivetti said it would sell up to $15 million in new stock and bonds the next five years in its first major move since Pirelli took a controlling stake in the company. The news set off a 16 percent decline in Olivetti's stock, and analysts said they were concerned because the company, which owns a controlling stake in Telecom Italia, would not disclose what it planned to do with the money

headline: Personal Business; The Perils of Planning One's Own Prepaid Funeral
abstract: Death care industry is becoming increasingly aggressive in marketing new products and services, especially prepaid funeral plans; trade groups are trying to help consumers sort through marketing blitz, but some consumer advocates complain that people are still being pressed to sign up for things they neither need nor want, and at prices that are often questionably high or not fully disclosed; photo (M)

headline: BIG AIRLINES RELAX STAY-OVER POLICY FOR LOWER FARES
abstract: Nation's biggest airlines are dropping Saturday night stay-over as requirement for cheaper fare on certain routes in effort to halt decline in business travel; stay-over rule, whose purpose is to persuade passengers to pay more for less restrictive ticket, has been bane of business travelers for more than 20 years; whatever success airlines have could damage hotel business, another industry struggling amid economic downturn, which has benefited as more and more companies forced employees to buy cheaper tickets with Saturday night stay-overs; graphs (M)

headline: One Less Thorn, Perhaps, in Peace Negotiations in Macedonia
abstract: Peace talks in Macedonia take tentative, but significant, step forward; political leaders announce agreement on perhaps thorniest issue dividing them and tense nation; say Albanian, spoken by roughly third of population, would become official language, alongside Macedonian; leaders say they would release no details of plan until they reach overall political agreement; say agreement on language question is provisional, meaning it would not go into effect until remaining issues have been settled; most difficult question on table is ethnic composition of national police force (M)

headline: Powell Presses to Resume Talks With North Korea
abstract: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell said today that American officials were prepared to go anywhere at any time of North Korea's choice to resume talks

headline: New Delhi To Intervene In a Dispute With Enron
abstract: Indian government says it will interview in dispute between Enron Corp and state-run electric utility in Maharashtra state over power from Enron-controlled Dabhol Power Co; Maharashtra utility, Dabhol's sole customer, defaulted on $64 million in back payments, saying Dabhol's prices were too high; project is largest foreign investment yet made in India, and dispute darkens India's investment climate; photo (M)

headline: The Battle Lines Of the Mommy Wars
abstract: Gerri Stiner letter comments on July 1 article about mothers who work

headline: MASTERCARD INTENDS TO BECOME PRIVATE SHARE COMPANY
abstract: MasterCard International plans to issue tradable shares to banks around world that own it (S)

headline: Italy's Leader Defends Police Actions at Genoa Summit Talks
abstract: Prime Min Silvio Berlusconi of Italy defends police actions at Group of Eight summit conference in Genoa, even as officials elsewhere in Europe question heavy use of force against demonstrators there; July 20-22 summit meeting has become international embarrassment for Berlusconi's center-right government; police shot one demonstrator dead and are accused of beating scores of peaceful protesters; 16 Austrians and 4 Americans remain in Italian jails, and Pres Thomas Klestil of Austria has formally petitioned Italy to release members of group that demonstrates through street theater; polls show majority of Italians agree with Berlusconi about way police handled demonstrators (M)

headline: Media Executives Ask Senate Not to Limit Ownership Growth
abstract: As Federal regulators prepare to loosen or eliminate the rules that have restricted the largest broadcasters from growing bigger and owning newspapers, senior executives from Viacom Inc. and the Tribune Company asked the Senate today not to intervene.

headline: A Tale Of Woe In Cable Country
abstract: Salvatore Muoio, media and communications analyst, assesses Comcast's huge bid to AT&T's cable television properties; photo (M)

headline: Robert R. Nathan, 92, Dies; Set Factory Goals in War
abstract: Robert R Nathan, economist who helped lead nation's industrial mobilization in World War II, dies at age 92; photo (M)

headline: CHINA NOW FACING AN AIDS EPIDEMIC, A TOP AIDE ADMITS
abstract: Senior Chinese official openly admits that China is facing AIDS epidemic that threatens to outpace government efforts to control it; Deputy Health Min Yin Dakui, in surprise news conference, departs from Chinese government's general reticence on subject of AIDS; concedes government's failure to develop effective education programs and tendency of some local officials to cover up extent of infection in their jurisdictions, allowing disease to spread unchecked; Yin discusses, for first time, AIDS epidemic covered up in Henan Province, where tens of thousands of poor farmers contracted AIDS by selling their blood using unsterilized practices; government's apparent commitment to greater openness about AIDS is undercut by fact that reports on Yin's lengthy news conference in state-controlled press are brief and statistical, leaving out Yin's judgment that China faces 'serious epidemic' and not mentioning Henan Province by name at all; photos (M)

headline: Trees Bind Angkor Temples in Perilous Grip
abstract: Trees threaten massive temples of Angkor, Cambodia, one of world's great cities between 9th and 15th centures; temples are one of history's architectural glories, but roots of century-old trees are have dug their way so deeply into monuments that they hold them at their mercy, binding them even as they rip them apart; photos; map (L)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Jet Sale Sets Record On Ebay
abstract: Gulfstream II business jet sells on eBay for $4.9 million, the highest price paid for any item on the company's online auction sites (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Sharon Visit Irks Iranian
abstract: Iranian Min Ali Shamkhani calls off major arms-purchasing mission to Russia, refusing to arrive during visit there by Israeli Prime Min Ariel Sharon (S)

headline: World Business Briefing
abstract: ASIA

headline: Charles S. Whitehouse, 79, Diplomat and C.I.A. Official
abstract: Charles S Whitehouse, former Central Intelligence Agency official and ambassador to Laos and Thailand, dies at age 79 (M)

headline: Energy Crisis Is Just One More Thing for Brazil
abstract: Major setback to Brazil's already faltering economy is California-style energy crisis that has forced government to ration electricity and warn that even twenty percent cut in consumption may not be enough to blackouts; photo of illegal electrical connections; wave of corruption scandals has already sapped public confidence in leadership, just six months after general optimism about growth and stability (M)

headline: I Frown on Distractions
abstract: Baltimore Ravens coach Brian Billick writes The Boss column; photo (M)

headline: No. 2 Official at I.M.F. Offers a Bleak Forecast
abstract: Stanley Fischer, outgoing deputy director of International Monetary Fund, says world economy is skirting edge of recession, harmed by Japan's predicted contraction and rapid slowing of US economy; says significant slowdown is exacting toll on emerging-market economies like Turkey and Argentina that are trying to recapture investor confidence and pull out of their own recessions (M)

headline: ARAB FURY RISING AT ENEMY WITHIN
abstract: Anger among Palestinians over Arabs suspected of collaborating with Israel is running high, especially since Israeli Army has renewed campaign of killing Palestinians it believes are security threats; most Palestinians believe turncoats among them are helping Israel track down men on its wanted list, and anger has fed demand that Palestinian police make priority of rounding up collaborators; indications are that police are doing so; about 60 Palestinians have been arrested in Nablus since killing by Israeli Army of eight people, including Hamas leader described by Israel as terrorism mastermind; Palestinian security courts have sentenced four people to death by firing squad for treason; Palestinian vigilantes have killed three or four men suspected of working with Israel; trial of Munzer Hafnawi, who is accused of helping Israel kill Hamas activist, discussed; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: France: No Haven
abstract: France will not open second refugee center near English Channel, and will work with Britain to tighten security at railroad and road terminal; France will also tighten sanctions against Afghan, Kurdish and other migrants trying to get into Britain illegally; British immigration authorities will go to French side to dissuade people at Red Cross center (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Bank Profits
abstract: Brazil's Uniao de Bancos Brasileiros says net income rose 51 percent to $89 million in second quarter of 2001, compared with same period in 2000 (S)

headline: W.W.F. Meets the Web: It's a Body Slam!
abstract: Web site of World Wrestling Federation aggressively directs users toward its many offline properties, including pay-per-view television events, magazines and videos; site develops relationship with fans and taps their boundless ardor; hopes to improve sophistication of streaming video, initiative that has potential to generate major profits; photo (M)

headline: Stocks Slump on Fears Economy Won't Recover Quickly
abstract: Stocks slump on fears that economy will not recover quickly; Dow Jones industrial average declines 234.99 points, to 9,605.85; Nasdaq composite index drops 17.94 points, to 1,687.70; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index falls 20.62 points, to 1,085.78; Treasury securities interest rates fall; 10-year note's yield is down to 4.78 percent; 30-year bond yields 5.37 percent; graphs; table of key rates (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Profit Up For Drug Maker
abstract: Aventis SA posts 31 percent increase in second-quarter earnings, to $345 million; raises forecast for growth in 2001 earnings; demand for blood-thinner Lovenox is strong (S)

abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   6.50   6.50   9.50        Discount rate   3.00   3.00   6.00        Federal funds   3.69   3.66   6.61        3-month T-bills   3.36   3.28   6.06        6-month T-bills   3.31   3.19   6.03        10-yr. headline: Trying to Regain Equilibrium in a World Turned Upside Down
abstract: Steven Putnam, flight attendant, writes My Job column on how terrorist attacks on New York and Washington have made him rethink flying; photo (M)

headline: Article 2001080490291912936 -- No Title
abstract: The New York Times: Business Paper Version                                                                                                          Find a Job            Post a Job            Find a Home            Personals            All Classifieds                 International            National            Politics           Business          -     Media & Advertising          -     World Business          -     Your Money          -     Markets          -     Company Research          -     Mutual Funds          -     Stock Portfolio          -     Columns            Technology            Science            Health            Arts            Sports            New York Region            Weather            Obituaries            NYT Front Page            Corrections                 Editorials/Op-Ed            Readers' Opinions

headline: Nations in Pacific Rim Are Supporting Airlines
abstract: Hong Kong, Singapore, South Korea, Australia and New Zealand say they will bridge sudden shortfall in insurance coverage by their carriers after terrorist attacks in US; moves come hours before industry says it will limit coverage to $50 million per flight for death, injury and property damage on ground for crashes, hijackings or other disasters; Cathay Pacific Airways and Dragonair have negotiated new policy with insurers that would allow them to continue flying without public assistance (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Reuters Net Falls
abstract: Reuters Group's first-half profit fell 21 percent, to 269 million pounds ($381 million); company will cut 1,340 jobs, or about 7 percent of work force (S)

headline: Martha Stewart to Run Spot on Space Organizers
abstract: Martha Stewart Spot On Space Organizer
