headline: Europeans Critical of U.S. Foreign Policy, Polls Find
abstract: Ordinary Europeans strongly back their political leaders' unhappiness with American foreign policy, polls in France, Germany, Great Britain and Italy show

headline: Executive Changes at Media Firms
abstract: Mark Berlinsky, an advertising sales manager at MetroChannels, was promoted to director for integrated sales at Rainbow Advertising Sales Corporation

headline: AOL, Blaming Terrorist Attacks, Says It Will Fall Far Short of Its Goals
abstract: AOL Time Warner Inc, world's biggest media company, says it will miss its financial goals for year, largely because Sept 11 terrorist attacks exacerbated erosion of advertising market; company expects revenue growth of at least 5 percent (M)

headline: Gauging a 'Morningstar Effect'
abstract: Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta reports that stock mutual funds attract 53 percent more money from investors in six months after receiving five-star rating from Morningstar Inc (S)

headline: Hidden Barriers to Health Coverage
abstract: Study by Commonwealth Fund finds that high premiums and tight restrictions play major role in keeping many workers without healthcare coverage, even those employed by companies that offer insurance plans; problems are most acute for low-wage earners; drawing (M)

headline: Founder Is Forced to Resign At Irish Software Developer
abstract: Fran Rooney, founder of Irish security software developer Baltimore Technologies, resigns as chief executive and deputy chairman; shareholders have been pressuring Rooney to resign after series of bungled announcements and missed financial goals last six months; chief financial officer Paul Sanders will also serve as acting chief executive (M)

headline: Deadly Attacks Traded Over West Bank Line
abstract: Israelis and Palestinians trade lethal blows across disputed boundary, and Prime Min Ariel Sharon says he is considering creating buffer zone in hopes of foiling terrorists by further separating snarled populations on West Bank; Israeli foreign minister, Shimon Peres, says he will meet next week with Yasir Arafat, head of Palestinian Authority, in attempt to halt fighting that has consumed both sides for nearly year; says meeting will be first of three he will hold with Arafat; details such as place, time and agenda remain up in air, and Arafat has not made firm commitment to take part; Palestinians are concerned whether Peres would have free rein from Sharon to negotiate range of differences; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: MP3.Com Loss Narrows, Along With Sales
abstract: MP3.com, Internet music site, reports second-quarter net loss of $11.6 million, or 11 cents a share, compared with loss of $177.1 million, or $2.71, year earlier; Vivendi Universal is in process of acquiring MP3 (S)

headline: BERKSHIRE HATHAWAY TO ACQUIRE XTRA
abstract: Berkshire Hathaway Inc, investment vehicle of Warren E Buffett, agrees to buy Xtra Corp, container leasing company, for about $590 million (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Hewlett Buys StorageApps
abstract: Hewlett-Packard Co acquires StorageApps for $350 million in stock (S)

headline: Warning on Internet Stocks
abstract: Warren E Buffett, chief executive of Berkshire Hathaway, says 50 percent decline in Internet stocks in last year has not made them more attractive as investments; says he still believes shares of some Internet companies are selling for unreasonably high prices (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: AOL Enters Deal With H&R Block
abstract: AOL Time Warner selects H&R Block to be exclusive provider of tax preparation services and tax advice within AOL's Tax Center and in Compuserve (S)

headline: Write-Downs Hurt Deutsche Bank Profit
abstract: Deutsche Bank reports profits fell to 2.45 billion euros (5

headline: Squeezing the Office Into a Palm
abstract: Beginning this week, every new Palm m500 or m505 comes with a copy of Documents to Go 4.0. It's a remarkable program, but do you need it?

headline: Conducting Music's Digital Shift; A Top Lobbyist Seeks Harmony In a Time Of Discord
abstract: Profile of Hilary Rosen, chief lobbyist for Recording Industry Association of America; she deftly represents interests of big record companies at time when industry faces mounting complaints from consumers, antitrust regulators and legislators about online efforts, complaints from disaffected musicians and sales slump; graphs of Internet downloads and industry sales; photos (M)

headline: Taliban Plea to U.S.: Don't Put Us in More Misery
abstract: If there are Americans clamoring to bomb Afghanistan back to the Stone Age, they ought to know that this nation does not have so far to go.

headline: For the Voiceless
abstract: Iris Fishman letter comments on article about uses for voice recognition technology

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: No Rush To Deal
abstract: Dutch telecommunications group Royal KPN appears to be in no rush to make deal with Belgian government-controlled Belgacom; Belgian government together with consortium of main minority shareholders wrote to KPN in bid to speed process; KPN has not determined how to value Belgacom, which is not listed on stock market (S)

headline: With Little Left, Japan Shaves Rate
abstract: Bank of Japan reduces its discount rate to 0.1 percent from 0.15 percent, move with little practical effect; bank also says it will coontinue to flood Japanese money market with cash, to ensure that neither companies nor investors are hamstrung by any shortage of credit; move is largely symbolic because much of money it has already made available to banking system has sat unused and there is little call for more; photo (M)

headline: G.M. to Pay $400 Million To Take Control of Daewoo
abstract: General Motors Corp formally announces agreement with creditors of bankrupt Daewoo Motor Co of South Korea that will give GM brand and substantial manufacturing foothold in Asia; GM will pay $400 million in cash for controlling interest in new company, including two modern plants in South Korea and two plants overseas; creditors keep minority interest; agreement is nonbinding, but executives at Daewoo, GM and lead creditor, government-controlled Korea Development Bank, express confidence that it will become firm once final inspection fo company's books and operations are completed; Rudolph Schlais, president of General Motors Asia Pacific, comments; photo (M)

headline: Industry analysts step back to reassess ad spending estimates, and the picture is not pretty.
abstract: Deteriorating economic outlook in wake of terrorist attacks is spurring advertising industry analysts to reassess their estimates for ad spending this year and next; most predict no growth, or steeper cutbacks, for 2001 and 2002; advertisers and agencies are reassessing marketing plans as they continue to change, delay or cancel campaigns; photo (M)

headline: Germ Warfare Talks Open in London; U.S. Is the Pariah
abstract: European nations and other major powers today urged the completion of a draft agreement to enforce the 1972 ban on biological weapons, a move that puts them at odds with the Bush administration.    Speaking on behalf of the European Union, Marc Baptist of Belgium told negotiators in Geneva that the draft accord, while not perfect, was still the best way to strengthen the ban on germ weapons.

headline: Happy Ending, but Rights Issue Casts Shadow on Royal Romance
abstract: Jorge Zorreguieta, wealthy Argentine rancher, signs document saying he agrees to stay away from wedding of his daughter, Maxima, to Prince Willem-Alexander of Netherlands, thus averting crisis in royal family; many Dutch politicians and historians say Zorreguieta was moral accomplice to abuses during Argentina's military dictatorship from 1976 to 1983; he has not been linked to atrocities, but Dutch government feared violent protests on wedding day if he attended (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Debate On Chechnya
abstract: Pres Vladimir Putin clashes with Russian parliamentary critics on Chechnya, saying peace talks will begin only after rebels lay down weapons and 'especially notorious' leaders surrender (S)

headline: In State of Union, Fox Asks More Time to Keep Promises
abstract: Pres Vicente Fox of Mexico, in first state-of-the-union address, acknowledges that he needs more time to live up to promises that helped him win power; reads statistics about his government's achievements, but much of speech refers to unaccomplished goals and to president's ability to single-handedly transform Mexico into prosperous democracy; repeatedly assures people that 'Mexico has a plan,' and he appeals to Congress for help; says he has created government without authoritarianism and arrogance and that Mexicans now live in empire of freedom of expression, but that 'old inertia' cannot be broken overnight (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Wireless Job Cuts
abstract: Canada's Wi-LAN, provider of high-speed wireless networking products, is cutting 55 percent of its work force of about 120 people; jobs of chairman, president, and chief executive will be combined; reports operating loss of 18.9 million Canadian dollars in six months to April 30; revenues fell 11 percent in period, to 44.1 million Canadian dollars (S)

headline: MediaTalk; CNN Chairman Resigns, Without the Spin
abstract: For months, people inside and outside CNN had predicted that the network's chairman, Tom Johnson, would not be long for his position. After all, CNN's ratings continued to sag. And CNN's parent company, Turner Broadcasting System, had just come under the stewardship of a new executive, Jamie Kellner.    Still, executives at Turner, a unit of AOL-Time Warner, swore that Mr. Johnson's announcement on Thursday that he was resigning took them completely by surprise.

headline: New Delhi Journal; In India's Capital, a Prayer for the Belching Buses
abstract: More than four million people in New Delhi, India, brace for possible Supreme Court decision to banish from roads thousands of diesel buses they ride daily; two years ago court ordered authorities to replace city's entire diesel fleet with 10,000 buses that run on cleaner compressed natural gas; this has not been done, and deadline is approaching; Delhi has among highest levels of particulate pollution in world, worst kind for public health; photo (M)

headline: Robust Economy Short of Workers; As Europe Fuses, Dutch Find Success Distorts the Job Market
abstract: Chronic labor shortage in Netherlands is limiting nation's striking economic success and spurring inflation; labor squeeze exists in almost every category; problem, which comes while much of Europe grapples with high unemployment and sluggish growth, underlines major challenges Europe faces in push to reshape itself as borderless economic powerhouse with uniform monetary policy despite varying economic needs; graphs of Dutch and European unemployment and inflation; photos (M)

headline: U.S. War on Terrorism:It's Likely to Be Long, Dangerous and Harsh
abstract: PARIS—  Retaliating effectively for the terrorist strikes that humbled American power may take years and require the United States to use overwhelming force — perhaps including political assassination — in ways shunned by Washington in recent decades, Western officials and experts said Wednesday.

headline: A Shattered Nest Egg
abstract: Forrest Preece letter on July 22 article holds high schools and colleges should give financial management classes high priority

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Airline Alliance Negotiations
abstract: Alitalia agrees to hold exclusive talks with Air France and Delta Air Lines on partnerships that could help profitability and give its passengers easier access to European and US flights; Alitalia's chief executive Francesco Mengozzi comments (S)

headline: PULL OUT QUICKLY
abstract: Israeli tanks, in Army's deepest thrust into Palestinian-controlled territory in West Bank, roll into Jenin, suspected base for some of suicide bombers who have attacked Israel in recent weeks; withdraw after demolishing Palestinian police station; Palestinians say Israelis commandeered headquarters of city's governor temporarily, and took with them about 70 Palestinians jailed by Jenin authorities on charges of having collaborated with Israel; Palestinian witnesses describe fierce exchanges of gunfire between Israelis and Palestinians; Army says assault is in response to various terrorist activities, including suicide bombing that wounded 21 Israelis on August 12 in cafe in Qiryat Motzkin, suburb of Haifa; map (M)

headline: The Browser as a Cookie-Control Key
abstract: P3P, cookie control technology debuting on Microsoft Corp's next-generation browser, Internet Explorer 6, promises to make privacy protection automatic; grew out of efforts in mid-1990's within World Wide Web Consortium to create set of tools to help Internet users automatically block sites with offensive content; some industry analysts and privacy advocates take dim view of P3P's prospects because users will still have to figure out how to use it and will not bother (M)

headline: TRADING OF PROFESSIONAL DETAILING SHARES IS HALTED
abstract: Professional Detailing Inc, which markets drugs for pharmaceutical companies, says it might end agreement with GlaxoSmithKline after US Appeals Court overturns order blocking generic version of Glaxo's antibiotic Ceftin; court ruled on Aug 20 that Glaxo was unlikely to prove that generic drug by Ranbaxy Laboratories of New Delhi, India, infringed its patent on cefuroxime axetil, chemical name for Ceftin (S)

headline: World Briefing | Middle East: Egypt: New Trials In Sectarian Violence
abstract: Egypt's high court orders retrial in case involving some of worst sectarian violence ever in country; overturns convictions of four Muslims (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Organized Crime Case Raises Issues of Privacy  The case of Nicodemo S. Scarfo Jr. has become the latest battleground in the struggle to determine the balance between the government's ability to conduct surveillance and the right to privacy. Mr. Scarfo has been awaiting trial on charges of running gambling and loan-sharking operations for the Gambino crime family.    A federal judge in Newark will hear defense pleas today to throw out evidence gathered by a system that recorded almost every keystroke typed into Mr. Scarfo's computer, including the password that investigators used to unscramble his files. [Page C7.]

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: UNITED INDUSTRIAL CORP., New York, a maker of flight simulators and military testing systems, said it was awarded a contract by the Air Force to provide training systems. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Bank Rate Unchanged
abstract: European Central Bank holds its benchmark interest rate unchanged at 4.5 percent despite faltering growth in euro zone (S)

headline: Canada Miffed at Bush Omission
abstract: Many Canadians are angered at what they see as slight in Pres Bush's address before joint session of Congress because Canada was not mentioned (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: SAF-T-HAMMER, Scottsdale, Ariz., said its subsidiary, Smith & Wesson, the world's largest handgun manufacturer, had reached a three-year agreement with Remington Arms Corp., Madison, N.C., to make parts for some of Remington's Centerfire brand rifles.

headline: No Headline
abstract: A panel of the world's leading financial and development experts called today for a new round of international trade talks devoted primarily to aiding the poor countries too weak to reap any benefits from the growing global economy.    The panel -- which included Robert Rubin, the former United States treasury secretary, and Ernesto Zedillo, the former president of Mexico - recommended that a ministerial-level World Trade Organization meeting planned for Qatar in November "should set an objective of making trade as free between industrial and developing countries as it already is among the industrial countries."

headline: World Briefing | Asia: China: A Job For All The King's Men
abstract: Final pieces of Navy surveillance plane that collided with Chinese fighter on Apr 1 are flown out of China on giant cargo plane to US, where engineers will determine whether aircraft can be put back together and flown again (S)

headline: All Those Boys' Toys
abstract: Kari Prager letter on Ellyn Spragins' August 5 article on men's need to buy expensive autos offers another motivation for why some men feel need to ride motorcycles

headline: German Data Led U.S. to Search For More Suicide Hijacker Teams
abstract: German intelligence interception of telephone conversations between jubilant terrorist supporters following Sept 11 attack led FBI to search frantically for two more teams of suicide hijackers; terrorists' mention of '30 people traveling for the operation' set off search of flight manifests for those beyond 19 hijackers believed to have died in four planes; one may have been Lotfi Raissi, Algerian pilot charged in London court as 'lead instructor' and monitor of hijackers while they trained in US; Scotland Yard believes 11 of 19 passed through Britain this year; probe focuses intently on Germany, where cell in Hamburg is believed to have plotted attack, aided by cells in at least three other European countries; photos; map; first substantial evidence linking suspect Zacarias Moussaoui to plotters is his call from Oklahoma, where he was in flight school, to Hamburg operative who lived with Mohamed Atta, suspected mastermind; German authorities diagram ties among about 20 members of Hamburg cell including Atta and Marwan al-Shehhi, apparent pilots of two planes, and Ramzi Muhammad Abdullah Bin al-Shibh, now being sought; Raissi, whose French wife, Sonia, works for Air France at Heathrow, visited US several times this year, flying from Las Vegas to Arizona in June, apparently to check on pilots in training; also on diagram is Mamoun Darkazanli, 43, Syrian businessman on US list for channeling money to Al Qaeda terrorist organization (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Telephone Profit Up
abstract: Australia's Telstra Corp says full-year net income increased 10 percent, to 4.06 billion Australian dollars ($2.15 billion); sales rose 12 percent, to 23.1 billion Australian dollars ($12.25 billion); company says results will be flat for next six months (S)

headline: Training a New Generation of Workers in Alaska
abstract: BP, largest operator of oil fields on Alaska's North Slope, leads industry effort to develop two-year training program at University of Alaska to develop new generation of oil field engineers and roustabouts; there are not enough skilled young workers to replace those who are approaching retirement even though production from North Slope is declining; photo (M)

headline: Aetna to Close Some Unprofitable H.M.O.'s
abstract: Aetna Inc says it will close or sell numerous unprofitable health maintenance organizations and expand its business with self-insured companies and medium-size employers in attempt to improve profitability (M)

headline: Executive Changes at Media Firms
abstract: Deutsch, New York, part of the Partnership unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies, promoted three executives

headline: The Digital Trail
abstract: Cellphones and PC's have made it easier for the government to track you. Page 6.

headline: Business Diary: Wonder Bread's Match
abstract: Scientists spent nearly three years figuring out how to shorten the time it takes to make a peanut butter sandwich. Their answer: eliminate the smearing

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Verisign Takes A Big Write-Off
abstract: The Internet software and services company VeriSign Inc. reported a second-quarter loss of $11.2 billion, or $55.49 a share, including a one-time noncash charge of $9.9 billion related to acquisition costs. In the period last year, the company, based in Mountain View, Calif., lost $453 million, or $3.37 a share. VeriSign, which last year purchased the company that runs the databases for .com, .net and .org addresses, Network Solutions Inc., said sales in the second quarter rose to $231.2 million, up from $70.3 million in the second quarter last year. Shares of VeriSign closed yesterday at $47.17.   Susan Stellin (NYT)

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Laptop Learning To the Editor:.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Economy Shrinks
abstract: Singapore's economy shrinks at annual 10.7 percent in second quarter from the first, greater than initial estimates (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Microsoft Meets With U.S.
abstract: Microsoft lawyers met yesterday with Justice Department officials for the first time since a federal appeals court set aside an order to break up the company. The two sides discussed procedures for renewed talks in the government's antitrust case, according to a spokeswoman for Eliot L. Spitzer, the attorney general of New York, one of the 18 states suing Microsoft. The participants refused to discuss the meeting. Microsoft's lawyers also met with Charles A. James, the department's antitrust chief, as well as Tom Miller, the attorney general of Iowa, and Richard Blumenthal, the attorney general of Connecticut. Also yesterday, Microsoft said it was making the source code of its Windows CE 3.0 operating system available over the Internet. Windows CE operates in electronic devices like hand-held computers and is increasingly used to power Internet-connected appliances.     Andrew Zipern (NYT)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Faster Growth Seen
abstract: India's economy expands at annual pace of 4.4 percent in quarter ended June 30, stronger than expected (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Gazprom Joins In China Bid
abstract: Russia's Gazprom receives approval from China's PetroChina to join Royal Dutch/Shell Group in consortium to bid for $6 billion pipeline that will link Xinjiang province with eastern Shanghai (S)

headline: Religious Arrests Cast a Pall Over Afghanistan Aid Efforts
abstract: Afghanistan's ruling Taliban has uneasy relationship with foreign aid organizations and workers in their poverty-stricken country; there are cultural conflicts and mutual distrust, as evidenced by arrest two weeks ago of 24 aid workers, accused of preaching Christian Gospel to Afghans; Abdul Ghafoor Afghani, Taliban's chief of protocol, claims those arrested were given visas as aid workers, not missionaries; Taliban is uncomfortable with what goes on behind high walls of aid workers' compounds: mingling of unmarried men and women, beat of rock 'n' roll, drinking at end of day; repeatedly, Taliban have warned against turning Afghan believers into Afghan apostates; arrested aid workers belong to Shelter Now, German-based group, but Foreign Min Wakil Ahmed Mutawakil has said that World Food Program itself is prime suspect; potential of more arrests leaves aid agencies in fear; huge withdrawal--or expulsion--of agencies would be catastrophic for needy; photos; map (M)

headline: CHAIRMAN OF STATE STREET GLOBAL ADVISORS RESIGNS
abstract: Nicholas Lopardo retires as chairman of State Street Global Advisors; Timothy B Harbert replaces him (S)

headline: It's Art? Oh.
abstract: Daniel Casner letter comments on Aug 9 article on art and computer games

headline: Cutting Prices to Thin Inventory, Staples Reports Profit Off 5.2%
abstract: Staples Inc says fiscal second-quarter profit fell 5.2 percent, to $40.4 million; sales rose 5.1 percent, to $2.31 billion (M)

headline: DirecTV Proceeds With a Local-Market Plan
abstract: Special spotbeam antennas on Hughes Electronics' DirecTV 4S satellite, due for launch in October, will be able to aim signals so precisely at many of nation's largest cities that many more local television stations, including those in New York and Los Angeles, can be efficiently added to DirecTV service; 465 channels rebroadcasting local signals will still leave DirecTV well short of carrying all 1,500 local broadcast stations in US; new satellite is meant to let DirecTV comply with federal law under which satellite service has to deliver all local channels in a market if it carries even one; satellite will lift DirecTV's channel capacity to some 750 from about 320 now; photo; map (M)

headline: Toronto Journal; Shedding a Bit More Than Its Image
abstract: Toronto, Ontario, has undergone change as it has become metropolitan center, leaving behind image of prudence and oh-so-proper English restraint; as it grows in worldliness, Toronto has been letting its hair down in many ways; it has North America's first talk-radio station for guys, hosts one of North America's largest gay pride parades, and is site of Internet newscast in which anchors appear nude; photo (M)

headline: S.E.C. SAYS PRE-PAID LEGAL SERVICES OVERSTATED EARNINGS
abstract: Pre-Paid Legal Services Inc says Securities and Exchange Commission has ordered it to restate earnings after concluding that company failed to comply with generally accepted accounting principles; company says order will wipe out 64 percent of last year's reported profit and reduce its net worth by $109 million (S)

headline: African Bloc Hoping to Do Better as the 'African Union'
abstract: Africa's current leaders want to create new Organization of African Unity that they pledge would redeem failures of its predcessor; on final day of OAU's last summit meeting, members endorse plan to retire OAU in next year and to transform it into African Union, which they hope to model after European version; skeptics point out that new organization will face same fundamental problems that hobbled its predecessor; except for its goal of ridding Africa of remnamts of colonialism, OAU's charter has favored status quo, rarely criticizing ruling governments and having little contact with African population (M)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Comoros: A Peaceful Island Coup
abstract: Mohamed Bacar, who seized power in breakaway Comoros island of Anjouan in August, is toppled in peaceful coup; Ahmed Abubakar Fundi is installed as president; map (S)

headline: EARNINGS OUTLOOK CUT AS WEAK CHEMICAL DEMAND IS SEEN
abstract: Dow Chemical Co will miss third-quarter earnings estimates because of slowing economy and reduction in demand for chemicals and plastics used in various products (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: KINDER MORGAN INC., Houston, which operates natural gas pipelines, said it would buy back as many as 5.7 million shares to return money to stockholders. The buyback is expected to cost about $300 million and affect about 4.4 percent of outstanding shares.

headline: Compressed Data; Passionate Pas Seul by Microsoft's Chief Executive Captivates Internet Audience
abstract: Steven A Ballmer, chief executive of Microsoft Corp, becomes object of some ridicule in programming community after he is videotaped at internal corporate pep rally, bounding about to Gloria Estefan song and screaming about how much he loves Microsoft; photo (M)

headline: Indonesia Ex-Chief Heads to U.S., Not Without Some Parting Shots
abstract: Abdurrahman Wahid, now Indonesia's former president, ends stubborn occupation of increasingly empty palace and leaves for medical checkup in US, as new president, Megawati Sukarnoputri, prepares for official reception; Muslim party leader Hamza Haz, who lobbied hard against candidacy of woman, is elected vice president by legislature that unanimously voted out Wahid; Wahid gives bitter, petulant answers in farewell interview (M)

headline: THREE COMPANIES WIN SYSTEM CONTRACT FOR MEDICARE
abstract: Health and Human Services Department awards Electronic Data Systems, Oracle Corp and PricewaterhouseCoopers a contract to create new accounting system for Medicare and Medicaid; potential value of contract is about $328 million (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Sun Sets Pact With Hitachi
abstract: Sun Microsystems sets wide-ranging partnership with Hitachi to market and jointly develop big computer storage systems for corporate customers; Sun president Ed Zander says deal is part of strategy to allow computer maker to supply software, storage and services; photo (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Rising Debt-Equity Ratios
abstract: Some conglomerates appear to have reverted to some of the practices that brought about Korea's economic crisis in 1997. The debt-equity ratios of some conglomerates have risen above the level of 200 percent that the government demanded during the crisis, the financial supervisory commission reported. The worst offender was the Hyundai Group, whose debt-equity ratio more than doubled, from 229.72 percent last year to 477.56 percent. The debt-equity ratio of the Samsung Group, Korea's largest conglomerate since the breakup of Hyundai last year, improved to 151.04 percent from 193.97 percent last year.   Don Kirk (NYT)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Rival Bid Offered For Comdisco Unit
abstract: Hewlett-Packard's $610 million acquisition of Comdisco's technology services division is facing challenge from rival suitor, SunGard Data Systems, which is offering $775 million for troubled unit; Sungard chairman James L Mann comments; photo (S)

headline: XM Satellite Radio Gets Help From Falling Stars
abstract: Familiar musicians will seem to fall from sky to help introduce XM Satellite Radio, service planning to offer almost 100 channels of music, news, sports and entertainment beginning in September for $9.99 monthly subscription fee; $100 million advertising campaign was developed by TBWA/Chiat/Day (S)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: THE AMERICAS CUBA: A GLIMPSE OF THE LITTLE HERO Elián González, the famously repatriated Cuban boy, made a rare public appearance exchanging an affectionate greeting with Fidel Castro at a children's rally. Elián and his father, Juan Miguel González, were in the front row with Mr. Castro and other senior leaders at the event in Havana. Mr. Castro gave Elián a kiss on the cheek and a paternal pat on the shoulder.    (Reuters) MEXICO: DRUG-CARTEL ARREST Mexican officials said they had arrested a man suspected of being the chief assassin of one of Mexico's most notorious drug cartels. Jorge Humberto Rodríguez, alias The Frog, had been detained since March, but he had falsely identified himself upon arrest. Officials said Mr. Rodríguez had undergone plastic surgery to alter his appearance. Mr. Rodríguez is believed to have worked for the Tijuana- based Arellano Félix drug cartel, Mexico's most violent criminal organization.    Ginger Thompson (NYT)

headline: Will the Economy Ever Party Like It's 1999? Don't Count on It.
abstract: The unemployment data for July seems to indicate that the economic decline is not getting worse. Only 42,000 non-farm jobs were lost, compared to a monthly average of 72,000 in the second quarter of the year. The 49,000 drop in factory jobs was also a slowdown from the second quarter pace. The manufacturing index of the National Association of Purchasing Management fell in July, but has not dropped back to its recent low.

headline: Technology Briefing | Security: Companies Join To Fight Worms
abstract: Several computer security companies join together to fight distributed-denial-of-service attacks, in which computers are flooded with messages from machines that have been surreptitiously commandeered; McAfee, division of Network Associates, says it plans to incorporate technologies developed by Asta Networks, Mazu Networks and Arbor Networks to fight off or prevent distributed attacks (S)

headline: Nairobi Journal; A Song About Corruption Takes Kenya by Storm
abstract: Song written about widespread corruption in Kenya is big hit with Kenyans, but not with country's officials; it was written by young Kenyan, Eric Wainaina, who is student at Berklee College of Music in Boston; corruption is so bad that World Bank is withholding financial aid to Kenya until government of Pres Daniel arap Moi takes serious steps toward addressing issue; only radio station with national reach has been banned from playing Wainaina's song, and when he sang it at national school musical festival, organizers cut microphone before he was through; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Prostitution Ruling
abstract: South Africa's High Court rules that prostitution should be decriminalized, sparking outcry among some churches; decision must be approved by Constitutional Court before it takes effect (S)

headline: So, Who's the Pro?
abstract: David Fox letter, commenting on July 5 article about e-mail, cites dangers of proprietary file formats

headline: A Hobbled Army Casts A Cloud in Macedonia
abstract: Military analysis of fighting between Macedonian government forces and Albanian rebels; even though Western experts have been vocal in criticisms of Macedonian military, which is ill-equipped and trained, few efforts are under way to help them do it right; nation could be plunged into nasty conflict if current cease-fire fails, in which neither side seems capable of winning decisive military victory but which may inflame ethnic tensions to point of civil war; photos (M)

headline: Balloonist Lands in Brazil, Ending Bid to Circle Globe
abstract: Fearing poor weather conditions in the days ahead, adventurer Steve Fossett chose to end his attempt to circle the globe solo in a balloon

headline: Back-to-Work Wall Street Seems Strangely Different
abstract: Wall Street returned to work today, after being closed since Tuesday following the terrorist attack on the World Trade Center.

headline: CITIGROUP DROPS 3,622 INDEPENDENT BROKERS
abstract: Citigroup severs ties with 3,622 independent brokers who arranged loans for Associates First Capital, consumer finance company acquired by Citigroup that has been accused of predatory lending practices (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Bidding For Tempus
abstract: WPP Group sends its official takeover proposal for Tempus Group, British media buying concern, to Tempus's shareholders, as rival bidder, Havas Advertising, considers its options (S)

headline: Brokerage Puts Limit on Stocks Analysts Hold
abstract: Merrill Lynch bars its stock analysts from buying shares of companies they cover, to avoid potential conflicts of interest and answer customers' concerns about trustworthiness of Wall Street research; issue has also been taken up in Congress and by securities regulators; Merrill Lynch's new policy does not address key area of conflict, role that rhapsodic research reports can play in supporting firm's lucrative investment banking deals (M)

headline: Chrysler Loss Isn't as Deep As Expected
abstract: DaimlerChrysler says its Chrysler unit lost $125 million in second quarter, better performance than analysts had expected because of stronger auto sales and gains from turnaround plan; Chrysler earned $986 million in year-earlier quarter; it lost $1.2 billion in first quarter; second-quarter net income at DaimlerChrysler fell 58 percent, to about $681 million; second-quarter earnings fell to $453 million from $1.52 billion; revenue dropped to $35.1 billion from $38 billion; DaimlerChrysler chief executive Jurgen Schrempp says company is on track to post operating profit for year of $1 billion to $1.5 billion; Chrysler chief executive Dieter Zetsche comments (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Online Toy Store Is Started
abstract: Amazon.com and Toys 'R' Us jointly open Imaginarium.com, online store for specialty and educational toys (S)

headline: Growing Audience Is Turning to Established News Media Online
abstract: Audience for online news continues to grow as readers, particularly younger ones, increasingly look to Internet for quick dose of news; beneficiaries of growth continue to be largest and best-known national news organizations, especially those with focus on national and international events; largest news audience on Web still gravitates to Yahoo, which is portal to material from other news organizations; graph of top five news sites (M)

headline: Technology Briefing
abstract: MEDIA MORE AOL LAYOFFS POSSIBLE AOL Time War- ner stock fell yesterday on speculation that more layoffs were coming. Jim Whitney, a spokesman for AOL Time Warner, declined to comment, but Wall Street analysts and some employees said they expected layoffs to begin this week. The cuts would be the second major round of layoffs this year at the company, the world's largest Internet and media company. The company cut about 2,400 jobs in January. John Corcoran, an analyst at CIBC World Markets, who met with J. Michael Kelly, AOL Time Warner's chief financial officer, on Friday, said that the company was looking to cut costs in its cable and music divisions. Mr. Corcoran said he had no specific knowledge of layoffs and maintained a strong buy on the stock. Last month, Gerald M. Levin, chief executive of AOL Time Warner, said that advertising revenue was stabilizing and that he did not expect to make specific layoffs.   Andrew Zipern (NYT) INTERNET LOUDCLOUD OFFERS SMALLER PACKAGES Loud- cloud Inc., which manages Web sites for corporations, said it would sell services individually rather than only as a large package. Individually sold services will include Web security and database management, said Jeff Kupietzky, general manager of the solutions group at Loudcloud. The change is meant to attract more customers, because businesses are cutting spending amid a weak economy. Loudcloud, founded by Marc Andreessen, above, who helped develop Netscape's Internet browser, cut its fiscal 2002 sales estimate in June to $53 million from $57 million. Stock in Loudcloud, which is based in Sunnyvale, Calif., has dropped 74 percent since March.   (Bloomberg News) INTERNET USE GROWING SLOWLY Fifty-eight percent of Americans had Internet access in their homes in July 2001, compared with 52 percent in July 2000, according to new data from the Internet audience measurement service Nielsen/NetRatings. In July 1999, 39 percent of the population in the United

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Exodus Files For Bankruptcy
abstract: Exodus Communications seeks bankruptcy protection; says it has obtained commitment for $200 million in financing from GE Capital that will allow it to pay employees and finance ongoing daily operations (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: BMC Says Profit Fell Short
abstract: BMC Software Inc says profit in fiscal first-quarter ended June 30 fell short of its forecasts; profit was 6 cents to 8 cents a share; revenue was $338 million to $345 million (S)

headline: Toyota Earmarks $8 Billion for Diversification Efforts
abstract: Toyota Corp, threatened with boycott backed by Rev Jesse Jackson, will commit nearly $8 billion over next decade to diversify its work force and reach out to more minority suppliers and customers; will spend millions of dollars more with black and Hispanic advertising agencies, work to expand number of minority dealerships, create new career training programs for minorities and invest capital with minority-owned asset management companies; Jackson lauds decision as big victory; Toyota spokesman says it was not made because of pressure from Jackson, but admits he was catalyst; photo (M)

headline: Bill in Brazil Would Allow More of Jungle To Be Razed
abstract: Joint commission of Brazilian Congress approves changes in forestry code that will more than double amount of Amazon jungle that ranchers, loggers and miners will be permitted to raze; environmentalists begin national campaign to defeat measure; Pres Fernando Henrique Cardoso opposes changes in code and was able to thwart effort to pass similar bill in May, but his government coalition in Congress has weakened since then and is likely to become more divided ahead of presidential elections in 2002 (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Advanced Micro Cuts 2,300 Jobs
abstract: Advanced Micro Devices will close two semiconductor-fabrication plants in Austin, Tex, and eliminate total of 2,300 jobs, or 15 percent of its global work force; Gateway Inc says it has stopped buying microprocessors from Advanced Micro in favor of Intel Corp; attributes decision to Gateway's efforts to save money by simplifying personal computer product lines and relationships with component suppliers; graph (S)

headline: A Pakistani Diplomat, Staying Calm in the Storm's Eye
abstract: Public Lives profile of Amb Maleeha Lodhi of Pakistan, who has been cast in spotlight since Pakistan allied with United States in its war against terrorism; she is her nation's most prominent diplomat abroad, caught in middle of gravest sort of international crisis; photo (M)

headline: 2 Big Names in Hong Kong Get Some Rare Good News
abstract: Hong Kong's Pacific Century CyberWorks, struggling communications company founded by Richard Li, reports its first profit since acquiring Cable and Wireless HKT last year; reports net profit of $120 million, on sales of $1.45 billion; Hong Kong Stock Exchange is close to approving media baron Jimmy Lai's plan to sell Apple Daily, Hong Kong's most popular newspaper, and its sister magazine, Next, to his publicly traded Internet company, Next Media; photo (M)

headline: Wall St. Remains Cool to Hewlett-Compaq Merger
abstract: Investor skepticism about proposed merger of Hewlett-Packard and Compaq Computer causes both companies' stocks to slide, and Moody's Investors Service lowers Hewlett-Packard's credit rating two notches to A2; photo (M)

headline: A MOVEMENT IN HIDING: A special report.; Sect Clings to the Web in the Face of Beijing's Ban
abstract: Hundreds of members of Falun Gong, outlawed spiritual movement, elude China's internal security forces, using temporary cell phone numbers, encryption programs and obscure Internet services based overseas to keep remaining network of followers connected to discipline's United States-based founder, Li Hongzhi; since China set out to crush Falun Gong two years ago, as many as 200 people have died, possibly thousands have been beaten or tortured, and millions have been cowed into renouncing their faith in Li's apocalyptic cosmology; He Zuoxiu, Communist Party member who has played integral role in having movement banned, says Falun Gong is evil cult that could threaten China's tenuous stability, should it galvanize millions of people disenfranchised by transition from centrally planned to market-driven economy; Li's message, at its core, is simple one--be better person; he casts his followers in pivotal role of cosmic morality play; photos (L)

headline: In Genoa's Noise, a Trumpet for Capitalism
abstract: Daniel Akst On the Contrary column criticizes anti-globalism demonstrators at G-8 summit meeting in Genoa; says demonstrators are mainly advertisements for strength of capitalist democracies that provoke them; cartoon (M)

headline: Investors Seek a Refuge, and Experts Do, Too
abstract: Investors' flight from stocks in first week of trading after Sept 11 wipes out gains built over substantial time; investment outlook is shakier because country appears to be entering war with uncertain mission and duration as well as a recession; experts share their views on prospects for recovery; photos (M)

headline: AUSTRALIAN COMPANY ADDS TO ITS U.S. MALL HOLDINGS
abstract: Australia's Westfield Holdings acquires quarter of Rodamco North America for $490 million from Stichting Pensioenfonds, Dutch pension fund, increasing its ownership of shopping malls in US (S)

headline: Credit Offerings Planned This Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three-  and six-month bills.    By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 3.45 percent and a six-month bill was 3.36 percent.

headline: Executive Changes at Media Firms
abstract: Wesley Hall was named Web applications developer at Archer/Malmo, Memphis

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Price of cocoa declines as wet weather improves prospects for crops in West Africa; December contract slips $39, or 4.1 percent, to $910 per metric ton on Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York; graph (S)

headline: Untangling the Online Gaming Web
abstract: Playing computer games online becomes simpler thanks to technological improvements; game design is better, gaming sites are more accomodating and home computers have gained speed and power; drawing; photos (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Donations to United Way Increased by 3.8% for Year  The 1,400 local United Way organizations raised $3.91 billion in the year ended June 30, an increase of $140 million, or 3.8 percent, over figures a year earlier, said Ellie Ferdon, chairwoman of United Way of America.     The modest real growth in donations to the nation's largest private funder of social services comes as demand for these services is rising as economic growth slows. [Page C2.]

headline: Accounts
abstract: * CHS/Community Health Systems, Brentwood, Tenn., to Doe Anderson, Louisville, to handle its account, which had been at Xor, Tulsa, Okla. Billings were estimated at more than $5 million.  * Hype Energy Drink, London, to Dcode, New York, part of Intelefilm, as its first agency of record in the United States. Billings were estimated at less than $5 million.

headline: World Briefing | Asia: India: Mental Homes Closed
abstract: India's government orders closing of all 15 poorly constructed shelters that house mental patients in southern town of Erwadi, where fire recently killed 27 inmates in one facility (S)

headline: Stocks End Higher on Cisco News
abstract: Stocks ended the day sharply higher with technology issues leading the way after Cisco said it saw signs that its business was stabilizing

headline: Gadgets to Pack for the Beach, for Work or Play; Weather Watching
abstract: Article suggests devices beachgoers can use to monitor weather conditions; photo (M)

headline: Personal Business Diary: Buying American as a Crisis Response
abstract: DIARY A Crisis Response:.

headline: Microsoft Talks Ordered by Judge
abstract: Judicial order to Microsoft and Justice Department to start new round of negotiations to settle antitrust case noted (S)

headline: Nortel Networks Plans to Sell $1 Billion of Convertible Bonds
abstract: Nortel Networks, communications equipment company, to sell $2 billion of convertible bonds (M)

headline: Frequent Fliers Then, Frequent Fliers Now
abstract: Hard-core business travelers are continuing to fly, some because their careers depend on it and others out of defiance to terrorism; photos (M)

headline: Britain to Tighten Controls On Its Air and Sea Borders
abstract: Britain says it will tighten border controls to reduce number of people seeking asylum and to deter terrorists after attacks on New York and Washington; announcement reflects fears that terrorists could turn on Britain because it is close ally in Washington's effort to build international coalition against terrorism (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia/Pacific: Vietnam: Accusations Of Crackdown
abstract: Religious and human rights groups accuse Vietnam of starting new crackdown on critics of Communist Party and on Buddhists (S)

headline: Its Last Client Gone, Agency Is in Limbo
abstract: Focus Agency president Mark Miller says decision about agency, Omnicom Group unit, and its employees will be made in next 90 days; agency has lost its last remaining client (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Online Class Materials
abstract: House Judiciary Committee's Subcommittee on Courts, Internet and Intellectual Property approves legislation that would permit colleges and universities to put copyrighted material for classes online; bill would allow students taking courses remotely to have access to texts and recordings for assignments using Internet; schools would be required to protect files from being viewed or copied without permission; Senate passed similar legislation in June (S)

headline: From A.T.M.'s to Bond Trades, a Difficult Comeback
abstract: Bank of New York is having mixed success in resuming operations in wake of terrorist attacks that forced evacuation of its downtown Manhattan offices; its automated teller machines have been down since attack, while its government-bond processing system is largely functioning normally; bank processes about half of all government securities trades (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: WORLD

headline: Executive Changes at Media Firms
abstract: Mike Haggerty was named senior vice president and managing director at Media Planning, New York, part of Havas Advertising

headline: Giving Away Computers, Dispensing Peace of Mind
abstract: Interview with Brent Woodworth, IBM crisis response team head, who personifies first wave of information technology industry's efforts to recover and rebuild from terrorist attacks; much of team's work is in form of humanitarian aid, distributing computers and setting up software without charge for relief workers; photo (M)

headline: After the Race Conference: Relief, and Doubt Over Whether It Will Matter
abstract: Whether governments will actually make good commitments made at United Nations World Conference Against Racism is far from certain; many countries used political muscle to ensure that they would not have to deal with prickly issues of race or discrimination; many presidents and foreign ministers delivered eloquent speeches condemning racism and intolerance, but few were willing to publicly address discrimination within their own borders (M)

headline: Airline Warns on Earnings
abstract: Frontier Airlines says fiscal second-quarter earnings will miss analysts' estimates because of slowing economy and intense competition (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Growth Slows
abstract: France's gross domestic product rose 0.3 percent in second quarter from previous quarter; first-quarter growth is revised to 0.4 percent from previously reported gain of 0.5 percent (S)

headline: A General Mills campaign goes mobile as vehicles become rolling peddlers for Reese's Puffs.
abstract: Advertising column on new advertising campaign by General Mills, in which 10 Minneapolis elementary-school teachers will earn $250 each for allowing their automobiles to be wrapped in orange and yellow vinyl, turning them into rolling advertisements for Reese's Puffs, sweetened breakfast cereal; promotion is first wrap campaign by Green Light Media in New York, industry newcomer; photo (M)

headline: Executive Changes at Media Firms
abstract: Kevin Patsel was named executive principal and managing director for public relations at the San Francisco office of Publicis Dialog, part of Publicis in the U.S

headline: Bush Might Meet Arafat If Truce Talks Yield Results
abstract: Administration officials say Pres Bush might meet with Yasir Arafat at UN later in month if some progress is made in high-level talksbetween Palestinians and Israelis; Bush convenes National Security Council meeting on refining Mideast policy as Arab countries pressure Bush to grant audience to Arafat (M)

headline: Paris Journal; Petition in Hand, Chirac's Pursuer Gains Ground
abstract: Arnaud Montebourg, young Socialist member of France's National Assembly, is leading campaign to impeach Pres Jacques Chirac, who is being investigated for possible role in illicit fund-raising scheme while he was mayor of Paris; photo (M)

headline: Willing to Do Messy Work
abstract: Ira A Lipman, chairman and president of Guardsmark Inc, security company in Memphis, writes The Boss column on his life and career; photo (M)

headline: Milosevic's Abode: 10 by 17 Feet but No Dungeon
abstract: Warden of Scheveningen, Netherlands, detention center where former Yugoslav Pres Slobodan Milosevic is being held pending war crimes trial describes perks available to prisoners; cellblock leased by tribunal is within high-security Dutch prison compound; houses only Yugoslav prisoners facing trial and those appealing sentences, which are served elsewhere; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: India: Poachers Shoot Rangers
abstract: Poachers kill forest guardÈ

headline: Emptying the Mailbox Of Credit Card Offers
abstract: Sally K Christman letter on credit card solicitations aimed at elderly

headline: SHARES OF ACCENTURE RISE AFTER AN INITIAL OFFERING
abstract: Shares of Accenture, consulting and project-management company, rise after its $1.67 billion initial offering (S)

headline: Southern Levitation: Battling Banks' Shares Keep Rising
abstract: IT'S the greatest election battle of the year, one in which ads from each side twist the record to make one candidate seem wonderful and the other horrible.    But although the tactics are straight out of politics, this battle is about business. Specifically, it is a bank takeover. Both First Union and SunTrust Banks want to buy the Wachovia Corporation, whose shareholders will vote a week from today on First Union's bid. The loser will have spent millions on ads with nothing to show for its trouble.

headline: A Continental Tire Is Under Scrutiny
abstract: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration says one model of tire that Ford Motor Co is using to replace Firestone Wilderness AT's has higher rate of damage claims than Firestones do; tire in question is General Ameri*550 AS, made by Continental M)

headline: Private Sector; None of the Above From Down Under
abstract: Anna Murdoch Mann, former wife of Rupert Murdoch, News Corp chairman, gives interview on their marriage to Women's Weekly, Australian magazine, in which she says none of their three children--Lachlan, James or Elisabeth--should take over Murdoch empire; photo (S)

headline: First Boston Merges Bond And Stock Divisions
abstract: Credit Suisse First Boston chief executive John J Mack merges investment bank's bond and stock divisions, naming one of his predecessor's top aides, Brady Dougan, to manage group of about 6,000 people (M);

headline: U.S. Reports Progress in Fighting Bias; Rights Groups Are Critical
abstract: Bush administration, in first report by US to UN body that monitors discrimination worldwide, says US has made significant strides in reducing discrimination against minorities; Ralph Boyd Jr, director of civil rights division of Justice Department who presented report in Geneva, notes African-Americans serve in highest levels of government in significant numbers, as well as in numerous other professions (M)

headline: Motorola Has Operating Loss of $232 Million in Quarter
abstract: Motorola Inc says it lost $232 million from operations in fiscal second quarter ended June 30 compared with profit of $551 million year earlier; revenues dropped 19 percent, to $7.52 billion from nearly $9.26 billion year ago (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Philippines: Exodus Of Brokers
abstract: Brokerage divisions of Citigroup and Merrill Lynch join exodus of investment banks leaving Philippine stock market, where average daily volume fell by almost half in 2001; Nomura Securities and at least seven others already have exited (S)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY  None

headline: Economic Scene; The many faces of Adam Smith: Rediscovering 'The Wealth of Nations.'
abstract: Alan B Krueger Economic Scene column on Emma Rothschild's book Economic Sentiments: Adam Smith, Condorcet and the Enlightenment; Rothschild says that to understand Smith, his contributions must be viewed in light of 18th-century institutions; drawing (M)

headline: Sweat Equity At the Tannery
abstract: Jeffrey Katz, president of Orbitz, online travel agency, writes My First Job column on working in leather tannery in Napa, Calif, during summer between his first and second years in college; photos (M)

headline: Buyer Beware:An Art World Nightmare Worthy of Kafka : The Mystery of a Looted Portrait
abstract: NEW YORK—  IHT INSIGHT / First of three parts

headline: Afghanistan, for Ages an Affliction to Mighty Empires, Is Not Easily Subdued
abstract: History of Afghanistan and its many conflicts through the ages discussed; authorities believe Osama bin Laden is living there under sanction by ruling Taliban; map; photos (M)

headline: Executive Changes at Media Firms
abstract: Patricia Breen and Dan Willey were named senior vice presidents and creative directors at the Troy, Mich., office of D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Blowin' In The Wind
abstract: Irish environmental mminister, Noel Dempsey, decrees 14-cent fee for each plastic bag used to carry groceries; notes that the Irish use 1.2 billion bags every year, or 325 per person, and that they are most visible form of litter in countryside (S)

headline: Turkey Arrests Leader of Sect Over Prayers Without Permit
abstract: The leader of an American-based mystic Islamic Sufi sect was arrested on Thursday in Izmir on charges of praying in a group without a permit and wearing banned religious dress in public.    Aydogan Fuat, also known as Sheik Abdul Kerim Fuat, was arrested while holding a prayer meeting for 40 followers. The police videotaped part of the session and questioned the followers before arresting Mr. Fuat. He has been held without bail pending a hearing on Tuesday. A judge is expected to decide whether Mr. Fuat should be turned over for trial in the state security court.

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Bank Profit Is Up
abstract: Bank of Montreal reports net income increased to 444 million Canadian dollars ($288.1 million) in fiscal third quarter ended July 31, compared with 401 million Canadian dollars ($260.2 million) year earlier (S)

headline: Leading Indexes Drop as Microsoft Casts Long Shadow
abstract: Nasdaq composite index falls 17.22 points, or 0.8 percent, to close at 2,029.37; Dow Jones industrial average drops 33.35 points, or 0.3 percent, to close at 10,576.65; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index loses 4.17 points, or 0.3 percent, to 1,210.85; US Treasury bond prices decline; 10-year note falls 2/32, to price of 99 5/32; yield rises to 5.11 percent from 5.10 percent; 30-year note falls 3/32, to 97 23/32; yield is unchanged at 5.53 percent; graphs; charts (M)a

headline: Banks Give Polaroid Time to Renegotiate Millions in Loans
abstract: Polaroid Corp receives waiver from its banks that will keep it from defaulting on $367 million in loans; waiver is Polaroid's third this year; company expects to renegotiate terms of loans, which mature at end of year; announces it will not make interest payments coming due over next five weeks on more than $500 million in bonds (M)

headline: As the economy falters, the tensions between advertisers and agencies rises, a new survey says.
abstract: Salz Survey of Advertiser-Agency Relations shows sluggish advertising economy is already causing rifts in relations between agencies and advertisers; those reporting they have felt slowdown describe serious consequences ranging from lower-quality campaigns to less teamwork to more of focus on money (M)

headline: McDONALD'S EARNINGS SLIP BECAUSE OF MAD COW FEARS
abstract: McDonald's Corp says second-quarter earnings fell 16 percent, to $440.9 million; sales rose 4.2 percent, to $3.71 billion (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Bid For Airport Operator
abstract: British airport operator TBI recommends that shareholders accept unsolicited $755 million offer from Vinci, Paris-based construction company (S)

headline: ASSOCIATED BANC-CORP TO BUY SIGNAL FINANCIAL
abstract: Associated Banc-Corp, leading bank in Wisconsin, agrees to buy Signal Financial Corp for $176 million to acquire branches in Minnesota (S)

headline: Amazon.com to Sell Products From Circuit City
abstract: Circuit City Group, nation's second-biggest consumer-electronics retailer, agrees to sell its products online through Amazon.com; customers will be able to buy electronic products from Circuit City through Amazon and pick up items at local stores or arrange delivery; Circuit City will pay Amazon percentage of revenue from each order (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Semiconductors: National Semiconductor Reports Loss
abstract: National Semiconductor Corp reports loss of $54.6 million for its fiscal first quarter, compared with net income of $144.2 million year earlier; sales fell 47 percent, to $339.3 million (S)

headline: Article 2001070592590894145 -- No Title
abstract: Education: From Working in Mines, to Learning Online

headline: Sometimes It's Better To Just Stop Playing
abstract: Charles Herold Game Theory column cites examples of computer games that require tremendous effort, make ridiculous demands and create needless busywork; photos (M)

headline: BUSINESS: DIARY
abstract: Sharper Image reported last week that same-store sales, those at stores open at least one year, declined 32 percent in August from same period year ago, while total company sales fell 23 percent; Walt Disney Co has revamped eight-minute Jungle Cruise ride at its Disneyland theme park in Anaheim, Calif, so that it no longer includes shots fired at mechanical hippopotamuses; change was made in response to comments from patrons; Kaiser Family Foundation survey shows premiums for employer-sponsored health insurance rose 11 percent this year, on average; finds average annual premium shared by employers and employees was $2,650 for single coverage and $7,053 for family coverage (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Government Handouts
abstract: Singapore's government says it will begin issuing citizens piece of future government surpluses in form of shares; photo (S)

headline: Bush Forgoes Trying to Bar Cuba Deals By Foreigners
abstract: Pres Bush, in setback for Cuban exile lobby and its Congressional allies, says he will not activate harshest sanction of 1996 Helms-Burton Act that seeks to punish foreigners for investing in American property in Cuba that was confiscated by Cuban government; says move is in US national interest and will expedite transition to democracy in Cuba; action appears aimed in part at avoiding conflict with European countries, critical of his policies and regard Helms-Burton as example of US legislating beyond its borders; decision raises likelihood that full force of Helms-Burton Act will never take effect; hard-line critics of Cuban government express dismay, but say Bush's approach to Cuba is preferable to Pres Clinton's more conciliatory stance (M)

headline: Universal Begins Account Review
abstract: Universal Studios said Monday that it had begun a review for its theme- park advertising account

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY  Consumer Borrowing -- July

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: Crackdown On Militants
abstract: Police in Pakistan arrest hundreds of militants one day after Gen Pervez Musharraf outlaws two Islamic groups blamed for sectarian killings (S)

headline: Business Survey Adds to Evidence of a Rebound
abstract: National Association of Purchasing Management's nonmanufacturing business index rose to 52.1 in June, from 46.6 in May; Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago's monthly National Activity Index shows risk of recession for economy increased to its highest point this year in May; Labor Department reports initial jobless claims rose by 7,000, to 399,000, in week ended June 30 (M)

headline: Court Rules Britain Violated Rights of 4 Kurds
abstract: In an unexpected blow to Britain's tough immigration policy, a British court ruled that the government had violated the human rights of four Kurdish asylum-seekers.

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Namibia: Regional Meeting On Land Problems
abstract: Senior officials from nine southern African nations open talks in Windhoek, Namibia, on ways to deal with inequity of land distribution in their countries (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Myanmar: Investigation Into Forced Labor
abstract: Four officials from International Labor Organization meet with diplomats and members of democratic opposition in Myanmar one day after meeting with interior minister; ILO is trying to verify government's claim that it is working to end forced labor (S)

headline: BE AEROSPACE AGREES TO BUY M&M, A FASTENER CONCERN
abstract: BE Aerospace Inc acquires M&M Aerospace Hardware Inc for at least $177 million in cash and stock to add aerospace fasteners to its line of products (S)

headline: EchoStar Bid For Hughes Could Hinge On Antitrust
abstract: Analysis of EchoStar's $30 billion unsolicited bid for Hughes Electronics and its DirecTV business says deal could hinge on antitrust; says DirecTV, with about 10 million subscribers, is nation's largest satellite TV operator; adds EchoStar, whose Dish Network has more than 6 million customers, is number 2; holds regulators will be likely to take hard look at such deal, and even most optimistic analysts and legal experts give chances of winning approval at only 50-50; says those would be bad odds, unless EchoStar were to raise its offer price to such level that potential rewards to GM would outweigh risk of lengthy regulatory review's ending in defeat; EchoStar chairman-chief executive Charles W Ergen says he believes chances are good that federal regulators will approve purchase of Hughes Electronics; photo (M)

headline: Archbishop Bids Brotherly Goodbye to Wife, and Returns to Fold
abstract: Archbishop Emmanuel Milingo faces his wife, Maria Sung; hands her rosary and tells her he is leaving her to return to priestly life, apparently ending embarrassing episode for Roman Catholic Church; Sung says she will abide by his decision to end marriage, which was performed as part of multiple wedding of followers of Rev Sun Myung Moon (M)

headline: La Vida Loca? In a Plaza in Madrid
abstract: New generation of Spanish young people are using public plazas as places to meet with friends and drink; fiesta of teenagers and college students, repeated on public squares all across Spain, is called el botellon, the big bottle; as gatherings gain in popularity, so do noise and filth they generate, angering residents who live near plazas; photo (M)

headline: A Bet on Bulgaria Pays Dividends; Plants Like American Standard's Bolster the Economy
abstract: Bulgaria's economy is beginning to grow with help of outside investment; American Standard Companies' investment has been boon for struggling Sevlievo region; American Standard's presence has made Bulgaria important supplier of bathroom fixtures to Europe and Middle East; graph; map; photos (M)

headline: U.S. Envoy, A Bridge To Vietnam, Ends Tenure
abstract: US Amb Pete Peterson ends four-year tenure as America's first postwar ambassador to Vietnam; was former prisoner of war and Democratic Congressman; his success in bringing aura of common sense to relationship still freighted with resentments and mistrust, earning respect in both Hanoi and Washington, discussed; photo (M)

headline: Central Bank In Europe Cuts A Rate Slightly
abstract: European Central Bank reduces its main refinancing rate by one-quarter of percentage point, to 4.25 percent, conceding that Europe has been hit much harder by American slowdown than it had expected; bank president Wim Duisenberg says slowdown in economic growth emanating from slowdown in US is larger, deeper and lasting longer that had been anticipated earlier (M)

headline: Suddenly, the Magic Is in Short Supply
abstract: Walt Disney Co is expected to be harder hit than other companies in aftermath of terrorist attacks because more than half of its revenue comes from businesses that depend on travel, including theme parks and cruises, or on advertising, like broadcast and cable television; company was having problems even before Sept 11; Bass family sale of $2 billion of Disney stock adds to worries; photos; graphs (L)

headline: Article 2001071091078648345 -- No Title
abstract: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

headline: U.P.S. AGREES TO BUY 75% OF UNI-DATA OF GERMANY
abstract: u.p.s. to4

headline: Just Relax, Surf the Net And Give Us Your Blood
abstract: Baxter International's reclining chair for blood includes Internet-connected computer for donors' amusement; photo (S)

headline: Israeli Strike Kills 4 in Bethlehem
abstract: The month-old cease-fire between Israel and the Palestinians seemed shakier than ever today with new violence

headline: How Powell Decided to Shun Conference
abstract: Article examines competing pressures within Bush administration that led to decision by Sec of State Colin L Powell to boycott UN World Conference Against Racism in Durban, South Africa (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Dow Posts Its Worst Loss Since the Great Depression  America's stock markets ended one of the worst weeks in their history, as fears of a deepening recession led many investors to move their money out of stocks into less risky assets.    For the week, the Dow Jones industrial average posted a 14.3 percent loss, its largest since the Depression. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 140.40 points yesterday, to 8,235.81. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, which includes the largest publicly traded companies, ended yesterday just above its low of Aug. 31, 1998, the last time fears of a worldwide recession overwhelmed Wall Street. The S.& P. fell 18.74 points, to 965.80, while the Nasdaq composite index fell 47.74 points, or 3.3 percent, to 1,423.19. [Page A1.]

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Queen Mother In Hospital
abstract: Queen Elizabeth the Queen Mother is hospitalized in London with anemia and is given blood transfusion after complaining of fatigue while attending outdoor events in 90-degree heat; photo (S)

headline: Bush Statement to Pope John Paul II
abstract: The following statement was delivered by President George W. Bush to Pope John Paul II today after their first meeting:

headline: A Speculator's Life Is Still Elusive
abstract: Off the Shelf column on book Jesse Livermore. World's Greatest Stock Trader by Richard Smitten; photo (M)
