abstract: Find a Job            Post a Job            Find a Home            Personals            All Classifieds                 International            National            Politics            Business           Technology          -    E-Business         -     Circuits          -     Columns            Science            Health            Arts            Sports            New York Region            Weather            Obituaries            NYT Front Page            Corrections                 Editorials/Op-Ed            Readers' Opinions

headline: Milosevic to Face Charge of Genocide
abstract: The chief prosecutor in the Hague war crimes trial of ex-Yugoslav leader Slobodan Milosevic said today she would charge him with genocide

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Sales Down At Computer Associates
abstract: Computer Associates International of Islandia, N.Y., whose software manages mainframe and network computers, reported a first-quarter loss yesterday of $342 million, or 59 cents a share, in contrast to profit of $23 million, or 4 cents, a year earlier. Sales fell to $713 million from $1.14 billion. Sam Wyly, a shareholder and Texas billionaire, is waging a proxy fight to replace the board and fire the top executives.

headline: Ad Downturn Fails to Deter WPP From Bid
abstract: WPP Group confirms offer for Tempus Group that values it at 5.55 million pounds ($632 million), or 5.55 pounds per share, besting earlier 5.41 pounds-per-share bid from Havas Advertising; reports first-half revenue grew 65 percent, to 1.9 billion pounds ($2.75 billion); says net income surged nearly 80 percent, to 167.1 million pounds ($241.7 million); photo (M)

headline: Pope Condemns Extremism Behind Terror
abstract: Pope John Paul II, on visit to Kazakhstan, which is heavily Muslim and Orthodox Christian, draws sharp distinction between 'authentic Islam' and extremism that led to recent terrorist attacks in US; reaffirms Catholic Church's respect for Islam, and says Catholics, too, should be careful in way they go about pushing their beliefs (S)

headline: Robert Miles Runyan, 76, Adroit Graphic Designer, Dies
abstract: Robert Miles Runyan, graphic desgier who changed way American corporations communicate by designing innovative annual reports, dies at age of 76; photos (M)

headline: Chinese Fight Crime With Torture and Executions
abstract: China's harsh crackdown on crime has executed unknown thousands of prisoners this year in judicial process in which torture is common and lawyers rare; photos; map; Liu Mingie in Hefei recounts torture that led to false confession, which was only overturned because of his former Communist party membership and family's position and money; at least 3,000 people have been executed since Pres Jiang Zemin announced crackdown in April; periodic campaigns in response to rising crime and concerns about weakening social order place huge pressures on local police to solve crimes quickly, which they often do by extorting confessions by torture; convictions are sometimes handed down days after arrests, appeals are processed briskly and executions are carried out just after sentencing; monthly tally of death sentences has become kind of grim score card showing how each province is doing, but real numbers are believed much higher (M)

headline: A Longtime Star Hopes It's a Short-Term Slump
abstract: Thomas F. Marsico, a star who had a knack for spotting small technology companies on the verge of becoming big hits, has seen his large-capitalization growth funds take a nose dive

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Kashmir: Arrest Powers
abstract: India's central government grants sweeping arrest and interrogation powers to security forces in four Hindu-dominated districts in Jammu and Kashmir; move follows two recent massacres of civilians, believed carried out by anti-India militants (S)

headline: Miscellany
abstract: * Allstate Corp., Northbrook, Ill., agreed for its Allstate Insurance Company unit to become the ''official'' home and automotive insurance sponsor for the 2002 Winter Olympics in Salt Lake City as well as for the 2002 and 2004 United States Olympic teams. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: Private Sector; A Landlord at Disaster's Margin
abstract: Bruce Flatt, chief executive of Brookfield Properties, oversees assessment of damages and repairs needed at several of its large buildings close to World Trade Center site; photos (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Australia: Hardware Acquisition
abstract: Australia's Wesfarmers Ltd to acquire Howard Smith Ltd for 2.65 billion Australian dollars ($1.35 billion) and become country's leading hardware retailer (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Chip Sales Index Dips
abstract: Semiconductor Equipment and Materials International says book-to-bill ratio, leading benchmark of health of computer chip equipment industry, showed slight decline in August; worldwide equipment orders were $742 million, for ratio of 0.61, meaning industry received $61 in new orders for every $100 in products shipped (S)

headline: Second Look Backs Doubts On Finding Key Particle
abstract: Re-analysis of data casts doubt on view of some researchers at CERN laboratory in Geneva that they might have finally discovered Higgs boson, long-sought particle believed to be source of mass and weight in universe; apparent trace of particle may have been mirage, product of random superimpositions of ordinary particles; lab director, Luciano Maiani, turned down pleas to delay demolition of equipment to make way for more powerful experiment; CERN's $4 billion Large Hadron Collider will not start up until 2006; hunt has now moved to Fermi National Accelerator Lab near Chicago, where new Tevratron accelerator is already collecting data (M)

headline: NATO Nations Vow to Support U.S., but Few Have Much to Offer Militarily
abstract: Few have special forces trained to do the kind of quick, surgical missions analysts believe the United States would want to conduct against terrorist training camps on other continents.

headline: World Briefing | The Americas: Mexico: Acquittal Denounced
abstract: Robert Rivard, editor of San Antonio Express-News, denounces acquittal of two Mexican suspects in murder of Philip True, correspondent for newspaper who was found dead after disappearing during 100-mile hike in state of Jalisco (S)

headline: $30 Million Campaign To Promote KFC Menu
abstract: KFC fast food chain, part of Tricon Global Restaurants, will begin $30 million advertising campaign to stimulate sales of its menu items; campaign begins on July 29 with television commercials; campaign was developed by BBDO Worldwide (S)

headline: Australian Case Shows Rescues Can Be Costly : In Migrants' Plight, a Sea Of Trouble for Skippers
abstract: SINGAPORE—  The global shipping industry and United Nations refugee officials are deeply disturbed by the ramifications of the incident involving the Tampa, the Norwegian-registered freighter that rescued 430 refugees from a sinking Indonesian ferry and spent eight days caring for them at sea because Australia refused to grant the refugees asylum.

headline: Columbia University Hires Star Economist
abstract: Columbia University hires Joseph E Stiglitz, Stanford University professor often mentioned as future Nobel prize winner for his contributions to economic theory; Columbia is trying to regain its old glory as teaching and research center in economics; Stiglitz comments; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Daewoo Talks
abstract: General Motors Corp is still negotiating with creditors of bankrupt Daewoo Motors and says it knows nothing about deadline for reaching agreement to acquire company by Aug 31 (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Infineon Plans Offering
abstract: The European chip maker Infineon Technologies said yesterday that it would sell new shares worth about 1.7 billion euros ($1.4 billion) to finance investments, acquisitions and refinance debt. The company will sell as many as 60 million shares in Germany and the United States and in private placements. Siemens, which owns 56 percent of Infineon, will not buy shares, Infineon said. Shares have fallen as much as 24 percent since June 20 when Infineon forecast a loss in the latest quarter because of slack demand and falling prices. The shares will be priced on July 12 and start trading July 13.

headline: Suicide Bomber Kills 2 Israeli Soldiers; 3rd Is Badly Wounded
abstract: Palestinian suicide bomber blows self up near train station in northern Israeli town of Binyamina killing two soldiers, critically wounding third, and injuring several other people; Israeli tanks shell Palestinian police positions near West Bank cities of Jenin and Tulkarm in retaliation (M)

headline: North Korea Denounces U.N. Refugee Agency as 7 Migrants Reach the South
abstract: Seven members of extended family that fled North Korea more than two years ago arrive in South Korea to televised reception; North Korea denounces UN refugee commission for providing refuge to family (S)

headline: Why Not to Stonewall in the Midst of a Scandal
abstract: Interview with David F D'Alessandro, corporate chief executive, on his book portraying how companies often fail to protect long-term corporate brand image when in pursuit of short-term goals; he discusses how effort to stonewall in midst of scandal threatens brand; photo (M)

headline: Judge Tells Microsoft and U.S. to Settle Antitrust Case Quickly
abstract: A federal district judge ordered the lawyers for Microsoft and the government today to begin a new round of intensive settlement negotiations.

headline: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Twist In State Politics
abstract: Lt Gov Bill Ratliff of Texas says he will run for re-election to State Senate; photo (S)

headline: Tobacco Dealer Posts Profit Drop
abstract: Dimon Inc says fiscal fourth-quarter profit fell 15 percent, to $15.6 million; revenue fell 11 percent, to $290.8 million (S)

headline: Poor Profit Outlook Sends Stocks Down
abstract: Stocks fell sharply and broadly as companies as varied as Dell Computer, Ford Motor and Gap provided Wall Street with further evidence that corporate profits appear unlikely to recover soon. Heavy selling in Microsoft also put pressure on the stock market.    The Nasdaq dropped more than 3 percent, bringing the week's loss to 4.6 percent. The S.& P. 500 was down 1.7 percent for the day and 2.4 percent for the week. The Dow Jones industrials dropped 1.5 percent, ending the week down 1.7 percent.

headline: Fast-food marketers worry about contests after a rigging scandal.
abstract: Advertisers and agencies try to determine how disclosure that promotional games at McDonald's restaurants were rigged during last six years will affect growing use of contests and sweepstakes to woo customers; photo (M)

headline: Gauging Analysts' Ratings
abstract: letters: gauging analysts'

headline: Officers of India Mutual Fund Arrested
abstract: India's federal anticorruption police arrest former head of country's largest mutual fund, Unit Trust of India, and three of its senior officials on charges of defrauding fund of $7 million; arrests come two weeks after resignation of P S Subramanyam as chairman in wake of dismal performance of Unit Trust's flagship fund; others arrested are M M Kapur, S K Basu and Prema Madhu Prasad (M)

headline: AT&T Unit Sees No Halt In Net Access
abstract: AT&T Broadband assures customers that its high-speed Internet service will remain uninterrupted if its partner, ExciteatHome, ultimately fails; Excite's auditors have questioned its financial viability (S)

headline: How to Enliven The Fields of Dreams
abstract: Gene Cofsky letter on August 12 article on baseball's decline in popularity holds fans should again be allowed to walk across baseball diamond to outfield exit gates when game ends

headline: MediaTalk; Striking up the Band, Despite Tough Times
abstract: The Internet bubble has burped, but that doesn't mean that The Industry Standard, the newly redesigned once-proud bible of the Internet economy, can't string up some lights in the barn and be host to a star-studded technology conference as it did in the good times.    And times sure are lean. Advertising pages have dropped from 991 pages for the four issues May of last year, to 131 this May, according to the Publishers Information Bureau.

abstract: Find a Job            Post a Job            Find a Home            Personals            All Classifieds                International          -     Africa          -     Americas          -     Asia Pacific          -    Europe         -     Middle East            National            Politics            Business            Technology            Science            Health            Arts            Sports            New York Region            Weather            Obituaries            NYT Front Page            Corrections                 Editorials/Op-Ed            Readers' Opinions

headline: SALTON REPORTS $11.4 MILLION 4TH-QUARTER LOSS
abstract: Salton Inc reports $11.4 million loss in fourth fiscal quarter, compared with net income of $15.3 million; sales fell 4 percent, to $169.1 million (S)

headline: The Dinner's Not on Me
abstract: Ray S Harding letter on Abby Ellin's August 19 Preludes column holds men should pay for dates because women have to spend much more to prepare for dates

headline: Pirelli Group Gains a Role In Telecoms
abstract: Pirelli joins with investment firm controlled by Benetton clothing family to buy 23 percent of Olivetti for $6 billion; move will give consortium control of Telecom Italia, in which Olivetti has 54 percent holding, and brings Pirelli into telecommunications; Roberto Colaninno is likely to resign as chief executive of Olivetti and Telecom Italia (S)

headline: India's 'Bandit Queen' Is Dead, Gunned Down at 37
abstract: Phoolan Devi, India's legendary 'bandit queen,' is killed by masked gunmen outside her home in New Delhi; this marks last installment in soap-operatic life where rape victim became avenging outlaw and champion of the oppressed; Devi grew up poor, was forced into marriage at age 11, escaped year later and joined gang of men, which she later led; she was apprehended and jailed for gang's crimes, and when she was released she ran for office and won seat in Parliament in 1996; there is speculation that her assassins were seeking revenge for murders committed by gang under Devi's leadership 20 years ago; photos (M)

headline: Article 2001093091558337904 -- No Title
abstract: Document is not available. A template could not be found for NYT_Article #1001753399661.

headline: F.A.A. Orders Troubled Freight Carrier to Suspend Flights
abstract: Federal Aviation Administration forces Emery Worldwide Airlines, cargo airline with its hub in Dayton, Ohio, to ground its fleet of planes because of extensive maintenance problems; cites litany of problems with airline, which it says has accumulated more than 100 violations, mostly for ignoring maintenance problems or fixing things poorly; photo (M)

headline: Ex-Chief Will Leave Archer Daniels Board
abstract: Dwayne O Andreas will step down from board of Archer Daniels Midland in November (S)

headline: For Bond Funds, A Very Good Year
abstract: New investments in bond mutual funds total about $7.5 billion in July; stock-fund inflows are between $1.6 billion and $3 billion for same month; this reverses previous year's trend (S)

headline: Swissair and Belgium Reach Accord on Sabena Finances
abstract: Swissair Group reaches agreement with Belgian government to give financial lifeline to Sabena in return for release from Swissair's commitment to raise its ownership stake in airline; two shareholders, Swissair and Belgian government, will provide $370 million over two years to save carrier; in return, Swissair is released from its promise to take 85 percent stake in Sabena; Swissair will continue to own minority stake in Sabena; photo (M)

headline: No Middle Ground
abstract: The Bush administration gave the nations of the world a stark choice: Stand with us against terrorism or face the certain prospect of death and destruction.

headline: Japan's Premier Visits War Shrine, Pleasing Few
abstract: Japan's Prime Min Junichoro Koizumi visits Yasukuni shrine near Tokyo that honors nation's war dead; yields to international pressure by abandoning plan to do so on August 15 anniversary of Japanese surrender in World War II; change of plan disappoints supporters and fails to mollify critics; he is met by small band of protestors, representing Korean residents in Japan and group of university students, who criticize decision to visit under any circumstances; original plan to visit on August 15 raised hackles of Asian neighbors, particularly South Korea and China; Asian countries regard Yasukuni, which includes war criminals among 2.47 million Japanese soldiers honored there, as symbol of Japanese militarism; photos (M)

headline: Sharp Blow to Already Struggling Companies
abstract: Some commercial airline carriers in Latin America may be driven out of business; Latin America's largest commercial carrier is Varig of Brazil, which logged loss of more than $200 million in first half of 2001; Aerolineas Argentinas has been on verge of collapse for months; various carriers in Ecuador, Peru, Colombia and Venezuela have also been struggling to stay afloat; industry analysts say Lan Chile and TACA Airlines, based in El Salvador, appear equipped to weather economic storm; photo (M)

headline: Target of Attack in Belfast: Little Girls Going to School
abstract: Militant Protestants trying to prevent Roman Catholic girls from reaching their elementary school in North Belfast hurl homemade bomb at children and their police escorts; four police officers are seriously injured; even hard-line Protestant politicians express revulsion at attack, which causes 100 students and their parents to flee in panic (M)

headline: Sana Journal; A Fittingly Gory Finale To a Sordid Murder Case
abstract: Mohammed Adam Omar Ishaak, Sudanese morgue attendant convicted of raping, killing and dismembering two female medical students in Yemen, is executed in as cruel and grisly fashion as legend built around him during sensational trial; was shot in heart and head after receiving 80 lashes before crowd of more than 30,000 people outside Sana; his frustrated attempts to offer version of events different from that of prosecution has worried many Yemenis, who hold commmon view that he may have been scapegoat in wider sex-and-murder scandal, possibly involving dozens of murders, that might have involved powerful figures protected at trial; maps; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: India: Ban On Diesel Fuel Postponed
abstract: Indian Supreme Court extends deadline for thousands of New Delhi buses to switch from diesel fuel to cleaner compressed natural gas (S)

headline: Sony Posts Loss, Citing Weak Sales And a Recall
abstract: The Sony Corporation said today that weakening worldwide sales of electronics products and costs arising from a large recall of cellular handsets caused it to lose 30.1 billion yen, or $243 million, in the first quarter. It also cut its profit forecast for the year by 40 percent.    ''The business environment surrounding Sony in the first quarter was characterized by clear economic slowdown in such primary markets as the U.S., Europe, Japan and Asia,'' the company stated.

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: High-Speed Access Rising Rapidly
abstract: Federal Communications Commission reports more than seven million homes and businesses had high-speed connections to Internet by the end of 2000, an increase of 63 percent in six months (S)

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: CAMBREX CORP., East Rutherford, N.J., which makes chemicals and drug ingredients, named Claes Glassell, executive vice president and chief operating officer responsible for the fine chemicals, biosciences and pharmaceuticals units, to the posts of president and chief operating officer.    CHURCHILL DOWNS INC., Louisville, Ky., which owns racetracks, named Carl F. Pollard chairman. He succeeds William S. Farish, who resigned to accept the ambassadorship to Britain.

headline: NASD Fines 10 Companies For Violations
abstract: Brokerage units of Deutsche Bank, Merrill Lynch and Goldman Sachs Group are among 10 firms settling regulators' charges that they violated market rule that is supposed to provide orderly start to trading shares in initial public offerings; firms agree to pay total of $473,000 to settle charges by NASD Regulation; NDB Capital Markets, unit of Deutsche Bank, is fined $250,000; nine others agree to pay from $10,000 to $61,000 in penalties (M)

headline: Vodafone Set To Lift Stake In Japanese Phone Giant
abstract: Vodafone Group plans to buy additional 21.7 percent of Japan Telecom's stock, purchase that would give it controlling two-thirds of company; it currently owns 45 percent; move is another example of how Vodafone is building global network by turning minority stakes in wireless companies around world into controlling interests; Vodafone is negotiating to buy all or part of 15.2 percent stake held by East Japan Railway and stakes held by SFR and Verizon Communications (M)

headline: Thailand's High Court Acquits Prime Minister of Graft
abstract: Thailand's highest court acquitted Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra today of financial irregularities, preserving his political career in a ruling that was seen as a test of Thailand's evolution toward the rule of law

headline: Rumsfeld in Russia: Less ABM, More Warm Ties
abstract: Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld will visit Russia for one day of talks on missile defense and nuclear reductions and to build new relationship between US and Russia that will take it beyond some of institutions of cold war; no agreements are expected on missile defense or nuclear reductions because, American officials believe, outcome is preordained and US position has prevailed (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Brunei: Here Come The Creditors
abstract: brunei: here come the creditor

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: EDO CORP.,  New York, a maker of military armament systems and components, said it had received a $17.4 million contract from the U.S. Air Force to continue making ''smart'' bomb racks for F-16 Falcon aircraft.    MARTHA STEWART LIVING OMNIMEDIA INC.,  New York, a multimedia company built around its founder's homemaking tips, said it had formed a partnership with Seiyu Ltd., Tokyo, a retailer with 226 stores, to be the exclusive seller of its home products and magazine in Japan.

headline: FOLLOWING MOODY'S, S.& P. LOWERS SAKS DEBT RATINGS
abstract: Standard & Poor's Corp lowers Saks Inc credit rating and senior unsecured debt to BB from BB+, or two notches below investment grade (S)

headline: A Virtual Slide Show On a SmartPhone
abstract: Album to Go software ClubPhoto.com developed for Palm operating system has been upgraded and now allows users to download and display pictures from computer on Kyocera SmartPhone and various Palm devices; photo (M)

headline: TERROR STRIKES AMERICA / World Reacts to Horror : World Leaders Unite in Condemnation of Terrorist Assault
abstract: Hundreds of millions of people around the world, watching the catastrophe in the United States unfold live on their television screens, reacted with horror, condemnation and stupefaction to the terrorist attacks Tuesday on the heart of American political and economic power

headline: Amazon Starts A Storefront For Computers
abstract: Amazon.com opens online computer storefront offering new and refurbished computers; prices are comparable to manufacturers' online outlets (M)

headline: Chief Creative Officer Leaves BBDO West
abstract: Chief Creative Officer Leaves BBDO West Ken Mandelbaum, chief creative officer at BBDO West in San Francisco, part of the BBDO Worldwide unit of the Omnicom Group, is leaving the agency

headline: Red Scare Over Newark
abstract: Helen Lippman column on disdain for conspicuous consumption she acquired from her parents, American Communists, even though she does not share their ideology; says she has even passed it on to her daughters; drawing (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Panel Praises C.I.A. Venture
abstract: Business Executives for National Security, nonprofit group, finds In-Q-Tel, venture capital firm Central Intelligence Agency created in 1999 to develop technologies from private sector, has been moderately successful and should continue; urges CIA to streamline procedures for reviewing and acquiring new technology; In-Q-Tel has evaluated over 750 projects and invested nearly $30 million in 23 (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Auction Case Settled
abstract: Federal Trade Commission says operators of Internet computer auctions that consistently delivered computers to winning bidders late, or not at all, agree to settle charges that their business practices violated federal law; Computers by Us Inc and its principals, Jeffrey M and Wanda Wesko and Richard A Wesko, Jeffrey's brother, sold computers through Internet auctions; settlement requires Weskos to post bonds before engaging in other Web-based marketing operations (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Canon, Tokyo, expanded its relationship with CIA Medianetwork, Dusseldorf and London, part of the Tempus Group, by naming the agency to handle its first consolidated media services account in Africa, Europe and the Middle East. Spending was estimated at $45 million. CIA Medianetwork already works with Canon in other countries, including Italy.  The Georgia Department of Industry, Trade and Tourism, Atlanta, to Match, Atlanta, to handle its advertising account, which had been at the Atlanta office of J. Walter Thompson, part of the WPP Group. Billings under a one-year contract were estimated at $5 million; the contract is eligible for an additional four years. The department will also work with Ant Farm Interactive, Atlanta, for interactive advertising, and Manning, Selvage & Lee, Atlanta, part of the Bcom3 Group, for public relations.  Resorts Atlantic City Casino Hotel to Gianettino & Meredith Advertising, Short Hills, N.J., to handle its account, which had been at Lang/ Durham, West Hartford, Conn. Spending was estimated at $5 million.  Silversea Cruises, Fort Lauderdale, Fla., to the New York office of Fallon Worldwide, part of the Publicis Groupe, to handle a branding and marketing assignment, with spending estimated at $2 million to $3.5 million. Silversea had handled advertising internally.

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Bahamas: Fire Consumes Tourist Site
abstract: Fire destroys renowned handicrafts market in Nassau, Bahamas; photo (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Bank Moves To Cut Costs
abstract: germany: bank moves

headline: When Free Markets Leave Workers in the Dust
abstract: Marc Beauchamp letter replies to Tom Redburn's June 17 column defending Pres Bush for protecting jobs of US steelworkers from imports while allowing California energy crisis to run its course

headline: On Top in Bulgaria: New Premier Is the Old King
abstract: Bulgaria's deposed king, Simeon II of Saxe-Coburg-Gotha, announces that he will accept position as prime minister; Simeon returned from exile three months ago to lead his fledgling political party to sweeping victory in national legislative elections in June; map; photos (M)

headline: Montedison Accepts Takeover Offer
abstract: Board of Montedison SpA, owner of Italy's second-largest power company, accepts sweetened offer of $4.79 billion from Fiat SpA and Electricite de France, bringing end to battle for control of company (S)

headline: Mideast Truce Holds, With Scattered Violence
abstract: Israelis and Palestinians largely hold their fire, in mutual gesture of good will aimed at restarting talks toward full truce; both sides report some violence, but meeting between Israeli Foreign Minister Shimon Peres and Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat could take place as early as Sept 20; outside officials, particularly from United States, push for truce as they work to put together coalition against terrorism; Arab leaders have said they want to see progress toward solving Israeli-Palestinian conflict before committing themselves (M)

headline: Power-Sharing Plans in Doubt as Ulster Peace Talks Falter
abstract: With peace negotiations stalemated, Britain faced the growing likelihood today of having to put the power-sharing Northern Ireland government on hold by this weekend

headline: AT&T to Be Allowed to Sell Some of Its Cablevision Shares
abstract: Cablevision Systems Corp agrees to permit AT&T, which owns 30 percent of company, to sell as much as $1 billion in shares; agreement clears way for AT&T to sell as many as 18.6 million shares, or 11 percent stake; blocking of AT&T's earlier attempt to register 30 million shares for sale noted (S)

headline: Northern Ireland Paramilitary Groups Ignore Disarmament Deadline
abstract: LONDON, July 2 — The international commission responsible for the disarming of Northern Ireland's paramilitary groups said today that the Irish Republican Army had passed the July 1 deadline for weapons moves without taking any steps to dismantle its arsenal or to indicate how it planned to do so.

headline: World Briefing
abstract: EUROPE THE HAGUE: MILOSEVIC CHASTISED Slobodan Milosevic, the former Yugoslav president who is awaiting trial on charges of war crimes, has been reprimanded for giving a telephone interview from detention in The Hague, the United Nations tribunal said. Mr. Milosevic told Fox News that he was sorry lives were lost in Kosovo but was proud of what he did for his country. The tribunal noted that its rules forbid detainees from communicating with the media before their cases are closed, and said that Mr. Milosevic had received a warning that if he broke the rules again he could have telephone privileges restricted or withdrawn

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Bank Raises $739 Million
abstract: United Overseas Bank raises 1.3 billion Singapore dollars, or about $739 million, in Singapore's largest corporate bond sale to date (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: UNION PACIFIC CORP., Dallas, the largest U.S. railroad, won a contract with General Motors Corp., Detroit, the automaker, to transport all 2.5 million G.M. vehicles moved by rail in the Western U.S. Union Pacific said the multiyear deal could increase the company's annual sales by about $60 million.

headline: Economic Scene; A tarnished new economy loses more luster with revised productivity data.
abstract: Jeff Madrick 'Economic Scene' column on recent revisions to productivity data reported by Bureau of Labor Statistics that show how thin new-economy thinking has been all along; graph (M)

headline: Walking The Trade Tightrope, Confidently
abstract: US trade representative, Robert B Zoellick, expresses confidence that he can advance Bush administration's free-trade agenda despite obstacles he faces at home and abroad; says most immediate challenge is to win authority from Congress to negotiate trade deals that will not be icked apart through amendments; photo (M)

headline: Israel Kills 3 Militants and Hits Syrian Site in Lebanon
abstract: In a day of expanding violence, an Israeli helicopter gunship killed three Muslim militants today in a rocket attack on a car in the West Bank, hours after Israeli warplanes struck a Syrian radar station deep in Lebanon in retaliation for a guerrilla attack on Friday.     The Israeli radio quoted security officials as saying that the car was packed with explosives, and that the men inside were on their way to carry out a terror attack.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Vatican: Making A Profit
abstract: Cardinal Sergio Sebastiani announces that Holy See's 2000 budget, which covers papal activities and some other Vatican expenses, is in black for eighth year in row, boasting $8.5 million profit on revenue of $182 million (S)

headline: Gunman Kills 14 and Himself in Attack on Swiss Legislators
abstract: A man armed with a grenade and an assault rifle burst into a parliamentary session in the central Swiss town of Zug today and killed 15 people, including himself.

headline: More Is More (Mostly): From Cable to Satellite TV
abstract: Alfred Balk article on his and his wife's experience with satellite television after moving from New York to semirural areas outside Chicago; says advantages over cable came with tradeoffs and they did not save any money; drawing (M)

headline: Eric Bedford, Who Changed London's Skyline, Dies at 91
abstract: Eric Bedford, British government's chief architect whose works are visible to millions but whose name is scarcely known, died July 28 at age of 91; photo (M)

headline: Porsche Reports 18% Increase in Earnings
abstract: Porsche says pretax profit was more than 1 billion deutsche marks ($459.8 million) in fiscal full year, compared with 848.5 million marks year earlier; sales rose 20 percent, to 8.5 billion marks; unit sales rose 12 percent, to 54,586 vehicles in last fiscal year (S)

headline: HCA Reports Strong Results for Quarter
abstract: HCA Inc., the largest United States hospital chain, said that its second-quarter net income was $263 million, a figure that beat expectations

headline: For Nations Traumatized By the Past, New Remedies
abstract: International Center for Transitional Justice has been formed to help countries come to terms with oppressions that mark their recent past; many governments and human rights groups in Asia, South America, Africa and Europe are asking for advice, information and technical assistance; center seeks to help countries emerging from state-sponsored terrorism or civil war (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: North Korea: On To Cambodia
abstract: Kim Yong Nam, North Korea's No. 2 leader, gets hero's welcome in Cambodia, last stop in tour that took him to Vietnam and Laos; King Norodom Sihanouk, who lived in exile in Pyongyang in 1970's, and his son, Prince Norodom Ranariddh, welcome Kim at airport (S)

headline: In Investigation, Internet Offers Clues and Static
abstract: Law enforcement agencies are expected to rely on Internet tools as never before as they pursue terrorists responsible for attacks of Sept 11 even though Internet and new capacity to eavesdrop on e-mail and phone did not permit them to prevent attacks; assessment of Internet's strengths and weakness with regard to conducting surveillance of suspects, facilitating cooperation among law enforcement officials and searching for clues; drawing; photo (M)

headline: GOODYEAR CUTS PRODUCTION AS SALES TO AUTOMAKERS FALL
abstract: Goodyear Tire and Rubber Co will reduce production by unspecified amount through September because of decline in sales to automakers (S)

headline: Judge's Words: 'Cleansing Became Genocide'
abstract: Excerpts from sentencing judgment against former Gen Radislav Krstic for genocide in Srebrenica (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: India: Strike Protests Privatization
abstract: Millions of federal and state workers in India stage one-day strike to protest plans to sell government-owned companies (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Cuts At Bombardier
abstract: Bombardier is cutting production of regional and corporate aircraft, reflecting lower demand; will not meet profit forecasts and will write off $590 million (US) related to development of turboprop aircraft and financial services unit; about 3,800 workers will be laid off in Canada, US and Britain; expects to deliver about 370 aircraft this year, about same as 2000, but down from 410 that had been expected; photo (S)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Peru: Unhappy With Japan
abstract: Peru protests Japan's decision to grant citizenship to former Pres Alberto Fujimori's brother-in-law, Victor Aritomi, who is wanted on corruption charges in Peru; he is now protected from extradition (S)

headline: World Briefing | Middle East: West Bank: Hamas Activist Killed
abstract: Israelis kill Salah Darwaza, Palestinian described as Islamic militant from Hamas who helped plan recent bombings in Israel; photo (S)

headline: Southwest Blocks Orbitz on Fare Data
abstract: Southwest Airlines blocks Orbitz travel Web site from displaying its fares and flight information (S)

headline: Fact-Driven? Collegial? This Site Wants You
abstract: Some 100 volunteers have been working since Jan to compile free encyclopedia on Wikipedia Web site; use relatively unknown and simple software tool called Wiki that enables site visitors to contribute entries and edit existing ones; peer pressure is encouraging volunteers to strive for objectivity; photo (M)

headline: MICHELIN TO CUT 2,000 JOBS IN NORTH AMERICA
abstract: Michelin North America will cut 2,000 jobs, or about 7 percent of its work force, citing downturn in tire markets and need to increase its long-term competitiveness (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: US dollar rises amid speculation that its decline since July was not justified as prospects for economic growth improve; in New York, euro settles at 91.33 cents, down from 91.74 cents; graph; chart (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Turkey: Rebel Leader Denies Charges
abstract: Kurdish rebel leader Abdullah Ocalan, on death row in Turkey for treason and terrorism, denies similar charges dating back more than twenty years, saying he has never personally killed anyone; photo (S)

headline: Powell Upbeat About Relations After a Visit With Chinese
abstract: The images of Secretary of State Colin L. Powell and Chinese leaders beaming at each other in their meetings this weekend, and a rare interview with the secretary broadcast today by Chinese state television, illustrate just how quickly the roller coaster relationship between the United States and China can turn.     Only three months ago, the two countries were snarling at each other over a downed American spy plane. But the message conveyed by all the bonhomie on Saturday was that, for the moment at least, those in the Bush administration who want to work with China are in the ascendancy.

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Argentina: Squad Leader Surrenders
abstract: Alfredo Astiz, a retired navy captain and former death squad leader who once bragged that he was the ''best trained man in Argentina to kill journalists and politicians,'' turned himself in to the police to face charges of kidnapping three Italian citizens during the 1976-83 military dictatorship. An Italian court sought his arrest. He now awaits an extradition hearing.   Clifford Krauss (NYT)

headline: 44 Die in Tokyo As Fire Sweeps Gambling Club
abstract: Fire sweeps through crowded gambling club, Tokyo, killing at least 44 people and injuring 3 others; incident is worst of its kind in city in two decades; map; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: GeoCities Will Charge For 2 Services
abstract: Yahoo Inc's GeoCities unit, biggest service that lets consumers set up their own Internet sites, will charge users for two new, expanded versions of its free basic service (S)

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Spying on Junior To the Editor

headline: COURT RULES AGAINST BOEING ON $419 MILLION TAX REFUND
abstract: Appellate court rules against Boeing, overturning $419 million tax refund and rejecting company's accounting allocations (S)

headline: Technology Briefing
abstract: INTERNETONLINE STOCK FIRM CUTS STAFF W. R. Hambrecht & Company, one of the few remaining online investment banks, dismissed 45 employees, or about 20 percent of its staff, this week. The dismissals came as Hambrecht, best known for running online auctions of shares in initial public offerings of stock, decided to stop trading more than 100 stocks. The firm will continue to sell new stocks and bonds through its online auction system. About 30 of the people dismissed were stock traders, said Sharon Smith, a spokeswoman for the three-year-old San Francisco firm. Hambrecht will continue to make markets in stocks it has taken public or that its research analysts cover, she said.   Patrick McGeehan (NYT) EARTHLINK SAYS LOSS NARROWED EarthLink Inc. said it lost $35.1 million in the second quarter, while revenue jumped 32 percent from the period a year earlier. The loss, equal to 27 cents a share, was in line with forecasts. The Internet service provider lost $35.2 million, or 29 cents a share, in the 2000 period. Counting long-term acquisition and merger costs, EarthLink had a $90.5 million loss in the quarter. EarthLink shares rose $2.33, or 15.6 percent, to $17.28. Revenue, buoyed by strong demand for high- speed service, increased to $303.7 billion from $230.8 billion. Broadband access represented 13 percent of the company's revenue.   (AP) HARDWAREGATEWAY LOSS EXCEEDS ESTIMATES The personal computer maker Gateway Inc. reported a second-quarter loss, after extraordinary items, of $20.8 million, or 6 cents a share, in contrast to a profit of $118 million, or 36 cents, in the period a year earlier. Analysts had expected Gateway to post a 1-cent loss. Sales fell to $1.50 billion from $2.21 billion, coming in below the average forecast of $1.89 billion. Gateway sold 923,000 units worldwide in the second quarter, down 21 percent from the year- earlier period and 16 percent from the first quarter.   (Reuters) DELL SEE

headline: A New Israeli Show of Force, Near Bethlehem
abstract: Israeli tanks take up positions near outskirts of Bethlehem and adjoining towns, seemingly poised to enter Palestinian-ruled areas of West Bank for second straight day (M)

headline: British Arrest 7 Near Air Base
abstract: British police arrest six Iraqis and one German after men, described as stowaways, are found hiding in truck outside RAF Lakenheath military base in Suffolk, which is used by American forces; men are initially held under immigration laws, then under Terrorism Act, which gives police wider powers (S)

headline: Japan Tries to Grease Economy Again
abstract: Bank of Japan says it will further loosen credit in economy in which short-term financing can be raised at virtually no cost; will step up purchases of government bonds 50 percent, to $4.9 billion a month, to inject liquidity and help fight deflation; move stuns analysts and investors, who expected bank to continue resisting calls by politicians and others for looser money; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Swiss franc rises as investors seek shelter after US threatens to retaliate for terrorist attacks last week; currency reaches 1.5771 francs per dollar in New York; graph; chart (S)

headline: Colombia's Army Rebuilds and Challenges Rebels
abstract: Revived Colombian military has been checking rebel offensives and winning several skirmishes; American military analysts say army is not about to win war against country's most powerful rebel group, Revolutionary Armed Forces, but its recent operations reflect new level of organization for military that was long known for being poorly financed, inept and corrupt; changes have come under leadership of former Defense Min Luis Fernando Ramirez and new military leadership, and with military aid from US; moderates in Colombia and in United States say army should be fortified to strengthen government's hand in peace talks with rebels; talks, centerpiece of Pres Andres Pastrana's three-year-old administration, have faltered; photo; map (M)

headline: STORM LOSSES WILL PARE CHUBB'S QUARTERLY EARNINGS
abstract: Chubb Corp says $80 million in storm-related losses in second quarter will cut earnings per share by as much as 31 percent (S)

headline: MY FIRST JOB; Demystifying The Computer
abstract: Kim Polese, co-founder and chairwoman of Marimba, software company in Mountainview, Calif, describes her first job, teaching beginning computer classes at Lawrence Hall of Science, hands-on museum in Berkeley; photos (S)

headline: Accord Is Set on Timor Gap Energy Revenue
abstract: Australia and East Timor agree on 30-year deal that would give East Timor 90 percent of revenues from development of offshore gas and oil deposits in seabed between two nations; Australia says East Timor should get over $3.6 billion from existing and planned developments in next 24 years; East Timor had previously gotten 50 percent of funds; map (M)

headline: Lessons In Coaching
abstract: Nick Bollettieri, longtime premier tennis coach, writes My First Job column on teaching tennis at public park in North Miami Beach, Fla, in 1950's; photos (S)

headline: Focusing on Bozell, Interpublic Retools
abstract: Interpublic Group of Cos continues to work out details of its reorganization, focusing on what had been Bozell Group; latest changes mainly involve account shifts and merging agencies at what became units of its new Partnership division; Boston and Pittsburgh offices of Bozell Kamstra are being merged into Mullen, part of Partnership; weighs options for remaining Bozell Kamstra and Bozell offices (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Sri Lanka: Soldiers Held On Rape Charges
abstract: Sri Lankan army arrests two soldiers for raping Tamil woman, crime that army had charged separatist rebels with committing (S)

headline: Israel, Living With Terror, Redefines 'Normal'
abstract: Israelis, who have been living intimately with terror for years, wonder if Americans fathom costs and patience required for a long fight against terror; generations of Israelis have been steeped in kinds of fear and accustomed to kinds of compromises that Americans are coming to grips with; photo of scene at Jerusalem shopping mall, where a father waits his turn to refresh his family's gas masks (M)

headline: FISHER SCIENTIFIC WILL BUY COLE-PARMER FOR $205 MILLION
abstract: Fisher Scientific International acquires Cole-Parmer Instrument Co, which also distributes tools used in scientific research, for $205 million in cash (S)

headline: Mexico Seizes 27 Sugar Mills
abstract: Mexico's government takes over nearly half of nation's sugar mills in attempt to save dying industry subsidized for decades by old government; will expropriate 27 of country's 60 privately operated and deeply indebted companies, spending at least $110 million to acquire them (S)

headline: AND YET SO FAR: A special report.; Quest for Mideast Peace: How and Why It Failed
abstract: Special report, And Yet So Far, offers detailed examination of failed peace effort in Israel during Ehud Barak-Bill Clinton era; in Israel and to some extent in United States, it is believed that then-Prime Min Barak offered Yasir Arafat moon at Camp David last summer, and Arafat turned it down, choosing instead the path of violence; many diplomats and officials believe that dynamic was far more complex and that Arafat does not bear sole responsibility for breakdown of peace effort; say there were missteps and successes by Israelis, Palestinians and Americans alike over more than seven years of peace talks between 1993 Oslo interim agreement and last negotiating sessions in Taba, Egypt, in Jan; chronology of events; map; photos (L)

headline: Business; Sudden Sense of Insecurity at Many Companies
abstract: Companies around country rush to bolster their security systems in wake of Sept 11 terrorist attacks; thousands of executives accustomed to freewheeling travel, loose record-keeping and open access to workspaces are finding their work lives changing; photo (M)

headline: As for 'Bespoke,' the Readers Have Spoken
abstract: Last week we noted that the venerable English word "bespoke" had found its way into information technology circles. Many readers weighed in

headline: China Sentences Three People to Jail Terms for Spying
abstract: Two permanent United States residents were among those sentenced today for spying for Taiwan, which threatens to overshadow Secretary of State Colin L. Powell's visit later this week

headline: Mexico Takes Small Steps To Improving Its U.S. Ties
abstract: US and Mexico report agreement on measures to improve food safety, enhance law-enforcement and fight money laundering, but concede that thornier job of revamping immigration policy could take years to complete; modest accords announced by Sec of State Colin L Powell and Mexico's Foreign Min Jorge G Castaneda on eve of first state visit by Pres Vicente Fox; are seen as evidence that relationship marked by strain in past is strengthening (M)

headline: People
abstract: Mel Korn, chief executive at Collaborative Marketing unit of Saatchi & Saatchi, is named chief executive at new collaborative marketing service division of Publicis, Collaborative Marketing Worldwide; Margaret Somers will succeed Korn at Saatchi & Saatchi (S)

headline: Treasury Officials Reluctantly Become Global Firefighters
abstract: TREASURY Secretary Paul H. O'Neill is not going to be asked to be an honorary member of the International Association of Fire Fighters. In his first seven months on the job, he has made it abundantly clear that he does not like fighting fires, which is the way he characterizes running to the rescue of emerging market countries that have gotten into financial trouble, as Argentina has right now.    He has said repeatedly that he wants to reduce the time and money that international financial institutions, led by the International Monetary Fund, spend on firefighting. ''Certainly, there will always be unexpected events that we and the institutions will have to deal with, but firefighting should be the exceptional cases for these institutions, not the norm,'' he said in April. All these comments were a rebuke of the Clinton administration's hands-on firefighting, from the rescue package for Mexico in 1995 to aid for Brazil in 1998.

headline: S.E.C. Needs a New Home, Fast
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission's offices at 7 World Trade Center were destroyed during terrorist attack, as were files containing depositions, trading records and other documents for several hundred cases; informal notes from interviews and jottings on documents or memo pads that helped SEC build cases were also destroyed; officials say evidence supporting many cases was backed up on central computer or stored in other locations; many former SEC employees and other securities lawyers say commission faces enormous task in reconstructing complex cases; SEC is likely to have to make hard choices to pursue, and some--involving small outfits or events that took too many years to prove--may be deemed expendable; agency is adamant that no crime or infraction will go unpunished; photos (M)

headline: Operating Profits Rise 33% at Eni
abstract: Eni SpA, fourth-largest European oil company, reports rise in second-quarter profits of 33 percent; credits $5.6 billion acquisition and higher natural gas prices (S)

headline: Time For the Boomers To Dig In
abstract: James Schembari column on how events of Sept 11 have changed outlook and fortunes of Baby Boom generation; drawing (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: I.M.F. Is Prepared to Offer Aid to Brazil and Argentina  The International Monetary Fund said it was prepared to lend $15 billion to Brazil and accelerate financial aid for Argentina as concerns rose that financial problems in the two nations had worsened and begun to spread through Latin America.    The aid packages announced by Horst Köhler, managing director, came with the blessing of the Bush administration, which has supported several financial rescues even though administration officials have often said that they intended to avoid international bailouts like those arranged during the Clinton administration. [Page A4.]

headline: Private Sector; The Shows Must Go On
abstract: Ben Affleck's admission to alcohol-abuse rehabilitation center is not expected to have big impact on LivePlanet, production company he co-founded; photo (S)

headline: BOEING AGREES TO PAY $92.5 MILLION IN INVESTORS' SUIT
abstract: Boeing Co agrees to pay $92.5 million to settle class-action suit that accused it of not telling investors fast enough that company would take $1.6 billion charge related to temporarily idling 747 and 737 jetliner assembly lines; shareholders contended in suit, filed in October 1997, that Boeing kept its production problems secret so its stock price would remain high and company could complete its merger with McDonnell Douglas in August 1997 (S)

headline: A Software Patch Brightens the Palm M505
abstract: Palm issues software patch for its model m505 that will correct shortfall in monitor screen's operation; photo (S)

headline: Bush Scolds Protesters at Genoa Talks
abstract: Pres Bush says that thousands of people gathering in Genoa, Italy, to protest meeting of leaders of industrialized naitons 'hurt the case of the poor' (S)

headline: Behind a Closed Door
abstract: Gretchen Morgenson column criticizes closed-door sessions between Kipp A Bedard, Micron Technology executive, and select investors during three-day Bear Stearn conference with institutional investors; says new SEC rule is supposed to insure that all investors, large and small, get same information from companies at same time; also questions Micron's use of inventory write-down in third quarter to provide cushion to profit margins for future quarter in which goods would be sold; graph (M)

headline: At Last, Ivanisevic Catches Up to Wimbledon Destiny
abstract: LONDON—  Destiny? Who believes in destiny anymore? But as the aces and the victories started to pile up during the last two weeks at Wimbledon, Goran Ivanisevic, for one and for once, certainly began to believe that it was finally meant to be.

headline: World Briefing | The Americas: Mexico: Drug-Cartel Arrest
abstract: Mexican officials say they arrested Jorge Humberto Rodriguez, man suspected of being chief assassin of one of Mexico's most notorious drug cartels (S)

headline: A Pattern In the Dots: Film's Rival Is Gaining
abstract: David Pogue State of the Arts column on improvements in digital photography; notes new maxi-megapixel cameras offer higher resolution but require gigantic graphics files that quickly fill up camera's memory card and take longer to transfer to computer; photos (M)

headline: Mining a Dot-Com Disaster for EBay Sales
abstract: Stock certificates of bankrupt Webvan, online grocery service, sold quickly on eBay auction site until eBay halted further auctions, citing requirement that certificates must be clearly marked as canceled; other Webvan financial ephemera is also being offered on eBay; photo (M)

headline: Leonard Pines, 90, Businessman Who Owned Hebrew National
abstract: Leonard Pines, who expanded his father's business selling deli meats from wagon on Manhattan's Lower East Side into Hebrew National Kosher Foods, dies at 90 (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Euro rises against dollar on concern that dollar has gained too much strength this year, hindering US recovery; in New York, euro climbs to 85.70 cents, from 84.78 cents; graph; chart (S)

headline: Olympic Committee To Begin Campaign
abstract: International Olympic Committee begins worldwide promotional program for 2002 Winter Games, to be held in Salt Lake City beginning on Feb 8 (S)

headline: Mysterious Life Of a Suspect From France
abstract: Authorities try to piece together profile of Zacarias Moussaoui, French national who has come under suspicion in wake of Sept 11 terror attacks; say he could be missing 20th hijacker who was unable to keep date with destiny because he was detained by immigration authorities (M)

headline: VITESSE LOSS WILL BE WIDER THAN PREVIOUSLY REPORTED
abstract: Vitesse Semiconductor Corp says fiscal fourth-quarter loss will be wider than previously expected (S)

headline: Daniel Lewin, Technology Executive, 31
abstract: Daniel C Lewin, co-founder of Akamai Technologies Inc, leading developer of Internet services, dies aboard hijacked jet that crashed into World Trade Center; he was 31 (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Not Funny, Police Say
abstract: Indonesian police will questir

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: More Job Cuts At I.B.M.
abstract: IBM is laying off another 500 employees from its personal computer sales and distribution businesses (S)

headline: Government Lifts Its Ban on Some Flight Training
abstract: Federal Aviation Administration lifts ban on all flight training, but says that many restrictions remain; flight training in major metropolitan areas, particularly around Chicago, Boston, Washington and New York, is still prohibited; some flight instructors say they believe training schools are singled out because of reports that several suspected terrorists received some training at flight schools in US; Federal officials decline to comment on specifics of ban; many schools are concerned about bankruptcy; Dean Ellis, owner of Windy City Flyers, flight school in Wheeling, Ill, comments; photo (M)

headline: Doner Gets PNC, a $30 Million Account
abstract: Doner Gets PNC, A $30 Million Accoun

headline: Investors See Some Missteps By SunTrust
abstract: Analysts and investors predict that First Union will prevail in battle with SunTrust Banks for control of Wachovia Corp; within banking circles, critique of SunTrust's missteps begins; photo (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Reinsurer's Profit Falls
abstract: Swiss Reinsurance Co reports that its first-half profit plunged 55 percent, to $800 million, due to steep drop in earnings from securities trading (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Australia/New Zealand: New Zealand: Qantas Bid Backed
abstract: Australian Min John Anderson holds Qantas Airways bid to buy into Air New Zealand and transfer carrier's Ansett unit, Qantas's major domestic rival, to Singapore Airlines offers better competitive balance long term than does Singapore Airlines's proposal to keep Air New Zealand intact but double its stake to 49 percent (S)

headline: Domestic Auto Sales Fell 6% in July
abstract: Auto sales in US fall 6 percent in July as slowing economy and continued struggles of domestic automakers dampen sales; all three major American manufacturers lose market share to foreign rivals as they temper their aggressive incentive programs; July rate equates to 16.2 million vehicles annually; demand moderates as competition stiffens (M)

headline: Pearson's Deals Finding Less Favor Among Investors
abstract: Pearson PLC posts first-half loss of 137 million pounds ($195 million), compared with year-earlier profit of 88 million pounds ($114.8 million); chief executive Marjorie Scardino and analysts comment; stock price graph; photo (M)

headline: Sears to Focus on Variety Not Price
abstract: Sears, Roebuck & Co, which spends $600 million to $1 billion annually on advertising, is overhauling its pitches to emphasize variety of name-brand merchnadise sold by its store rather than trying to compete on pricing with discounters; campaign plays up retailer's strengths and plays down its weaknesses; two principal agencies are Chicago offices of Ogilvy & Mather and Young & Rubicam, both owned by WPP Group; photo (M)

headline: Protester Is Killed in Genoa; Leaders Upbeat on Economy : Violence Rages at G-8 Talks
abstract: GENOA—  Rampaging protesters turned parts of Genoa into a war zone on Friday as the death of one man together with more than 100 injuries overshadowed the efforts by Group of Eight leaders to talk up the world economy.

headline: In Pakistan, Guarded Talk Of Movements By Troops
abstract: Pakistan denies that American troops are there, leaving open possibility that special forces may already have used Pakistan as staging ground; intelligence officials confirm that American and British special forces crossed into Afghanistan from Pakistan days after Sept 11 attack on America (M)

headline: BORDEN SELLS MOST OF ITS PASTA BUSINESS TO NEW WORLD
abstract: New World Pasta Co to acquire most of Borden Foods Corp's pasta business in United States, Canada and Italy for $43.1 million; will offer jobs to 1,000 Borden workers at six sites (S)

headline: Argentine With a Headache: The Economy
abstract: Economy Min Domingo Cavallo, who was welcomed as knight in shining armor in March, concedes that he did not then realize magnitude of fiscal problems facing Argentina; bank withdrawals are accelerating, industrial production and consumer sales are slipping and two labor confederations are planning general strike to protest latest of Cavallo's assortment of economic fixes; photo of Cavallo at daughter's wedding (M)

headline: A Kinder, Safer Workplace
abstract: Society for Human Resource Management survey suggests that in wake of terrorist carnage, employees will be more caring toward one another and that employers will put stronger security measures in place (S)

headline: Brunei: From Oil Rich to Garage Sales
abstract: Oil-rich tiny nation of Brunei is in state of financial collapse, hit hard by Asian economic crisis in 1997, drop in oil prices and by Prince Jefri Bolkiah's $15 billion spending spree; saga of profligate prince is latest cautionary tale about dangers of economic windfall; Nigeria, like Brunei, has been all but ruined by corruption spawned by discovery of oil; Brunei holds six-day auction of depleted assets of prince's construction and supply company, which went bankrupt in 1998; Prince Jefri, favorite brother of Sultan Hassanal Bolkiah, held dual positions of finance minister and head of Brunei Investment Agency, which invested huge oil wealth; his profligate spending has caused sultan's personal fortune to shrink by as much as three-fourths; last year sultan sued his brother and forced him to give back all his assets; Prince Jefri now lives abroad on monthly allowance of $300,000 as country he left behind tries to put itself back together in new form; photos; map (L)

headline: First-Half Bond Fever Cools
abstract: Thomson Financial/First Call reports that US corporations issued more investment-grade debt in first half of 2001 than in all of 2000; lower interest rates is reason (S)

headline: Wall Street's Driven Steward Presses for Business as Usual
abstract: Interview with New York Stock Exchange chairman Richard A Grasso, steward of Wall Street's attempts to get financial markets up and running following terrorist attacks against World Trade Center; he is repressing emotions to focus on task ahead; photo (M)

headline: North Korean and Vietnamese Trade Compliments
abstract: SEOUL—  North Korea's second-in-command won words of praise but no promises of rice for his hungry country as he concluded a three-day visit to Vietnam.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Lord Archer's Move Blocked
abstract: Jeffrey Archer, member of British House of Lords serving four-year sentence for perjury, is denied expected assignment to low-security prison because of new investigation of his affairs (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Economy Edges Up 0.2%, Bolstered by Consumers  The American economy grew more slowly in the second quarter than at any time in eight years, the Commerce Department reported. Still, the new numbers suggested that if consumers continue to spend at their present level, the nation may avoid a recession.    Instead of shrinking in the second quarter, as many forecasters had feared, the nation's output of goods and services rose by 0.2 percent at an annual rate. Consumers kept the economy above water, stepping up their spending in the spring and early summer -- and, possibly, setting the stage for stronger growth in the current quarter. [Page A1.]

headline: Iran's Top Leader Puts Off Inauguration of Reformist President
abstract: Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, Iran's supreme leader, postpones indefinitely inauguration of reformist Pres Mohammad Khatami; acts after reformist Parliament rejects most of new members suggested by conservative judiciary for Guardian Council, group dominated by conservatives that reviews laws passed by Parliament and vets election candidates (M)

headline: User Agreements and a 'Timeless Issue'
abstract: A judge has ruled that some Internet users who downloaded software were not bound by a software licensing agreement because they never consented to it.

headline: 10 Folders or 2? Some Tips for Organizing E-Mail
abstract: IT really doesn't take long to learn about and set up folders and filtering," said Catherine M. Beise, who teaches about computer systems at Florida Gulf Coast University in Fort Myers. "Every decent program has them." The Help features in your e-mail program usually tell you all you need to know to set them up. But keep in mind

headline: U.S. Law on Trade Fines Is Challenged Overseas
abstract: European Union and eight nonmember countries ask World Trade Organization to rule on US law allowing fines from antidumping cases to be paid to American companies that started complaints; at issue is amendment sponsored by Sen Robert Byrd and passed by Congress, changing law barring sale of foreign goods at prices below cost of production in American markets (S)

headline: Lau Journal; An Outpatient Exorcism (It Was Only a Crab)
abstract: Sukari Yasir, dukun, or faith healer, in Lau, Indonesia, performs white magic to extract cursed objects that black magicians have inserted into people'e bodies to make them sick; photos; map (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Autodesk Profit Slips 7.6%
abstract: Autodesk says fiscal second-quarter profit declined 7.6 percent, to $19.2 million; sales in period ended July 31 fell to $231.4 million from $232.8 million (S)

headline: Business; In a Consolidating Industry, Peugeot Goes Its Own Way
abstract: PSA Peugeot Citroen increases market share and profits by following fiercely independent strategy laid down by its chairman and chief executive, Jean-Martin Folz, who has forged alliances with other automakers on specific projects and rejuvenated Citroen brand; photo (M)

headline: The Yukon's Wide Open Spaces Luring Europeans
abstract: Charter flights are disgorging hundreds of European tourists every week in Whitehouse, capital of Yukon Territory in Canada's far north; map; Yukon this summer drew 250,000 tourists, almost ten to each inhabitant, and tourism has now supplanted mining as leading private sector employer (S)

headline: MediaTalk; Next Season May Not Be 'Friends' Final Farewell
abstract: NBC executives say next year may not be last season for popular program Friends; say some members of cast may leave, however; photo (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Global Trade: Steel Ruling
abstract: World Trade Organization panel upholds ruling that US government has illegally increased duties on Japanese steel imports; US and Japan must now agree on when duties will be eliminated (S)

headline: A Keyboard Puts Shortcuts Within Fingers' Reach
abstract: Microsoft offers computer keyboard with new set of buttons and keys that let users do previously mouse-intensive operations with press of single button; keyboard has also been designed to take fuller advantage of Microsoft's operating systems by providing one-touch access to mainstay programs; photo (S)

headline: Toyota puts music at the center of a big cross-media campaign built around the 2002 Camry.
abstract: Toyota Motor Sales USA's new advertising campaign for 2002 Camry involves music artists as diverse as Lyle Lovett, Earth, Wind and Fire, John Lennon and Gos-Gos; campaign was developed by Saatchi & Saatchi Los Angeles; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Ratings Lowered
abstract: Standard & Poor's downgrades credit ratings of seven Indian companies to negative after cutting India's credit to negative from stable because of nation's rising budget deficit and rising domestic debt; says credibility of India's privatization process is at risk as government has divested itself of stakes in only 2 of 240 state-run companies (S)

headline: Back-to-School Retailer Blues; Consumers Now Seem to Be in Belt-Tightening Mode
abstract: Retailers brace for lackluster back-to-school shopping season; see no immediate upturn in sight to reverse consumer caution resulting from soft economy; stores known for deep discounts are the exception, but even there consumers are showing unusual degree of caution, buying carefully and hunting for sales; some stores are changing how they manage inventory levels, cutting back their orders to avoid having too much merchandise on their hands; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Kazakhstan: Bribery Sentence
abstract: Kazakhstan's former prime minister, Akezhan Kazhegeldin, is sentence in absentia to ten years in prison for abuse of authority and taking bribes; US State Department has suggested political motivation (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Prosecutors Hold Soldiers
abstract: Russian prosecutors detain six soldiers in probe of alleged torture and looting in Chechen village (S)

headline: From Brazil, An Emerging Steel Giant; A Family Company Shops Abroad for Acquisitions
abstract: Metalurgica Gerdau SA, 100-year-old family-owned steel company based in Porto Alegre, Brazil, has transformed itself into global business, demonstrating how once-obscure company from emerging nations like Brazil are becoming increasingly important on international economic stage; Gerdau has 12,000 employees, operates in six countries and produces more than seven million tons of steel a year; Jorge Gerdau Johannpeter, president and chairman, comments; photo (M)

headline: Pink Prose
abstract: hink pink!" was the advice Kay Thompson gave in the 1957 classic movie musical, "Funny Face." That colorful suggestion is now being taken by a leading publisher as it seeks to promote sales for a sequel to a classic summer beach book.

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Insurance For Risky Region
abstract: Leaders of seven East and Central African nations meet, Ugï

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Aid From West Drops Sharply
abstract: Aid to Africa from rich Western nations fell by a third between 1994 and 1999, a United Nations report found. At the same time, investment in Africa stagnated. Africa still attracts less than 5 percent of all investment in the developing world at a time when it faces its severest health crisis with AIDS and suffers from low prices of commodities produced by many of its countries. The report was prepared for the United Nations Economic and Social Council, now meeting in Geneva.   Barbara Crossette (NYT)

headline: Factory Jobs Move Overseas As Japan's Troubles Deepen
abstract: Global technology bust sends Japan's manufacturing sector into precipitous decline that may lead its chronically sick economy into another recession; giant manufacturers of chips, home electronics and other goods announce plans for sharp cuts in employment as country faces up to its high labor and production costs and sharp slowdown in world economy; some companies are cutting jobs abroad first, but others are making painful cuts at home; during decade of economic stagnation, Japanese largely avoided company shutdowns and bankruptcy auctions that devastated manufacturing centers in America's Midwest and Northeast generation ago; but layoffs are picking up speed in Japan, and unemployment figures have hit psychological threshold of 5 percent, level not seen since post-World War II American occupation; photos; graphs (M)

headline: In Indonesia, Uncertainty Amid Hopes For Stability
abstract: Currency traders drive up Indonesian rupiah 13 percent, sending powerful signal that they expect Indonesia's new president, Megawati Sukarnoputri, to restore stability to economy; Megawait, daughter of Indonesia's founding president, Sukarno, takes control even though her predecessor, Abdurrahman Wahid, refuses to leave presidential palace; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Seychelles: President Retains Power
abstract: Seychel4

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Kazakhstan: Corporate Bond Issue
abstract: Kaztransoil, Kazakhstan's national oil transportation company, issues $150 million in Eurobonds in country's first corporate bond issue (S)

headline: NIKE TO CREATE PANEL ON LABOR AND ENVIRONMENT
abstract: Nike Inc will create committee to oversee company's labor, environmental and diversity policies; Jill Ker Conway, Nike director and visiting scholar at Massachusetts Institute of Technology's program in science, technology and society, will lead committee; Nike is trying to address complaints that its factories engaged in unfair labor practices (S)

headline: New Sense of Anxiety Lifts Insurance Sales
abstract: Insurance agents and industry executives say sales of life insurance, property and business coverage and special policies for air travel have picked up sharply since terrorist attacks; some insurance agents in New York City say their business has doubled since attacks, not only for life insurance but for coverage of businesses and possessions as well; sales of various insurance policies have increased outside New York (M)

headline: A Partnership Frays After An S.& L. Fails; In Laying Blame, Trying to Sort Out One Deal Maker's Complicated Legacy
abstract: Heirs of late Jay Pritzker are at odds with his friend and partner, Alvin Dworman, New York real estate developer, over failure of Superior Bank in Illinois; complicated workings of Pritzker came into light two weeks ago when regulators seized Superior Bank, half-owned by family, in what is expected to be one of costliest savings and loan failures in decade; Pritzers, who insist they are passive investors in Superior, have complained that Dworman did not do his share in waning days of Superior to bail out savings institution, even though he managed Superior out of his Manhattan office; Pritzkers have told friends that Dworman refused to pay back $100 million loan from bank that Jay Pritzker helped him secure when Dworman was in financial straits--accusations Dworman denies; photos (M)

headline: Compaq's Revenue and Income Fall
abstract: Compaq Computer Corp reports steep drop in second-quarter earnings, to $67 million, excluding special charges; revenue totaled $8.5 billion, down from $10.1 billion year earlier (M)

headline: Refugees From Afghanistan Flee Out of Fear and Find Despair
abstract: Cities and towns in Afghanistan are emptying as people, defying orders from ruling Taliban, try to protect families from threat of American-led military attacks and flee to safety; those with money pay smugglers to take them to Pakistan, while others are marooned at closed borders or hiding in Afghan countryside; United Nations relief officials estimate that 1.5 million Afghans will try to leave and that two to three million more could face starvation; worst-case scenario is that people cannot leave and aid workers cannot get in with food and other assistance; photo (M)

headline: Perhaps the Revenge Of Candlestick Park?
abstract: San Francisco Giants' Pacific Bell Park is not included on list of 405 businesses exempted by California Public Utilities Commission from rolling blackouts (S)

headline: PATHMARK IN TALKS TO BUY BIG V SUPERMARKETS
abstract: Pathmark Stores is in talks to buy Big V Supermarkets Inc, currently in Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, for more than $200 million (S)

headline: Omsk Journal; In Which We Learn How to Hide a Head of State
abstract: Kim Jong Il, leader of North Korea, makes rare public appearance in Omsk, Russia, during his Trans-Siberian railroad trip en route to Moscow for meetings with Pres Vladimir Putin; Kim's two-week trek across Russia, on mission of potentially global import, is being made in almost complete secrecy; map; photo (M)

headline: New Middle East Peace Bid Brokered by German Envoy
abstract: Relations between Israel and Palestinians have so thoroughly deteriorated that glimmer of diplomatic action, planned meeting organized by German Min Joschka Fischer, is seized on as possible path to truce; small bomb explodes in Russian Compound section of Jerusalem, punctuating difficulties; photos; no time or place is set for Min Shimon Peres to meet with Yasir Arafat (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Lord Archer Moved
abstract: Lord Jeffrey Archer, disgraced former politician, leaves high-security prison in London to continue four-year jail term at Wayland prison, lower-risk institution near Thetford; photo (S)

headline: New-Home Sales Rose in July, Cushioning Industrial Slump
abstract: Sales of new homes rise by 4.9 percent in July, to 950,000 houses at annual pace, helping ease damage to national economy from slumping orders for factory goods, which decrease 0.6 percent; average rate on 30-year mortgage drops to 6.91 percent, underpinning housing demand (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | The Americas: Canada: Steel Duties Lifted
abstract: Canada lifts four-month-old duties on imports of steel sheet from six countries, quashing claim by Dofasco Inc of Hamilton, Ont, that cheap overseas products are hurting producers; says imports do not cause material injury or retardation to Canadian steel makers and do not threaten to do so; importers are China, India, Malaysia, Russia, South Africa and Taiwan (S)

headline: World Briefing | Middle East: Iran: Journalist Sent To Prison
abstract: Iranian court sentences journalist Akbar Ganji to six years in prison, overruling verdict of appeals court that had reduced original 10-year prison term to six months; court finds Ganji, who has already served year in prison, guilty of 'propagating against the regime' for taking part in conference in Berlin in 2000 on possible reforms in Iran (S)

headline: Indonesia Gets A New Leader; Ex-Chief Balks
abstract: In the most peaceful transfer of power in Indonesia's history, Megawati Sukarnoputri was sworn in as president today, moments after the nation's top legislative body voted to cut short the fractious and rudderless tenure of her predecessor.    But in a historical novelty, Indonesia, the world's fourth-most-populous nation, was left with two claimants to the presidency as Abdurrahman Wahid refused to recognize the action to remove him and remained isolated in his official residence.

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Ad Bureau Issues Guidelines
abstract: Interactive Advertising Bureau issues size guidelines for online ads that contain audio, animation and video (S)

headline: Pizza Hut Unites Its Media Buying
abstract: Advertising: Pizza Hut Unites

headline: Turkey's Ruling Coalition Uneasily Awaits Arrival of New Party
abstract: Turkey's coalition government faces new challenge from populist-oriented party being formed from remains of outlawed Islamic-oriented party; new party boasts popular former mayor of Istanbul as its leader, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, and promises to broaden its appeal beyond religious voters; Erdogan spent four months in jail and was barred from politics for five years; ban on his political participation was lifted in last year's general amnesty (M)

headline: S.E.C. Waives Some Rules to Try to Ease Market Volatility
