abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission, hoping to avoid wave of panicked selling when stock exchanges open next week, issues order waiving certain regulations to permit companies and executives to help prop up prices of their shares; officials say temporary order, which will be in effect for next week if, as regulators hope, markets reopen on Sept 17, will enable publicly traded companies to buy shares of their companies in market without normal restrictions on volume and timing of those trades; order will also permit company directors and senior executives who had issued sell orders shortly before markets closed to re-enter market and try to repurchase their company's stock; agency also eases some accounting and capital rules and relaxes some lending restrictions on mutual funds (M)

headline: Wahid Removed as Sukarnoputri Becomes Indonesia's President
abstract: Megawati Sukarnoputri was sworn in as Indonesia's president today moments after parliament voted to cut short the tenure of her predecessor, Abdurrahman Wahid

headline: Direct Deutsch Unit Names New Official
abstract: Direct Deutsch Unit Names New Official Deutsch Inc. in New York, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies, has named Ian Baer to the new post of executive vice president and director for the Playa del Rey, Calif., operations of Direct Deutsch, the agency's direct marketing division. Mr. Baer, 34, had been president at the Chicago office of Rapp Collins Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group; Rapp Collins announced in May that the Chicago office would be reduced to a support operation from a full-service of

headline: Ex-State Dept. Aide Guilty In Conflict-of-Interest Case
abstract: Retired State Department official C Kenneth Quinones pleads guilty to improperly using his influence to help secure government contract for wealthy New Jersey businessman David Chang, who had lavished tens of thousands of dollars in gifts on him and his family; Chang pleaded guilty in June 2000 to giving $53,700 in illegal campaign contributions to Sen Robert G Torricelli and has since been cooperating with federal prosecutors in inquiry into Torricelli's political and personal activities (M)

headline: The Picture Tube And the Bigger View
abstract: My First Job column by Jeff Dreben, chairman and chief executive of CVF Technologies Corp, recalls how he repaired television sets in late 1950's and early 60's when he was in high school; photos (M)

headline: Year of Intifada Sees Hardening on Each Side
abstract: Israelis and Palestinians disagree about date that latest intifada began, but people on opposite sides describe similar effects: fear and desperation have unified Israelis, unified Palestinians, and hardened each population against other; unlike first intifida, when Israeli group Peace Now held rally drawing 100,000 people, this intifada has had opposite effect, and peace camp is having tremendous difficulty rallying people to its side; inside Israel, there is change in other Israelis' attitudes toward settlers; they are no longer seen as cowboys, but as Jews under attack; photo; graph showing tallies of deaths per week (M)

headline: Technology Briefing
abstract: TELECOMMUNICATIONSCOMPETITION HURTS WORLDCOM PROFIT World- Com Inc. said increased competition hurt second- quarter profits for its data and Internet business group. The earnings report was the first since WorldCom split itself into the WorldCom Group, comprising the company's data, international and commercial voice businesses, and the MCI Group, which holds its consumer, small-business, wholesale, long-distance, wireless and Internet access businesses. WorldCom's net income for the quarter ended June 30 was $110 million, or 4 cents a share, compared with a pro forma $716 million, or 25 cents, a year earlier. MCI had a net loss of $29 million, or 25 cents a share, in contrast to a profit of $541 million, or $4.75, a year earlier

headline: Senate Approves Bill to Lift Barriers to Trade With Jordan
abstract: US Senate approves legislation that would remove all trade barriers between US and Jordan after Bush administration persuades Sen Phil Gramm to drop his objections; measure commits two nations to upholding workers' rights and environmental standards, first time full-scale trade agreement has passed Congress with labor and environmental provisions at its core; its adoption illustrates how political and ideological considerations in federal government are giving way in push to prepare for campaign against terrorism (M)

headline: For Better Mousing, A Better Mousetrap
abstract: MouseTrapper, available from Axcess Technologies, saves computer operator from movements that could injure shoulders; photo (S)

headline: World Briefing | The Americas: Canada: Deportation Sought
abstract: Canadian authorities ask federal judge to order deportation of Egyptian teacher, Mahmoud Jaballah of Toronto, who has ben linked to terrorist group responsible for 1998 bombings of two American embassies in Africa (S)

headline: Operating Profit Is Off at British Air
abstract: British Airways reports operating profit fell 48 percent in quarter ended June 30, to 50 million pounds ($71.4 million) from 97 million pounds year earlier; chief executive Rod Eddington says company's financial situation will be tough until next summer; photo (M)

headline: Economic Troubles Worsen in Argentina
abstract: Argentina's financial troubles deepen as government has to offer 14.01 percent interest to attract investors to its three-month Treasury bills; rate, on $827.7 million of securities, is highest since government began issuing such bills in 1996 and well above 9.10 percent paid on similar securities two weeks ago; government also sells $22 million in one-year securities with yield of 15.96 percent; Argentina has been in recession for three years (M)

headline: Brazil Leftists Oppose Deal to Let U.S. Launch Satellites
abstract: Agreement that would allow American companies to launch satellites from equatorial spaceport in Brazil is in jeopardy because left-wing nationalist groups in Brazil contend that it is really Trojan horse, intended to give US control of site; leftists say US government will be able to launch military spy satellites from site at Alcantara against countries with which Brazil maintains good diplomatic relations (M)

headline: Crossing Into Cinema and Real Life
abstract: Charles Herold reviews computer video games Max Payne, developed by Remedy, and Majestic, developed by Electronic Arts; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Turkey: European Court Finds Rights Abuses
abstract: European Human Rights Court rules Turkey denied fair and timely trial to 16 suspected members of militant far-left group who were held for years awaiting verdict; awards plaintiffs, all Turkish nationals, $165,000 in damages (S)

headline: Sharp Drop in Sales Expected for Chip Equipment Makers
abstract: Semiconductor equipment makers will see their sales decline by more than a third this year, and they will not surpass last year's sales levels until 2004

headline: Pitch to Condit Raises Ethical Questions
abstract: Letter sent by San Francisco Chronicle executive editor Phil Bronstein seeking interview with Rep Gary A Condit raises ethical questions because it noted that paper had not called for his resignation and did not plan to do so; editorial writers and news executives elsewhere hold it left strong implication that Chronicle editorial page would continue to help Condit if he helped paper's news department; Bronstein, noting editorial page editor John Diaz does not report to him, holds Condit aides knew he could not barter editorial policy for interview; Diaz denies Bronstein sought to influence editorial policy (M)

headline: Microsoft Leads Stock Rally; Nasdaq Surges 5.3 Percent
abstract: Stock prices surged today after Microsoft said its second-quarter revenue would exceed Wall Street's forecasts

headline: At Home Corp. Dealt Blow As Auditors Doubt Future
abstract: Ernst & Young, independent auditors of ExciteatHome, expresses 'substantial doubt' about financial viability of company, once mighty Internet portal turned broadband provider; Excite says it currently does not meet conditions to continue listing on Nasdaq and could face delisting; stock falls 40 cents a share, to 49 cents (M)

headline: Japanese Parties Hope Celebrities Will Be a Ticket to Success
abstract: Many sports and entertainment celebrities are seeking election to Japan's Parliament; entry of large numbers of famous novices into politics was foretold last year when Liberal Democrats pushed changes in electoral system to allow voters to choose either individual candidates on ballot, or party itself, by in effect voting the ticket; move was bitterly denounced by opposition, but now it is opposition that is most eagerly turning to famous candidates, desperate to avert landslide defeat; photo (M)

headline: On Television; High-toned or reality-ridden? NBC's hybrid persona is hardly new.
abstract: On Television column examines shift taking place at NBC, with its decision to add down-and-dirty fare like Fear Factor and Spy TV, reality shows; photo (M)

headline: FedEx Freight Rates to Rise
abstract: FedEx Corp's freight companies are planning to increase rates 5.9 percent in August (S)

headline: Help for Marketers in Selling to Women
abstract: An agency is starting a brand consulting division that will specialize in helping national marketers reach female consumers more effectively.

headline: Tehran Journal; Dog Lovers of Iran, Beware Growling Ayatollahs
abstract: Iran has no specific law against owning dogs, but they remain religiously suspect and periodically they are confiscated by authorities; last canine condemnation came two years ago, when Ayatollah Muhammad Yazdi said dogs should not walk on streets because they are unclean; Artin Zaman, one of founders of Iranian Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, suggests that going after dogs is way for authorities to divert attention from country's bigger problems; despite official hostility, dog ownership is on rise as children view foreign scenes of children and their pets on satellite television; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Mobile Phone Sales Drop
abstract: Dataquest reports that sales of mobile phones fell 7 percent in second quarter as network operators reduced subsidies and customers held off buying new phones until new versions appear (S)

headline: La Rumorosa Journal; To Risk Death in the Desert: An Inalienable Right?
abstract: More than 650 Mexican immigrants have died in recent years trying to cross barren territory that stretches from La Rumorosa, Mex, into southern California; Mexican immigration agents say successful crossing requires training and special gear; Mexican officials want to try to close known death trap, and plans are under way to station agents along highway at edge of desert to prohibit trucks and buses from dropping off immigrants in isolated areas; critics of plan, including human rights advocates and political opponents of Pres Vicente Fox, charge plan violates Mexican Constitution, which prohibits government from impeding free movement of its citizens; photo; map (M)

headline: Recreating a Japanese Art With a Few Deft Clicks
abstract: Jintae Lee constructs computer model of traditional Japanese black ink painting called sumie (S)

headline: On Trial: Fighting Drugs vs. Fighting Dictators
abstract: Richard Horn, Drug Enforcement Administration's attache in Myanmar in early 1990's, is frustrated by government tactics in his seven-year-old lawsuit against CIA station chief for Myanmar and State Department's chief of mission at embassy; Horn, who retired in December 2000, says says his civil rights were violated when his home was illegally wiretapped in 1993, probably by CIA; government is defending both officials and has invoked provision of national security law to prevent disclosure of classified information; says there is no merit to allegations; Horn was forced to leave Myanmar after State Department officials complained he was flouting diplomatic policy guidelines in eagerness to do job to stem flow of heroin (M)

headline: Invercreran Journal; Fish Farms Spawn Trouble for Salmon Anglers
abstract: Focus on bitter contest in Invercreran, Scotland, that pits environmentalists and anglers against fish-farmers; anglers say fish farms, where salmon is grown by tens of thousands in netted pens, is robbing them of livelihood; say farms are source of parasites that kill off youthful wild salmon as they head out to sea, blocking natural ability of local rivers to restock themselves; duel is sharpened by competing scientific evidence, buttressed by economic disputes over income and jobs and prolonged by fish farming industry's long refusal to acknowledge any role in decline of wild salmon; Invercreran has been home to salmon fishermen for centuries; maps; photo (M)

headline: Personal Business; Business Cards Escape the Plain White Rectangle
abstract: Various businesses become creative and innovative in design and use of business cards; comments from Lynella Grant, author of The Business Card Book: What Your Business Card Reveals About You -- and How to Fix It; photos (M)

headline: Samsung and Toshiba Consider Link on Chips
abstract: Samsung Electronics is weighing proposal to take over semiconductor manufacturing from Toshiba Corp; Samsung says Toshiba has also approached Infineon Technologies, unit of Siemens AG, about deal, and might consider three-way arrangement (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Sri Lanka: Truce Considered
abstract: Min Lakshman Kadirgamar says Sri Lanka weighs asking Tamil separatist rebels to discuss cease-fire; diplomats say government lacks broad political support it needs to effectively bargain with rebels (S)

headline: Letters: The Battle Lines of the Mommy Wars
abstract: Readers thoughts on "Is My Mom Better Than Yours?", Ellyn Spragins' column discussing the dispute between stay-at-home moms and working moms

headline: World Briefing | The Americas: Argentina: Ex-Dictator Facing Trial
abstract: Argentina court rules that former dictator Jorge Videla must stand trial for abductions of 70 foreign nationals between 1976 and 1981; photo (S)

headline: G.E. Finance Unit Will Acquire Heller Financial for $5.3 Billion
abstract: General Electric's GE Capital unit to buy Heller Financial for $5.3 billion in cash; Heller's stock price soars; Fuji Bank Ltd, which owns 45 percent of Heller's equity and controls 77 percent of its voting stock, agrees to tender all its shares (M)

headline: CBS Expels Reality Show Contestant Over Threats
abstract: Justin Sebik, contestant on CBS TV program Big Brother, is dismissed from program for holding kitchen knife against throat of female contestant, Krista Stegall; network says Sebik was previously warned about threatening behavior; incident is likely to provide further grist for critics who say reality shows are taking too many risks and stretching boundaries of taste on broadcast television (M)

headline: New Visors Have Buyers Hunting High and Low
abstract: Handspring offers two new Visor hand-held computers, one aimed at high-end business user and other at entry-level consumer; photos (M)

headline: This Stock Pays 21% in Dividends, but Few Are Interested
abstract: MCI's new tracking stock, issued by parent company WorldCom, is of little interest to investors despite dividend payment of 21 percent; lack of interest attributed to companies' poor performance since spinoff of MCI, and doubts that dividend can be maintained in increasingly competitive industry in which revenues are falling; WorldCom chief executive, Bernard J Ebbers, says investors should be confident of company's ability to service debt and pay dividend for foreseeable future; graph (M)

headline: Auto Sales Increased in June, Despite Decreases at Ford and G.M.
abstract: United States auto sales rose 0.3 percent in June from June 2000, to seasonally adjusted annual rate of 17 million vehicles; foreign automakers reap most of gains, with Ford Motor and General Motors reporting sales dips; graph; tables (M)9

headline: Victims of '93 Bombay Terror Wary of U.S. Motives
abstract: Residents of Bombay, India, recall sudden horror of terrorist attack in 1993, when bombs exploded in Bombay Stock Exchange and many other sites across city, killing more than 260 people and wounding more than 700; yet there is wariness about America's motives in announcing that every country must either stand with or against US as it goes after terrorists and states that harbor them; to get at prime suspect, Osama bin Laden, US is working with Pakistan, which many Indians regard as principal incubator of terrorism directed against them; some Indians think American goal is limited to fighting terrorists who struck US, not ones who hit India; photos (M)

headline: Metro Business Briefing
abstract: BONDS UP IN THE CATSKILLS A financial recovery in Sullivan County has led a Wall Street bond-rating agency to upgrade the county's debt rating to A, from A-minus. The agency, Standard & Poor's, raised the rating yesterday in advance of the sale of $8.7 million in bonds next week by the county, which is northwest of New York City in the foothills of the Catskill Mountains. The county's tourism-based economy is rebounding and becoming more diverse, S.& P. analysts said, and improved budgeting practices have turned a budget deficit into a surplus.    Leslie Eaton (NYT) VIOLENCE IN WORKPLACE DEATHS Violent acts caused a high proportion of on-the-job deaths in New York City last year, but the overall number of workplace fatalities fell sharply, according to new data from the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics. The number of fatal occupational injuries fell 7.5 percent last year, to 111 from 120; nationally, such deaths fell by about 2 percent, the bureau said. But 52 percent of these fatalities in New York City were caused by violence, a percentage second only to the District of Columbia's 62 percent. Nationally, highway accidents are the leading cause of on-the-job deaths.    Leslie Eaton (NYT) FIGHTING GRID CONSOLIDATION Attorney General Richard Blumenthal says he is prepared to go to court to block a federal agency's plans to change the Northeast power grid. Mr. Blumenthal said the issue was the order by the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission last month that forced separate power grid operators in New England, New York and the Mid-Atlantic states to consolidate into a single organization

headline: The Graduate Meets the Slowdown
abstract: Article by Anna Blumenthal of Manhattan, recent college graduate, describes her discouraging job search during period of ecomonic slowdown; drawing (M)

headline: Can Hacking Victims Be Held Legally Liable?
abstract: Stanford law Prof. Margaret Jane Radin is asking whether companies can be found legally liable when their sites are hacked.

headline: Business Travel; Delta's chief generates a debate over airport runways.
abstract: Readers respond to Aug 8 Business Travel column in which Delta Air Lines chief executive, Leo F Mullin, argued that US has transportation crisis because domestic airports' lack enough runway capacity to handle annual pasenger load (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Share Price Grazes Cut-Off Level
abstract: Sagging stock prices could cause one of conditions that would allow Portugal Telecom SGPS to back out of its $1.6 billion bid for remaining shares of Telesp Celular Participacoes, Sao Paulo wireless telecommunications provider (S)

headline: Mesa Gets Loan Accord
abstract: Mesa Air Group, which runs commuter flights for larger airlines, reaches agreement with Raytheon that ends default on aircraft loans; Raytheon also agrees to help reduce operating costs on aircraft, Beech 1900D (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Industrial Slowdown
abstract: Brazil's industrial production fell 1.4 percent in June from year earlier and 1.1 percent from May; production for first six months grew 4.9 percent, compared with first six months of 2000 (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: More Layoffs Coming At Lucent
abstract: Lucent Technologies chief executive Henry B Schacht tells employees to expect further layoffs; company says 8,500 managers have accepted buyout offers (S)

headline: R.V. Coalition Reviews Its Account
abstract: GO RVing Coalition is beginning review of its advertising account, which has been handled for six years by Eisner Communications; spending for three years is estimated at $38 million to $40 million (S)

headline: Nortel Posts A Huge Loss For the Quarter
abstract: Nortel Networks reports record loss of $19.4 billion for second quarter; net loss from continuing operations was $1.6 billion compared with profit of $637 million year earlier; revenue from continuing operations was $4.6 billion, down from $7.2 billion (M)

headline: Ruth Sanger, 82, Expert on Blood Grouping
abstract: Dr Ruth Ann Sanger, blood research and co-author of blood-group manual that helped make transfusions safer, dies at age 82 (S)

headline: Veritas Shares Fall 32%
abstract: Shares of Veritas DGC Inc, oilfield-service company, fall 32 percent after company reports that fiscal fourth-quarter profit will be about 83 percent less than analysts' estimates (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Turkey: Inquiry Fells Cabinet Member
abstract: Koray Aydin resigns as Turkey's Housing minister in face of corruption investigation (S)

headline: Macedonians Await NATO, Some Wary of Mission
abstract: Ethnic Albanians welcome NATO's formal decision to send 3,500 troops to Macedonia; among Slav majority, there is deep skepticism; they say they do not believe rebels will give up all their arms as agreed, and they also fear that NATO will become permanent presence that will transform Macedonia into Western 'protectorate'; photos (M)

headline: MediaTalk; St. Louis Paper Ends Readers' Advocate
abstract: St Louis Post-Dispatch eliminates post of readers' advocate, holding all editors should be accessible to readers; publishes detailed listing of editors; Carolyn Kingcade, who held post, defends role, farewell column (M)

headline: Spanish Utility to Buy an Italian Generator
abstract: Endesa, Spain's largest power company, agreed today to buy Elettrogen of Italy for 3.69 billion euros ($3.2 billion) to become the third-largest generator in Italy. It beat 11 rivals in an eight-month auction.     Endesa will pay Enel, Italy's dominant utility, 2.63 billion euros ($2.29 billion) in cash and assume 1.06 billion euros ($921,000) in debt, Enel said in a statement. Elettrogen, which produces 7 percent of Italy's power, is the first of three units Enel must sell by the end of next year as Italy opens its energy industry.

headline: West Bank Settler Dies, Another Blow to Faltering Cease-Fire
abstract: Jewish settler's body is found in West Bank shot and stabbed, aparently by Palestinians, dealing another blow to faltering cease-fire that has all but collapsed in surge of violence (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Political Party Limits
abstract: Russian Pres Vladimir Putin signs law requiring political parties to have national member, and also providing government financing of campaigns (S)

headline: Refiner Courts California Over Pending Merger
abstract: Valero Energy Corp, relative newcomer to California, is courting state over pending takeover of rival Ultramar Diamond Shamrock; its chairman and chief executive, William E Greehey, is trying to presuade Atty Gen Bill Lockyer to approve deal; Federal Trade Commission is conducting extensive analysis of Valero and Ultramar's operations; sticking point may be combined ownership of three California refineries, two in Bay Area and one in Los Angeles County; photo (M)

headline: Next to Old Rec Hall, a 'Germ-Making Plant'
abstract: Article describes Camp 12, former military recreation hall and barbershop, converted into germ warfare test facility at Nellis Air Force Range in Nevada; facility is creation of Defense Threat Reduction Agency, arm of Pentagon that works to contain spread of nuclear, biological and chemical weapons; officials say project is intended to assess how hard it would be for terrorist or rogue nation to assemble germ factory; map; photos (M)

headline: Equity Offerings For This Week
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:    Alliance Imaging Inc., Anaheim, Calif., an initial offering of 9.4 million shares. Deutsche Bank Alex. Brown and Salomon Smith Barney.

headline: Article 2001070293723573220 -- No Title
abstract: Education: From Working in Mines, to Learning Online

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: L'Oreal's Profit Is Up
abstract: L'Oreal reports first-half net profit soared to 587 million euros, or $528 million, from 465 million euros a year ago, on 14 percent revenue increase, to 6.9 billion euros; operating income rose 12 percent, to 814 million euros (S)

headline: Bush Asks Arafat to Condemn Bombing in Jerusalem
abstract: Pres Bush calls on Yasir Arafat to condemn suicide bombing in Jerusalem and to arrest those responsible for attack; Arafat does condemn violence, hours after getting telephone call from Secretary of State Colin Powell; Powell also calls Israeli Prime Min Ariel Sharon, urging him to practice restraint despite domestic pressure to act otherwise; Powell describes situation as 'very dangerous' but makes clear that Bush administration is not considering any new initiative to try and temper violence; other administration officials say solution to violence does not lie in stepped-up involvemnt by US but rather in acts and deeds by two parties; photo (M)

headline: AMERICAN HOME PRODUCTS RECALLS HORMONE TABLETS
abstract: American Home Products recalls two batches of its best-selling hormone-replacement drug, Premarin, after tests show that some of tablets do not meet certain quality requirements; drugs failed to meet government quality-control standard during what is known as 'dissolution test' (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Telecom Sale Plan
abstract: South Korean government will try again to sell off much of its controlling stake in Korea Telecom (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: Bombs Defused
abstract: British security forces defuse two bombs, Ballycastle, Northern Ireland, day after large car bomb was found and defused in town; Protestant paramilitary group claims responsibility for car bomb (S)

headline: AT&T Rejects Comcast's $40 Billion Offer for Broadband Unit
abstract: AT&T Corp. said on Wednesday its board rejected Comcast Corp.'s unsolicited bid to purchase its AT&T Broadband unit

headline: Added Rights For Indians Are Ratified In Mexico
abstract: Mexico ratifies landmark constitutional changes aimed at granting 10 million Indians new rights and protections against discrimination; indigenous leaders overwhelmingly reject amendments as an affront and threat to government efforts to resolve Indian uprising in Chiapas (M)

headline: Investing; Forecasters Try to Assess the Terror Factor
abstract: Economists, stock market strategists and money managers struggle to revise their forecasts in wake of Sept 11 attacks; their current forecasts are even fuzzier than usual, ranging from quick return of robust economy and stock market growth to fundamental scaling back of long-term expectations; forecasters also seek to identify sectors that are likely to prosper despite turmoil; photos (M)

headline: It's Time to Look Beyond Conventional Wisdom on the Dollar
abstract: Jonathan Fuerbringer column cautions against shifting investments overseas simply because dollar is weakening, saying dollar has often been indicator of economic health abroad as well as at home; chart (M)

headline: African Migrants Risk All on Passage to Spain
abstract: Growing tide of migrants from African countries is desperatly trying to enter Europe by way of Spain across treacherous Strait of Gibraltar, route once used almost exclusively by Moroccans; 15,000 illegal immigrants were detained along Spanish coast in 2000, more than four times as year before, and 20 percent were from sub-Saharan Africa; Spanish government is taking strong measures to seal southern coast, including installation of $120 million radar system to form electronic wall across strait; illegal immigration and its dangers have become troubling issues for Europe after year of calamitously failed attempts at immigrant smuggling; maps; photos (M)

headline: Personal Business; Ways to Cope When Vulnerabilities Are Laid Bare
abstract: There are ways for people to cope with loss of relatives or friends in terrorist attacks of Sept 11; people need to find things in their lives that are hopeful in order to heal; photos (M)

headline: Technology Briefing
abstract: HARDWARE SANMINA ISSUES EARNINGS WARNING The San- mina Corporation, which builds electronic equipment for other companies, said yesterday that sales and earnings this quarter would be less than forecast as customers reduce spending. Sales will be $600 million to $620 million for the fourth quarter, ending Sept. 29, the company said. Excluding acquisition-related expenses and charges, Sanmina expects to have a profit of 1 to 2 cents a share. The company was expected to earn 9 cents on sales of $734 million, according to the average estimates of analysts polled by Thomson Financial/First Call. Sanmina, which makes mobile telephones, personal computers and telecommunications gear, is experiencing falling demand for its products as sales slow for its customers. The company has been buying the manufacturing operations of other companies to add more services and increase efficiency to combat dropping sales.   (Bloomberg News) DECREASE IN CHIP SALES Worldwide sales of semiconductors fell more than 37 percent in July, to $10.86 billion, said a prominent industry trade group yesterday. The quarterly global sales report, from the Semiconductor Industry Association, attributed the slackening to the economic slowdown and excess inventories, but also indicated that highly expected new products could lead to a turnaround by the end of the year

headline: South Korea Asks F.A.A. To Help Upgrade Standards
abstract: South Korea's transport ministry, shocked by Federal Aviation Administration's decision to downgrade nation's air safety rating, plans to ask FAA to set up office in South Korea to show what must be done to meet agency's standards; Min Oh Jang Seop apologizes publicly for ministry's shortcomings and pledges efforts to raise rating; politicians from government and opposition parties pledge to work together on air safety oversight bill, as required by FAA (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Microsoft Upgrades Pocket Software
abstract: Microsoft Corp plans to release new version of its software to run hand-held organizers, updating product that has taken sales from Palm Inc; Microsoft Pocket PC 2002 operating system will go on sale Oct 4 in hand-held computers from Hewlett-Packard; Hewlett-Packard and Intel Corp announce that Intel processor, StrongARM, and memory chip, StrataFlash, will be used to power Hewlett-Packard's new line of Jornada hand-held computers (S)

headline: Investing: Vicarious Investing; For the Rich, a Hedge Fund With an Eye on Taxes
abstract: Bear Stearns Companies offer investors with $5 million or more in assets a hedge fund with special tax-efficient feature: warrant that lets them put up portion of their stake in fund, borrowing rest from Bear Stearns; idea is that if investors hold warrants for seven and a quarter years and then exercise them, they will be able to declare long-term capital gain, rather than pay annual taxes on funds' short-term gains (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Bank Cutbacks
abstract: Sumitomo Mitsui, Japanese banking group, to cut 600 more jobs and close 80 more branches to cut costs (S)

headline: Compressed Data; Group Encourages Workers to Turn In Software Pirates
abstract: For those who have been overlooked, slighted or perhaps even fired by an uncaring employer, an opportunity for revenge may be at hand.    Beginning today, a group of software companies, the Business Software Alliance, is appealing to disgruntled employees in New York and four other cities to act as informers if their companies are using unlicensed copies of computer software. A study commissioned by the alliance, which began conducting such campaigns in other cities in August, estimates that American software companies lost more than $2.6 billion to piracy last year.

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: US dollar falls against euro and Japanese yen; in New York, euro settles at 92.68 cents, up from 92.44 cents; dollar trades at 117.23 yen, down from 117.73 yen; graph; chart (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Enron Reshuffles Leaders In Wake of Chief's Exit  Enron promoted a top official in its core energy-trading business to be the company's No. 2 executive, two weeks after the unexpected departure of its chief executive.    Greg Whalley, 39, the president and chief operating officer of Enron Wholesale Services, was named president and chief operating officer. He will join Mark Frevert, 46, who was promoted to vice chairman, and Kenneth L. Lay, the chairman and chief executive, in an ''office of the chairman.'' [Page C2.]

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Human Cloning
abstract: Order of Italian Doctors says it had started disciplinary procedures against Dr Severino Antinori, who is expected to announce during meeting at National Academy of Sciences that he intends to produce cloned humans for infertile couples later this year (S)

headline: Robert Half, 82, Founder of a Job Agency
abstract: Robert Half, founder of emplyment agency, dies at age 82 (S)

headline: To Cash In on a Lifestyle, Apple Hits the Mall
abstract: Apple Computer will open retail outlets in 25 high-traffic shopping areas across nation by end of 2001, in foray into direct sales to customers; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing
abstract: TELECOMMUNICATION

headline: The New Tobacco Bonds
abstract: TSASC Inc investor relations director Raymond J Orlando letter on investing in cigarette settlement bonds holds most entities selling them assume significant and continuing decline in cigarette consumption

headline: World Briefing | Europe: France: More Trouble For Ex-Official
abstract: Former French Foreign Min Roland Dumas, who was sentenced to jail earlier in year for part in corruption scandal, is now under investigation over contested sale of some Alberto Giacometti sculptures; he was executor of Giacometti's wife's estate and may have gotten illegal 'commission'; photo (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Cuts At Bank
abstract: Germany's Dresdner Bank will extend its reorganizing program by cutting additional 1,300 jobs in effort to reduce costs by 15 percent through end of 2003, or 1.3 billion euros ($1.2 billion) annually (S)

headline: With Eye on Unequal World Wealth, Young Europeans Converge on Genoa
abstract: Tens of thousands of people who have come to Genoa to protest meeting of world leaders speak of narrowing gap between rich and poor, which they see as steadily widening; to them, levers of power around world are controlled by political leaders who meet in cloistered summits, by free trade organizations that care little about poor or developing countries and by corporations whose principle goal is to fatten bottom line; despite fact that one radical protester was shot and killed by Italian policeman, vast majority of those who are marching in Genoa are determinedly pacifist and nonviolent; photos (M)

headline: O'REILLY TO BUY MID-STATE AUTOMOTIVE FOR $46.2 MILLION
abstract: O'Reilly Automotive Inc, auto-parts retailer, will acquire Mid-State Automotive Distributors Inc, US parts retailing unit of London-based Mid-States PLC, for $19.5 million (S)

headline: Morton's Forecasts a Loss
abstract: Morton's Restaurant Group expects to report third-quarter loss and close its Wall Street-area restaurant indefinitely in aftermath of terrorist attacks on World Trade Center (S)

headline: Beate Uhse, 81, Entrepreneur In the Business of Erotic Goods
abstract: Beate Uhse, who peddled birth control pamphlets as destitute war widow and founded major German company dealing in erotic goods, dies at age 81; photo (S)

headline: Farm Unrest in Mexico Challenges New President
abstract: Mexico's small farmers are being battered by explosion of free trade under Nafta, plummeting market prices and cuts in government support; they complain that free trade accord has not given them access to American markets they were promised, and has forced hundreds of them out of business; tens of thousands of farmers hold protests around country, including 5,000 sugar cane farmers who converge on capital and block access to government offices; for Mexico's new president, Vicente Fox, reforming agricultural industry and finding alternative employment for millions of subsistence farmers at time of widespread resentment may prove his most important domestic challenge; photos; map (L)

headline: Management: New Guards To Lessen Liability; Software Trains Workers to Avoid Improper Behavior
abstract: Jessica Hartman is a silent victim of sexual harassment in the workplace.    She says a technician who is supposed to be helping her with her computer has made flirtatious comments, sent her personal gifts, asked her to lunch repeatedly and even kissed her on the lips at a company party, in front of her colleagues.

headline: Venice Journal; The Gondola Builder, Oddly, Is From the U.S.
abstract: Thom Price of North Carolina seeks to save dying craft of gondola building in Venice; his dream is to eventually open school in Venice for gondola builders; photo; map (M)

headline: Internet Services Must Help Fight Online Movie Pirates, Studios Say
abstract: Anyone who wanted to see 20th Century Fox's ''Planet of the Apes'' over the weekend had a choice: pay to see it in a theater or get it free over the Internet, where pirated copies surfaced within hours of its release on Friday.    The instant Internet availability of illicit copies of new Hollywood films has become commonplace over the last year. And Internet providers, which are legally obligated to remove pirated material from Web sites they host once a copyright holder asks them to do so, are accustomed to quickly complying with such requests.

headline: Melee at Jerusalem's Most Sacred, and Explosive, Site
abstract: Jerusalem and its sacred places returned to the center of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict today when Palestinians on an elevated Muslim compound hurled stones at Jews praying below, provoking a battle with the Israeli police.    Hundreds of Israeli officers in riot gear rushed into the Aksa compound after a barrage of rocks, some quite large, sent Jewish worshipers fleeing from the Western Wall. The attack came on a day when Jews traditionally gather there to mourn the destruction of two ancient temples.

headline: Deutsche Bank To Buy Scudder In Deal Worth $2.5 Billion
abstract: Deutsche Bank agrees to buy Scudder Investments, United States asset management unit of Zurich Financial Services, for about $2.5 billion in cash and assets; Deutsche Bank will pay $1.2 billion in cash for Scudder, which manages $370 billion; deal will create fourth-largest manager of assets globally, with about $900 billion under management; deal is expected to be announced before markets open in Germany on Sept 24 (M)

headline: U.S. Explores Other Options On Preventing Germ Warfare
abstract: Senior Bush administration official says that although White House rejects draft agreement under discussion at talks in Geneva, it remains committed to strengthening 1972 treaty banning biological weapons, and is exploring alternative approaches (S)

headline: AMERICAN HOME PRODUCTS TO CUT GENERIC DRUG BUSINESS
abstract: American Home Products Corp will exit most of its generic drugs business and cut 240 jobs (S)

headline: Butler, Shine Acquires PeñaBrand
abstract: Butler, Shine & Stern acquires PenaBrand, design ad agency (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Insurer Doubles Profit
abstract: Munich Re says net profit doubled in first half of year, to 1.3 billion euros ($1.18 billion); income rose 12 percent, to 17 billion euros ($15.5 billion); graph (S)

headline: Napster Is Told To Remain Shut
abstract: Judge Marilyn Patel orders that Napster music-sharing service remain shut down until it can prove that it can more effectively filter copyrighted material (S)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Mozambique: A Booming Economy
abstract: Mozambique government says economy is flourishing despite some flooding in central provinces earlier this year (S)

headline: Arafat and Peres Set to Meet
abstract: There was no sign that either side expected a breakthrough in talks between Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat and Israeli Foreign Minister Shimon Peres

headline: Persepolis Journal; Shah's Tent City, Fit for Kings, May Lodge Tourists
abstract: Extravagant tents that Shah Mohammed Reza Pahlavi erected in Persepolis 30 years ago for lavish celebration marking 2,500th anniversary of first Persian empire are to be restored, probably for tourists; 50 tents once had marble bathrooms, finest French bed linens and exquisite Persian carpets; plan is to turn them into some kind of lodging for tourists; historians point to Shah's $200 million fete as beginning of end for him, a breathtaking symbol of how out of touch he was with ordinary Iranians, none of whom were allowed within miles of place during party; photos; map (M)

headline: British Conservatives Choose 'Euroskeptic' Leader; Facing Fractious Party
abstract: Britain's Conservatives choose Iain Duncan Smith as their new leader; Duncan Smith is former military man known for his fierce opposition to Britain's further integration into Europe; in mail-in vote, Duncan Smith, 47, defeats Kenneth Clarke, former chancellor of exchequer, and party's best-known supporter of Britain's becoming more actively engaged in European projects like common currency; photo of Duncan Smith (M)

headline: The Low-Cost Way to Battle M.B.A.'s
abstract: DIARY

headline: Defragmenter Craves A Desktop Unto Itself
abstract: Q.  I am trying to run Disk Defragmenter on my Windows 98 computer, but I never make it all  the way through because the program keeps starting over. How can I fix this?    A.  Disk Defragmenter, a system tool that comes with Windows, can help keep your computer running efficiently. If other programs are running on the computer and writing data to the hard disk, though, Disk Defragmenter may keep starting over.

headline: CORN SYRUP PRICE-FIXING SUIT TO BE DISMISSED
abstract: Judge Michael M Mihm says he intends to dismiss class-action lawsuit accusing Archer Daniels Midland, Cargill, Tate & Lyle and Cerestar of conspiring to fix prices in $2 billion market for high-fructose corn syrup; suit was filed by Coca-Cola, PepsiCo and 24 other food companies (S)

headline: No Plot Twists In a Novelist's Portfolio
abstract: Ken Follett, British novelist, distrusts stocks and says that his ultimate investing goal is to preserve earnings from his books; closely monitors international economies and markets, however, as most of his earnings come from abroad; photos; table (M)

headline: AT ARRAIGNMENT, MILOSEVIC SCORNS HIS U.N. ACCUSERS
abstract: Slobodan Milosevic appears for arraignment before international tribunal that has accused him of crimes against humanity, and he dismisses court with disdain as 'illegal organ'; Former Serbian leader chooses to appear in The Hague without counsel and to deliver his own rebuttal; refuses to hear indictment or enter plea, and court enters not guilty plea for him in 12-minute proceeding led by British Judge Richard May; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Governors Draft Sales Tax Appeal
abstract: Group of more than 40 governors calls on Congress to allow states to develop system for collecting sales taxes on purchases made online; moratorium on Internet taxes expires in October; photo (S)

headline: People
abstract: Lynne Seid is named to new post of chief client officer at BBDO Worldwide (S)

headline: Defense Is Trying to Bar Witness in Auction Trial
abstract: Lawyers for Sotheby's former chairman, A Alfred Taubman, seek to bar testimony of Christopher M Davidge, former chief executive of Christie's, in Taubman's criminal antitrust trial; argue that prosecutors violated professional ethics rules in their dealings over cooperation of Davidge; motion hinges on claim that Davidge, who resigned from Christie's in December 1999, was given $7.5 million severance payment that was contingent upon his cooperation in helping auction house receive amnesty from prosecution in four-year antitrust investigation; auction house did not receive conditional amnesty (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: North Korea, Vietnam: A Friend In Need
abstract: Kim Yong Nam, North Korea's second in command, travels to Vietnam in search of aid he hopes Vietnamese will give to show gratitude for past favors (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: WPP Is Said to Be Near A Rival Offer for Tempus  WPP Group, the British advertising firm, plans to make a formal offer for Tempus, the media-buying agency, that values the company at about $636 million, people close to the talks said. The bid is an attempt to trump a rival offer from Havas Advertising of France.   WPP is expected to file its offer with British regulators today, although it does not have the support of the Tempus board, a condition that WPP had sought. Instead, Tempus will withdraw its support for the Havas offer and remain neutral during the bidding. [Page C2.]

headline: The Fiber Optic Network: Not Exactly a Railroad
abstract: Richard Becker letter questions Daniel Akst September 2 article comparing glut of long-haul fiber optic lines to early railroad system

headline: E-Commerce Report; Merchants who sneered at their Internet rivals now struggle to assess their own Web sidelines.
abstract: As Internet retailing has dwindled mainly to online extensions of old-line merchants, ideas about e-profitability have become a bit more nuanced; recent reports by Internet consulting firms show that bricks-and-mortar retailers that judge their Web division solely on basis of profits may be shortchanging themselves; photo of Walmart.com sign (M)

headline: World Briefing | World: Dutch Approve International Court
abstract: Netherlands becomes 37th country to ratify treaty establishing International Criminal Court (S)

headline: Fewer Investment Clubs
abstract: National Association of Investors Corp says that number of investment clubs has shrunk every month since Feb, 2000, and now stands at 33,500 (S)

headline: Biggest Banks in Canada May Be Set for Marriages
abstract: Canada's largest banks--Royal Bank of Canada, Toronto-Dominion Bank, Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce, Bank of Nova Scotia and Bank of Montreal--may be set for mergers in wake of new law that eases ownership rules and opens way for more vigorous competition among banks and other financial institutions; graph (M)

headline: ALIGNING WITH U.S.
abstract: Pres Vladimir V Putin offers United States broad support for antiterrorist operations in Afghanistan, including opening Russian airspace to relief missions, taking part in search-and-rescue operations, and arming anti-Taliban forces inside Afghanistan; combined with Russian effort to rally Central Asian countries to American side, Putin's pledge provides crucial support to international coalition that White House seeks to build in wake of terrorist attacks; his offer of support is most decisive alignment of Russia's military and intelligence resources with US-led campaign since end of cold war; his motive is defeat of Islamic militance in Central Asia, on Russia's southern doorstep; Putin makes pointed reference to Russia's own problems with Islamic militants in breakaway province of Chechnya; many Russians say doses of terror in New York and Washington should silence American fault-finding with Russian behavior in Chechnya; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Phone Company Profit
abstract: France Telecom says first-half profit fell 49 percent; net income fell to 1.95 billion euros ($1.73 billion), from 3.8 billion euros year earlier; profit rose 2.8 percent (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Utility's Profit Up
abstract: E.ON AG says first-half operating profit rose 52 percent, to 1.96 billion euros ($1.8 billion); net income fell 74 percent from year earlier (S)

headline: Bush, in Britain, Enjoys the Calm Before the Storm
abstract: President Bush stood side by side with Prime Minister Tony Blair, who did everything he could to minimize his differences with Washington

headline: Seeking to Regain Fliers, United Cuts Chicago Fares
abstract: United Airlines, trying to win back passengers from big rivals and to ward off competition from discounters, is reducing fares on some flights between Chicago and other large American cities and will remove Saturday-night stay requirement (S)

headline: Burden Seems to Be on Japan to Salvage the Fast-Eroding Climate Treaty
abstract: Japan is in the driver's seat to determine whether a global climate treaty will ever take effect. And supporters of the treaty said yesterday that they were discouraged by the remarks made on Saturday by Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi when he met with President Bush, a fervent opponent of the treaty.    At Camp David, Mr. Koizumi said that Japan was willing to work until the last minute to rally support for the treaty, but that in the end it would not proceed without the United States.

headline: W.T.O. Tries to End Work in China Case
abstract: Trade negotiators in Geneva, set back by last-minute squabbles and thrown off schedule by ripple effects of terrorist attacks in United States, are racing to tie up host of technical loose ends by Sept 17 so that China can join World Trade Orgn (S)

headline: What Government Gives, It Can Take Away
abstract: Gretchen Morgenson column scores plan to begin charging companies and employees Social Security taxes beginning in Jan 2003 on difference between discounted price at which employees buy shares through employee stock purchase plans and prevailing market price; warns many employers may discontinue plans; graph (M)

headline: Afghan Judge Denounces Aid Workers Now on Trial
abstract: Afghan chief justice, mullah Noor Muhammad Saqib, strongly suggests in sermon that he has decided eight foreign workers are guilty of preaching Christianity; refers to confiscated Bibles in local languages, videotapes and audiocassettes that mullah says praise Jesus above God (S)

headline: Bush Latin America Nominations Reopen Wounds
abstract: Pres Bush's plan to give top posts responsible for Latin America and human rights to Reagan administration veterans who worked together in State Department during bitter policy fights over Central America in 1980's has inflamed critics of their actions; critics warn of polarizing debate; Senate Democrats say they plan to scrutinize nominees, including Elliott Abrams, Otto J Reich and Roger Noriega, and in some cases delay or even block confirmations; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: China: Sister Sent To Labor Camp
abstract: Li Wangling, sister of Chinse labor activist Li Wangyang, is charged with subversion and sentenced to three years in labor camp, apparently for talking with foreign reporters (S)

headline: For Cellphone Holdouts, Worry Closes the Sale
abstract: A NATION CHALLENGED: COMMUNICATIONS: For Cellphone Holdouts, Worry Closes the Sale**Several wireless telephone companies say sales increased after terrorist attacks on World Trade Center and Pentagon; it is too early to compile reliable figures, but AT&T Wireless, Verizon Wireless and Nextel all report anecdotal evidence of increase in cellphone sales (M)

headline: At Least One Stock Market Signal Is Flashing Green
abstract: Mark Hulbert Strategies column says stock investors should take heart from Value Line's median appreciation potential, index whose current reading is 100 percent; says it provides solid evidence that stock should have average annual returns of about 12 percent over next four years; graph (M)

headline: SONOCO PRODUCTS BUYS A RIVAL PACKAGE MAKER
abstract: The Sonoco Products Co to buy rival Phoenix Packaging Corp (S)

headline: Another Source
abstract: Francis W Rodgers letter suggests teachers be provided with computers they can take home so they can model technology for their students

headline: Article 2001070990814532040 -- No Title
abstract: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

headline: Dim Rawlings Report
abstract: Rawlings Sporting Goods Co says it had lower-than-expected fiscal 2001 earnings (S)

headline: Spending Weakens as Confidence Wanes
abstract: Conference Board reports consumer confidence index fell to 97.6 in September from 114 in August, largest single drop since October 1990, suggesting that nation was moving quickly toward recession before terrorist attacks; new reports of falling retail sales suggest that attacks have done fresh and perhaps long-term damage to consumer spending, which had already weakened before Sept 11 in response to rising unemployment and declining stock prices; most forecasters believe statistics will show that mild recession probably started in late summer and that attacks deepened it; National Association of Realtors says sales of existing homes reached record annual rate of 5.5 million, from 5.2 million in August, and median sale price rose to $154,700 from $151,700; graph (M)

headline: Metro Business Briefing
abstract: VANISHING INK CITED IN CHECK CASE A former secretary at Bear, Stearns & Company and her husband were each indicted yesterday on 13 counts of grand larceny, forgery and other crimes after they were accused of stealing more than $50,000 from a partner at the brokerage house. The secretary, Anamarie Giambrone, was accused of using quick-fading ink to write checks that her boss, Eli Wachtel, then signed. Once the ink faded, prosecutors said, Ms. Giambrone made the checks out t

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Natural gas prices drop 5.6 percent on expectations that mild weather will curb demand; August contract falls 18.2 cents, to $3.068 for one million BTUs on New York Mercantile Exchange; graph; chart (S)

headline: STAPLES NAMES SUCCESSOR TO ITS CHIEF EXECUTIVE
abstract: Staples Inc president and chief operating officer, Ronald Sargent, will succeed Thomas Stemberg as chief executive on Feb 3, 2002; Stemberg is named executive chairman (S)

headline: In the Footsteps of Their Parents?
abstract: In the Footsteps Of Their Parents? To the Editor

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Cambodia: Khmer Rouge Tribunal
abstract: King Norodom Sihanouk of Cambodia signs into law framework for tribunal to try former leaders of Khmer Rouge (S)

headline: AUSTRIAN DRUG COMPANY WINS APPROVAL FOR FACTORY
abstract: Sanochemia Pharmazeutika of Austria wins American regulatory approval for factory that produces galantamine, chemical used in Reminyl, a treatment for Alzheimer's disease; Johnson & Johnson and Shire Pharmaceuticals Group will sell Reminyl (S)

headline: Ugandan, Seeking Higher Office, Submits to Higher Education
abstract: Nasser Ntege Sebaggala, popular Ugandan politician, expects to graduate from adult education program in Britain to meet strict educational requirement for president and all members of Parliament in Uganda; prerequisite has frustrated many political aspirants and prompted some to forge academic records; Sebaggala sees himself as role model for Ugandans, and he does not mind ribbing about returning to classroom as adult (M)

headline: Publisher Will Pay Clinton Over $10 Million for Book
abstract: Former Pres Bill Clinton agrees to sell worldwide rights to publish memoirs to Alfred A Knopf Inc for advance of more than $10 million, amount believed to be largest ever for nonfiction book; advance exceeds both $8.5 million paid for book by Pope John Paul II and $8 million recently paid to Sen Hillary Rodham Clinton for memoirs; Knopf is betting that Clinton will continue to be regarded as one of fascinating personalities of second half of 20th century, captivating readers both in US and abroad; president Sonny Mehta comments; Clinton will write book himself, with help from and hands-on guidance from Robert Gottlieb, highly regarded editor who was previously editor in chief at Knopf and later editor at New Yorker; publication scheduled for 2003, same year as wife's; sets up possibile competiton with Simon & Shuster; advance, compared with wife's $8 million payment, will go long way toward putting Clintons on firm financial footing; they accumulated $11.3 million in legal expenses during Clinton's presidency, all but $3.9 million of which has been paid off; photos (M)

headline: Thailand's Popular Premier Cleared in Corruption Case
abstract: Thailand's highest court acquits Prime Min Thaksin Shinawatra of financial irregularities, preserving his political career; ruling seen as test of country's evolution toward rule of law; Thaksin had overwhelming support of public; 15-member Constitutional Court was under intense pressure to acquit him, despite what Thaksin himself has admitted was clear violation of financial-disclosure laws; Thaksin, now freed from threat of removal, will be under intense pressure to bring country out of its economic slump; photo (M)

headline: Swiss Group To Expand Its Holdings Across Europe
abstract: Martin Ebner says his BZ Group Holding will reach outside Switzerland to buy shares in some European banks; photo (S)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: ASIA AFGHANISTAN: ENVOYS ARE REBUFFED Three envoys — an American, an Australian and a German — met with Abdul Rehman Ottaq, left, director of the Taliban consulate department, but were refused visits with the eight aid workers held on charges of preaching Christianity. The envoys gave the Taliban letters for the workers and bags of cookies and supplies. Under Taliban law, a foreigner found guilty of preaching Christianity would face a short jail term and expulsion. Mr. Ottaq said the investigation has broadened to include all aid groups, including the United Nations and the World Food Program.    (AP) NORTH KOREA: PEACE GROUP ALLEGES PRESSURE A spokesman for a delegation of 311 South Korean peace activists, Lee Soo Un, said that North Korean officials had pressured them to attend ceremonies at a new monument in Pyongyang dedicated to Korean reunification on terms not acceptable to the South. A third of the group attended the opening ceremony on Wednesday, the 56th anniversary of the end of Japanese colonial rule on the Korean Peninsula, according to pooled South Korean newspaper reports. South Korean officials ordered those going to Pyongyang for the anniversary not to appear to endorse the North's position by visiting the monument.    Don Kirk (NYT) INDIA: CAMPAIGN FOR SAINTHOOD A 35,000-page report on the life of Mother Teresa, put together by a diocesan commission in Calcutta, will be sent to the Vatican in six sealed boxes. Her order, the Missionaries of Charity, hopes she will be beatified and eventually be made a saint

headline: Economy Grew at 0.7 Percent in Second Quarter of 2001
abstract: The economy grew at a barely perceptible rate in the second quarter, its weakest pace in eight years, as businesses slashed spending and inventories, the government reported today

headline: World Business Briefing
abstract: ASIA.

headline: VIACOM IS COMBINING 2 OUTDOOR ADVERTISING DIVISIONS
abstract: Viacom forms new unit, Viacom Outdoor Group, by combining two advertising divisions of its Infinity Broadcasting Corp (S)

headline: Power Crisis Is Creating Opportunity In Brazil
abstract: Energy conservation measures that have forced Brazilians to curtail energy use since spring have also created market for more efficient appliances; home appliance manufacturers and stores are trying to lure energy-conscious consumers back into stores to replace, energy-guzzling appliances with newer, more efficient models; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Lets Employees Leave As Indonesia Protests Mount
abstract: United States Embassy in Indonesia tells most staff that they can leave, as protests against America by militant Islamic groups mount; photo (M)

headline: In Florida, Fraud Doesn't Matter. Will Congress Object?
abstract: Floyd Norris comment on pending federal bankruptcy bill focuses on whether Congress will allow loophole in bill that allows some people to live in luxury while stiffing their creditors; notes case of Elmer C Hill, Tennessee coal broker, who paid $650,000 in cash to buy waterfront home in Florida and $75,000 to funish it before Florida ruled on whether he owed $15 million to company that said Hill defrauded it; under Florida law, people cannot lose their homes in bankruptcy, but it is not clear to federal appeals court whether that applied if house is bought with clear intent to defraud creditors; photo (M)

headline: Koreans Slice Their Fingers in Anti-Japan Rite
abstract: Twenty young Korean protesters chop off tips of their little fingers during protest in Seoul, in which they demand apology from Japan for alleged offenses committed against Korean people during World War II; ritualistic display reflects rage over planned visit by Japanese Prime Min Junichiro Koizumi to shrine honoring Japan's war dead, including war criminals; photo (M)

headline: New York Jobs Cut By Interpublic Unit
abstract: Foote, Cone & Belding's New York office is laying off some 50 to 75 employees, some 10 percent of staff (S)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: English Name Provokes Bomber
abstract: Rheal Mathieu, man associated with Quebec separatist movement 30 years ago, is sentenced to several months in jail for trying to firebomb three coffee shops in Montreal because of their English name (S)

headline: Beijing Convicts Professor; Orders Expulsion
abstract: China convicts Prof Li Shaomin, Chinese-born American citizen, of spying for Taiwan; orders him expelled; move resolves first of several cases that have complicated US-China ties (M)

headline: Trial Offers Look at Secretive Warriors in Bosnia
abstract: United Nations war crimes tribunal in Hague has accused three Muslim warriors in Bosnia of committing atrocities against civilians and prisoners that are strictly forbidden under code of conduct of Islamic 'holy warriors'; three are retired Gens Mehmed Alagic and Enver Hadzihasanov, as well as Brig Amir Kubura; they have pleaded not guilty; case is expected to throw light on mujahedeen, secretive movement of Islamic volunteer fighters who have been operating in Balkans for decade (M)

headline: Shift in Battle at Computer Associates
abstract: Sam Wyly will no longer seek to become chairman of Computer Associates International, changing course after management wins support of two shareholder-rights groups; Wyly is now asking for minority interest of four seats on company's board, down from his previous plan to remove all 10 directors; new board would nominate chairman to replace Charles Wang (S)

headline: Ancient Egypt, With a Pager as Your Guide
abstract: Port Discovery Children's Museum, Baltimore, offers children who visit exhibition use of BlackBerry pager to lead them through series of interactive activities designed to enhance exhibition; devices are linked to network provided by Aether Systems; other museums are exploring how wireless devices can be used both at and away from museum; photo (M)

headline: Business Inventories Were Unchanged in May
abstract: Business inventories were unchanged in May as sales rose more than in any month since March 2000, sign pickup in economy may lift production months from now; inventories, which fell 0.2 percent in April, have not increased in last four months; business sales surged 1.1 percent in May after falling 0.5 percent; graph (M)

headline: Scouring the Internet in Search of the Tracks of Terrorists
abstract: Federal Bureau of Investigation and anti-terrorism investigators are asking Internet service providers to help conduct online wiretaps as part of probes into terrorist attacks; some online advocates say probers are demanding companies attach Carnivore wiretap system to their networks; note using that system's broadest capabilities would be illegal (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Malaysia: Aiming At A Tycoon
abstract: Malaysia's government offered to pay 3.72 billion ringgit ($979 million) to buy the construction company United Engineers Malaysia, a deal that would give it control of an affiliated conglomerate, the Renong Group, from the tycoon Halim Saad. Renong became a storehouse of ruling-coalition commercial interests two decades ago, and Mr. Saad was installed at its helm as a model of ethnic Malay entrepreneurship. During the Asian financial crisis of 1997 and 1998, however, Renong emerged as the nation's largest debtor. The government stood by as Mr. Saad shuffled assets rather than sell them, becoming emblematic to disenchanted foreign investors of the country's refusal to make the political sacrifices that accompany economic reform.   Wayne Arnold (NYT)

headline: Amid Anxiety, Markets Edge Back Toward Routines
abstract: Economists, citing new figures suggesting that economy was tipping into recession even before terrorist attacks on World Trade Center and Pentagon, say ripple effects from assault will almost surely bring to end record-setting expansion that began more than decade ago; University of Michigan consumer confidence index dropped to 83.6 last week from 91.5 in August; number of workers filing initial claims for unemployment rose by 21,000 last week, to 431,000, well above what economists had expected; Federal Reserve Bank of New York injects $70.2 billion into system by buying governemnt securities; Fed also agrees to arrangement with European Central Bank under which it will make $50 billion credit line available to European financial institutions operating in US; Republicans start drafting plans for package of fiscal stimulus, including business tax breaks and reduction in capital gains rate; Democrats say that they are not sure of package's fate but that Congress is more likely to agree on further fiscal stimulus than it would have been few days ago; graph; photo (M)

headline: United Nations Proposes Joint Effort Against Terrorism
abstract: The Security Council today pressed toward the adoption of a resolution committing all 189 countries in the United Nations to crack down on terrorist movements and their supporters.

headline: Greenspan Hopeful Attacks Won't Have Long-Term Effect on Economy
abstract: Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve's chairman, and other federal officials urged the Senate today to have faith in the country's long-term prospects.

headline: A False Challenge to News Photos Takes Root on the Web
abstract: False story that CNN news photos of few East Jerusalem Palestinians celebrating terrorist attack on New York really dated to 1991 has taken root around world, even though film's authenticity has been verified by CNN and Reuters, whose cameraman took images; was begun by Brazilian graduate student Marcio A V Carvalho, who sent e-mail message to list of sociologists, and forwarded to tens of thousands of people on respected Internet mailing list run by David Farber; recantation by Carvalho has not stopped e-mail, which is now being misattributed to BBC aide; second videotape of celebrations in Nablus was never broadcast after Palestinian authorities reportedly warned of threat to Associated Press cameraman and third tape was confiscated; photo (M)

headline: Medical Center Seeks More Payments From Genentech
abstract: Trial begins in lawsuit by City of Hope National Medical Center in Duarte, Calif, seeking additional sizable royalty payments and damages from Genentech for groundbreaking research that helped spawn biotechnology industry more than two decades ago; scientists, working under contract with Genetech in 1978, synthesized gene for human insulin and then produced insulin by putting that gene in bacteria; human insulin, which Genentech licensed to Eli Lilly & Co, became first pharmaceutical product created by genetic engineering; Eli Lilly has paid $285 million in royalties to City of Hope on sales of insulin and of human growth hormone, another early biotechnology drug that City of Hope helped create; City of Hope says Genentech also owes it royalties arising from more than 20 deals in which Genentech licensed patents to other companies (M)

headline: With Net Off, Swiss Insurer Plans to Shed Zurich Re
abstract: Zurich Financial Services says it will spin off about 70 percent of reinsurance unit, Converium, formerly known as Zurich Re, in initial public offering sometime in fourth quarter; unit had $98 million profit in first six months of 2001; company's American fund management business, Zurich Scudder Investments, is also on block; Zurich Financial reports net profit fell 32.9 percent, to $861 million, in first half of 2001; chairman-chief executive Rolf Hueppi comments (M)

headline: Slow to Yield, Brazil Passes Equal Rights For Its Women
abstract: Brazil, after 26 years of debate, amendments, delays and parliamentary maneuvering, approves legal code that for first time in country's history makes women equal to men in eyes of law; among oddities new measure eliminates is much-criticized provision that allows husband to obtain annulment if he learns that his wife was not virgin at time of their marriage; new code also does away with restriction that prevents anyone determined to have engaged in adultery, which is criminal offense in Brazil, from remarrying (M)

headline: Lost High-Tech Jobs Cast a Pall in Dallas
abstract: Early last year, high-technology employers in suburban Dallas's Telecom Corridor were so frantic to lure talent that one of them asked whether it could pay professors at the University of Texas at Dallas $5,000 for each recruit. But no more.

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: CORN DROPS. Corn fell on speculation that rain would quickly rejuvenate plants after a heat wave. In Chicago, corn for delivery in December, after the harvest, fell 1.75 cents, or 0.8 percent, to $2.295 a bushel.

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Sugar falls 0.42 cent, to 7.93 cents a pound, on inreased shipments from new crop in Brazil; indexes of commodities are noted (S)

headline: British Telecommunications Rejects Bid for Local Telephone Wires
abstract: British Telecommunications has rejected an initial $11.4 billion offer for its local telephone wires from a consortium led by Babcock & Brown, an American asset-finance company, people close to the discussions said today.    An initial approach by the group, named Earth Lease, which also includes the New York investment bank Chancery Lane Capital, was made in May, and a meeting with Sir Christopher Bland, the chairman of BT, was held a month later. The rebuff came late last week, although British Telecommunications held open the possibility of resuming the talks in the future, these people said.

headline: Time Inc. Picks Fortune Editor to Be Its Editorial Director
abstract: John Huey, the editor of the Fortune group of magazines, was named editorial director of Time Inc. today, replacing Walter Isaacson, who was named chairman and chief executive of CNN on Monday.

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Computer Associates Directors Survive Challenge
abstract: Computer Associates International soundly defeats effort by dissident investor Sam Wyly to replace four directors, including founder and chairman, Charles Wang; at least 60 percent of shares are voted in favor of current board, while fewer than 20 percent are cast for Wyly's slate, annual meeting; photos (Market Place column) (M)

headline: AT&T Reports a Loss; Long-Distance Is Weak
abstract: AT&T reported a loss in the second quarter yesterday, hampered by the swift erosion of revenue from long-distance operations and a $1-billion-plus plunge in the value of an Internet-related investment.    The company, the nation's largest provider of long-distance and cable television services, lost $149 million, or 5 cents a share, in contrast to a profit of $1.77 billion, or 53 cents, in the period a year ago. The loss, its third consecutive quarterly shortfall, includes one-time events like expenses related to this month's spinoff of AT&T Wireless.

headline: Compressed Data; Lucent to Sell Its Golf Complex at a Profit
abstract: Lucent Technologies has gone on a cost-cutting rampage in an effort to return to profitability, announcing job cuts and spinoffs last week that will soon leave the company with 60,000 employees -- down from 155,000 a year ago. Even Lucent's top executives are feeling the pinch.     To curtail executive use of its corporate jet fleet, for example, the company is selling a Falcon 2000 jet valued at $20 million. And executives must now show they have exhausted commercial airline alternatives before they can use the company's other aircraft, two Gulfstream G-IV jets, each valued at more than $26 million, and a Sikorsky helicopter valued at about $8 million.

headline: Violence Flares in West Bank and Gaza Strip
abstract: In a surge of violence today in the West Bank and Gaza Strip, 10 Palestinians, including a 9-year-old girl, were killed by Israeli army gunfire, and an Israeli settler was shot dead by Palestinian gunmen.

headline: Equity Offerings
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:       Infineon Technologies, Munich, $60 million American Depository Shares. Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley and Salomon Smith Barney.

headline: DataBank; Life in Technology Stocks Helps the Market
abstract: Summary of week's financial markets; graphs; table (S)

headline: The Times Company Names Financial Officer
abstract: Leonard P Forman, senior vice president of The New York Times Co, will become chief financial officer at end of year, succeeding John M O'Brien, who will retire then; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing | The Americas: Brazil: Aircraft Purchase
abstract: Brazilian Air Force will buy 76 light attack planes from Embraer as part of $3.35 billion modernization effort; has also solicited bids on $700-million contract for 24 jet fighters (S)

headline: A Ban on Memorabilia Auctions
abstract: Ebay temporarily bans sales related to World Trade Center or Pentagon out of deference to victims of terrorist attacks (S)

headline: Online Travel Agency Shares Post Losses for a Second Day
abstract: Main online travel stocks--Expedia, Priceline and Travelocity--are down for second consecutive day; declining stock prices reflect general fear among investors that any companies with ties to air travel could be entering protracted revenue slump (M)

headline: Russian in Digital Copyright Case Is Released on Bail
abstract: Dmitri Sklyarov, Russian programmer whose arrest in Las Vegas has incited international protests against American digital copyright law, is released on $50,000 bail, after three weeks in custody; case is one of first criminal prosecutions brought under Digital Millennium Copyright Act, 1998 law that has been criticized as overly restricting ability of computer users to gain access to and distribute digital media material; it is also one of first criminal copyright cases that does not explicitly involve copying, but focuses on distribution of program that could crack Adode Systems software used to encrypt electronic books (M)

headline: Britain Again Reinstates Direct Rule on Northern Ireland
abstract: Britain suspends Northern Ireland's three-year-old government and reinstates direct rule from London for second time in two months, to forestall yet another crisis over fulfillment of 1998 Good Friday peace accord; decision by Northern Ireland Sec John Reid puts province's Parliament on hold indefinitely, although first suspension lasted only a day (S)

headline: OBITUARY : Walter Oberreit, 72, Lawyer
abstract: Walter W. Oberreit, 72, a partner of the New York-based international law firm of Cleary, Gottlieb, Steen & Hamilton, died on July 15 in Brussels, where he had lived for more than 30 years. He was recognized as the dean of American law practitioners there.

headline: Bush Theme: End the Cycle Of Violence In the Mideast
abstract: Pres George W Bush, repeating consistent theme on Middle East, says that it is up to Israelis and Palestinians to break their cycle of violence; says that until they do, it will be impossible for United States to initiate peace talks (M)

headline: Management: Family Conflicts That Can Bring A Business Down; Money and Personality Clashes Are Often the Prime Culprits
abstract: Less than one third of 22 million family-owned businesses operating in US will continue to be family owned in next generation because conflicts revolving around money or personalities; conflicts at door companies in Queens, NY, owned by descendants of founder Samuel Sklar, and at El Paso Chile, co-owned W Park Kerr and his mother, Norma, who brought in Mrs Kerr's son-in-law to help manage business, discussed; graph; photo (M)

headline: A Boon to the Elderly
abstract: Nelson Marans letter observes that senior citizens might benefit from disposable cellular telephones discussed in Aug 2 article (S)

headline: New Economy; The terror in Lower Manhattan tests the fabric woven from a variety of strands of the communication network.
abstract: Amy Harmon column holds aftermath of terrorist attacks on New York City and Washington showed how matrix of communications technologies bridges distance and destruction to help businesses, families, friends and governments connect; drawing (M)

headline: Viewing a Daunting Afghan Landscape Dotted With Scattered Taliban Forces
abstract: Tour of rugged terrain in northern Afghanistan's rebel-held area suggests challenges that face any force trying to control nation; Dr Abdullah Abdullah, rebel coalition's foreign minister, suggests strategy involving American air attacks and rebel ground attacks on Taliban forces; urges United States to do more to broadcast data about terrorist attacks in Afghanistan (M)

headline: United Makes Further Reductions in Effort to Weather Crisis
abstract: United Airlines will cut total number of passengers it can fly by 6 percentage points more than 20 percent cut it previously indicated as it tries to survive huge decline in passenger traffic since terrorist attacks on Sept 11; several other major carriers have said they would reduce their capacity by 20 percent; analysts say new cuts do not necessarily mean that airlines are in worse shape than was thought; note that industry might face challenging rebuilding problem next summer if large numbers of passengers return (M)

headline: Personal Business; Cleaner Cars Are Here, if You Can Find Them
