abstract: Unpredictable fuel prices have helped spur demand in small assortment of cars and trucks that are available with diesel engines and for hybrid vehicles that run on combination of electric motor and gasoline engine; CNW Marketing/Research study shows about 37 percent of car shoppers in 2001 considered themselves 'extremely concerned' about environment, more than triple 11 percent who put themselves in that category in 1996; sales of alternative-fuel vehicles make up only fraction of overall market, about 50,000 of more than 16 million vehicles sold nationwide this year; finding diesel vehicle, most familiar alternative for improving fuel economy, is difficult in US; graph; photo (M)

headline: G.M. Official Says Dollar Is Too Strong
abstract: General Motors chief financial officer John M Devine says dollar's strength continues to hurt United States manufacturers, auto industry conference, Traverse City, Mich; asks Bush administration to rethink its currency policy; weak currencies abroad pose problem for American companies, which must convert their overseas sales into dollars before reporting results; photo (M)

headline: France Télécom's News Is Good, and Early
abstract: France Telecom rushes out part of its earnings report for first half of 2001, one week ahead of schedule; reports income increased 14 percent, to 6.07 billion euros ($5.52 billion) for period; company still plans to report its net income on Sept 5 (M)

headline: American Express Earnings Tumble, as Warned
abstract: The American Express Company said yesterday that its profit fell in the second quarter, even without its $826 million loss on high-yield bonds, as companies tightened travel and entertainment spending.    The company, which said last week that per-share earnings fell 76 percent from a year earlier, reported net income of $178 million, or 13 cents a share in the quarter ended June 30, compared with $740 million, or 54 cents, a year earlier. Analysts had expected 53 cents a share before last week's announcement.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Compromises Are Explored On Additional Tax Cuts  Leaders in both parties responded to the darkening economic outlook by exploring possible compromises on additional tax cuts, and the Democratic chairman of the Senate Budget Committee suggested that such a deal could involve the politically perilous step of tapping temporarily into the Social Security surplus.    Pressure mounted on President Bush to drop his cautious approach to dealing with the weakening economy, much of it from within his own party. [Page A1.]

headline: Finding Ways to Reassure Employees
abstract: Supervisors find ways to reassure employees after attack on World Trade Center; Lynne Einleger, executive vice president of DEI Management Group, Andrew Senchak, vice chairman of Keefe, Bruyette & Woods, and Alice Bergman, administrative assistant at Warburg Pincus comment; photo (M)

headline: Tories Choose a New Leader Fiercely Opposed to Europe
abstract: The Conservatives declared their new leader to be Iain Duncan Smith, a former military man known for his opposition to Britain's integration into Europe.

headline: The Videoconference as a Bicoastal Pas de Deux
abstract: Videoconferencing is costly, yet its ability to create instantaneous and real-time collaboration often justifies cost; business and artistic endeavors save time and lower travel budgets; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: ASIA JAPAN: KOIZUMI RETHINKS VISIT TO MEMORIAL One day after helping his Liberal Democratic Party secure a major victory in parliamentary elections, Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi hinted that he would reconsider his pledge to visit a shrine to Japan's war dead on Aug. 15

headline: You've Got Maelstrom
abstract: E-mail programs refine possibilities for creating subject folders, setting up filters that automatically sort incoming mail into those folders and locating individual messages and text within them; still, most people's e-mail is disorganized maelstrom; photos (M)

headline: Dollar's Slow Slide Indicates Foreign Investors May Be Wary of U.S.
abstract: Dollar's slow tumble against euro continues; dollar also slips against Japanese yen; analysts are unsure where it will stop, given concern that American economy may not begin to rebound as soon as many expected; graph (M)

headline: Investing; Amid Building Boom, Wariness on Stocks
abstract: Home building has generated strong profits this year, and some investors worry that it is due for a fall after multiple strong years; analysts offer their predictions for industry and individual stocks; graph (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Bombing Suspect
abstract: Scotland Yard looks for man with Northern Ireland accent who purchased car used in car bombing of West London neighborhood which injured 11 people; blast is seventh in London in past 18 months to be attributed to Real IRA, dissident group opposed to efforts to force political solution in Ulster (S)

headline: The Irish and Europe: A Time for Soul-Searching
abstract: Irish voters sort out their reactions to their rejection of European Union treaty that would have paved way for 12 new members; from international point of view, Ireland seems to be turning cold shoulder toward applicant countries and denying them sort of help Irish used to escape poverty over last few decades; Irish reject that interpretation, saying process of European integration is increasingly bureaucratic and undemocratic; say institutions like European Central Bank and single European currency threaten Irish sovereignty; second national referendum on treaty will be held, probably next year (M)

headline: Secondhand Book Wrangler; A Pulitzer Prize Winner Is Also a Profitable Bookseller
abstract: Larry McMurtry, author and winner of Pulitzer Prize, runs vast secondhand book business, Booked Up, in his tiny hometown, Archer City, Tex; says he hopes to turn Archer City into 'book town' where serious bibliophiles will make their pilgrimage; prides himself in having no personal access to Internet and his business has no Web site or online catalog; says he has been 'scouting' books--running around country buying and selling secondhand books--since mid-1950's, before his writing brought him wealth; photos; map; graph (M)

headline: Bold Move Will Test Executive's Skill
abstract: Hewlett-Packard Co's bid for Compaq Computer Corp erases many doubts about skills of Hewlett-Packard chief executive, Carleton S Fiorina; merger would make her leader of company that would rival IBM in size and reach; analysts say Fiorina, her leadership skills and her blueprint for new Hewlett-Packard will be tested in coming days and months as she sells merger to Wall Street, antitrust authorities, customers and employees; photo of Fiorina with Michael D Cappellas, Compaq chief execuitve, who will become president of combined company (M)

headline: Shares Resume Slump on Gloom Over Economic Prospects
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average falls 92.58 points, or 1.1 percent, to 8,567.39; Nasdaq composite index falls 37.60 points, or 2.5 percent, to 1,464.04; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index falls 5.23 points, or 0.5 percent, to 1,007.04; US bond prices rise and yields fall; yield on benchmark 10-year note falls to 4.63 percent from 4.70 percent; yield on 30-year bond falls to 5.50 percent from 5.57 percent; graphs; charts (M)

headline: New Rights for Dutch Prostitutes, but No Gain
abstract: Netherlands, where prostitution has long been legal, has now legalized brothels and is trying to devise regulatory system; new law is intended to help police control industry and grant labor rights and protections to more than 30,000 working prostitutes, but many are now complaining about stupid bureaucratic rules and regulations that may force operations to close down or go underground; prostitutes trying to set themselves up as self-employed businesswomen are being turned down by accountants, banks and health insurance companies; photos; map (M)

headline: Ignore What We Said Earlier
abstract: Matt Richtel humorous article revamps predictions of changes Internet will make in people's lives; drawing (M)

headline: Brazil Urges Activating Rio Pact
abstract: Brazil has called on the Organization of American States to activate a regional collective security agreement when its members meet in Washington in a special session on Wednesday.

headline: MediaTalk; Group Says Fox Has a Right-Wing Slant
abstract: The momentum Fox News Channel is enjoying is causing considerable chagrin to some liberal groups, disturbed by what they call its decidedly conservative bent.    They seem most irked by the network's slogan, ''Fair and Balanced,'' and also by the general belief among media critics that the conservative slant is confined to Fox News's opinionated, prime-time talk shows -- and is kept out of its news coverage.

headline: Executive Changes at Advertising Firms
abstract: Penny Feldstein was named campaign director for the Office of National Drug Control Policy campaign at the Advertising Council, New York. She had been account supervisor for Hasbro's United States toys account at DDB Worldwide, New York, part of the Omnicom group.

headline: TOP AIR CHIEF SENT
abstract: Top Air Force commander, Lt Gen Charles F Wald, flies to Saudi Arabia to oversee air attacks against Afghanistan and other potential targets in war against terrorism; Army secretary, Thomas White, says American ground troops are also being sent to region to join two dozen bombers and support aircraft that are moving within easy striking distance of Afghanistan; Defense Dept officials say Pentagon will send combat search-and-rescue teams into former Soviet republics in Central Asia, probably Uzbekistan, where they would be ready to get downed pilots; administration's military campaign is extremely sensitive politically because Islamic countries like Saudi Arabia and perhaps Pakistan are to be used as base of operations for many major attacks (M)

headline: Blair and Chirac Head to U.S. For Talks and a Show of Unity
abstract: France's president Jacques Chirac plans to arrive for talks with Pres Bush and British Prime Min Tony Blair will come later in week in show of support for United States following attacks on World Trade Center and Pentagon; administration defines different types of support, from rhetorical to military, that it needs from members of coalition it is trying to build; senior officials say they expect Britain, and possibly other allies, to contribute troops, although administration reserves right to act unilaterally; European Union will convene special summit meeting to work on ways of pooling resources to combat terrorism; following initial shock of attacks, some are tempering rhetoric to encourage patience (M)

headline: Fed Is Trying to Determine How Assets Affect Spending
abstract: Alan Greenspan, chairman of Federal Reserve, says Fed is trying to sort out ways in which different assets, such as stocks or homes, affect consumer spending; rule of thumb used by many economists is that for every one dollar increase in household's wealth, members of that household increase their spending by 3 to 5 cents; Greenspan says Fed has found that when home is sold, seller's consumer spending goes up 10 to 15 cents for every dollar of capital gain (M)

headline: Europeans Pledge to Mount a Joint Battle on Terrorism
abstract: European governments expressed solidarity with the U.S. as a democratic ally under attack, and European Union foreign ministers scheduled an emergency meeting for Wednesday.

headline: Lucent Raises $1.75 Billion in Convertible Stock Offering
abstract: Lucent Technologies raises $1.75 billion in securities offering, providing it with sizable injection of cash after months of seeking to dispel concerns about its liquidity; convertible preferred stock will pay annual coupon of 8 percent and allow holders to buy common Lucent stock at about $7.48 a share, 22 percent premium to yesterday's closing price (M)

headline: Large U.S. Force Is Assembling As Bush Decides How to Strike
abstract: United States assembles diverse military force of 28,000, plus 300 warplanes and two dozen warships across military theater with Iraq and Afghanistan at center; forces bring potent range of military options to keep pressure high, but senior Pentagon officials acknowledge risk as well as need for vast and expensive network of bases, command posts, flight decks, refueling outposts and defensive weapons; Bush administration has resisted temptation to retaliate immediately for attacks on World Trade Center and Pentagon, as it continues to rally support for coalition and gather intelligence on Osama bin Laden and his Al Qaeda network (M)

headline: Delicately, Pope Deplores 1915 Killings Of Armenians
abstract: Pope John Paul II accomplishes delicate diplomatic and linguistic feat in Yerevan, Armenia, deploring 1915 massacre that Armenians consider genocide by Turks without offending Turkey, a key Islamic American ally; issued document in 2000 calling massacre genocide, but Turks have asked that he avoid using word in Armenia; uses Armenian term that signifies genocide to people of Armenia but translates literally as 'big calamity'; photo (M)

headline: Home Depot Appointment
abstract: Home Depot Inc names Ricardo Saldivar as regional president and managing director of operations in Mexico (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: GOODYEAR TIRE & RUBBER CO., Akron, Ohio, won a 10-year contract to supply tires for the U.S. Postal Service fleet of 200,000 delivery vehicles.    CARDINAL HEALTH INC., Dublin, Ohio, a maker of pharmaceuticals and medical supplies, said its pharmacy distribution unit had signed a three-year agreement to sell wholesale prescription drugs to Express Scripts Inc., Maryland Heights, Mo., a provider of pharmacy benefit services.

headline: The Forecast Follies
abstract: Diane Forve letter comments on July 1 article on faulty economic forecasts

headline: U.S. Case Against Microsoft Could Take Years to Conclude
abstract: The government proposed a schedule for the remaining proceedings in the Microsoft antitrust case that, by taking years to conclude, could have limited effect on the software company's new operating system.

headline: MAN WINS $55 MILLION VERDICT AGAINST KELLY-MOORE PAINT
abstract: Kelly-Moore Paint is ordered to pay Alfredo Hernandez Sr and his family $55.5 million after Texas jury finds his cancer was caused by asbestos in company products (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Turkey: Official Resigns
abstract: Turkey's transport minister, Enis Oksuz, whose opposition to sale of state phone company Turk Telekomunikasyon helped undermine confidence in government, resigns after currency has its biggest one-day decline in four months; stalled efforts to replace political appointees on board of phone company, as demanded by International Monetary Fund; that contributed to IMF and World Bank holding up $3.2 billion in loans; lira falls 7.7 percent, to 1.5 million to dollar (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Company Changes Name
abstract: BT Wireless, mobile phone subsidiary of British Telecommunications, will change its name to MMO2, ahead of its spinoff into separate company later this year (S)

headline: Fits and Starts as Companies Strain to Restore a Sense of Normalcy
abstract: Many US companies strain to restore sense of normalcy almost one week after attacks on World Trade Center and Pentagon building; many workers say daily tasks seem trivial in face of tragedy, while many companies grapple with loss of colleagues (M)

headline: Luxury Groups Battle a Wave of Counterfeit Goods
abstract: MILAN—  When it was discovered in late summer that someone had broken into the Florence headquarters of the Ferragamo luxury goods group, investigators were initially at a loss to explain the purpose of the burglary.

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Sales Fall 31% At Texas Instruments
abstract: Texas Instruments, whose chips run two-thirds of the world's cellular phones, reported a second-quarter loss of $197 million, or 11 cents a share, in contrast to income of $1.3 billion, or 72 cents, in the period a year earlier. Sales fell 31 percent, to $2.04 billion. The company also forecast a loss for the third quarter.

headline: JOHNSON TOLD TO PAY $8.3 MILLION IN PATENT CASE
abstract: Jury decides that Johnson & Johnson must pay Boston Scientific Corp $8.3 million for infringing patent on stents that prop open clogged blood vessels; Boston Scientific sought $226 million (S)

headline: Malaysia's Internet Road Show
abstract: Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad has made creation of 'knowledge economy' a national priority in Malaysia; government-funded Mobile Internet Unit represents effort to help bridge 'digital divide' by delivering technology to poorest, most remote schools using 40-foot bus loaded with 20 Internet-connected computers; MIU has reached 2,800 Malaysian children in its two years of operation; photos; map (M)

headline: Hyundai Unit Threatens To Close as Bailout Fails
abstract: Hyundai Petrochemicals threatens to shut down, while Hyundai Merchant Marine is granted temporary reprieve by creditors; Hyundai Group's problems represent what many analysts see as most worrisome aspect of slump in which country's growth rate is declining from 8 percent last year to about half that much this year (M)

headline: A Messenger to China Business; U.S.-Trained Telecom Chief Builds a New, Hybrid Model
abstract: Chinese telecommunications market is expected to grow rapidly over next few years as more nimble companies using Western-style business practices take on long-dominant China Telecom, with encouragement of Chinese government; China Netcom's chief executive, Edward Tian, is exponent of new style; graphs; photos (M)

headline: Investing; Not Just for the Birds: Timber Is a Commodity for the Long Run
abstract: Timber is one of few investments whose returns have outpaced stocks, bonds and real estate over past 30 years, averaging 15.2 percent annually; investors with less than $100,000 for buying timberland may want to acquire shares in publicly traded companies, such as Plum Creek Timber Co; photo; graph (M)

headline: Prime Minister Offers to Resign, Sending a Shock Wave Through New Delhi
abstract: Prime Min Atal Behari Vajpayee India, seemingly exasperated by sniping within his governing alliance, suddenly offers to resign, jolting political establishment; apparently agrees to stay on in response to pleas from own party (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Sanmina Issues Earnings Warning
abstract: Sanmina Corp says sales and earnings this quarter will be less than forecast; graph (S)

headline: Quantum Theory Could Expand the Limits of Computer Chips
abstract: Researchers are using quantum mechanics to exceed limits of classical optics in using light to carve circuits, effort that could lead to faster computer chips; diagram (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: EMC Profit Down 71%
abstract: EMC Corp says earnings fell 71 percent in second quarter, to $109 million; sales declined 6 percent, to $2.02 billion; photo (S)

headline: U.S.-Based Scholar To Be Tried in China
abstract: Gao Zhan, a permanent United States resident accused of spying for Taiwan, has been indicted and will probably stand trial this month in Beijing, one of her lawyers said.    Her indictment, for which conviction is virtually assured, comes just days after her friend and fellow scholar, Li Shaomin, was convicted of spying in a related case and ordered deported. Ms. Gao's fate is less certain than his, however, because -- unlike Mr. Li, a naturalized American -- she is a Chinese citizen.

headline: MediaTalk; Reporter to Cover Mergers from Other Side
abstract: Wall Street is abuzz over former Wall Street Journal reporter Steve Lipin's plans to become communications specialist handling media coverage of mergers on behalf of corporate clients as partner at Brunswick (M)

headline: Roche Asks for Meeting With Brazil Health Minister
abstract: Dispute between Brazilian government and Swiss drug maker Roche intensifies as company asks to meet with country's health minister, Jose Serra, who repeats his threat to authorize generic copies of Roche's AIDS medicine Viracept (M)

headline: By-the-Numbers Operation at Morgan Stanley Finds Its Human Side
abstract: Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Co, biggest tenant in World Trade Center, changes after Sept 11 from firm not known as sensitive, touchy-feely sort of place to company that is concerned about its most important asset, its people; Philip J Purcell, chairman and chief executive, Philip J Purcell, comments; photo (M)

headline: Article 2001070693681389960 -- No Title
abstract: Untangling the Online Gaming Web

headline: Powell Will Not Attend Racism Conference in South Africa
abstract: Sec of State Colin L Powell will not attend UN conference on racism in South Africa and US may boycott gathering; decision on whether US will attend depends on whether language in meeting's agenda criticizing Israel is changed in coming days; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Avaya Plans More Job Cuts
abstract: Avaya Inc. said that it would cut an additional 2,000 jobs, adding to 3,000 cuts announced last month, as the maker of telephone equipment for businesses seeks to counter a decline in sales. Avaya, which is based in Basking Ridge, N.J., also said that revenue in the most recent quarter fell 10 percent, to $1.71 billion from $1.9 billion in the year-earlier period. Net income fell 27 percent, to $24 million from $33 million, the company said. Avaya, which was spun off from Lucent Technologies last year, will have 23,000 employees after the latest round of cuts is concluded.   Simon Romero (NYT)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Wheat prices rise on expectations that heat wave will damage crops in Midwest and northern Great Plains; September contract jumps 6 percent, or 16.5 cents, to $2.8925 per bushel; graph; chart (S)

headline: A Shattered Nest Egg
abstract: Julie Everitt letter holds July 22 article raises question of what would happen if US allows brokers to invest individuals' Social Security funds

headline: Airport Film Rentals
abstract: David Strom letter, commenting on Aug 9 article on portable DVD players, notes they can be rented at airports

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Pharmacy In Trial With Grocer
abstract: Pharmacy chain Boots PLC will begin selling products at six outlets owned by supermarket chain J Sainsbury PLC next year as part of trial (S)

headline: 2 More Agencies Decide to End Operations
abstract: Add two more agencies to the growing list of ones closing

headline: Article 2001070593297319660 -- No Title
abstract: Untangling the Online Gaming Web

headline: A Guide to Gadgets For Sun, Sand and Sea
abstract: From music to books to beachcombing, almost every seaside pursuit now has its own digital devices and accessories, like the watch that measures ultraviolet exposure. A roundup is on Page 7.

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Airline's Woes Continue
abstract: Air Transat, Canadian charter company whose Airbus ran out of fuel in both engines near Azores in August, had several more mishaps over weekend, involving fuel spill and other mechanical problems that delay flights (S)

headline: Telecom Italia Inquiry
abstract: Turin prosecutor Bruno Tinti leads probe of investment bankers who helped arrange Telecom Italia's $25 billion acquisition of Seat Pagine Gialle and of Telecom chief executive Roberto Colaninno; sees possible conflicts of interest and false accounting (S)

headline: Lack of Financing May End Trial of an AIDS Vaccine
abstract: Pfizer Inc, after reviewing results of clinical trial, pulls out of partnership with Immune Response Corp to develop AIDS vaccine Remune; Immune Response will take over trial, its best hope of proving drug works; seeks funds from other investors (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Investment: Venture Invests In Nanotechnology
abstract: Lux Capital, venture capital firm, and McGovern Capital, investment firm, form venture to start Angstrom Partners, merchant bank focusing on clients in nanotechnology industry--technology based on tiniest molecular structures (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Sri Lanka: Parliament Opens After Suspension
abstract: Pres Chandrika Kumaratunga re-convenes Sri Lankan parliament; opposition revives efforts to bring down her government; photo (S)

headline: Honors
abstract: Advertising industry awards noted (S)

headline: More Departures at the Top
abstract: Challenger, Gray & Christmas reports that 555 chief executives vacated their offices in first half of 2001, 22 percent increase over first half of 2000 (S)

headline: Manufacturing and Consumer Data Signal a Recovery
abstract: An index of manufacturing rose to a seven-month high in June, and consumer spending increased more than expected in May, industry and government reports showed today. The data were seen as a sign that the economy could be starting to recover.    The National Association of Purchasing Management's index increased to 44.7 last month from 42.1 in May. Last month's reading, the highest since November, was lifted by gains in orders and production. Still, a reading below 50 signals a decline, and the index has been in the 40's since last August.

headline: Greenspan Says Fed's Rate Cuts Are Working
abstract: Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, tells Senate committee that Fed's interest rate cuts are having their desired effect on weakened economy; leaves door open to further cuts if slowdown does not bottom out soon; photo (M)

headline: Sharon Booed by Fellow Rightists Who Say He's Too Soft
abstract: Prime Min Ariel Sharon of Israel, bane of Arabs and target of international human rights groups, is facing rising chorus of critics within his own rightist Likud Party who accuse him of going soft on Palestinian terrorism; was booed and heckled in Tel Aviv at gathering of party's faithful, led by former prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, who is seeking to make political comeback and is presenting himself as Israeli who can stop terrorism; Sharon rejects criticisms and says government is following policy of active defense, referring to Israel's practice of hunting down and killing militant Palestinian figures, especially those from Hamas and Islamic Holy War; photos (M)

headline: UNB, NORTHEAST OHIO BANK, TO PURCHASE BANCFIRST OHIO
abstract: UNB Corp agrees to buy BancFirst Ohio Corp for $193.4 million in stock (S)

headline: Inquiry Opens Over Rules On Pilot Rest
abstract: Transportation Department inspector general, Kenneth M Mead, agrees to review allegations that Federal Aviation Administration failed to enforce safety regulations at American Airlines; has received letter containing accusations of collusion and lax enforcement by FAA's southwest regional office from Richard Rubin, captain at American Airlines, who has been leading fight to persuade FAA to enforce longtime regulation that limits pilots to 16 hours of duty in single day (M)

headline: Jordache Stays True To Its Disco-Era Roots
abstract: Jordache Enterprises, which recently revived television commercial for its jeans from 1979, is beginning its first new ad spot in 20 years; spot was created by Concept Farm (S)

headline: Official History Describes U.S. Policy in Indonesia in the 60's
abstract: A supposedly secret State Department history, released today by a private research group, discloses new details of United States policy during the 1965 campaign by the Indonesian Army to wipe out the Communist opposition in Indonesia.     The National Security Archive, a Washington group that pushes for the declassification of government documents, obtained a copy of an official State Department history that describes American policy in  Indonesia in the mid-1960's.

headline: The National Pastime Falls Behind in the Count
abstract: Business of Major League Baseball is in a slump, with stadium attendance and television ratings down; ideas for re-energizing sport and winning new fans are proposed by luminaries Rudolph Giuliani, Phil Dusenberry, Doris Kearns Goodwin, Dan Rather, Tom Viertel, Henry Kissinger, Michael Veeck, Trip Hawkins, Stuart Greenbaum, Ken Burns, Jim Bouton and Frederick Reichheld; photos; charts (L)

headline: As North and South Korea Open Discussions, the Issue of Terrorism Takes Center Stage
abstract: A ministerial delegation from North Korea arrived in South Korea on Saturday to begin a four-day series of meetings heavily dominated by the issue of terrorism.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Lithuania: Ex-Communist Named Premier
abstract: Algirdas Brazauskas, Lithuania's last Communist boss and popular former president, wins Parliament's approval as next prime minister; photo (S)

headline: U.S. Professor to Be Tried In Beijing on Spying Charge
abstract: China confirms that Li Shaomin, Chinese-born US citizen who is business professor in Hong Kong, will go on trial on charges of spying for Taiwan; photo; trial will not be open to public, but American diplomat and interpreter will be allowed to observe (S)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: MONDAYConsumer BorrowingJuly.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Priceline Reverses Fortunes And Posts Quarterly Profit  Priceline.com, the name-your-own-price Internet travel service that six months ago was reeling from unhappy customers, reached a milestone in the second quarter that few other Internet companies have passed: It made a profit -- a penny a share -- according to generally accepted accounting principles.    The company's revival was driven by a sharp and unexpected increase in sales. Travel has been the one bright spot on the Internet as online advertising and shopping contract. Before Priceline reported its results, its shares closed at $8.87, up 38 cents. [Page C8.]

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY  None

headline: Despite Aid, Argentina Will See More Pain
abstract: Argentine government tells population that even deeper cuts in spending and more national sacrifice are in offing, despite emergency rescue agreement with International Monetary Fund; Pres Fernando de la Rua tells country's 36 million people that they should be happy with new accord, but reaction is mixed; Argentine press had been talking, perhaps unrealistically, of much larger lifeline than IMF has agreed to after two weeks of tough negotiations; timing of agreement will be bad for politicians; congressional elections are scheduled for Oct 14, with people irate at travails they are being asked to endure and eager to punish those they view as responsible; graph (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Brazilian real strengthens, settling at 2.5 reals per dollar from 2.4835 previously; graph (S)

headline: Article 2001070593425465251 -- No Title
abstract: July 2, 2001

headline: U.S. Reports Retail Sales Grew Less Than Expected
abstract: Commerce Department reports retail sales, which account for 40 percent of consumer spending, rose by less-than-expected 0.2 percent in June; excluding vehicle sales, retail sales declined by 0.2 percent; economists estimate overall consumer spending grew at annual rate of about 2.5 percent in second quarter; University of Michigan's index of consumer sentiment rose to 93.7 in June from 92.6 in May; Bureau of Labor Statistics reports Producer Price Index fell by 0.4 percent in June; Labor Department reports initial claims for unemployment pay rose in week ended July 7; graphs (M)

headline: Federated Cuts Profit Forecasts Sharply for Quarter and Year
abstract: Federated Department Stores cuts its profit forecast sharply, citing slow sales and steep markdowns (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Ratings Lowered Again
abstract: Moody's Investors Service lowers ratings on India's debt and currency; move follows similar action by Standard & Poor's, which cited laxness in carrying out economic reforms (S)

headline: Pakistanis, but Not Many, Angrily Take to the Streets To Denounce Bush's Stand
abstract: Pakistan's hard-line Islamic groups, deeply opposed to military action against Taliban, try for show of strength in Peshawar but instead manage only modest display of intimidating street power they often possess; their call for nationwide strike is ignored by majority of store owners; attendance at rallies is generally unremarkable; four people are killed in three incidents in Karachi as protesters pelt police with rocks; protesters in Karachi attack convenient symbols of West like KFC restaurant; one shopkeeper near airport is beaten to death for defying demand for complete shutdowns; photo (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: Komag Inc, maker of storage disks for computers, files Chapter 11 bankruptcy recovery plan that has support of more than half of its creditors (S)

headline: Charleroi Journal; A Rust-Belt City's Mean Streets Keep Their Edge
abstract: Article profiles Charleroi, city of 200,000 people in Belgium's rust-belt that is notorious for crime; has 800 police officers; map; photos (M)

headline: L'Oréal Buying Colorama
abstract: The cosmetics maker L'Oréal has agreed to buy Revlon Inc.'s Colorama line of make-up and shampoo in Brazil for $55 million as L'Oréal expands in emerging markets.    The Colorama line, introduced in 1976, includes Brazil's most popular nail polish. The cash purchase from Revlon, based in New York, includes a factory in São Paulo, the companies said.

headline: Have Your Freedom Now, or Later?
abstract: Preludes column by Abby Ellin says she is beginning to wonder whether her free-wheeling, freedom-loving, commitment-phobic generation has it right; says her parents married, raised children, and worked hard, and now their are enjoying their retirement years; says it makes her think that perhaps deferred gratification is not such a bad idea; photo (M)

headline: Fred Hoyle Dies at 86; Opposed 'Big Bang' but Named It
abstract: Sir Fred Hoyle, one of most creative and provocative astrophysicists of last half century, who helped explain how heavier elements were formed and gave name Big Bang, meant to be derisive, to theory of cosmic origin he vehemently opposed, dies at age 86; photo (M)

headline: Private Sector; Hip-Hop and Green
abstract: Michael Diamond of Beastie Boys seeks to organize musicians against Bush administration energy plan; photo (S)

headline: ONLINE DIARY
abstract: Two genealogy buffs, Stephen Morse and Edward Rosenbaum, develop aids to searching Ellis Island Web site (M)

headline: Opening Up A Bottleneck For Power; New York Acts to Modernize A Creaky Electricity Grid
abstract: Static compensator is being installed at New York Power Authority transmission control center in Marcy, and it will allow authority to redicted about 100 megawatts of energy between two parallel routes running from Marcy to New York City area, relieving crucial bottleneck and raising system's capacity by about 240 megawatts over all; that is small fraction of 12,000 megawatts that Con Ed alone can deliver at peak consumption, but it could be enough to avoid blackouts or other problems on particularly hot summer days; photos; map (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Insurers On Credit Watch
abstract: Standard & Poor's puts credit ratings of five of Japan's eight major life insurance companies on watch for possible downgrade, citing weak capital levels and high exposure to Japan's slowing economy; assets of five companies, Asahi Mutual Life, Meiji Life, Mitsui Mutual Life, Sumitomo Life and Yasuda Mutual Life, are dwindling dangerously as stock market weakens (S)

headline: Israelis and Palestinians Prepare for a Long Struggle
abstract: Israeli military strategists brace for possibility that bitter conflict with Palestinians could drag on for years; tensions are rising amid grievances on both sides; map; photo (M)

headline: Israeli Party Is Bickering After Near-Tie In Its Primary
abstract: Election for new leader of Israel's venerable Labor Party dissolves into charges of ballot-box rigging and theft; party has been rudderless since Ehud Barak was defeated in Feburary by present prime minister, Ariel Sharon; contest to lead party is between Avraham Burg, left-leaning speaker of Parliament, and his right-leaning opponent, Defense Min Binyamin Ben-Eliezer (M)

headline: With Politics and Market in Mind, Megawati Picks a Cabinet
abstract: Megawati Sukarnoputri, new president of Indonesia, chooses cabinet, winning immediate praise for her selection of economic team and for overall professionalism of her choices; Megawati selects as her chief political and security minister Bambang Susilo Yudhoyono, former general who is seen as reformist; he held same post under former Pres Abdurrahman Wahid, struggling to maintain order until he was fired (M)

headline: Weary Ulster's Tortuous Path: Once More to the Brink?
abstract: News analysis; Northern Ireland's politicians have again pulled back from brink to which they seemed condemned after Britain temporarily suspended home rule following tensions stemming from refusal of Irish Republican Army to disarm; contortions used to rescue home rule Assembly has angered Roman Catholics and Protestants who comprise it and may have built yet another brink from which retreat will be increasingly difficult; photo (M)

headline: Entrepreneur Is Quiet About His Past And Gets New Start in Net Surveillance
abstract: Irvin Meyer, who won Tony Award in 1977 for co-producing Broadway musical Annie, and who also served time in prison for tax fraud, has reinvented himself as Internet entrepreneur; in 1999 he discovered a technology that could scour Internet chat rooms for rumors, innuendo, opinions or lies about a particular person or company; he created company to offer service to any business worried about its image--and its stock price; company's most recent name is NetCurrents Inc; photo (M)

headline: CBS Executives Take a Journey To CNN Land
abstract: CBS News executives visit CNN's Atlanta headquarters as part of continuing discussions about possible news-gathering partnership (M)

headline: Congressional Leaders Meet With President
abstract: Following is a text of President Bush's news conference today with Congressional leaders at the White House, as recorded by The New York Times:

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: 2 Giants Join Wireless Group's Board
abstract: Representatives of Microsoft and Intel join board of Wireless Ethernet Compatibility Alliance, trade group promoting Wi-Fi platform for small wireless networks; Wi-Fi format, also known as 802.11b, has taken hold at airports and college campuses (S)

headline: Kleenex to Sponsor Movies to Cry By on TV
abstract: Kimberly-Clark Corp, maker of Kleenex tissues, and TNT, part of Turner Broadcasting System, in unusual promotion aimed at women ages 18 to 49, are collaborating to capitalize on impulse to use tisses to wipe away tears while watching films; Kleenex will be exclusive sponsor of yearlong series of 'tearjerker' movies that TNT will show on Sundays beginning in October (S)

headline: PLAYBOY TO ACQUIRE 3 SEX TV CHANNELS, AND A NETWORK
abstract: Playboy Enterprises has agreed to buy three sex television channels -- Hot Network, Hot Zone and the Califa Entertainment Group -- for $28.3 million, exercising an option obtained when it purchased Spice Entertainment two years ago. Also, Playboy said it would buy Vivid TV networks for $41.7 million from V.O.D. The prices may rise by $12 million if the companies meet performance goals. Playboy, based in Chicago, also extended by 10 years a contract with Vivid Video, which gives Playboy television rights, video-on-demand and video-streaming rights.

headline: Iraqis Nearly Hit a U.S. Plane
abstract: Surface-to-air missile comes very close to American U-2 surveillance plane high above southern Iraq; senior Defense Dept official says this is more evidence that Saddam Hussein's forces are increasingly adept at zeroing in on aircraft patrolling no-flight zones (S)

headline: G-8 Leaders Call for 'Third-Party' Monitors for Mideast
abstract: The foreign ministers of the major industrialized countries told the Israelis and Palestinians today that they should agree to accept a plan for outside monitors

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: In Rural India, A Passage To Wirelessness; Companies Jump In As Convenience And Need Catch On
abstract: Two dozen companies providing cellular telephone service compete for rural customers in India; mobile phone demand is growing rapidly, and its usage flourishes where fixed-line service is nonexistent; photos; charts (M)

headline: An Icelandic spring water strains its national mythology through an adage: sex sells.
abstract: Advertising: An Icelandic spring water strains

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Sri Lanka: Vote Postponed
abstract: Sri Lanka's Pres Chandrika Kumaratunga postpones referendum on new Constitution until October 18; ballot measure, scheduled for August 21, has been criticized by opponents and legal experts as vaguely worded and unlawful; photo (S)

headline: Russia Launches Pontoon In a Race Against Time To Help Raise Sunken Sub
abstract: Russia launches first of two large pontoons that will help in trying to raise nuclear submarine Kursk from bottom of Barents Sea next month; meantime, divers 800 miles to north fight clock and stormtossed seas, cutting more holes in hull of Kursk where it lies on bottom in more than 300 feet of water; festive mood at pontoon launching in Severodvinsk is tinged with anxiety about whether Russia can fulfill pledge made by Pres Vladimir Putin to raise Kursk this year; there is also grim task of recovering bodies of remaining Russian sailors inside its dark and flooded compartments; photo; map; drawing (M)

headline: Reaching Overseas, China Tries to Tether Its Own
abstract: Chinese government reportedly is conducting heavy-handed campaign to monitor activities of Chinese scholars living abroad; academics affected by effort say this has muted criticism of Communist Party and curbed free speech beyond country's borders; emigres and expatriate intellectuals, moved to speak by recent spy trials, say intimidation has increased in recent years and is much broader than previously thought; Kang Zhengguo, senior Chinese language teacher at Yale University, tells of being detained and interrogated for three days when he returned to China to visit his mother; estimates that thousands of people have been similarly harassed in what China's Ministry of State Security euphemistically calls 'returnee interviews' (M)

headline: Pursuing a New Line In Optical Research
abstract: Corning, leading maker of optical fiber, and handful of other companies and academic labs seek to develop new hollow-core fiber with far greater information-carrying capacity than today's designs despite current deep slump in fiber optics; communications industry continues to believe that optical networks are still in early stage of vast expansion; market share graph; diagram; photos (M)

headline: Brazil Is Getting a New Political Party: Its Base Is in State Prison
abstract: Brazil's notorious criminal group, First City Command, looks to extend influence by organizing political party, having demonstrated its dominance of prison system during mass uprising; group names lawyer Anselmo Neves Maia as candidate for Congress in next year's national elections; group is also said to run flourishing 'escape industry' that enriches coffers (M)

headline: Economic Scene; Gross domestic product vs. gross domestic well-being.
abstract: Alan B Krueger Economic Scene on economic impact of terrorist attacks of Sept 11 recalls how past disasters affected economy; says conventional wisdom is that disasters, natural and otherwise, typically have only modest effect on economic activity because human capital survives intact; says that in modern economies, human capital accounts for as much as 70 percent of national income; photo (M)

headline: I.B.M. WINS $100 MILLION CONTRACT FROM SHELL
abstract: IBM gets $100-million contract to help Royal Dutch/Shell Group consolidate global computing system (S)

headline: What's Behind Karmazin's Sale of Viacom Stock?
abstract: Viacom's president and chief operating officer Mel Karmazin has sold 15 percent of his shares in company, raising $35 million and eyebrows of some investors, who wonder if Karmazin is losing faith in stock's growth potential; transaction's timing also upsets chief executive and controlling shareholder, Sumner M Redstone, who has never sold any of his shares in company and has limited Karmzin's right to sell stock to no more than 800,000 shares per year; some investors and analysts question timing of Karmazin's sale of 700,000; several people close to Karmazin point out that he remarried in spring and wants to liquidate some of his holdings; photo (M)

headline: A Market Rebound Is Their Springboard
abstract: Managers of Safeco Growth Opportunities fund, Wasatch Core Growth fund and MFS Med-Cap Growth fund tell how funds realized outsized gains in second quarter; are cautious about stock market for remainder of year; they are Thomas M Maguire (Safeco), J B Taylor (Wasatch) and Mark Regan (MFS); photos (M)

headline: Terror Up Close Gave Air Safety A Lift in Britain
abstract: Bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland, in 1988, jolted British government into revamping its rules of airport security; sophisticated X-ray machines screen every piece of luggage checked at Manchester Airport and must be matched to passenger who gets on plane; photos; diagram of X-ray screening system (M)

headline: Pakistan Leader Defends Joining U.S. in Hunt for bin Laden
abstract: Gen. Pervez Musharraf asked his nation to trust him as he dealt with Pakistan's gravest crisis in the 30 years since it lost its last major war, with India.

headline: Unions at Airlines Assail Management For Denying Benefits
abstract: Airline unions are enraged at what they say are moves by several carriers to use national emergency to deny pay or benefits to workers idled as air travel stalls; American Airlines says carrier's finances have been hurt so badly that it cannot afford to pay severance benefits to thousands of workers that it plans to lay off; union officials criticize American, asserting that least airline can do after Congress approved multibillion-dollar bailout is to make good on its commitments to its workers; American insists company is honoring its contract and is invoking emergency clause that it says allows company to suspend certain commitments under extreme circumstances; its chief executive, Donald J Carty, says he will take no pay for rest of year and urges American employees to agree to voluntary cuts in pay; several union officials and airline workers say United Airlines is leaving some workers in limbo by not calling them to work and not laying them off; say US Airways is citing emergency conditions to override no-furlough clause in certain union contracts; photo (M)

headline: ST. PAUL SAYS COURT REVERSES SUSPENSION OF ITS LICENSE
abstract: Judge Gail S Tusan throws out order suspending St Paul Companies' license in Georgia; suspension was ordered after company said it would not renew more than 1,200 medical-malpractice policies up for renewal in June (S)

headline: Stocks Surge After Cisco Says Business Is Stabilizing
abstract: Technology stocks lead market surge after Cisco Systems announces seeing signs that its business is stabilizing; Nasdaq composite index climbs 73.83 to close at 1,916.80; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index ends week at 1,184.93, up 22.84; Dow Jones industrial average rises 194.02, closing at 10,423.17; 10-year Treasury bond price falls, its yield rising to 4.92 percent from 4.87 percent, and 30-year bond's drop in price brings its yield to 5.45 percent, up from 5.41 percent previously; chart; table of key rates (M)

headline: Economic Scene; With evolving technology, good monitors make for better contracts.
abstract: Hal R Varian's 'Economic Scene' column use of computers to monitors contracts in video rental business, trucking and other industries, which reduces cost of monitoring and thus makes economic relationships more efficient, if at the cost of some loss of privacy; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Computer Program Takes Toll On Internet
abstract: Malicious computer program takes its toll on Internet, causing slowdowns on network as it attacks personal computers and corporate servers (S)

headline: New Security Clogs U.S. Borders
abstract: Traffic congestion at border crossings with Mexico and Canada begin to ease as US brings in off-duty Customs agents and National Guard troops to relieve delays caused when security was tightened after terrorists attacked World Trade Center and Pentagon; shoppers from Mexico and truckers from Canada can still face waits of more than hour to cross border; since attacks, number of cars crossing into US at McAllen-Hidalgo International Bridge in Texas has dropped by one-third, to about 12,000 a day, as drivers seek to avoid delays from increased searches and other security measures; slowdown at border crossings has crimped flow of shoppers; photos (M)

headline: Matching The Battery To the Task
abstract: David Pogue column on choosing batteries for host of battery-operated gadgets; notes there is little variation across brands among standard alkaline batteries, which should be used with low-drain and moderate-drain devices; discusses wide and confusing range of choices for high-drain gear; offers advice on storing batteries; drawing; photo (M)

headline: Economic Cooperation Planned
abstract: Finance ministers of seven leading industrial nations, meeting in Rome, appear uncertain about whether worst of world's faltering economy has been reached; they agree to draw back from sharpening differences and from identifying structural weaknesses in individual countries and focus on greater cooperation; ministers hope to lay groundwork for meeting of leaders of Group of 7 countries in Genoa, Italy, in two weeks (M)

headline: G.M. Hires Lutz to Head Product Development
abstract: The General Motors Corporation said today that it had hired Robert A. Lutz, the former president of the Chrysler Corporation, to head its product development

headline: GENERAL MOTORS AFFIRMS PROFIT OUTLOOK
abstract: General Motors Corp affirms its third-quarter profit outlook and production for year, four days after Ford Motor Co lowers its earnings forecast; third-quarter profit at GM will be about 83 cents a share, and production is expected to remain at about 1.23 million units (S)

headline: 16 U.S. Tourists Die In Mexico Air Crash
abstract: Sixteen American tourists and two Mexican crew members die in crash of twin-engine turboprop plane carrying them to see Mayan ruins (S)

headline: Death, Terror and Business Journalists
abstract: Business journalists are struggling to cope with decimation of close-knit community of traders and bankers they normally cover as result of terrorist attacks on World Trade Center; these reporters are part of story as they file reports on Wall Street's struggle to get on its feet; Wall Street headquarters of some news organizations were damaged by attack or closed in its aftermath; some editors of The Wall Street Journal fled their offices near World Trade Center by ferry across Hudson River to begin preparing next day's paper; financial news Web site TheStreet.com evacuated its location across street from New York Stock Exchange; James Grant, founder of Grant's Interest Rate Observer, says its staff abandoned its headquarters and failed to publish on schedule for first time; many reporters and writers are preparing to attend memorial serives for business associates that were killed in attacks; photo (M)

headline: Argentine Bank Changes Policy
abstract: Banco de la Nación, Argentina's largest bank, Friday reversed a day-old policy to sell fewer dollars at a one-to-one rate to the peso

headline: Business; In the Tobacco Deal, a Bond Is Born
abstract: Individual investors begin showing interest in tax-exempt tobacco settlement bonds, product of 1998 settlement in which four biggest American tobacco companies pledge to pay 46 states about $206 billion over 25 years; bonds allow states to get more of settlement money immediately and are backed entirely by tobacco company revenues instead of tax revenues, as with conventional municipal bond; chart (M)

headline: World Business Briefing
abstract: ASIA INDIA: FOREIGNERS SELL STOCKS The threat of military action in the region after last week's terrorist attacks has foreign institutional investors cashing out their Indian equity holdings, throwing an already shaky Indian stock market into a steep decline. The benchmark Bombay index fell 5.25 percent yesterday, reaching an eight-year low, and analysts said it would fall further after yesterday's weakness on Wall Street. The value of the Indian rupee also fell.   Saritha Rai (NYT).

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Stimulus Plan
abstract: South Korea's Finance Min Jin Nyum promises huge government spending program in effort to increase economic output; says government will add $7.8 billion to its total expenditures; photo (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: An Increase In Prices
abstract: Consumer prices in Britain rose 2.4 percent in June, surprising analysts who expected smaller increase (S)

headline: SingTel Is a Step Away From Australia
abstract: Singapore Telecommunications wins regulatory approvals from Australia and US for its $7.5 billion purchase of Australia's Cable and Wireless Optus; approval is seen as triumph over political objections to Singapore's increasing role in Australia; Singapore Telecommunications' plans in Australia have raised concern because it is controlled by Singapore and its chief, Lee Hsien Yang, is son of former prime minister; photos (M)

headline: Executive Changes in Media and Marketing
abstract: Michael Blanchard was named to head a new health care division of GMR Marketing, Milwaukee, as supervisor for health care programs. He had been education coordinator for the intensive care unit at Waukesha Memorial Hospital, Waukesha, Wis.

headline: Arafat and Peres Renew Peace Vow Despite Nearby Clash
abstract: Yasir Arafat, Palestinian leader, and Shimon Peres, Israeli foreign minister, jointly pledge renewed drive for peace, but choreographed harmony of meeting in Rafah, Gaza, is marred by clash within earshot between Israeli and Palestinian fighters that injures three Israeli soldiers (M)

abstract: James Truman, editorial director of Conde Nast, hires Dutch architect Rem Koolhaas to work for Conde Nast; says Koolhaas will offer editorial and marketing advice; photo (S)

headline: Oshima Journal; After 90 Years, Small Gestures of Joy for Lepers
abstract: Japanese government has formally apologized and paid damages for its past treatment of lepers; 4,500 people with leprosy who survive in Japan have been forced to live in isolation for decades, long after effective treatment had been found; court ruled in May that government must pay $15 million to 127 plaintiffs who challenged law that kept them confined to sanitariums on distant mountains and small islands like Oshima; photo; map (M)

abstract: Sony Broadband Entertainment and Yahoo enter into temporary promotional and consulting trade-off agreement (S)

abstract: Ernest W DuBester answers questions on Pres Bush's use of Railway Labor Act to delay strike at Northwest Airlines and his threat to do so again if American Airlines and its flight attendants do not reach pact by strike deadline; photo (M)

headline: America the Vulnerable Meets a Ruthless Enemy
abstract: The image on the grainy videotape is mesmerizing: a tall, slim, middle- aged Arab man, with the bushy beard, white robes and draped white headcloth of a devout Muslim, standing before a gathering somewhere in Afghanistan. He is reading an Arabic poem, apparently his own, on papers that riffle in a breeze.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Turnaround Experts Land Atop Recruiters' Wish Lists  Two years ago, Edward J. Zander, the president and chief operating officer of Sun Microsystems, created a division to cater to the company's telecommunications clients -- and four months ago, as the industry fell apart, he collapsed that division into the company's hardware business.    Mr. Zander's name appears on several companies' wish lists, along with other executives who specialize in turning companies around. [Page C6.]    Inquiry Into Possible Jeep Defects  The Transportation Department has opened a preliminary investigation into complaints from owners of 1995-1999 Jeep Grand Cherokees that the vehicles have shifted themselves from park into reverse. The National Highway Transportation Safety Administration has 48 reports of such incidents, causing 32 crashes and 14 injuries. The engine was running in 29 cases and shut off in 19. [C2.]

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: European Union: Inflation Concerns
abstract: Jean-Claude Trichet, council member of European Central Bank, expresses concern about inflation in dozen countries that use euro; photo (S)

headline: Amid Jingles And Slogans, A Sober Mood
abstract: Hear that plaintive noise emanating from Madison Avenue? That is the sound of the national advertising economy still bumping along the bottom far longer than industry executives had feared.    When the economy suddenly slowed late last year, most advertisers, advertising agencies and media companies took it in stride, estimating that a recovery would begin by the second half of 2001, or right about now. Certainly by the fourth quarter.

headline: A Résumé Distinguished By What It Didn't Mention
abstract: Becton Dickinson, one of nation's largest medical device companies, unknowingly hired man convicted and imprisoned for attempted murder to fill top scientific post; Dr Seymour I Schlager worked as medical director at Becton Dickinson for three years before company discovered his past history and fired him last July; company, by its own admission, did not do simplest of background checks before hiring Schlager, nor did outside experts company hired to review Schlager's work; Schlager contends he was not fired, but left Becton Dickinson for personal reasons; declines to explain why his resume states that he worked for small pharmaceutical firm during six years when he was serving prison term in Illinois for attempted murder of his wife; Schlager's case is remarkable for how brazenly he pulled off his deception, not only at Becton Dickinson but at company that published book he wrote and other company that named him to its board; photos (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Advertising account changes noted (S)

headline: Big Belgian Beer Maker Posts 63% Rise in Profit
abstract: Interbrew says net profit rose 63.6 percent in first half of year, to 200.2 million euros (about $177.7 million); sales rose 56 percent, to 5.05 billion euros (about $4.4 billion) (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: HEALTH CARE REIT, Toledo, Ohio, which invests in nursing homes and assisted-living facilities, said it plans to sell $150 million of notes to repay bank borrowings and fund future investments.

headline: Corporate Plagiarism
abstract: Letter from Roy Burkhead contends that plagiarism discussed in June 28 article is not limited to students

headline: Metro Business Briefing
abstract: AUDIT OF DRIVING TEACHERS New York driving instructors should not be permitted to teach driving, State Comptroller H. Carl McCall said in an audit released yesterday, blaming the Department of Motor Vehicles for poor oversight. The department can deny an instructor's certificate to someone with a criminal history, but it does not have access to the state's database of criminal records, the audit found. In 50 driving schools, Mr. McCall's office found that 14 instructors had criminal convictions. It also found that instructors who had their licenses suspended or revoked should not have been allowed to hold certificates. In addition, the audit said, the D.M.V. did not keep required information on the schools' insurance and vehicle registrations. Joe Picchi, a department spokesman, said that the audit reviewed practices more than a year ago and that many of the problems had already been addressed

headline: Accounts
abstract: Heinekin of Amsterdam switches advertising account to Betancourt Barba Beker Euro RSCG of Mexico City, part of Euro RSCG Worldwide unit of Havas Advertising (S)

headline: Business; Continental's Blunt Leader Faces Crisis, Again
abstract: Terrorist attacks of Sept 11 confront Continental Airlines chief executive Gordon M Bethune with crisis that recalls his first days leading company in 1994, when it had just emerged from its second bankruptcy reorganization in 10 years; strong relationship he has built with employees is threatened by scale of layoffs he has announced; photos (L)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Korea: Gas Pipeline Study
abstract: Engineers from North and South Korea will work together on feasibility study of pipeline that would deliver natural gas from Siberia, through northeastern China, and on to North and South Korea (S)

headline: University Allows U.S. Scholar to Continue Teaching
abstract: A Chinese-born American scholar, who was convicted as a spy on the mainland, was told today that he could keep his position at City University in Hong Kong

headline: INDUSTRIAL NATIONS CALL FOR MONITORS FOR MIDEAST TRUCE
abstract: Foreign ministers of major industrialized countries, including Secretary of State Colin L Powell, urge Israelis and Palestinians to agree to 'third party' monitors as most assured way of halting violence in Middle East; ministers' call for outside monitors, in face of Israel's frequent objections to outside monitors, is seen as reflecting frustration with disintegrating cease-fire as well as effort to take more active role in encouraging peace; Bush administration policy on peace in Middle East has evolved in last six months from hands-off approach to limited involvement to brokering current cease-fire five weeks ago; Israel has consistently objected to 'international' monitors but appears more willing to entertain 'third party' monitors, particularly from United States; Israeli officials reject latest suggestion, saying that creating monitoring team would be pointless and even dangerous in absence of working cease fire (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; As Cyberian Outpost plunges toward the abyss, two suitors wait patiently to pick up the pieces.
abstract: WHEN the stock of an online company drops to 50 cents, you can usually chalk up another one for the dot-com bust. But for Cyberian Outpost, an online seller of computers and electronics, the half-dollar benchmark was precisely when it found itself in the position of having two suitors vying to buy it.    In May, PC Connection, a direct online seller of computer equipment primarily for small businesses, regarded Cyberian Outpost as a way to jump into the consumer market. The company offered to pay Cyberian shareholders $12.7 million to $26 million in company stock, with the final figure to be determined by a combination of Cyberian's summer revenue and the price of PC Connection stock in the fall. At the very least, the deal offered a graceful exit to the cash-short company, which operates online as Outpost.com.

headline: Stocks End Day Higher After Two Days of Losses
abstract: After two days of heavy selling, stocks rallied today as investors took their cues from a few good earnings reports despite the preponderance of bad ones

headline: Ulster Disarmament: One More Last-Chance Strategy
abstract: news analysis of struggle to bring political stability to NorthIreland in wake of fresh outbreak of violence related to refusal by Irish Republican Army to disarm (M)

headline: New Economy; A dot-com editor sheds his five-year 'cocoon,' and looks at how journalism has changed in the age of the Internet.
abstract: Dave Kansas article on how journalism has evolved to handle rapid emergence of Internet; notes Internet has become trusted medium for delivery of news, with mainstream news organizations making Web important part of their distribution systems; drawing (M)

headline: DataBank; A U.S. Void Unnerves Overseas Markets
abstract: Roundup of overseas stock market and US bond market activity following terrorist attacks on World Trade Center and Pentagon as US markets remained closed for four days; graphs; charts (M)

headline: The Therapeutic Listener
abstract: As the only psychologist for 880 patients, I've been warmly received by staff and residents. Not long ago, I asked a middle-aged AIDS patient with a history of sporadic violent outbursts whether he got depressed. His reply was: ''The food

headline: Insurers, Reaching Out to the Public, Hope to Alter Their Image
abstract: Many major life and property insurers have been using newspaper and radio advertising to reach out to public since Sept 11; some say ads, in which companies offer compassion and toll-free information numbers, could improve industry's often negative reputation (M)

headline: James J. McCaffrey, 79, Co-Founder of Top New York Ad Agency
abstract: James John McCaffrey, the co-founder of a New York advertising agency known for campaigns of understated elegance, died on Saturday at a hospital in Bangor, Me. He was 79 and lived in Blue Hill, Me., after residing several years in Castine, Me.    The cause was complications from a stroke he suffered last month on a fishing trip to Canada, his family said.

abstract: Maytag Corp says second-quarter profit fell 71 percent, to $21.8 million; sales fell to $1.07 billion from $1.1 billion (S)

abstract: Sony introduces five-megapixel DSC F707 digital still camera, $1000 breakthrough in amateur photography; photo (S)

headline: China Frees U.S. Citizen Held Since April on Spy Charges
abstract: China releases Wu Jianmin, Chinese-born US citizen and freelance journalist who has been held for almost six months on spy charges; recent high-profile detentions have hindered Chinese effort to improve US relations; US citizens Fuming Fong and Liu Yaping are still being held (S)

headline: Anxiety Rises After Attacks In West Bank And Israel
abstract: Month-old cease-fire between Israel and Palestinians is shakier than ever following Palestinian mortar attack against Jewish neighborhood on edge of Jerusalem; Israel continues targeting terrorists, killing four men in Bethlemen with helicopter-fired missiles; two are described as senior Hamas figures plotting major terrorist attack; Israeli action follows suicide bombing in Binyamina that killed two young soldiers and wounded nine others (M)

headline: California Energy Crisis Hits Scottish Power
abstract: Scottish Power says it miscalculated so badly in California power shortages and resulting wild swings in American energy prices that it will have to take $300 million charge to cover its loses; company is Britain's largest electric utility and owns PacifiCorp, which serves 1.5 milion customers in eight Western states; photo (M)

headline: ABC to Take Over WEVD, Bastion of Liberal New York Radio
abstract: The group that owns WEVD, the venerable New York radio station that was founded to promote fiercely liberal programming, has signed an agreement to turn over control of the station to AB

headline: Sentiment in Pakistani Town Is Ardently Pro-Taliban
abstract: Ancient trading city of Quetta, Pakistan, which lies just 60 miles from Afghanistan border, embodies shifting passions and loyalties of Pakistan and its war-plagued neighbor; Afghanistan's ruling Taliban are mostly from Pashtun ethnic group, which also dominates life in Quetta; tribal link contributes to ardent backing among many in Quetta for Afghan government; recent years have brought torrent of refugees from Afghanistan who have swelled Quetta's population to estimated two million, but Pakistan has closed border in wake of Sept 11 terrorist attacks on America and resulting US threats to attack Taliban for harboring Osama bin Laden; graduates of Quetta's religious schools include many leaders of Taliban, as well as hundreds of young men who went off to fight against Soviets and, years later, for Taliban; some Taliban leaders still keep their families in Quetta; hostility toward West is palpable, and leading cleric at rally this week called on faithful to march again to Afghanistan and to sabotage any military sites in Pakistan that Americans try to use; photos (M)

headline: An Israeli Hints At Permitting U.S. Observers
abstract: Defense Min Binyamin Ben-Eliezer hints that Israel might agree to foreigners monitoring worsening conflict with Palestinians, but says outsiders would have to be Americans; other officials close to Prime Min Ariel Sharon seek to minimize importance of remarks, which come day after foreign ministers of major industrialized countries urged introduction of 'third-party' monitors as way to keep violence from spinning out of control, a suggestion immediately embraced by Palestinian leaders and rejected by Israelis; photo (M)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week

headline: A Corner Office Has Little Room for Books
abstract: Daniel Akst column argues that rising to the top of business is not hastened by reading, whether of literature or books on management, and may even by slowed by it (M)

headline: His Job Is to Keep the Legend Going
abstract: H Lee Scott Jr, Wal-Mart chief executive, has unenviable task of keeping company's legend going; is credited having keen analytical mind; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Argentina: Chasing Pinochet, Again
abstract: Federal Judge Rodolfo Canicoba Corral asks Chile to extradite former Chilean dictator Augusto Pinochet to Argentina so he can faces questions about conspiracy by South American dictators to execute leftists in 1970's and 1980's (S)

headline: Freed Chinese Scholar, Still Defiant, Returns to the U.S.
abstract: American-based Chinese scholar Gao Zhan returns to US after five months in Chinese jail, and promptly defies Chinese authorities who convicted her of spying and sentenced her to ten years in jail, before expelling her; sociologist at American University says she was warned not to talk about experience but will give account in print, although she sidesteps some sensitive questions on advice of husband, Xue Donghua, and Sen George F Allen of Virginia; photo with family at Dulles International Airport (M)

headline: China Spurns Spy Plane Offer as Inadequate
abstract: China angrily rejects as inadequate US offer of compensation to help cover expenses related to American spy plane, which collided with Chinese fighter over South China Sea in April and made emergency landing on Hainan Island; US says it will pay China $34,567 to help defray costs, not $1 million China demanded; plane was dismantled and sent back to US on July 3 after months of acrimonious negotiations (S)

headline: MERCK GAINS EXTENSION FOR SALES OF CHOLESTEROL DRUG
abstract: Merck & Co receives additional six months of exclusive sales rights for its cholesterol-lowering drug Mevacor after Food and Drug Administration reverses decision that would have allowed immediate generic competition (S)

headline: A Bold Gambler Ups the Ante Despite Long Odds
abstract: Theodore J Forstmann gambles that Forstmann Little & Co's infusion of $275 million of additional capital into McLeodUSA, telephone company whose stock has lost 88 percent of its value in last six months, will bear fruit similar to his resurrection of Gulfstream Aerospace Corp 10 years ago; McLeodUSA serves markets with little competition in 25 states; photo (M)

headline: Basic Research Pays Off
abstract: PricewaterhouseCoopers survey finds that the most accurate securities analysts conduct fundamental research, instead of trying to predict upcoming earnings (S)

headline: Enticing Third World Youth; Big Tobacco Is Accused Of Crossing an Age Line
abstract: World Health Organization accuses tobacco companies of trying to entice underage youth, especially in developing nations, to take up smoking cigarettes by distributing them for free; study by WHO and Centers for Desease Control and Prevention finds that 11 percent of Latin American and Caribbean schoolchildren ages 13 to 15 were offered free cigarettes by company representatives in 1999 and 2000, as were nearly 17 percent in Russia and 25 percent in Jordan; shrinking smoking market in US is seen as stimulus for American tobacco companies to increase smoking populations elsewhere; local tobacco companies in third world are sometimes even more overt than global cigarette makers in reaching out to young people; among companies cited are Philip Morris, British American Tobacco and Indian Tobacco Co; photos; graph (M)

headline: Connecting Visor Users To Sprint Network

headline: Stocks Soar in Wake of Terrible Week on Wall Street
abstract: Stocks surged today in a broad-based rally, as Wall Street tried to recover from its worst week since the Great Depression.

abstract: Datek Online Financial Services reports that 65 percent of its account holders anticipate major stock market rally within a year (S)

headline: Once-Strong Pillar of Houston's Economy Looks Shaky

headline: U.S. Argues Against Delay That Microsoft Is Seeking
abstract: Government urges federal appeals court to swiftly send Microsoft antitrust case to new federal district judge; seeks denial of Microsoft's request for delay until Supreme Court decides in October whether it will hear company's appeal (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: The Hague: Croat Reports For Trial
abstract: Gen Rahim Ademi, Croatian Army general, turns himself in to UN war crimes tribunal in The Hague to face charges linked to killing of Serbian civilians during Serbian-Croatian fighting in 1993; photo (S)

headline: Data Suggests Weak Growth, Not a Recession
abstract: Commerce Dept reports American economy grew more slowly in second quarter than at any time in eight years; many economists say new numbers suggest that nation could avoid recession if consumers continue to spend at their present level; nation's output of goods and services rose 0.2 percent, at annual rate; stepped-up consumer spending caused inventories to fall $38.4 billion, suggesting merchants now may have to begin placing new orders to restock their shelves; industrial production needed to fill new orders would give economy lift; Commerce Dept figures showing economy grew, even by such small amount, is relief to nation braced for start of recession; photo; graph (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Sales Down At Chip Maker
abstract: STMicroelectronics says second-quarter sales fell 15 percent from year ago, to $1.59 billion, and net income dropped 54 percent, to $155 million (S)

abstract: Marilyn Carlson Nelson, chairwoman and chief executive of Carlson Companies, parent of Radisson hotel and Wagonlit travel agency chain, answers questions prospects of travel and tourism industry in wake of Sept 11 attacks; photo (M)

headline: Arctic Energy Reshapes A Village
abstract: Inuvik, in Canada's Northwest Territories, grows and changes in response to growing North American need for future supplies of natural gas; town is logistical hub for gas exploration and for future pipeline construction in Canadian Arctic; photos (M)

headline: China Clears Last Hurdle On Path to Trade Group
abstract: US, Europe and China remove last remaining obstacle blocking China's admission to WTO; negotiators in Geneva agree that dispute over different status of European and American insurance companies in China market need not be resolved now; US envoy Robert B Zoellick sees evidence that US and Europe can work together, and that US is not 'paralyzed' in aftermath of terrorist attack on US (M)

headline: United Arab Emirates Cuts Ties With Afghanistan
abstract: The United Arab Emirates broke off relations with Afghanistan today because of the ruling Taliban's refusal to hand over Osama bin Laden.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Rate Outlook
abstract: Prospects for imminent reduction in interest rates in Britain seem to recede after release of data showing higher wage increases and reports of reluctance among some Bank of England officials to cut rates; National Statistics Office says average earnings rose annualized 4.8 percent in quarter through June, compared with 4.6 percent in three months through May (S)
