headline: Play Money? Not to These News Investors
abstract: NewsFutures, French Web site, poses questions about possible future events--whether in sports, finances or politics--and players then stake a position on how things will turn out, adjusting their position as events unfold; its chat rooms and forums allow players to discuss each day's events and their impact on their position; table (M)

headline: AOL Time Warner Posts Mixed Results in Quarter
abstract: AOL Time Warner's revenue grew 3.3 percent in second quarter, falling short of analysts' expectations and raising doubts about company's ability to meet its revenue target for year; says overall revenue was $9.2 billion; reports loss of $734 million, down from loss of $927 million year earlier (M)

headline: I.M.F. Official Warns Asia About Barriers to Recovery
abstract: Stanley Fischer, senior official for International Monetary Fund, warns that structural reforms demanded by Japan's Prime Min Junichiro Koizumi could undermine long-term regional efforts to recover from economic crisis of 1997 and 1998; says Koizumi's proposal for cutting public works and shutting down financially weak banks and companies might deal with problems in short run but they risk adding to problems of region already hurting from economic problems in West as well as Japan; photo (M)

headline: An Electronic Bass Turns Everything Into 'Silent Night'
abstract: Yamaha develops upright string bass whose volume control can be turned down to almost nothing so that one can play without disturbing neighbors; photo (S)

headline: So That's Who's Talking: A Hearing Aid Points to the Sound
abstract: Innovation in hearing aids being developed in Sweden, called sound localizer, will enable user to determine direction sound is coming from; deemed especially helpful for people with severe vision impairment as well as hearing problems; photo (M)

headline: The Federal Reserve Is Now Finding the Limits of Its Power
abstract: Despite six interest rate cuts by the Federal Reserve this year and the possibility of more to come, analysts say that monetary policy is packing less of a punch so far than expected.    The Fed's rate reductions work to the degree that they ripple through the banking system and the financial markets into the economy. And in this business cycle the three main vehicles through which lower rates affect business, investor and consumer behavior -- the stock, bond and currency markets -- have remained persistently unresponsive to the Fed's actions.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: BSKYB Loss Grows
abstract: BskyB posts loss of $244 million for fiscal fourth quarter, roughly third more than year earlier (S)

headline: Patents; Software to provide 'personal' attention to online customers with service untouched by a human.
abstract: NativeMinds chief executive Walter Tackett patents software technology called automated virtual representatives to conduct customer service, sales and marketing for online businesses; software uses computer-generated images to answer customer questions in real time using natural language; Tackett and co-inventor, Scott Benson, say technology can mimic human customer service operators at fraction of cost; Dan Erlin patents system for swiping credit card through TV remote control for use with television home shopping network, other applications (M)

headline: Vote by Conservatives Deals Severe Blow To 'Sunshine' Policy : Seoul Vote Forces Out Unification Advocate
abstract: The South Korean National Assembly, in a conservative backlash, on Monday overwhelmingly approved a resolution of no confidence in the minister whom President Kim Dae Jung has relied on to execute his "sunshine" policy of reconciliation with North Korea. A few hours later, the minister quit.

headline: China Holds Ill American In Hospital
abstract: Ailing US-based executive Liu Yaping is still being held in Chinese hospital under stringent conditions; Liu, who was arrested on minor charges connected to Web design company that he was starting in China, was granted bail last month after five months in prison (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Equipment Maker Forecasts Loss
abstract: ASML Holding, biggest maker of machines that etch circuits onto computer chips, says it will have first-half loss of as much as 105 million euros ($89 million) as result of canceled orders (S)

headline: New Economy; Services can be a viable business even when sales of information technology equipment are slow.
abstract: Hal R Varian column on Hewlett-Packard's planned merger with Compaq Computer and its stress on building a business in providing information technology services to its customers; notes that corporations have not yet figured out how to use their modern, efficient information technology infrastructure very well; drawing (M)

headline: With Some Premiums Higher, A.I.G.'s Income Rises 16%
abstract: The American International Group said yesterday that second-quarter profit increased 16 percent as the company, a huge insurer and one of the world's largest financial groups, raised prices on policies to businesses and increased sales of life insurance and annuities.    A.I.G. had net income of $1.63 billion, or 69 cents a share, compared with $1.41 billion, or 60 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier.

headline: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Land Grabbers Beware
abstract: South African government will toughen criminal penalties for people who illegally occupy private property, describing recent spate of land invasions as 'unacceptable' (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: SUMMA INDUSTRIES, Torrance, Calif., a maker of engineered plastic products, has hired U.S. Bancorp Piper Jaffray, Minneapolis, an investment bank, to assist it in considering strategic options, including the sale of the company.    FEDERATED DEPARTMENT STORES , Cincinnati, owner of Macy's and Bloomingdale's, signed agreements with stores in Australia, Chile and Peru to supply private-brand merchandise. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: Three Seats in Coach, For Armchair Travelers
abstract: TWA and its new parent, American Airlines, to offer at auction on eBay triple-seat set of coach seats that have been removed from first row of five seats removed from TWA MD-80 aircraft; hope to attract memorabilia collectors (S)

headline: Adding Demands, Afghan Leaders Show Little Willingness to Give Up bin Laden
abstract: Hard-line Islamic clerics who control Afghanistan's Taliban government postpone for at least another 24 hours a final response to US demand that they hand over Osama bin Laden and top lieutenants in his terrorist organization, Al Qaeda; at same time, they set new conditions that make peaceful end to crisis seem increasingly unlikely; demands include diplomtic recognition of Taliban, cutoff of all support for its opponents and resumption of economic aid; high-ranking Pakistani military officers, concluding two days of negotiations with elusive Taliban leader Mullah Mohammed Omar, say hard-liners seem likely to prevail in their refusal to give up bin Laden, whatever the risk; photo (M)

headline: WORKERS STRIKE AT MITSUBISHI PLANT IN ILLINOIS
abstract: UAW members at Mitsubishi Motor Co plant in Normal, Ill, strike over wage dispute (S)

headline: Trying to Regain Equilibrium in a World Turned Upside Down
abstract: Danny Lin, garment district wholesaler, writes My Job column on making T-shirts to commemorate attack on World Trade Center; photo (M)

headline: Coca-Cola Still Faces Suits In Race Discrimination Case
abstract: Coca-Cola still faces lawsuits from current and former black employees; at least 17 of 23 employees who chose not to participate in $192.5-million settlement will pursue own cases (S)

headline: World Briefing | The World: Population Forecast
abstract: New scientific analysis finds human population is likely to stop growing in 2100 as sharp drop in birthrates in some countries make up for continued growth in others; projects world population at turn of next century at about 8.4 billion people, compared with long-term assessment of 9.4 billion by UN (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Change At Hyundai
abstract: Kim Dong Jin is appointed chief executive of Hyundai Motor Co, replacing Lee Kye Ahn; photo (S)

headline: Cyberspace Isn't So Lonely After All
abstract: New data compiled by Robert Kraut of Carnegie Mellon University contradicts, in many respects, his earlier conclusion that loneliness, depression and isolation are associated with Internet use; photos (M)

headline: Where All the Soldiers Have Six Legs
abstract: Charles Herold reviews two computer games, Empire of the Ants from Microids and Stretch Panic from Treasure; photos (M)

headline: INVESTING WITH/David G. Herro And Michael J. Welsh; Oakmark International Small Cap Fund
abstract: Carole Gould profiles David G Herro and Michael J Welsh, co-managers of Oakmark International Small Cap fund; photo; chart (M)

headline: VeriSign Deal Lets It Move Into Billing
abstract: VeriSign Inc acquires Illuminet Holdings Inc for $1.2 billion in stock to sell Web billing and other services to phone companies (M)

headline: INVESTING WITH/Kathryn D. Beyer and Jeffrey D. Lorenzen; Vintage Bond Fund
abstract: Carole Gould profile of Kathryn D Beyer and Jeffrey D Lorenzen, managers of Vintage Bond fund; photo; chart; table (M)

headline: MediaTalk; Sports as News or Entertainment: A Question of Rights in Oregon
abstract: Newspapers in Oregon condemn University of Oregon for making all football game broadcasters' credentials contingent on agreement to limit coverage to 20 seconds of highlights and 20 seconds of interviews for two days after game; Oregon's athletic director, Bill Moos, says school objected to station that was shooting footage for entertainment production and not for news; drawing (S)

headline: World Business Briefing
abstract: AMERICASCANADA: BANK PROFIT IS UP A leading Canadian bank, the Bank of Montreal, said its profit rose 14 percent in its most recent quarter, helped by securities trading and electronic banking. Net income in the period ended July 31, the third quarter of the bank's fiscal year, increased to 444 million Canadian dollars ($288.1 million), or 83 Canadian cents (54 cents) a share, from 401 million Canadian dollars ($260.2 million), or 69 Canadian cents (45 cents), a year earlier. Earnings at BMO Nesbitt Burns, the Bank of Montreal's investment firm, rose 21 percent, and profit at the Emfisys electronic-banking unit rose more than fourfold.   (Bloomberg News) EUROPEGERMANY: STEEL MAKER'S PROFIT FALLS The German steel maker ThyssenKrupp, one of the biggest in Europe, lowered its forecast for full-year earnings for the third time after profit again plummeted. The company said third-quarter profit before taxes and a one-time gain through June 30 fell 89 percent, to 44 million euros ($40.1 million) compared with 408 million euros ($372.1 million) a year earlier. ThyssenKrupp also said it no longer expected its sales this year to match last year's. Its shares fell 0.06 euro (5 cents), to 15.16 euros ($13.83).   Alan Cowell (NYT) FRANCE: SPACE AGENCY EXECUTIVE Arianespace, which markets the European Space Agency's Ariane rocket, said it had named Jean-Yves Le Gall, 42, as chief operating officer, succeeding Jacques Rossignol. The change took effect on Monday. The company did not give a reason for the change but said Mr. Le Gall'

headline: Hurt by Cable, Networks Spout Expletives
abstract: Broadcast television is under siege by smaller cable competitors that are winning audiences while pushing adult content; there is struggle between broadcast television's censors and producers, as networks seek to satisfy advertisers who want younger audience that has grown up with language that network censors rule out; network censors are becoming more lenient, but broadcast television, which is available to every home with television set, can only go so far; it still has to appeal to largest audiences possible and operate under decency standards enforced by Federal Communications Commission; networks face growing pressure to walk fine line; photos (M)

headline: Amid Slump, Cisco Announces a Revamping
abstract: Cisco Systems will restructure its business as sharp decline in sales shows signs of easing; expresses cautious hope that business is stabilizing (M)

headline: Mexico Vows To Retaliate Against U.S. On Trucking
abstract: Pres Vincente Fox of Mexico reacts strongly to United States Senate vote to impose restrictions on Mexican trucks; vows to bar American trucks from Mexico until Mexican truckers are allowed on American highways (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | New Zealand: New Zealand: Trade Deficit
abstract: New Zealand reports trade deficit of 46 million New Zealand dollars ($20 million) in July, reversing surplus of 146 million New Zealand dollars in June, but better than deficit of 126 million year ago (S)

headline: E-Commerce Report; Some businesses are starting to seek out dot-coms for new ventures.
abstract: Businesses from outside and within e-commerce realm are selectively seeking dot-com partners for marketing and product distribution; new deal-making, after 18-month shakeout, could point to accelerating recovery for some e-commerce companies; photo (M)

headline: Executive Changes at Media Firms
abstract: Tim Farish and Deb Medsker were named vice presidents at Starcom North America, part of the Starcom MediaVest Group unit of the Bcom3 Group

headline: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: Webvan Shareholders Approve Reverse Split
abstract: Shareholders of the online grocer Webvan have voted to approve a plan for a 1-to-25 reverse stock split, in the hope of preventing the company's stock from being delisted by the Nasdaq stock market. Webvan said it had been notified by Nasdaq that the company must put the reverse stock split into effect by July 23. Even so, Webvan must still meet Nasdaq's minimum-bid requirements after the split in order to avoid being delisted, which Nasdaq typically does when a company's stock consistently trades below $1. Webvan shares closed yesterday at 7 cents, down 1 cent.   Susan Stellin (NYT)

headline: World Briefing | The Americas: Canada: Premier To Visit New York
abstract: Prime Min Jean Chretien and leaders of Canadian Parliament will visit New York to express sympathy in aftermath of terror attack; Chretien is under fire at home for having uncaring attitude about atrocity; at least 25 Canadians are missing (S)

headline: Zimbabwe Fund for AIDS Patients Is Frozen in Bureaucracy
abstract: Zimbabwe government for more than year has been collecting 3 percent tax on personal and corporate income to pay for national AIDS trust, to help care for country's many AIDS victims, but most of millions raised so far is unspent, mired in bureaucracy that has frustrated many people who welcomed trust's creation (M)

headline: Fate of a Polish Bazaar Shows Shifting Patterns of East Europe's Economy
abstract: New markets in Central and Eastern Europe usurp Warsaw's role as shopping center for Russians; Asian producers, selling through Poland's sizable Vietnamese community, have undercut Poland's sweatshops; many companies now use Warsaw simply as distribution center; huge outdoor market in Warsaw, once magnet for bargain hunters from former Soviet Union, loses much of its business; photos (M)

headline: A natural marketing alliance finally takes some tentative steps: gays and sports.
abstract: Advertising campaigns aimed at homosexual consumers are beginning to feature athletes and sports imagery, while campaigns intended for general market are beginning to feature gay and lesbian athletes; trend reflects efforts by marketers to sharpen and freshen sales pitches; photo (M)

headline: A French Connection in a U.S. Insurer's Demise
abstract: Investigation in California is trying to determine whether Francois Pinault, billionaire French entrepreneur, made smart investment when he acquired junk bond portfolio of Executive Life of California, or whether he conspired with Credit Lyonnaise to sidestep American law and defraud creditors of insurer and State of California; matter is complicated by fact that at time of dealings in question Credit Lyonnaise was controlled by French state; bank, which has since been privatized, appealed to Justice Department in June to half investigation, and French foreign minister asked State Department to intervene on bank's behalf; Jeffrey B Isaacs, assistant US attorney in Los Angeles, has proposed indicting Credit Lyonnaise, accusing it of defrauding state by secretly arranging to acquire Executive Life through group of investors connected with French insurance company, MAAF; photo (M)

headline: Game Makers Scale Back; Players Have Other Ideas
abstract: Computer game makers, in response to terrorist attacks, modify or delay release of games with scenes that might now be seen as insensitive; one group of game players makes use of game feature that lets players create own missions to create mission to assassinate Osama bin Laden in Afghanistan; photos (M)

headline: Early Tracking of Dow Average Is Planned
abstract: In September, Dow Jones & Company will begin to calculate how the Dow Jones industrial average has been affected by trading in Europe

headline: A marketing blitz is aimed at promoting a 'living brand' from Britain for the U.S.
abstract: Anne McKevitt, popular British television host whose programs and books about home decorating and interior design have led to lines of merchandise sold under her name, will be featured in advertising campaigns in US for HSN Direct International, majority owned by Britain's Telewest Communications, and Frederiksen Entertainment division of Frederiksen Group, company sepcializing in developing products and programs centered on marketable celebrities; photo (M)

headline: E. T. Hall, 77, Archaeologist Who Debunked Piltdown Man
abstract: Dr E T Hall, archaeologist and art historian who devised scientific tools used to unmask fraudulent Piltdown Man and to try to determine Shroud of Turin's age, dies at age 77 (M)
